webTitle: Horlock inspires faith in the City

fields.headline: Horlock inspires faith in the City
fields.trailText: Man City 5 - 0 Everton
fields.body:
This result may have looked barely credible, with Everton suffering their worst defeat in 137 league matches against a City outfit who had lost their last six in the Premiership. But for Joe Royle and at least one of his supporters, it was a reward for true faith.

"It was a game we had to win, and I'd have taken 1-0 in the last minute with a deflected goal," grinned Royle. "But we have kept our faith going. The spirit in the side has never changed."

Maybe, but most City fans were reluctant to count any chickens even with a 3-0 half-time lead. Reverend Tony Porter, the club chaplain, was an exception.

The success of the last two years has all been down to a club carol service in December 1998, apparently. "What followed was quite remarkable," revealed the Rev. "On Christmas Day, City were in 12th place in Division Two. Boxing Day was a battle at Wrexham, with City scraping home by a single goal, followed by a 12-match unbeaten run. The rest is history."

After suggesting that "Jesus Christ would have loved the atmosphere of Maine Road", Porter then urged City fans ("Blue Angels") to attend a carol service before Christmas, pointing out, slightly incongruously, that "you'll be joining millions across the world, including Cannon and Ball".

Porter prays regularly for City, he revealed, but they hardly needed divine intervention against this hapless Everton team. Walter Smith stuck with five men in midfield and Kevin Campbell as his lone striker but admitted: "City looked quicker to the ball and more eager to win the game."

Then there was Everton's defending. City's 14th-minute opener was a gift from Paul Gerrard, who pushed Kevin Horlock's free-kick into the path of an unchallenged Paulo Wanchope. Nine minutes later, Wanchope earned a corner and Horlock's perfect left-foot delivery presented Steve Howey with a free header. Then as half-time neared Shaun Goater collected Wanchope's flick-on and shrugged off David Weir to score his first Premiership goal.

"They were three poor goals," said Smith. "We've had inconsistency through the season and lost quite a number of goals from set pieces, but not quite as bad as that."

Royle preferred to credit Wanchope and Goater, starting a Premiership game together for only the second time. "We decided to be slightly more direct and play into them, and obviously it worked because they scored a goal apiece and created several more opportunities," he added.

Horlock, Royle's man of the match, had been out of favour for much of the autumn but he set up City's fourth goal early in the second half with a superb first-time centre which Gerrard, under pressure from Wanchope, could only palm to Paul Dickov, who had come on for the injured Goater.

An own-goal from Gary Naysmith completed Everton's misery. The supporters were given a soaking to go with the team's thrashing, in the uncovered area at the corner of the Kippax - never has its nickname, the Gene Kelly stand, been more appropriate. But there was no reason for them to sing in the driving rain.

webTitle: Relief for Strachan as Sky Blues move out of relegation zone

fields.headline: Relief for Strachan as Sky Blues move out of relegation zone
fields.standfirst: Coventry 1 - 0 Leicester
fields.trailText: Coventry 1 - 0 Leicester
fields.body:
A rare goal from Craig Bellamy went some way towards improving Gordon Strachan's job security and also vindicated the Coventry manager's judgment in the transfer market. The striker's 39th-minute header was sufficient to overcome a subdued Leicester side and lift Coventry out of the Premiership's relegation zone.

A relieved Strachan said afterwards that continual failure - only one point from their previous seven games - had been stretching his credibility with the players.

"I keep telling them that if they keep working they will get their just rewards," he said. "This win has proved it, but it was becoming harder and harder to get the players to believe it. It's to their credit they kept believing."

Strachan has never lost his own belief in Bellamy, the player he made Coventry's record signing when he bought him from Norwich for £6m in the summer.

Thus far the return on that investment has been poor, with Bellamy scoring only four goals, three from the penalty spot. Strachan dropped him for City's last game but because of the 21-year-old's response in training had little alternative but to recall him against Leicester.

"He wants to be a better player and his attitude in training bears that out," the manager said. "That was especially the case this week and he forced me to pick him."

Bellamy was deployed this time on the wing rather than as an out and out striker. Slight of stature, he blossomed away from the hurly-burly of the penalty area, fully exploiting the extra space with his pace and trickery. In his place, Strachan again opted for a midfielder up front, continuing with Mustapha Hadji.

Likewise the Leicester manager Peter Taylor played Muzzy Izzet up front alongside Ade Akinbiyi but, with City Neil Lennonless and Robbie Savage in pantomime-villain mode, the pair were given few opportunities.

By contrast the hosts' dominance in midfield, which coincided with Lee Carsley making his debut, always suggested that Coventry would score. They were particularly potent at left-wing corners, with David Thompson's inswinging delivery causing uncertainty in the visiting rearguard.

Hadji headed one against the base of the post but it was from a cross from the opposite flank and in open play that Bellamy scored the winner. Paul Telfer delivered it and Bellamy nipped in front of the hesitant Frank Sinclair to nod the ball past Simon Royce and just inside his right-hand post.

Bellamy, his confidence boosted by scoring his first goal at Highfield Road, proceeded to give the Leicester defence a thorough chasing. He became a particular source of frustration to Savage and the Leicester captain Matt Elliott, who was fortunate to escape punishment when he appeared to use an elbow to halt another threatening run.

Taylor replaced Izzet at the interval because the Turkish international was exhausted from lack of sleep after the birth of his child on Friday. His replacement Trevor Benjamin added more physical presence to the visiting attack but the end product remained the same: a largely trouble-free return from injury for Coventry's keeper Magnus Hedman.

It all added up to a depressing afternoon for the visitors, but Taylor was not prepared to offer any excuses. "We can play a lot better than that and I'm very disappointed with our performance," he said. "We had a couple of half-chances in the second half but I'm not so sure that we deserved anything from the game."

webTitle: Ipswich make Houllier pay

fields.headline: Ipswich make Houllier pay
fields.standfirst: Liverpool 0 - 1 Ipswich Town
fields.trailText: Liverpool 0 - 1 Ipswich Town
fields.body:
Perhaps fittingly, it was beneath bleak skies that Liverpool were again confirmed as little more than bit-part players in the Premiership's grand scheme of things.

The fact that they most certainly did not deserve to slip to a first home defeat in seven months is an irrelevance, for hard-luck stories are ten a penny in modern football.

Ipswich had won just one of their previous 28 senior fixtures at Anfield, curiously on their last visit five years ago shortly before they were relegated. Their sojourn among English football's elite will be longer and more productive this time around.

"I am very, very proud," said the Ipswich manager, George Burley. "To come to Anfield and win is something very special for all of us."

At least those bemused Merseysiders who have looked on with a mixture of admiration and incredulity at the rise and rise of the Ipswich phoenix will this morning appreciate what all the fuss is about.

Rather like another recently promoted side, Charlton Athletic, Ipswich move the ball smartly, intelligently and with great speed; they have learned quickly that in the Premiership an ability to transform defence into attack in the blink of an eye really is to be envied.

In some respects they were a little fortunate yesterday for they accepted the one opportunity which came their way and then profited handsomely from a curious sense of lethargy which, for lengthy periods, held Liverpool firmly in an unyielding grip.

For once scoring on home soil represented a struggle for Liverpool. Certainly had their forwards been clinical rather than clumsy, proficient rather than profligate, the stalemate would not have endured quite as long as it did.

But, a reduction in Liverpool's potential for plunder was, perhaps, inevitable with manager Gérard Houllier opting to leave his most potent weapon, Emile Heskey, on the touch-line. The big man's entrance was delayed until the 60th minute which was precisely 60 minutes too late in most people's estimation. " We couldn't believe it when we saw that Heskey wasn't on their team-sheet. That's when we knew we had a real chance," said Ipswich goalscorer Marcus Stewart.

Mind you, in technical terms at least, there wasn't too much wrong with the pair invited to make light of Heskey's absence - Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler. Of course, the debate as to whether the two can actually forge a meaningful partnership rages on - it has come to represent the ultimate pub debate in Liverpool.

Maybe they can, maybe they can't. Yesterday, as on many previous occasions it didn't work out. The most worrying aspect was that few present actually believed it would.

Unfortunately for Houllier, having bounded off the bench to thunderous applause, Heskey was struck by what is best described as Fowler's Disease, that is to say he stormed clear only to delay his shot so long that John McGreal and Fabian Wilnis could usher him away from goal.

The game was decided deep into first-half stoppage time when Stewart displayed the predatory instinct which was to elude Liverpool, skipping around Stephane Henchoz and Sander Westerveld before steering home low and hard.

"We had enough chances to have won this game with something to spare but, for what ever reason, we just did not take them," said Houllier with the look of a man whose Christmas had already been ruined.

webTitle: Yeovil storm back to the big time

fields.headline: Yeovil storm back to the big time
fields.standfirst: Blackpool 0 - 1 Yeovil Town
fields.trailText: Blackpool 0 - 1 Yeovil Town
fields.body:
A strike in first-half injury-time yesterday by their former Chelsea youth player Nick Crittenden led to one of the most imaginative goal celebrations of the season and, more importantly, a place for Yeovil Town in the third round for the 13th time, a record for a non-League club.

The latest upset produced by the Somerset club - Blackpool became their 20th league scalp - also stemmed from an astonishing goalkeeping performance by Tony Pennock, a former Hereford player in his seventh year with Yeovil, who was magnificent in the wind and driving rain at Bloomfield Road.

The tie fulfilled every Cup cliche, as the Third Division club's downcast manager Steve McMahon noted when pointing out that the presence of television cameras meant postponement was never a danger despite the waterlogged conditions. So Sky's desire for drama and upset was satisfied.

No one was more satisfied than Crittenden, who said: "I spent five years at Chelsea waiting for moments like these. We always knew we were in with a chance against Blackpool. We had them watched several times and picked out their weaknesses."

The runaway Conference leaders, who crushed Second Division Colchester in the first round, fear no one. "We haven't lost for 10 games now so it's a case of bring on the big boys," Crittenden added. That will be Bolton, four times Cup winners but now in the First Division.

After Crittenden struck, Yeovil's cult figure Warren Patmore, whose waistline was the subject of abuse from the home fans, lifted his shirt to expose an unflattering figure and chased after the scorer in homage to the "lose the beerbelly" television advert.

Vintage stuff and part of an occasion that offered a glowing commendation for the increasingly maligned and often overlooked grassroots of professional football.

"They're such a young team you think you're taking the youth team in training some days," said Yeovil's experienced manager Colin Addison.

"Some of them haven't even been to Blackpool before and they've been so excited they've been up the Tower this morning."

McMahon must have felt like throwing himself off it after his side squandered a host of chances. Even before the goal, John Murphy and Brett Ormerod had both been played through on Pennock, the former putting his attempt over the bar, the latter finding out this was Yeovil and their goalkeeper's afternoon.

It became ever more so shortly after. Darren Way's cross found Crittenden who, having seen his first effort blocked, reacted more rapidly than his leaden-footed opponents and finished clinically. After the interval Patmore also had an excellent chance but was denied by the legs of Phil Barnes. But those moments apart, the movement was in one direction.

Pennock was unflappable. Two years ago, his error cost Yeovil heavily against Cardiff. The goalkeeper said: "It was just one of those days when everything went right. People still remind me about the Cardiff game, so it was nice to play a full 90 minutes on TV and have a good one."

John Hills's effort and a header from Murphy were superbly stopped before, in the last minute, Pennock kept out a desperate shot from the substitute Phil Clarkson.

webTitle: United face tough Cup trip to Fulham

fields.headline: United face tough Cup trip to Fulham
fields.standfirst: FA Cup third round draw
fields.trailText: FA Cup third round draw
fields.body:
Having missed last season's FA Cup to take part in the World Club Championship in Brazil, Manchester United were given a tough welcome back to the competition when they were drawn away to the runaway First Division leaders Fulham.

Jean Tigana's side have won 14 and lost only one of their matches at Craven Cottage this term, knocking Derby out of the Worthington Cup there last month. That took to five the number of Premiership clubs they have beaten in the past three seasons, though United saw them off at Old Trafford en route to their FA Cup victory in the 1999 treble season.

Arsenal, second favourites behind United to lift the trophy, face a less daunting visit to Carlisle, currently bottom of the Nationwide League. The holders Chelsea begin at home to Peterborough or Oldham, and last season's runners-up Aston Villa face a difficult start at Newcastle United, losing finalists in the two previous years.

Morecambe, 17th in the Conference, were rewarded for their second-round defeat of Cambridge United with a home tie against Ipswich. Though none of the other guaranteed non-league survivors were drawn at home, Dagenham and Redbridge were given a lucrative trip to Charlton. Chester visit Blackburn, Kingstonian travel to Southend, and Yeovil Town will hope to make Bolton their 21st league scalp.

Potential banana-skins for Premiership sides include Spurs' visit to either Leyton Orient or Northwich Victoria, and Everton's trip to Watford in a repeat of the 1984 final. That was at Wembley; next year's final is likely to be at the Millennium stadium in Cardiff. Newcastle United v Aston Villa

webTitle: Division one round-up

fields.headline: Division one round-up
fields.trailText: It has been a good month for the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce, whose team are finally overcoming their hesitant start to the season and moved into second place with a 4-1 victory over Crewe .
fields.body:
It has been a good month for the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce, whose team are finally overcoming their hesitant start to the season and moved into second place with a 4-1 victory over Crewe .

Bolton might lack the flair of the First Division leaders Fulham but they are still a tough proposition, as Dario Gradi's attractive but lightweight side discovered, and look a good bet to be thereabouts come the play-offs.

Another side putting a bad start to the season behind them are Lou Macari's Huddersfield , who remain bottom but proved they may not stay there with a 3-0 win over the frustratingly inconsistent Wolves . Colin Lee was furious about his team's blunders: "It was embarrassing. We turned periods of control into goalscoring opportunities for the opposition."

Yet Wolves' inconsistency is nothing compared with that of Sheffield Wednesday . In recent weeks Paul Jewell's side had shown signs of a revival and moved off the bottom of the table with a series of convincing wins. But at home to Stockport County they were back to their old ways, taking a 2-1 lead before losing 4-2.

It was also a frustrating afternoon for the Blackburn manager Graeme Souness, whose side could not break down QPR at Ewood Road despite dominating much of the game.

Yet Wolves' inconsistency is nothing compared with that of Sheffield Wednesday . In recent weeks Paul Jewell's side had shown signs of a revival and moved off the bottom of the table with a series of convincing wins. But at home to Stockport County they were back to their old ways, taking a 2-1 lead before losing 4-2. It was also a frustrating afternoon for the Blackburn manager Graeme Souness, whose side could not break down QPR at Ewood Road despite dominating much of the game.

webTitle: FA Cup  Round-up

fields.headline: FA Cup  Round-up
fields.trailText: The Conference's Northwich Victoria have a great incentive to beat Third Division Leyton Orient in their FA Cup second-round replay: a plum draw at home to Tottenham Hotspur in the third round.
fields.body:
The Conference's Northwich Victoria have a great incentive to beat Third Division Leyton Orient in their FA Cup second-round replay: a plum draw at home to Tottenham Hotspur in the third round.

Northwich fought back from 2-0 to lead Orient 3-2 at Drill Road before Chris Tate's late equaliser kept the east London side in the competition. The Orient manager Tommy Taylor admitted his side had had a lucky escape, adding: "At 2-0 it should have been all over but Northwich put us under enormous pressure and kept the tie alive."

If Northwich paid for a lack of concentration at the end, there were no such problems for their fellow non-league side Dagenham & Redbridge , who face Charlton after beating Third Division Lincoln City 1-0 away with Mark Janney's 90th-minute goal.

Yet for every club enthralled by the "romance of the Cup" there is another for whom the competition is an unnecessary diversion. So it was with promotion-chasing Second Division Millwall, who were unable to muster much enthusiasm and struggled against Lawrie Sanchez's Wycombe Wanderers at the New Den yesterday.

"It was a very low-key cup tie," said Sanchez. "I can't even remember getting any abuse from the crowd, which is strange here."

Millwall eventually came to life in the second half, Paul Moody hitting a post and the substitute Richard Sadlier striking the underside of the bar with two minutes left, but Wycombe clung on for a 0-0 draw.

Chester City , dumped out of the Third Division last season after an ill-advised flirtation with American football tactics, rediscovered the joys of playing league opposition when they came from 2-0 down to beat Oxford United 3-2. Oxford have had a miserable season and are seven points adrift at the bottom of the table but any hopes of an extended Cup run to boost the spirits were swiftly expelled by Chester's fighting performance.

It was a different story for the Third Division's bottom club Carlisle, who made a mockery of their poor form to beat Kidderminster 2-0.

It was not all about the triumphs of the little clubs. The Conference side Nuneaton followed their victory over Stoke with a 3-0 defeat by Bournemouth, and the UniBond Premier League's Gateshead were outclassed by Swindon , losing 5-0.

webTitle: Contract deadline for Bergkamp

fields.headline: Contract deadline for Bergkamp
fields.trailText: The Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger hopes to persuade Dennis Bergkamp to make a decision about his future with the club in the next couple of months.
fields.body:
The Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger hopes to persuade Dennis Bergkamp to make a decision about his future with the club in the next couple of months.

The 31-year-old Dutch international striker has yet to sign a new contract. He had hoped to be offered a deal lasting two years, which would keep him at Highbury until the end of his career, but he will be available on a free transfer at the end of the season and is entitled to open talks next month with any interested clubs.

Wenger said: "Dennis is still very much wanted here, but I would like to see his contract talks settled before we go back into the Champions League."

The Rangers defender Tony Vidmar has announced that he wants to leave the club by the end of the season. The Australian international is not a first-team regular under Dick Advocaat and says he would like a new challenge.

Celtic's new £5.75m signing Neil Lennon has criticised Alan Shearer for allegedly kicking him in the head two seasons ago. "I will never forget what he did to me," said the midfielder. "It was certainly the worst challenge I have ever had made on me."

webTitle: Quayle strike brings out the sunshine

fields.headline: Quayle strike brings out the sunshine
fields.standfirst: Morecambe 2 - 1 Cambridge United
fields.trailText: Morecambe 2 - 1 Cambridge United
fields.body:
Morecambe hit the bull's-eye and Cambridge United left Christie Park empty-handed. The Conference club, whose new honorary president is Jim "Bullseye" Bowen, added the Second Division club to the long list of full-time teams making early exits from the FA Cup this season with a display that was a credit to their league.

Mark Quayle, the substitute who scored the winning goal, said: "We deserved to win and hopefully people will start to sit up and really take notice of Conference football. We've shown what we can do."

The victory earned Morecambe a place in the third round for the first time in nearly 40 years and even the Cambridge manager Roy McFarland could not begrudge them their place in the draw.

McFarland and his players made a hasty departure to the sound of Morecambe's theme tune Bring Me Sunshine, chosen in honour of Eric Morecambe, whose childhood home overlooks the ground. The irony was surely not lost on Cambridge, who had struggled throughout on a heavy pitch made more treacherous by constant rain (even a streaker kept his underpants on). They were conditions designed for an upset and Morecambe obliged.

Quayle's goal restored the lead that the promising teenage defender John Hardicker had provided after seven minutes. Tom Youngs had equalised three minutes later but Cambridge, who are without a league win in 10 games, were outfought for long periods.

The visitors at least finished with some overdue spirit, with the final minutes heightening the tension of a cup tie that was always enthralling for more than 3,000 home fans. John Dreyer twice went close with headers, but this late rally also served to reveal the quality to be found in the lower league; the goalkeeper Mark Smith and the Morecambe defenders were impressive.

Their manager Jim Harvey, a former Tranmere Rovers player, said: "Mark's goal was excellent but I've got to pick out and praise our defence. We were under the cosh in the last few minutes but when it came to the crunch my players stood up to the pressure.

"It was a performance that said everything about the quality of the Conference nowadays."

webTitle: Ward is Canvey's great leveller

fields.headline: Ward is Canvey's great leveller
fields.standfirst: Canvey Island 1 - 2 Southend
fields.trailText: Canvey Island 1 - 2 Southend
fields.body:
Respectability is not always a word one associates with Canvey Island, but it was yesterday. "One team in Essex," chanted the Southend supporters, momentarily forgetting Dagenham and Redbridge's heroics on Saturday, but the relief with which they greeted the final whistle spoke volumes.

The truth was that there was as little between the teams as the score suggests. The men from the Ryman Premier League can be very proud. The most proud of all should be their centre-half Steve Ward. Now 29 and a physical education teacher, professional football has passed Ward by, but in so doing it missed a gem because he was the best player on the pitch by a margin.

An oasis of calm in the melee, he read the game beautifully, distributed the ball with skill and timed every tackle to perfection. Time and again Southend's attacks foundered on Ward, whose claim to fame has hitherto been his scurrilous regular column in the Canvey programme under the nom de plume "Ginger Sex God".

"He should be playing at a higher level than this," Canvey's manager Jeff King said with feeling afterwards. Ward smiled and shook his head: "I'm just an average non-league player. It's taken me 13 years to get this far."

Far from the heavy, sodden turf of Roots Hall proving a welcome leveller - Canvey agreed to switch the game for safety and financial reasons - both King and Ward felt Can vey would have benefited from a drier pitch.

They had a point. When a sliding tackle by the former Southend defender Mark Stimson in the opening minute ploughed a four-foot furrow which immediately filled with water, it was clear it was never going to be a game for the purist.

Neither goalkeeper had been seriously tested when Southend took the lead seven minutes before half-time. Kevin Maher found Scott Forbes on the left edge of the Canvey area and the midfielder produced a fine, curling shot to beat Ashley Harrison. The Canvey fans groaned in disbelief; Forbes had spent pre-season training with the Islanders before Southend came in for him.

At half-time King switched to a 3-5-2 formation and Canvey began to create oppor tunities of their own. A Mick Bennett header skidded a foot wide and Alex Inglethorpe, in a similar position to Forbes, could only pick out the goalkeeper. It was an expensive miss, because with 10 minutes to go Ben Abbey latched on to a long goal-kick, ran into the area and squeezed his shot under Harrison.

Canvey had scored two injury-time goals against Port Vale in the previous round, so no one at Southend was counting any chickens; sure enough, with 90 minutes on the clock Wayne Vaughan pounced on a loose ball after an Andy Jones cross.

The legs, though, were desperately weary now. Once more they launched the ball into the Southend area, once more it was cleared, before the whistle finally ended the adventure.

webTitle: Fulham's cutting edge too sharp for the rest

fields.headline: Fulham's cutting edge too sharp for the rest
fields.standfirst: West Brom 1 - 3 Fulham
fields.trailText: West Brom 1 - 3 Fulham
fields.body:
While those below them continue to cut their own throats, Fulham maintain their pursuit of Premiership football with razor-sharp efficiency.

Jean Tigana's side stretched their lead in the First Division to 10 points with an emphatic victory over a resurgent West Brom, and the ease with which they brushed aside the west midlanders, who had started this fixture in third place after an impressive run of four league wins in succession, hammered home the fact that, barring a Devon Loch-style collapse, the other promotion hopefuls are scrapping for second place.

This belief was echoed by Gary Megson, the West Brom manager. "We'll have to wait and see what happens in the future but it looks like everybody else is playing for second at best. It's very difficult to criticise when you're up against that type of quality. What we've got to do is try and learn from that. The standards they have set are what we have to attain."

As a contest, the game was effectively over within the first 30 minutes after Sean Davis's two early goals made sure that the visitors' fluid, penetrative passing game was given tangible reward.

The first came after only four minutes, Davis heading home a Bjarne Goldbaek corner, and the young midfielder doubled Fulham's lead just before the half-hour mark with an opportunistic strike from 30 yards that looped over a helpless Brian Jensen.

Although West Brom came back into the game during the second half, the visitors were on cruise control for large parts of the match and began to sweat only when Des Lyttle reduced the arrears with 19 minutes to go.

Fulham then withstood increasing pressure to hit a late goal and secure the points. Andrejs Stolcers, a £2m signing from Spartak Moscow, marking his debut with a neat finish three minutes from time.

Their rivals may have all but given up hope of catching them but Davis once again underlined the fact that no one at Fulham is taking anything for granted. " I don't think we can think of promotion yet. The boys are all down-to-earth and Lee Clark, who played for Newcastle when they lost a big lead, is always reminding the boys of that."

Indeed, but Kevin Keegan is no longer at Craven Cottage.

webTitle: Ferguson cracks frozen Well to keep Gers' home fires flickering

fields.headline: Ferguson cracks frozen Well to keep Gers' home fires flickering
fields.standfirst: Rangers 2 - 0 Motherwell
fields.trailText: Rangers 2 - 0 Motherwell
fields.body:
Rangers might yet be a plot-twist in the script of this championship race. It has been a haggard few days for these players and their manager, Dick Advocaat, given the savaging doled out following their European exit on Thursday. This result at least keeps domestic fires burning.

Motherwell committed three players to attack - a policy always to be lauded, but yesterday misguided. They battled hard in midfield and enjoyed a couple of gaping openings before Barry Ferguson scored a peculiar second goal for Rangers on 78 minutes.

Billy Davies, the Motherwell manager, was entitled to feel hard done by as three players - Benito Kemble, Kevin Twaddle and Scott Leitch - all departed early with injury.

The game had a doleful air about it, mostly provided by a throng of Rangers fans whose dejection over their Uefa Cup hiding from Kaiserslautern on Thursday was brought with them to this sabbath chore of Scottish Premier League duty.

Advocaat, though, treats no match lightly; Rangers still have two games in hand over the league leaders Celtic, and their successful negotiation, as well as every other impediment between now and May, will rest heavily on his mind.

The quest to be re-named champions may yet invigorate Rangers, though other factors at Ibrox will bring only depression; Michael Mols is still only an imitation of the striker whose knee gave out in Munich a year ago. Yesterday was one of the Dutchman's rationed first-team outings since his slow recovery from surgery. "He is at war with his knee in some games," said Advocaat vividly. "He says it can be like a knife tearing into his flesh."

Not a lot had gone right for Rangers before Bert Konterman hung in the air to nod home a corner from Albertz after 39 minutes. The moment was savoured by Konterman, a defender who, like a few other Rangers players, spent the latter part of last week cowering from the shrapnel which flew following the Uefa Cup debacle.

Ferguson's goal had a freak air to it. Every Motherwell player appeared to freeze at the sight of Tugay's cross, and before Andy Goram had rubbed his eyes, Ferguson's header had bounced past him into the net.

webTitle: Bradford fightback knocks Spurs off balance

fields.headline: Bradford fightback knocks Spurs off balance
fields.standfirst: Bradford 3 -3 Tottenham
fields.trailText: Bradford 3 -3 Tottenham
fields.body:
Even the fastest goal ever scored in the Premiership could not prompt Tottenham to their first away win in the league this season. Spurs led 3-1 early in the second half but an inspired fightback by Bradford City ensured the honours were eventually shared and the Bantams achieved lift-off from the bottom of the table for the first time in a month.

That is three games unbeaten now for the new Bradford manager Jim Jefferies and his get-tough methods seem to be paying dividends. "A month ago if we'd gone 3-1 down we'd have thought, 'That's it'," said Dean Windass, whose diving header began the fightback. "But we came back against Coventry last week to win 2-1 and we've come back today to gain a valuable point."

Jefferies, he admitted, was a hard taskmaster but his methods were paying off. The injury list had shrunk, the training had improved and there was competition for places. "Everybody's trying to prove a point to him, everybody wants to play. If you work hard during the week he looks at your performances and then at half past one on a Saturday he picks the team - and no one knows they're playing until then."

George Graham, another Scottish taskmaster, preferred to blame Tottenham's split personality for their capitulation rather than any Bradford revival. "The word is balance," the Spurs manager said. "We've got to get the balance between going forward, which is what the Spurs fans like, and then, when the opposition have the ball, defending better. We've got to be positive going forward and resolute when defending and it's very difficult." But that was to discount Bradford's never-say-die attitude.

The rookie midfielder Ledley King had put Spurs ahead with a deflected shot after only 10 seconds - the fastest since the First Division became the Premiership in 1992, but a tardy six seconds behind what appears to be Jim Fryatt's record Fourth Division goal for Bradford Park Avenue against Tranmere Rovers in 1965 - and although the home side quickly hit back through Jamie Lawrence, Sol Campbell's diving header restored Spurs' advantage before half-time.

When Chris Armstrong side-footed Spurs' third in the 54th minute there seemed only one outcome. Spurs' old-fashioned power game, with five across the back pumping long balls into the channels for Armstrong and Les Ferdinand to chase and three destructive midfielders breaking up any rhythm to the match, was putting Bradford permanently on the back foot.

Chances for the home side were few and far between and Stan Collymore, having been beaten up in a nightclub during the week, was noticeably subdued. Then Jefferies brought Dan Petrescu and Lee Sharpe on and suddenly Spurs were having to deal with a fresh threat as Bradford attacked down the wings.

In the 69th minute Windass hurled himself forward to pull a goal back and, with Bradford's frenzied support turning the rain-lashed Valley Parade into a Pennine bear pit, Sharpe crossed to Petrescu who knocked the ball back and Benito Carbone arrived to smash it home from two yards out.

"If it's about spirit and determination to stay up then I think we showed that," said Jefferies. "You can't fault our players for effort and commitment. If we are going to go down then we will go down fighting and if we work as hard as that we've got a chance."

Next up are Newcastle away, with Collymore beginning a three-match suspension. For Tottenham it is the grudge match against Arsenal and Graham desperate to prove that the old ways are the best. At least Spurs are at home.

webTitle: Venables must build from the bottom up

fields.headline: Venables must build from the bottom up
fields.standfirst: Sunderland 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
fields.trailText: Sunderland 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
His cheeky cockney swagger may have been restored to the touchline but, by the end, the hubbub among the away supporters was more hell's bells than El Tel. Defeat left Middlesbrough bottom of the Premiership, hardly the ideal start for Terry Venables's six-month sojourn on Teesside. Well, he said he wanted a challenge.

For once, Venables passed up the opportunity to appear on Saturday night television - it was the BBC and not ITV, after all - and, grim business as usual, Bryan Robson conducted the post-match interviews. "Terry only worked with the boys on Friday and I selected the side and the tactics," said the manager. "He's bringing in his own ideas from Monday. The fans will be looking forward to seeing how things work in next week's game."

Venables's former club Chelsea will provide tasty opposition, but at least things cannot get any worse. This defeat, not unexpected against a Sunderland side now beaten once in 16 games and resplendent in fifth place, sparked rumours of a £20m transfer kitty burning a hole in the chief coach's tracksuit pocket. Even by Boro's standards, splashing the cash may be premature; Venables has had precious little time to work with the current crop of Teesside millionaires, and even his reputation may struggle to attract the cream of Europe to the bottom of the league.

Still, his presence may be inspiration enough. "He's giving us a bit of know-how," said the Boro captain Paul Ince. "He's a bubbly character and keeps things simple in training; it's just great to have someone like him around. The lads are looking forward to see what he'll come up with on Monday morning."

"A change can bring a bit of a spark," said the Sunder land manager Peter Reid. "If you don't change the players, a manager can become a bit monotonous. I'm sure it will work out for them."

Reid and Venables bumped into each other at a restaurant the night before this Wear-Tees derby and their players followed suit in a gory opening. Darren Williams returned bloodied but patched up after clashing with Keith O'Neill; Phil Stamp proved less durable after being kicked on the forehead by his team-mate Ugo Ehiogu.

Stamp's early departure scuppered Robson's tactics and, with the manager fretting over how to accommodate the substitute Christian Karembeu, his chief coach descended from the directors' box to offer assistance.

What followed was more masterclass than masterstroke. Venables pointed and prompted while Robson and his assistant Viv Anderson took mental notes; enthralled, all that was missing was a rosy red apple for their teacher on the final whistle.

"We were bouncing things off each other," insisted Robson. "I did the half-time team talk but Terry came in with a few pointers. He was encouraged by the performance."

There was much with which to be heartened and, had Hamilton Ricard displayed any form, Boro would have claimed at least the point they deserved.

Virtually all the visitors' chances fell to the Colombian. Still without a league goal this season, he fluffed into the side netting early, then the referee Graham Poll strangely disallowed his headed goal after 37 minutes. Frustration culminated in a theatrical penalty dive, a yellow card and an easier header gratefully caught by Thomas Sorensen. Ricard was left thumping the turf, perplexed by his own inability.

By then, Michael Gray had burst on to Ehiogu's weak clearance to fire through Mark Schwarzer at the near post. The home side were as dogged and uncompromising as ever; they have beaten both their north-east rivals this season and can justifiably claim to be the region's best. One day their lofty position will generate its own headlines, although they were happy to spend Saturday basking in El Tel's shadow.

"If we can sneak up the Premiership as quietly as possible, that's brilliant," said Gray. "We had to scrap to win, but we don't want the limelight. Our aim is Europe."

Venables may be thinking wistfully about sunny Spain himself. Despite boasting the wrong type of 100% record, Boro officials are already publicly hoping his long-term future is on Teesside. "I think there is a chance he could be persuaded to stay longer; he's a football man so it will be difficult for him [to walk away]," said the chief executive Keith Lamb.

"I don't envisage being remotely tempted to stay," dismissed Venables, although the on-off nature of his arrival suggests that though he is pouring cold water now, it may be luke-warm in May.

webTitle: Battle lines drawn on the Preston front

fields.headline: Battle lines drawn on the Preston front
fields.standfirst: Preston North End 2 - 1 Burnley
fields.trailText: Preston North End 2 - 1 Burnley
fields.body:
Preston took the honours in the latest contest to determine the First Division championship of Lancashire, but for the moment there are not many people at Deepdale getting carried away with success.

The rise of Preston, and their neighbours Burnley who were promoted with them in May, has seen them join Bolton and Blackburn in the contest to see which two teams will slipstream Fulham into the Premiership next season, but Preston's captain Sean Gregan said: "It's another three points; the main objective is to mathematically be safe and then we'll see where we go from there.

"Everyone wants to win derby games but I thought we put on a performance that totally deserved a win."

Still, there is no doubting that passions run high in this corner of the football world. Preston officials were obliged this week to ask fans buying tickets to answer a "quiz" about their team, ensuring Burnley supporters did not infiltrate the home sections. Next weekend Burnley entertain Blackburn, and police and club officials were meeting as long ago as September in anticipation of trouble.

But for this week at least Preston can claim to be the pride of Lancashire, after Graham Alexander's 67th-minute winner from a neatly worked short corner. That added to Jon Macken's 30-yard effort six minutes after the restart, which equalised a first Burnley goal for Ian Moore.

webTitle: No sex and travel makes the Dons grow stronger

fields.headline: No sex and travel makes the Dons grow stronger
fields.standfirst: Birmingham City 0 - 3 Wimbledon
fields.trailText: Birmingham City 0 - 3 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Terry Burton's notion that his players perform more effectively in away games because they have not been able to spend the previous evening romping with their wives or partners gained further credence here on Saturday.

Wimbledon, who have won once at Selhurst Park this season, collected their seventh victory on their travels at the expense of off-form Birmingham. So jaded were Trevor Francis's team that, if there is any mileage in Burton's thinking, City must have been on the razzle for the best part of a fortnight.

But Francis provided a far less colourful if more plausible reason for City's heaviest defeat of the season: the Worthington Cup.

"In the last seven weeks we've produced just two good performances - against Spurs and Newcastle in the Worthington Cup," the City manager explained.

"This result has been on the cards for a while and I'm not surprised it's come just before our quarter-final against Sheffield Wednesday on Tuesday. Some of my players clearly had that game on their minds and lacked motivation. I've told them they were an embarrassment."

City's players were not the only ones to feel their manager's wrath. The referee Dermot Gallagher did not escape after going into "I see no ships" mode when John Hartson elbowed Darren Purse.

For Francis, the official showed such ignorance of the rules that it might as well have been Liam or Noel Gallagher blowing the whistle.

"If a player deliberately elbows an opponent in the face he has to be sent off. It's violent conduct," he added. "Mr Gallagher is an experienced referee but I didn't understand his interpretation."

Hartson was finally given first use of the dressing room soap when he was cautioned for a second time following a reckless challenge on David Burrows in the 66th minute.

His exit had little bearing on the game. By then first half-strikes by Damien Francis and Jason Euell had put the visitors in control and City were unable to capitalise on their numerical advantage. Instead Francis piled on the humiliation with a third goal 12 minutes from time.

webTitle: One point but three cheers for Charlton

fields.headline: One point but three cheers for Charlton
fields.trailText: Charlton 3 - 3 Man Utd
fields.body:
To list the attributes of Charlton Athletic FC is to catalogue the areas Manchester United need to work on: friendly, unassuming, approachable, solicitous about their supporters, a fan on the board, personable manager.

To Charlton's players OK! is a sauce and Fame is a musical. Yet in a ground as modest as their transfer kitty, this corner-shop club proved themselves every bit the equals of Manchester United Inc on Saturday. And the game of football, not to mention the Premiership table, was all the better for it.

There is always a certain satisfaction in seeing the toffs brought down to earth and even more so when a little club like Charlton do the deed. After eight league wins in a row, the scale of United's superiority had become annoying, dispiriting, boring, the title race reduced to a field of one.

So to Charlton go many thanks for injecting some much-needed hope into the proceedings; for bursting United's bubble of invincibility; for showing the way for their future opponents; and for cutting the gap at the top of the table to a more bridgeable six points.

In a cracking game, Alan Curbishley's valiant troops thrived on a potent brew of effrontery and persistence after seeing a one-goal lead, that could easily have been three, disappear in the space of a minute just before half-time as United struck twice.

When it became 3-1 midway through the second half, the game looked over. But to their immense credit Charlton kept going, kept getting balls and bodies into the box and came up with two late goals and a draw.

Now at this point it would be wise to add a touch of bromide to the celebrations. For all the plaudits that Charlton deserve, United were partly the architects of their own problems.

Sir Alex Ferguson started with a baffling 4-3-2-1 formation, playing Ole Gunnar Solskjaer as a lone striker, in front of two wide men, the fledgling Luke Chadwick and Ryan Giggs.

Charlton exploited the resulting space down the wings to pump in a series of crosses which spread panic in a United defence badly missing the injured Jaap Stam.

In the first five minutes Raimond van der Gouw, in for the rested Fabien Barthez, had to tip away a Jonatan Johansson header while Charlton's new loan signing Shaun Bartlett hit the woodwork.

Eventually the South African - ironically a United fan - found the net, darting between the bemused Neville brothers to head in a right-wing cross. Shortly after that Johansson and Claus Jensen also went close.

But Charlton had only managed to poke a dozing alligator. Fergie stormed down to the bench to restore 4-4-2 and suddenly United came alive, passing the ball with biting accuracy, snapping at Charlton in possession and generally pinning them back for the rest of the half.

Giggs, making his first start in a month, was United's key man, directing his fast, tricky runs directly into the heart of the defence and forcing Dean Kiely into an acrobatic save on 38 minutes before finding the net from 18 yards a few minutes later.

The brilliant Welshman set up United's second almost from therestart, executing an audacious lob on the volley from within the centre circle which hit the bar and fell to Solskjaer. Only the Norwegian had bothered to follow up, thinking that something might come of Giggs's long- range punt. And his reward was a simple tap-in.

Kiely then saved from Giggs, Solksjaer and Chadwick before Roy Keane extended United's lead with a toe-poke from 18 yards. Giggs went close again shortly after but, amid suspicions of United complacency, Charlton hit back.

Bartlett, who can boast Nelson Mandela as a wedding guest, did his hopes of a permanent move to Charlton from FC Zurich no harm by heading in his second goal. And five minutes from time John Robinson swivelled to fire home the equaliser.

Curbishley is still waiting to hear from the Football Association on his exact role as one of the Sven-Goran Eriksson's posse of young English coaches. But he knows what his job at Charlton entails: avoiding relegation and establishing the club as Premiership regulars. On Saturday's evidence, this game could well become a permanent fixture.

webTitle: Parlour trick keeps Arsenal in picture

fields.headline: Parlour trick keeps Arsenal in picture
fields.standfirst: Arsenal 5 - 0 Newcastle United
fields.trailText: Arsenal 5 - 0 Newcastle United
fields.body:
By lunchtime on Boxing Day Arsenal will have a clearer idea of where their season in the Premiership is heading. Either Arsène Wenger's team will be in with a realistic chance of usurping Manchester United's throne or, like a Queen's consort, they will continue to keep a respectful distance while wondering what life is for apart, that is, from a place in the next Champions League.

At least Arsenal have rediscovered the scoring touch that deserted them in November. On Saturday they showed scant sympathy to a Newcastle side who arrived at Highbury with novices in defence and attack while in midfield a bewildered Chilean, Clarence Acuna, did not look as if he was about to revive memories of the Robledo brothers of the early 50s.

Ray Parlour scored three of Arsenal's five goals, his first hat-trick in the Premiership and only his second altogether, as well as giving an industrious performance of the kind that used to win Soviet coalminers the order of Lenin.

Primarily, however, it was the pace and technique of Thierry Henry which left Newcastle quivering like a rabbit trying to cross a French autoroute. Whenever the striker gained possession Bobby Robson's defence covered its ears and whiskers.

"We needed to win today," said Wenger. "We knew that Manchester United could take an 11-point lead if we didn't. This victory will give us the confidence we need for our next two games at Tottenham and Liverpool." And Leicester City at home on Boxing Day, he might have added.

Wenger is right nonetheless. United's draw at Charlton may have enabled Arsenal to reduce their lead at the top to six points but if Sir Alex Ferguson's side beat Liverpool at Old Trafford on Sunday Arsenal will face a nine-point gap when they go to White Hart Lane the following evening. So they urgently need to repeat the sort of run that saw them go 12 league matches unbeaten after losing at Sunderland on the opening day.

Even now Arsenal cannot match United's strength in depth. Wenger has found it harder to advance on the two fronts of Premiership and Champions League and practically admitted as much. "Considering the demands of the Champions League, I think we have done well to get 34 points in the Premiership," he said, "and you might have expected Manchester United to have no more than 37 or 38 by now, but they have already got 40."

Wenger, therefore, will not have been displeased to achieve such a convincing victory over Newcastle without the unfit Patrick Vieira and Silvinho and with Dennis Bergkamp, another recent casualty, reduced to a walk-on part when the game was already won.

Robson could not remember the last time one of his teams had lost by five goals. In fact it happened at least three times during his 13 years at Ipswich but that was long ago and greater defensive stability has been one of his prime achievements at Newcastle.

On Saturday, however, he was forced by injuries to play the less-experienced Aaron Hughes and Steve Caldwell at centre-back with Robert Lee screening them. The plan was undone in the 13th minute, when Henry gathered a long pass from Tony Adams and cut inside Hughes to send a low shot into the far corner, and completely unravelled three minutes later as Parlour drove in his first goal after Andy Griffin's loss of the ball on the right had enabled Fredrik Ljungberg and Kwankwo Kanu to catch Newcastle on the break.

With Alan Shearer waiting to hear if he needs surgery on an injured knee and Carl Cort another absentee, Newcastle's attacking resources were thin. Yet Lomana Lua Lua showed snatches of skill and created his team's sole scoring attempt - a rising shot from Kieron Dyer pushed wide by Alex Manninger - with an astutely angled pass.

Once Kanu had casually slipped in Arsenal's third soon after half-time, Ljungberg's lob having caught the defence square, Newcastle were reduced to damage limitation. But Parlour was far from done and scored twice more in the last four minutes, first with a rare header from Henry's precise centre and then from Robert Pires's pass.

Wenger reckoned that Parlour made better scoring runs playing in central midfield than wide on the right and implied that he would continue to use him in this position, along with Gilles Grimandi and Vieira.

Clearly Arsenal will not be attempting to catch Manchester United from the wings. It remains to be seen if they have sufficiently enduring qualities to oust them from centre stage.

webTitle: Scottish website seeks to cash in on Madonna wedding

fields.headline: Scottish website seeks to cash in on Madonna wedding
fields.trailText: A Scottish tourist body is launching a website encouraging people to follow Madonna and tie the knot in the Highlands. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A Scottish tourist body is seeking to capitalise on the media frenzy surrounding Madonna's wedding plans by launching a website to encourage people to tie the knot in the Highlands.

The Highlands of Scotland Tourist Board has devised the site, www.highland-wedding.com, to exploit the worldwide interest the wedding has generated.

The superstar's plans to marry her fiance, Guy Ritchie, in a Scottish castle were revealed last week.

Board chief executive David Noble said: "We want to promote the Highlands as a romantic get-away-from-it-all wedding destination, so this seemed like the ideal opportunity to get it up and running.

A spokeswoman for the board said it was unclear how many hits the site has had since it was launched on Friday, but she added the site would be expanded over the next few weeks.

It has been widely reported that Madonna will marry Mr Ritchie at Dornoch Cathedral or Skibo Castle on December 22, the day after their son Rocco is christened in the cathedral.

webTitle: From: Fran (11 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Fran
fields.trailText: If you're going to Vegas then go midweek; the hotels are so much cheaper than at the weekend. And stick five dollars on number three for me.
fields.body:
Sam,

If you get a chance when you're in California, go to the Mystery Spot in Santa Cruz (www.mysteryspot.com). It's probably the best place I went to when I did my coast-to-cost trip, and it was well worth the amazing long walk through the forest in flip flops (if you do go, try and get a lift with someone, or hire a bike). If you go, while you're in S nta Cruz make sure you get a burrito from the Mexican shop opposite the amusement arcades, and go on the oldest roller coaster in the US. You can also walk along the bridge that they jump off in the Lost Boys, even though you'll be disappointed because it's not as high as it looks. In fact, you could jump off it without hurting yourself, even if you're not a vampire.

Anyway, back to work while I seethe with jealously at your trip.

Have fun!!!

PS If you're going to Vegas then go midweek; the hotels are so much cheaper than at the weekend. And stick five dollars on number three for me.

webTitle: One in a hundred in care get to university

fields.headline: One in a hundred in care get to university
fields.trailText: Only one in a hundred children who have lived in local authority care gets into university, a study has found.
fields.body:
Only one in a hundred children who have lived in local authority care gets into university, a study has found.

Over one in three school leavers from the population as a whole currently enrol onto university degree courses .

The findings come from a pilot study which is part of a five year project aiming to help young care leavers get into and successfully complete university.

London University's Institute of Education is to undertake a £650,000 research project, sponsored by the Buttle Trust, a children's charity, and directed by Professor Sonia Jackson of the Institute's Thomas Coram Research Unit.

At present only 3% of young people in public care obtain five or more GCSEs at grade C or above, compared with 49 per cent of the school population as a whole.

Researchers will work with three cohorts of care leavers in higher education to establish what support is needed and how it should be provided. They will analyse the obstacles the young people face from entering university until they graduate and evaluate the types of assistance needed to overcome them.

They will also provide detailed guidance to local authorities on how to meet their statutory duties towards care leavers entering universities, including yardsticks for assessing financial need. The care leavers, who will come from all parts of England, will have access to grants from the Buttle Trust.

webTitle: From: Ted and Yvonne (10 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Ted and Yvonne
fields.trailText: In Singapore, you must do your shopping, have a gin sling in Raffles, see the orchids in the botanical gardens, and have dinner on one of the riverside or floating restaurants.
fields.body:
Hi from two old(er) grey nomads.

We did a six-month round-the-world trip between April and October this year, and loved (almost) every minute of it. We needed the imodium too, on occasion, but mostly took our GP's advice (he is a former backpacker) "A stomach upset means there is something in your gut that the body does not want. The best thing to do is let it flush through, if you can. But, if you've got a plane to catch..."

Having looked at your route map, we didn't go to most of the places you have planned, except Singapore and Peru, so we don't have much advice.

However, in Singapore, you must do your shopping - and cameras are almost as cheap in the UK now - have a gin sling in Raffles, see the orchids in the botanical gardens, and have dinner on one of the riverside or floating restaurants. There is a lot more to do, but we did not have time to do anything else. But do find time to eat an authentic laksa.

In Lima, there is a travel agency called Turismo Inkaiko, (610, Avenida Jose Pardo). They organised a three week tour of Peru for us that was well within our budget, and was so carefully worked out that we gradually faced the altitude - Peru can get up to 4000 metres; Ben Nevis is 4000 feet. One word of warning, though: don't let your credit card out of sight, and destroy any card voucher you do not intend to go through - some may be taken "by mistake".

If you get to Macchu Pichu, do stay overnight in Aguas Calientes; your Macchu Pichu entry ticket allows you in next day for half-price. Go up on the first bus - around 6 am. You won't see a sunrise, but you will see the site almost empty. And, if you have the energy, try the hike up Wayna Pichu (we didn't, and sort of regret it.)

In Peru, you can use the ATM's, and they ask if you want to read English or Spanish, and take dollars or soles. You can (usually) safely exchange money on the street - the official guys should be wearing authorised tabards - and they can give a better rate of exchange than the banks, but be prepared to haggle, fiercely. Arequipa is beautiful.

We wish you a great time, and wish we were going with you.

You will meet lots of new friends, enjoy their company, relive their experiences, and take their advice.

Ted and Yvonne.

webTitle: Player power takes continent by storm

fields.headline: Player power takes continent by storm
fields.trailText: It was a case of "trouble at t'mill" for many of Europe's leading clubs this week, as several off-the-field problems emerged to overshadow some great performances on the pitch. Player power, passport problems, legal challenges and transfer disputes - not to mention allegations of racial abuse - all surfaced in the past seven days, providing further evidence that the wonderful simplicity of the beautiful game is not what it once was. American politicians conduct themselves with more dignity than European football clubs.
fields.body:
It was a case of "trouble at t'mill" for many of Europe's leading clubs this week, as several off-the-field problems emerged to overshadow some great performances on the pitch. Player power, passport problems, legal challenges and transfer disputes - not to mention allegations of racial abuse - all surfaced in the past seven days, providing further evidence that the wonderful simplicity of the beautiful game is not what it once was. American politicians conduct themselves with more dignity than European football clubs.

Take Bayer Leverkusen. Fresh from celebrating a 4-0 win over Hertha Berlin which took them to the top of the Bundeslegia, the German club threatened to appeal to Fifa if their attempt to sign Brazilian international defender Lucio from Porto Alegre was scuppered by the intervention of other clubs. Barcelona, Internazionale and Bayern Munich are all chasing the Brazilian's signature, but Bayer chairman Reyer Calmund was adamant that Lucio would still be joining them. "He has signed with us, and he will come to us," said Calmund. "Despite the efforts of Barcelona, and the calling of Rivaldo, he has agreed." All cleared up then.

Or perhaps not, and with the Porto Alegre board under pressure to sell Lucio to the Catalan giants, who are thought to be offering more than Leverkusen's £4.5m, the involvement of Fifa remains possible. "It would be a pity if Fifa were forced to decide, but it may be the only way if you want a war over who owns him," Calmund threatened.

Bayer are certainly winning the war on the pitch, and Sunday's destruction of Berlin - who were level on points with them at the start of proceedings - took them one point clear of previous leaders Schalke 04. Schalke had enjoyed only the briefest spell at the summit, courtesy of a 2-1 win over bottom club Stuttgart 24 hours earlier, whose coach Ralf Rangnick now faces an uncertain future.

Rangnick's survival until this point had much to do with Stuttgart's Uefa Cup defeat of Feyenoord ten days ago, but the result has clearly had little effect on either side's domestic fortunes. As Stuttgart crumbled at the weekend, Feyenoord increased their lead at the top of the Eredivisie to four points with a stunning 3-1 victory over Ajax in Rotterdam. Bonaventure Kalou, Patrick Paauwe and - Newcastle fans take note - Jon Dahl Tomasson gave the home side a 3-0 lead within 50 minutes, before Andy van der Meyde scored a consolation for the visitors.

Feyenoord though have problems of their own, and their Brazilian teenage prodigy Leonardo could be banned from playing following fears that he has been using a fake Portuguese passport and doesn't hold a work permit. The Public Prosecutor has warned the league leaders against playing the 17-year-old winger, who made his debut in Sunday's defeat of Ajax, and Leonardo could be forced to return to Brazil, despite being touted as a future star of Dutch football. The club have denied any wrongdoing, with a spokesman saying: "Feyenoord believed Leonardo had Portuguese nationality." Arsene Wenger would doubtless sympathise.

Third placed Vitesse Arnhem are also experiencing player problems centring on a man much beloved to English fans and managers - Pierre van Hooijdonk. Vitesse are still owed the £4m transfer fee "paid" by Benfica for the Dutch striker in the summer and have started legal action in Portugal in an attempt to recoup the cash. A spokesman for Vitesse Arnhem said: "We have information that Benfica cannot pay the £4m until February, and that being the case there's no point talking about it further." Van Hooijdonk has failed to settle in Lisbon, and Benfica are sixth place in the Portuguese Primeira Liga, well off the pace.

All is also not well in France, unless you happen to support Bordeaux, who returned to the top of First Division with a 2-1 win over St Etienne. A Nicolas Anelka goal gave Paris Saint-Germain their first win in eight league games, but morale in the capital remains low after midfielder Stephane Dalmat claimed he had been racially abused by his own supporters.

"I took certain remarks made by supporters badly and such incidents have affected my morale," he said. "I have problems in my head and it is possible that this can be seen on the pitch."

George Weah is also far from being a happy bunny, despite his sublime performance in Marseille's 2-0 victory over Nantes, in which he created both goals. Weah received a standing ovation on being substituted with ten minutes remaining, but after the game launched a stinging attack on coach Javier Clemente's tactics. "I gave two decisive passes, but don't get any chances," he said. "It is difficult to play alone, but I don't get any choice. For me, I can't go on like that - I can't play that way."

He may be forced to, as Clemente is not a manager to cross, and his handling of Weah may yet prove that player power does have its limits.

webTitle: A happy Christmas for the big clubs

fields.headline: A happy Christmas for the big clubs
fields.trailText: The wispy December snow caresses the Alps like glucose atop a bowl of Alpen; the "ceppo" - the Italian version of the Christmas tree - stands proudly in every front room, and signs wishing customers "Buon Natale" flash from every shop front. Everywhere, it seems, there are signs of a traditional Italian Christmas.
fields.body:
The wispy December snow caresses the Alps like glucose atop a bowl of Alpen; the "ceppo" - the Italian version of the Christmas tree - stands proudly in every front room, and signs wishing customers "Buon Natale" flash from every shop front. Everywhere, it seems, there are signs of a traditional Italian Christmas.

And, rather late in the day, Serie A too has entered in on the act. Because after a season where the big clubs have wheezed like an asthmatic reindeer negotiating a mountain pass, now Christmas is fast approaching they have started to reassert themselves.

Roma are top, Juventus lie third, Lazio are fourth and AC Milan are within striking distance in fifth. Meanwhile, those surprise early season pace-setters - teams like Udinese and Bologna - are now back in their usual Uefa Cup-seeking place.

But the indefatigable Roma march on. Once again they were inspired by Gabriel Batistuta and Francesco Totti, who both scored. Once again Fabio Capello's men were unstoppable at the Stadio Olimpico, battling their way to a 2-1 victory against Udinese to move six points clear at the top of Serie A.

And once again Capello was contented, but demanding. "I was happy with the result, even though the margin could have been greater," he claimed. "The players I have at my disposition, the ones I used from the bench, didn't reduce the quality of the performance."

Elsewhere Atalanta - still missing their main striker Nicola Ventura - hung on in second despite a dreary 0-0 draw against Perugia on a sodden pitch. But they will be anxiously watching over their shoulder, particularly as their rivals all won.

Lazio were probably the most impressive of the chasing teams, garrotting hapless Vicenza 4-1, with goals from Nedved (2), Crespo and Salas - and leaving one supposing under-pressure coach feeling mightily pleased. "It was certainly one of our best games of the season, if not the best. I really hope our championship starts now," said Sven-Goran Eriksson.

"Hopefully this win could put the team in the right frame of mind and on the right track. We played with the correct amount of determination for the entire 90 minutes of play. I noted a lot of positive aggressiveness and the team always tried to push the ball forward in search of the goal," he added.

And two-goal hero Nedved was also in rambunctious mood, claiming: "I would like to dedicate my goals to the team and especially to Eriksson. This victory proves that we are not a team in crisis and that we are still able to put fear in our adversaries."

Meanwhile AC Milan continued their impressive run with a 4-1 home win against Lecce - who, having beaten Internazionale at the San Siro last month, found an in-form Shevchenko and co. an entirely different proposition. The Ukrainian striker scored twice, and goals from Leonardo and Jose Mari completed the rout. Juventus were much less exciting - grinding out a 1-0 victory after an early goal from Ferrera - but they are hovering ominously in third.

In fact out of all of Italy's big clubs, only Internazionale's scudetto chances look over, after they succumbed to a 2-0 defeat away at Fiorentina - a fact admitted by their coach Marco Tardelli. "We have many problems - in defence, in midfield, and in attack," he whined. I don't like the way team played. This team has to learn to fight. And now we have to find a target.

"The Scudetto is now lost, but we have to try and join next year Champions' League or to win Uefa Cup," he added, the anger and the despair evident in his voice.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: The issue explained: the NHS consultant contract

fields.headline: The issue explained: the NHS consultant contract
fields.trailText: The government has proposed an overhaul of the consultant contract, which critics say is currently open to abuse as doctors manipulate their NHS positions in order gain more money from private patients. Patrick Butler explains.
fields.body:
Who are consultants?
Consultants are highly trained, senior health professionals. The UK has around 25,000 consultants. They are contracted to work around 35 hours a week for the NHS, although the BMA claims the average consultant spends 50 hours a week on NHS work. NHS consultants earn, on average, £68,000 a year. The pay scale runs from £49,000 to £64,000, with the prospect of adding discretionary point bonuses of £2,500 and distinction awards of up to £61,000.

What is the consultant contract?
There are two types of consultant contract, whole time and maximum part time. The former obliges consultants to spend "substantially the whole of their time" on NHS work, with an option to add up to 10% of their earnings from private practice.

The latter have the same professional obligations to the NHS - but in exchange for losing one-eleventh of their salary they are not restricted in the amount they can earn from private practice.

How much extra can NHS consultants earn from private practice?
Anything from a small fortune to pocket money, depending on speciality and predisposition. The average net annual private practice income for an NHS plastic surgeon is £75,000 (1999 figures). Orthopaedic surgeons rake in an average of £58,000 a year from private practice. The least lucrative speciality is pathology (£7,572).

Why doesn't the NHS 'buy out' consultants' private work?
Much as it might want to insist consultants spend all of their time working for the NHS, it can't afford to pay them. The NHS estimates it would cost at least £700m to compensate consultants. There are also fears that, faced with the choice, top consultants would simply opt to work exclusively for the private sector, in many cases doubling their income in the process.

If the NHS money is so bad why don't consultants abandon the NHS and go private?
Most consultants need the NHS as much as it needs them. An NHS post brings status, profile, credibility and access to a regular source of potential private patients, not to mention an NHS pension.

The former obliges consultants to spend "substantially the whole of their time" on NHS work, with an option to add up to 10% of their earnings from private practice. The latter have the same professional obligations to the NHS - but in exchange for losing one-eleventh of their salary they are not restricted in the amount they can earn from private practice. How much extra can NHS consultants earn from private practice? Anything from a small fortune to pocket money, depending on speciality and predisposition. The average net annual private practice income for an NHS plastic surgeon is £75,000 (1999 figures). Orthopaedic surgeons rake in an average of £58,000 a year from private practice. The least lucrative speciality is pathology (£7,572). Why doesn't the NHS 'buy out' consultants' private work? Much as it might want to insist consultants spend all of their time working for the NHS, it can't afford to pay them. The NHS estimates it would cost at least £700m to compensate consultants. There are also fears that, faced with the choice, top consultants would simply opt to work exclusively for the private sector, in many cases doubling their income in the process. If the NHS money is so bad why don't consultants abandon the NHS and go private? Most consultants need the NHS as much as it needs them. An NHS post brings status, profile, credibility and access to a regular source of potential private patients, not to mention an NHS pension.

webTitle: Consultant contract goes back to 'unfinished business'

fields.headline: Consultant contract goes back to 'unfinished business'
fields.trailText: The government's proposal to overhaul the consultant contract goes back to a deal made in the creation of the NHS in 1948, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
The government's proposal to "fundamentally overhaul" the consultant contract is one of the most symbolically important aspects of its National Health Service plan, reaching back as it does to "unfinished business" in the creation of the national health service in 1948.

The then health minister Aneurin Bevan, Labour's architect of the NHS, agreed to a "sweetheart deal" in which senior hospital doctors gained highly preferential terms and conditions in return for their support for the nascent NHS, much to the shock of some in the Labour movement.

Since then the consultant contract has remained largely unchanged, despite repeated criticism that it is open to abuse by consultants who carry out large amounts of private work, that it causes long NHS waiting lists and that it is not good value for money for the NHS.

The government has disappointed NHS purists by declining to abolish NHS consultants' contractual right to carry out private practice. But it has ambitious plans to manage the contracts more closely, which is likely to bring it into conflict with the health service's most powerful interest group.

Health secretary Alan Milburn has made it clear that he is determined to introduce an "updated and modernised" contract which will clarify consultants' minimum obligations to their NHS work and create financial rewards for those senior doctors who "do most for the NHS".

According to the NHS Plan: "Consultants' current contract is far from satisfactoryToo few have proper job plans setting out their key objectives, tasks and responsibilities and when they are expected to carry out these duties."

Ministers want to introduce an annual appraisal of consultant performance and effective job plans "to ensure that NHS employers are able to manage the consultant workforce effectively in order to ensure the best use of their time and of the resources of the trust".

The proposed new contract would require newly qualified consultants to "work exclusively for the NHS for the first seven years of their career" and agree to carry out a minimum amount of NHS work each week.

Consultants will be able to carry out private work only when they have fulfilled their NHS requirements.

In return, consultants stand to benefit from increased financial rewards, with the bulk of bonuses and distinction awards going to those consultants who make the biggest contribution to improving services and who make long-term commitments to the NHS.

The government also promises a 30% expansion in consultant numbers and a greater role for consultants in shaping the NHS modernisation plans.

Mr Milburn underlined his commitment to push through the proposed changes in his speech to the Labour conference this year, where he declared: "For too long the issue of consultant's private practice has been left unresolved. Today we have the courage to make this change."

Consultants' leaders responded favourably to some aspects of the proposal, but objected strongly to the attempts to place a limit on consultant's private practice, calling it "an ill-conceived, vindictive attack on new consultants' freedom to work outside the NHS".

The British Medical Association (BMA) believes that attempts to tie in recently qualified consultants into working for the NHS for "perhaps seven years" may be illegal under Human Rights legislation. "We don't think that you can control what qualified doctors do in their spare time," says BMA chairman Ian Bogle.

Negotiations on the consultant contract continue. Perhaps more than any other part of the NHS Plan, it will be seen as a litmus test of government radicalism. Success for the government would be a highly symbolic victory.
