webTitle: Whistles, rows and red cards

fields.headline: Whistles, rows and red cards
fields.trailText: John Carew controls a ball further than most players can kick it. But the Giant Norwegian (a title that's fast becoming as irritating as Gianfranco Zola's Little Italian tag) is certainly doing the business for Héctor Cúper's Valencia.
fields.body:
John Carew controls a ball further than most players can kick it. But the Giant Norwegian (a title that's fast becoming as irritating as Gianfranco Zola's Little Italian tag) is certainly doing the business for Héctor Cúper's Valencia.

Yes, this is the same man who gave an awesome display of wasteful finishing at Euro 2000. But no, it's not the same player. Valencia have Carew to thank for their return to the top of La Liga on Saturday night. The Giant Norwegian (see?) scored an excellent first and created the second for Juan Sánchez as Valencia strolled to a 2-0 victory against struggling Real Sociedad at the Mestalla.

Despite the return to top spot, Valencia's fans aren't all that happy. In fact, in an opinion poll carried out by the newspaper La Provincia, 86% of Valencia fans declared themselves "against" their side's style of play. And they've been getting on the players' backs, too. So much so, in fact, that Juan Sánchez - like Mendieta a few weeks back - refused to celebrate his goal on Saturday "because I couldn't believe that they'd been whistling me".

Without Piojo López, Gerard et al, Valencia may not be as exciting to watch as last year, but top of the table's a pretty nice place to be. And Héctor Cúper's side will be there for at least a week after Deportivo La Coruña only managed a 1-1 draw against Rayo Vallecano at the Riazor on Sunday.

Once again, Brazilian playmaker Djalminha was the focus of attention. The hero of recent weeks set up Roy Makaay for the opening goal, but turned villain soon after when he was sent off for something he said (or didn't say) to the referee, Losantos Omar.

Omar claimed afterwards that the Brazilian had made a comment about "the prostitute mother that gave birth to me". But Djalminha accused the referee of wanting to be a big star, insisting that he "didn't say anything about his mother". Depor coach Javier Irureta declared it "two different games" - that's a "game of two halves" to you and me - the one up to the sending off and the one after. And so it proved; Bolic finally making Rayo's pressure count with an equaliser.

Real Madrid are hot on the heels of the leaders (two points behind with a game in hand) after an impressive and ultimately comfortable 3-0 win over Celta Vigo at the Bernabéu. Iván Helguera scored the first from a suspiciously off-side position with a classy flick. Luis Figo added a sensational second, reminiscent of "that Matt Le Tissier goal" against Newcastle. And Robert Carlos whacked in a second-half free-kick that moved around more than a 99p garage football in a gale-force wind.

The Man in the Moustache was getting a bit over-excited after the game, claiming that Real Madrid "have got everything we need to be the perfect team". Don't worry, he soon returned to type: The key to Madrid's success, he said, was "hard work". Phew, that's more like it.

Plenty of excitement over in Barcelona too, where Spain won the Davis Cup amid fantastic scenes and Barcelona played host to city rivals Espanyol. Lorenzo Serra Ferrer's side ran out winners for the fifteenth year running, 4-2. A dubious penalty (even Patrick Kluivert was "surprised" it was given) set Barça on their way. Rivaldo scored from the spot and got another in the second half, while Xavi and Luis Enrique grabbed the others. There was a huge reception for the returning Pep Guardiola, too - he came on as a second half sub for Xavi.

It's still not happy days at Barça, though. Sergi spent the afternoon getting booed by his own fans, after making the mistake that let Martín Posse for Espanyol's first, and the Club (sorry, "More than a club") have just discovered that they're not even one of Spain's Big Two anymore. Fifa have decided that they only want 12 sides, not 16, to compete for the World Club Championships to be held in Spain next summer. And that means bye bye Barça - you're just not very good.

What of Mallorca duo Messrs Eto'o and Aragonés after last week's little spat? Well, the Cameroon striker was back in the side for their poor 1-1 draw against Numancia, despite manager Luis Aragonés's admission that he felt like head-butting him, and everything's officially "back to normal" (whatever that means with Aragonés).

Aragonés, perhaps wisely, chose not to replace Eto'o this time (opting for a knackered-looking Alberto Luque instead), but he's hardly calmed down - the veteran boss told the press afterwards "I'm fucked off because I always want to win - even at marbles".

Real Oviedo travelled to Athletic Bilbao, with the Basque side's coach Txetxu Rojo wary that "one day Oviedo will have to score away". One day maybe, but not today - Radi Antic's side crashed to a 4-0 defeat. Elsewhere, Dario Silva scored the fastest goal in Spanish football history (seven seconds) to set Málaga on their way to a 3-1 win over Valladolid.

Amavisca scored in the last minute to complete a surprise 2-1 victory for new Racing Santander coach Gregorio Manzano against Alavés. And strugglers Numancia and Zaragoza drew 1-1 in Soria. Villarreal hammered Las Palmas 5-1, but worry not you Vinny Samways fans - Villarreal boss Víctor Muñoz reckons "there's no way Las Palmas will go down". That's OK then.

Meanwhile, Djalminha wasn't the only one in trouble with the ref this weekend. Real Betis's substitute goalkeeper Joaquín Valerio managed to get sent off in the tunnel before his side's trip to Albacete. When Valerio saw referee Valle Gil, he turned to a member of Albacete's staff (he played for them last year) to ask "is this the son of a bitch who screwed us last year at Eibar?"

Unfortunately for the keeper, the son of the bitch who screwed him the year before has pretty good hearing and was perfectly happy to screw him again.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Interview: Lynne Segal

fields.headline: The truth about men and women
fields.standfirst:
Feminist, activist, optimist - as Lynne Segal takes up her prestigious new professorship, Dave Hill asks her what gender really means in the 21st century

Extended interview with Lynne Segal for Guardian Unlimited
fields.trailText:
Feminist, activist, optimist - as Lynne Segal takes up her prestigious new professorship, Dave Hill asks her what gender really means in the 21st century.
Extended interview with Lynne Segal for Guardian Unlimited
fields.body:
She is a red-haired, brown-eyed, witty and wise rebuke to those who parody "the feminists" as hard-faced agents of sexual prohibition or as shrieking harpies who eat testicles for tea. On Wednesday, Lynne Segal will give her inaugural lecture as professor of psychology and gender studies at Birkbeck College, University of London, the first in the discipline to take up such a post in one of British academia's most elite institutions.

Coincidentally, it will be almost exactly 30 years since she arrived in London from Sydney, a dissident scholar in her early 20s with a brilliant PhD, a boy baby in her arms and her life a total mess. "I felt so lost and confused, I almost didn't know my name," she says now.

It's been a lively three decades, if not always in the ways Segal would have wished. As an activist, writer and university teacher, she has spent them developing, sustaining and, latterly, defending the kind of feminism she says she was saved by. This begins with the feminism of the 70s Women's Liberation Movement: a feminism that was optimistic, imaginative and inclusive, that said no to sexism but yes to whatever sort of sexual pleasure a woman could find; that took issue with misogyny and male domination, but welcomed engagement with generous, thoughtful men; and that has brought a sometimes dazzling set of intellectual insights to bear on a mixed-up world.

For Segal, the crashing of feminism's "second wave" was not only desirable but inevitable: "It just had to come." The postwar contradictions that blighted women's lives were simply too absurd to be sustained - an insight first acquired through raw experience. Segal grew up in Australia in what she bluntly calls "the usual, unbelievably unhappy family of the 50s" in which her mother "cried herself to sleep every night". She says that in the manner of Jewish families like hers, all three children had to excel in education, but that unlike their older brother, she and her younger sister were encouraged to see futures in which nice, rich husbands would come first.

So, like her compatriot Germaine Greer, just a year or two her senior, Segal discovered revolt. At university, she studied psychology in order to understand people, but found that in those days "psychology meant understanding rats". So she took issue with the subject. Adapting a phrase of Wittgenstein's, her PhD was called Conceptual Confusions in Experimental Psychology ; it had to be sent to the US for marking because no one in Australia knew what to do with it.

Meanwhile, she had fallen in with a group called the Sydney Libertarians who set about "opposing the hypocrisies of those 50s lives: the incredible hypocrisies. That's how I became a progressive person, just trying to expose those vicious little secrets."

At that time she found feminists unnerving. "It was because I loved being the centre of male attention - until I accidentally got pregnant." Under pressure from her family, she spared them the shame of a bastard grandchild by wedding the prospective father. A less suitable husband would have been difficult to find. "It was clear by this time that he was homosexual - a homophobic homosexual. He said: 'If our son is homosexual, I'll shoot myself'."

It was her tormented spouse who finally drove Segal to buy a plane ticket to England. "If I left the house he would start ripping up my clothes and threaten to set fire to the building."

It is a biography worthy of being set to music and sung by Gloria Gaynor. Segal, though, has never been claimed by celebrity. She is a problem for the media because she is unable to provide them with convenient "gender clichés". Hacks and researchers call her on the phone, only to hang up disappointed. "When my book on masculinity came out (Slow Motion, Virago, 1990), they said, well, have men changed: yes or no? What are they talking about? My point is that men never stop changing, just as women never stop changing. And they say, give us the cliché, give us a straightforward polarisation between men and women. And I have to say, there aren't any!"

Segal looks on in frustration at a culture now obsessed with comforting notions of fixed sexual essences, with trying to identify crude oppositions between all women on the one hand, all men on the other. From one direction comes evolutionary psychology, feeding the media mania for genetic explanations, urging us once again that biology will always be destiny in the end.

It's time to thump the table: "As human beings, we are never in any way at the mercy of biology. We are always able to do with our biology what the cultural and social and personal resources available to us allow. Anybody, given the right resources, can be almost anything at all. But here comes Helena Cronin, and here comes Richard Dawkins saying, well, men fundamentally want to do this, and women fundamentally want to do that, and what we've learned - from the Palaeolithic age! - is that this is the way we will be happy. I mean, it could not be more stupid!"

From another direction, bearing the same conservative message, come those who positively live on gender clichés: Greer to shout that girls are much better than boys, Andrea Dworkin to demonise men, Camille Paglia to worship them. By absolute contrast, Segal poses a much better class of question: why begin with difference in the first place? Why be so preoccupied with mapping and defining things that barely exist? "The truth is, there's not that much difference between men and women. The point about being human is we're so adaptable and adjustable. Trying to tell us that there's some fixed way of being anything is always going to be more foolish than helpful."

There is another reason, though, why Segal has not become a star of the dreary old "sex war". It is that she has had better things to do. A conventional cv would say her 70s were spent teaching psychology - her kind of psychology ("They all thought I was nuts") - at what would eventually become Middlesex University but in those days was just plain Enfield Tech. Her greatest energies, though, went into grass roots politics in Islington, in women's centres, alternative newspapers, childcare facilities, socialist societies. "We tried to create a community, crossing as many lines of class, race and sex as we could. We were on the side of the dispossessed."

This grass roots socialist feminism achieved its greatest visibility when incorporated by Ken Livingstone into his Greater London Council in the early 80s. The establishment harrumphed, yet the crumbling of the left was already under way. In 1980, at the instigation of friend and ally Sheila Rowbotham, Segal had helped author Beyond the Fragments, a pamphlet arguing for broad alliances among trade unionists, feminists and left political groups. A subsequent conference drew an encouraging attendance, but the sectarian die was already cast, including within feminism. "From about 1976, if you went to a women's liberation conference, you'd have a pretty lousy time. You'd just become engaged in the fiercest rows, usually with separatist lesbians."

A desire to challenge the retreat of feminism into identity politics and defensive fundamentalism has informed much of Segal's more recent writing. Slow Motion was followed by Straight Sex (Virago, 1994) which defended the legitimacy of women seeking heterosexual pleasure, skilfully exposing the reactionary heart of the "radical" school of feminism, with its bleak insistence that heterosexual intercourse is, and only can be, the enactment of oppression. In these books she maintains the common threads of all her deeds and thinking: a refusal to believe that humankind is fixed by nature and an absolute conviction that we may still be authors of our own histories.

Her most recent, Why Feminism? (Polity Press), remakes the case for a dynamic feminism that rejects pessimism and becomes once again a "movement of transformation", able to liberate both sexes from the tyrannies of labour, of fear and, of course, gender. She looks at younger women struggling to Have It All, and the fears daily expressed for and about men and boys, and believes she just might have a few suggestions. It's a grim comment on the times that so few powerful people want to know.

We are always able to do with our biology what the cultural and social and personal resources available to us allow. Anybody, given the right resources, can be almost anything at all. But here comes Helena Cronin, and here comes Richard Dawkins saying, well, men fundamentally want to do this, and women fundamentally want to do that, and what we've learned - from the Palaeolithic age! - is that this is the way we will be happy. I mean, it could not be more stupid!" From another direction, bearing the same conservative message, come those who positively live on gender clichés: Greer to shout that girls are much better than boys, Andrea Dworkin to demonise men, Camille Paglia to worship them. By absolute contrast, Segal poses a much better class of question: why begin with difference in the first place? Why be so preoccupied with mapping and defining things that barely exist? "The truth is, there's not that much difference between men and women. The point about being human is we're so adaptable and adjustable. Trying to tell us that there's some fixed way of being anything is always going to be more foolish than helpful." There is another reason, though, why Segal has not become a star of the dreary old "sex war". It is that she has had better things to do. A conventional cv would say her 70s were spent teaching psychology - her kind of psychology ("They all thought I was nuts") - at what would eventually become Middlesex University but in those days was just plain Enfield Tech. Her greatest energies, though, went into grass roots politics in Islington, in women's centres, alternative newspapers, childcare facilities, socialist societies. "We tried to create a community, crossing as many lines of class, race and sex as we could. We were on the side of the dispossessed." This grass roots socialist feminism achieved its greatest visibility when incorporated by Ken Livingstone into his Greater London Council in the early 80s. The establishment harrumphed, yet the crumbling of the left was already under way. In 1980, at the instigation of friend and ally Sheila Rowbotham, Segal had helped author Beyond the Fragments, a pamphlet arguing for broad alliances among trade unionists, feminists and left political groups. A subsequent conference drew an encouraging attendance, but the sectarian die was already cast, including within feminism. "From about 1976, if you went to a women's liberation conference, you'd have a pretty lousy time. You'd just become engaged in the fiercest rows, usually with separatist lesbians." A desire to challenge the retreat of feminism into identity politics and defensive fundamentalism has informed much of Segal's more recent writing. Slow Motion was followed by Straight Sex (Virago, 1994) which defended the legitimacy of women seeking heterosexual pleasure, skilfully exposing the reactionary heart of the "radical" school of feminism, with its bleak insistence that heterosexual intercourse is, and only can be, the enactment of oppression. In these books she maintains the common threads of all her deeds and thinking: a refusal to believe that humankind is fixed by nature and an absolute conviction that we may still be authors of our own histories. Her most recent, Why Feminism? (Polity Press), remakes the case for a dynamic feminism that rejects pessimism and becomes once again a "movement of transformation", able to liberate both sexes from the tyrannies of labour, of fear and, of course, gender. She looks at younger women struggling to Have It All, and the fears daily expressed for and about men and boys, and believes she just might have a few suggestions. It's a grim comment on the times that so few powerful people want to know.

webTitle: Consultant contract 'open to abuse'

fields.headline: Consultant contract 'open to abuse'
fields.trailText: Opponents say some consultants manipulate their NHS position to maximise their private earnings, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
Opponents of the current consultants contract argue that it is open to abuse by consultants who wish to manipulate their NHS position to maximise their private earnings.

The most serious allegation is that some consultants ensure their NHS waiting list is as long as possible in order to more profitably market their private practice to patients who are prepared to pay for immediate treatment.

The House of Commons Health Select Committee investigated these allegations, and found that they were "not proven".

But it added: "What is indisputable is that NHS patients wait longer than private patients, and that private earnings are highest in those specialties where NHS waiting times are longest."

The British Medical Association (BMA) argued that long waiting lists are caused by shortages of staff, theatre capacity and beds, rather than as a result of private practice.

A second criticism is that consultants are so tempted by the financial rewards of private practice that they neglect their NHS contractual obligations.

A MORI poll carried out by the Doctors and Dentists Review Body in 1998 found that 5% of consultants - equivalent to 1,000 consultants nationally - were working less than 35 hours a week and therefore failing to meet contractual obligations.

The BMA questioned the poll and argued that only a small minority of consultants fail to carry out their contracted NHS work.

The health committee concluded: "It is not possible to ascertain the extent to which consultants are failing to meet their NHS obligations because of their private practice, because the information collected on consultants' workload is currently inadequate.

"In addition, we are not convinced that NHS trusts themselves have the information they need to be able to make this judgement about their consultants."

A third criticism of the consultant contract is that it is inequitable, and creates a two-tier service in which people able to pay for private treatment can jump the queue for treatment.

Professor John Yates has illustrated the practice by telling the story of "Keith", a patient requiring heart surgery.

He wrote: "Keith discovered that he required heart surgery. The surgeon explained that ideally the operation should be performed soon, but as his condition was not urgent he would have to wait about nine months.

"For a payment of about £10,000 the same surgeon would operate on him within two weeks in the same NHS hospital or in a private hospital in a neighbouring city."

webTitle: Week 2: New York to Washington

fields.headline: Skiing suggestions
fields.standfirst: Now enjoying the relative peace of Washington, Sam needs advice on a skiing trip to the Rockies
fields.trailText: I'm keen to do some skiing, so I'm heading for the Rockies. However, I'm having trouble deciding where to go, and even more trouble finding cheap accommodation. Anybody know the area or got any advice?
fields.body:
I'm in Washington DC now. New York was amazing. In the last couple of days I've seen the sun set on Manhattan from a ferry in the harbour; I've been to the top of the Empire State building at night; ridden in yellow cabs; walked round Greenwich Village and shopped on 5th Avenue. What made it extra special was that it snowed on my last day. Walking round Central Park in the snow with the skyscrapers all around me was fantastic.

I met up with some friends of a friend who live on the Upper East Side: Rachael, Stuart and their gorgeous baby Maisie. Considering they didn't know me from Adam they were really kind and showed me some of New York's nightlife (and let me stay in their apartment so I could escape the hostel and the champion snorer in the bunk next to mine!)

But after a few days I was pretty exhausted. New York is loud and frantic and runs at full pace 24 hours a day. I've got to admit I'm quite glad to have moved on to somewhere a bit more laid back.

I'll tell you a bit more about how I'm getting on in Washington later in the week, but now I've got a slight problem which I was hoping someone out there might be able to help me with. I'm keen to do some skiing, so in a few days I'm catching the train for a mammoth three-day journey up into the Rockies. I was booked into a hostel in Glenwood Springs, but I hear the ski area there is really small, and I'd be better off going to one of the bigger resorts in Colorado such as Breckonridge or Silverthorne. However, I'm having a bit of trouble deciding where to go, and even more trouble finding cheap accommodation. Anybody know the area or got any advice?

webTitle: Naughty at Nice : EU summiteers betray a lack of vision

fields.headline: Naughty at Nice : EU summiteers betray a lack of vision
fields.body:
The Nice summit of the European Union has presented a dismaying prospect to those who favour a stronger, more democratic enlarged community. At every stage of the prolonged negotiation, raw national interest has overshadowed the broader vision. This has been most fully demonstrated by the frequently inept manoeuvrings of the French presidency, whose job it is to promote the big picture. A series of drafts, deals and supposed compromises revealed, on closer scrutiny, the deep, primary attachment of President Jacques Chirac to his country's own agenda, his own political standing and, by remove, his own re-election prospects in 2002. But Mr Chirac was far from alone in failing to seize the European moment. Tony Blair, that self-proclaimed champion of enlargement, seemed for the most part preoccupied with his "red lines" on matters such as tax and social security harmonisation. This may save him from a more serious mauling by British Eurosceptics, in the short term at least, but it will do little to impress candidate nations such as Poland and the Czech republic that have pinned much hope on Britain. Only Germany's Gerhard Schroder appeared strong or disinterested enough to make a significant gesture towards "Europeanism" - by agreeing to France's intrinsically illogical but obsessive insistence on voting parity.

On all the main issues under discussion, the EU's leaders have defined themselves first and foremost as national politicians rather than European statesmen. The biggest row - over the reweighting of votes in the council of ministers - has seen largely irrational, essentially historic rivalries swamping the shared interest. Thus not only were France, Germany and Italy accused of trying to humiliate members with smaller populations but Portugal was to be heard complaining vociferously about unfair voting disparities with Spain. A similar spat erupted between Belgium and the Netherlands. The summiteers fudged plans to limit the size of the European Commission, dodged and dived around each others' veto sensibilities, and nearly failed their first real test of enhanced cooperation (on defence, after a last-minute row between Britain and France over the relationship of the EU's new rapid reaction force to Nato).

Mr Blair will probably be able to emerge from Nice claiming that British interests have been upheld. Apart from the RRF, for example, and British veto rights, the charter of rights was merely declared, as Britain had insisted, rather than bound in law. Nor were interchangeable Tory and tabloid predictions that the the prime minister would be "isolated" or "mugged" on the Riviera borne out. This will comfort those on the Labour side who most feared negative Nice fallout in an election year.

But there is scant solace to be found in this descent towards lowest common denominators for those who would see genuine reform. The agreement to hold yet another intergovernmental conference in 2004 will merely encourage cynics and be seen by east Europeans as another excuse for delaying expansion. The summit 's results are unlikely to do much for the still weak euro, either. For while Nice definitively demonstrates how far away Europe's nations are, in reality, from forming a superstate, Mr Blair's Warsaw ideal of a European superpower remains equally distant. Still, despite these many disappointments, Nice does look like producing some modest steps forward in joint policy and decision-making. And it has certainly opened up a vigorous debate that will not now be stilled.

webTitle: Chilean court drops Pinochet charges

fields.headline: Chilean court drops Pinochet charges
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The Santiago court of appeals today blocked the arrest of General Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
The Santiago court of appeals today blocked the arrest of General Augusto Pinochet.

Voting 3-0 in favour of the former dictator, the court agreed to drop homicide and kidnapping charges stemming from 189 criminal complaints relating to human rights abuses during his 1973-90 regime

"We won, we won," an exultant Pinochet lawyer, Sergio Castro, told reporters as he brandished three fingers to indicate the voting margin.

Carmen Hertz, an anti-Pinochet lawyer and the widow of a dissident killed during the dictator's regime, dismissed the court's decision as "a mere technicality."

"The court has only ruled that the indictment of Pinochet was improper because he was not questioned by a judge before it was issued," Hertz said. "But the ruling does not involve the essence of the case against him."

"We will now go to the supreme court," she added.

The arguments for the defense concentrated on their claim that Judge Juan Guzman acted illegally by indicting Pinochet before he had been questioned.

Pinochet was accused of responsibility for the "Caravan of Death," a military operation that executed political prisoners shortly after the 1973 coup in which he ousted Marxist president Salvador Allende.

Pinochet was charged with homicide for 55 victims whose bodies were recovered and kidnapping for 18 who remain missing.

A supreme court verdict, if the plaintiffs lodge their appeal, is expected as early as Thursday.

webTitle: Blunkett launches anti-bully guidelines

fields.headline: Blunkett launches anti-bully guidelines
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, will this week pledge to stamp out the culture of "ingrained thuggery" among youngsters as he launches tough anti-bullying guidelines for schools.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, will this week pledge to stamp out the culture of "ingrained thuggery" among youngsters as he launches tough anti-bullying guidelines for schools.

Mr Blunkett is determined that bullies responsible for tormenting an estimated one million victims each year are given an uncompromising message that bullying is unacceptable.

Two weeks after the murder of 10-year old Damilola Taylor - who had been the victim of bullying at school - Mr Blunkett said it was time to end the "no-blame" culture of the 90s.

In a move also designed to stem the growth of yobbish behaviour in schools, the government will launch a text book designed to encourage teen-agers to become "model citizens".

But teachers' leaders said it was unfair to expect schools to take responsibility for tackling bullying, claiming the problem stemmed from upbringing. They also warned that core subjects would have to be squeezed to accommodate the citizenship teaching.

Labour introduced rules in 1998 which for the first time required schools to have an anti-bullying policy. But new guidance will shortly be issued to all 25,000 state schools in England, incorporating a hard-hitting video for classroom use and an updated information pack. The video will feature the story of a girl who tried to commit suicide after being bullied, but survived, as well as the accounts of celebrities who were victims of bullying.

"We have to change the policy from the 90s, when there was too much of a no-blame culture," Mr Blunkett said. "Kids need to know that the school will support them if they are being bullied. The bullies have to know what is not acceptable. Otherwise they will push the boundaries out. We have to stamp out the worst elements of thuggery and bullying."

Mr Blunkett insisted the new measures had been drawn up before the death of the Damilola Taylor, who was stabbed in Peckham, south London. His mother claimed he was victimised by pupils at Oliver Goldsmith primary school in the short time he was there. Tensions between Afro-Caribbean and Asian pupils are known to be a problem at the school. Damilola's killers have not yet been caught.

But the tragedy has put the spotlight back on bullying. A recent high court ruling said, significantly, that although schools and local education authorities had a legal duty to prevent bullying on school premises, they could not be held accountable for incidents beyond the buildings.

Mr Blunkett, who will launch the guidance at an anti-bullying conference on Wednesday, said it would focus on good practice. He hopes that schools will swap ideas and learn from others who have successfully combated bullying, while giving victims support. Victims of bullying, for example, often stay away from school out of fear and are then labelled truants.

The citizenship textbook has been written by American educationalist Francine Britton and makes extensive use of new-age jargon. The book ex plores role-playing games to help teenagers get to grips with "spiritual, moral, social and cultural" issues. Among the book's suggestions are that pupils form a circle, each telling the youngster to the left, "I'm glad you're here".

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, said: "This is a load of theoretical rubbish which won't last a minute in the classroom. What are teachers supposed to leave out in order to include this kind of material?"

Impressed by evidence that "learning mentors" in schools under the Excellence in Cities programme, for example, are helping to tackle the problem through mediation, Mr Blunkett is planning to expand the number of mentors - who are hired to back teachers by helping children overcome learning barriers - from 800 to nearly 2,500 by the end of the year.

webTitle: OFT invites comment on Express deal

fields.headline: OFT invites comment on Express deal
fields.trailText:
The Office of Fair Trading is inviting comment on the takeover of the Express newspapers by OK! tycoon Richard Desmond, writes Dan Milmo.
Express takeover: news round-up
fields.body:
The Office of Fair Trading is inviting comment on the takeover of the Express newspapers by OK! tycoon Richard Desmond.

The OFT has set a deadline of December 27 for written representations, in what a spokesman described as a "routine" procedure to decide if the deal broke competition laws.

Mr Desmond bought the titles from United News & Media in a surprise £125m deal that stunned the other bidders, including the Daily Mail & General Trust and the Hinduja brothers.

Lord Hollick, chief executive of United, chose Mr Desmond because his lack of newspaper interests guaranteed a quick deal.

Because Mr Desmond managed to avoid these regulations, it is very unlikely he will be brought to book by competition laws.

The deal provoked a furious reaction from rival suitors, with the Hinduja brothers accusing Lord Hollick of treating them like "a stalking horse" for Mr Desmond's bid.

The billionaire family said they were willing to pay £140m for the titles.

webTitle: Interview: Zadie Smith

fields.headline: White knuckle ride
fields.standfirst: It has been an extraordinary year for Zadie Smith. Last Christmas she was an unknown 24-year-old living in Willesden. Then her novel, White Teeth, was published to great acclaim, and the spotlight has been on her ever since. So how has the winner of last week's Guardian first book award been affected by her fame? Simon Hattenstone found out
fields.trailText: How has Zadie Smith, the winner of last week's Guardian first book award been affected by her fame?
fields.body:
It can't be easy being Zadie Smith. She has become so much more famous than her celebrated first novel because she had the fortune, or misfortune, to be the perfect demographic. Young, attractive, black, female - and very talented. She is everything the media hankers after, the ideal head and shoulders to parade on a newspaper's masthead. Perhaps inevitably, she is also the object of huge envy. Before meeting her, so many people - mainly women - tell me they've heard she's bitchy, supercilious, smug, cold, a fake, you name it.

Smith, now 25, has just won the Guardian's first book prize for White Teeth. Earlier this year she hogged the headlines for failing to win the Orange prize. And she also grabbed her share of the news when she didn't make the Booker shortlist - black, bookish babe fails to win prize, accompanied by a swanky picture.

I don't recognise Smith when we meet. The big specs and Afro have disappeared. She looked lovely on the cover of White Teeth - not a face you could forget. Today, she's all long straight hair and lip gloss, and looks like any number of drained All Saints waltzing around clubland.

She rushes us to the bar at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, orders cranberry juice, no, make that a coffee, and bounds off up staircase after staircase looking for somewhere nice and quiet. She's talking all the time, fast and furious - about life as writer in residence at the ICA, judging an art competition, how all artists today just produce huts and tell you that's art, and how, if she's honest, she doesn't have a clue whether a hut is art, but what an honour, what joy, to be in such a privileged position.

Eventually we find an office to squat in. Right at the top. Smith looks down over London - the Eye, the Thames, parliament, Westminster - queen of all she surveys. "Amazing isn't it? The best possible view of London." She burns with zest, with life.

Then I turn on the tape recorder. Suddenly the Zadie Smith in front of me is morose, self-conscious, resentful. She stumbles over her words. "Oh Gawwwwwd! I'm so bad at interviews." She picks up a Rizla paper and rolls a fag, says that most writers are useless speakers, and that's why they write. "I have nothing to say." So we talk about her new hair.

Smith is worrying away at her momentary incoherence. What she hates about talking, she says, is the way she can't edit herself. She's very precious about words. "There's this great quote by Nabokov. 'He wrote like a genius, he thought like a man of letters and he spoke like a child' . . . it's a bloody good quote, and I think it's true of some very, very great writers. I'm always a bit suspicious of writers who have the gift of the gab." She immediately qualifies herself - not that she's a great writer.

Smith has spent much of the past year travelling with her book, being feted. Yes, it's been amazing, she says, but terrifying, and she reaches for another reference. "In Amis's book, I think this is a quote from McEwan, 'Going on a book tour is like being the blue-collar employee of your former self'." When Smith quotes authors, as she often does, it tends to be them talking about the writer as personality rather than the writing; the image rather than the product.

Suddenly, the girl who sat alone in her bedroom for two years writing a book was exposed to the glare of the publicity machine. Suddenly, she was expected to be more than a novelist - a spokesperson for race, youth, women. She didn't know what to do, so she talked. "I was expected to be some expert on multicultural affairs, as if multiculturalism is a genre of fiction or something, whereas it's just a fact of life - like there are people of different races on the planet. I give my opinion, then you get 50 phone calls saying, 'Well, I don't think Ms Smith has the right to give an opinion on something she knows nothing about'." She laughs, but it was obviously bewildering, dizzying.

She tells me about the time she went to do a photo shoot for a magazine and found herself lost in a sprawl of make-up artists, dressers and little Prada dresses that could never have fitted her. "I wouldn't mind it if I saw five-hour photo shoots for Martin Amis, but that doesn't happen. If you're a woman it's as if they want to reduce everything to the same denominator." Which is? "That you must present yourself as an attractive woman even if you're a rocket scientist. It's total arse isn't it?"

White Teeth is a rich, sprawling domestic epic, about how families and people come together and fall apart in the most unlikely ways. It's also very much a book about modern London, a city in which 40% of children are born to at least one black parent, a city in which the terms black and white become less and less relevant as we gradually meld into different shades of brown. White Teeth reflects a new generation for whom race is the backdrop to daily life rather than the defining characteristic of existence. Some people have said Smith is depoliticising race, removing it from its historical context, others say she's ahead of her time, representing modern London as it really is for the first time.

Smith has been compared with Salman Rushdie. She says it may be well intended, definitely a compliment, but racist nonsense none the less. She yawns. "I think I have brown people in my book, and so does Salman, and so does Hanif Kureishi. So it's a genre, don't you see that?" Stereotypes, more bloody nonsense - she's often described as having come from a humble background. What do they mean? "I went to a comprehensive school, got into Cambridge. I may have been working class once, I think once you live in a nice flat in a nice area and you've had a great education, you're really pushing it, to continue to claim to be salt of the earth. Life changes, my family is a picture of change." White Teeth is also a picture of such social fluidity.

"I don't intend to be a spokesman for anything or anybody apart from . . . " She cuts herself off. "My work isn't a statement, they're novels and funny novels, and hopefully . . . yeh, brilliant sentence, Zadie, thank you very much !" And she gives up.

"I was 21 when I wrote White Teeth, what difference does it make what I think?" She's conscious of her youth, still monitors every event by how old she was at the time. "I'm not a rentaquote." The trouble is that even when she's rebutting the notion of being a spokesperson ("a white male writer is never asked to be a spokesman for anything; he has complete artistic freedom"), she ends up giving good quote, and keeps the publicity wheel rolling.

It's too easy to reduce Smith to a victim of fame. She seems to have spent much of her life preparing for celebrity. She was five or six when she started writing poems and stories. A few years later she was writing pastiches of Agatha Christie. Her photographer dad and psychotherapist mum sent her to the local comprehensive in Willesden. Was she swotty? "Was I swotty? Yes, I was very swotty," she echoes in her deep singsong voice. At 14, Sadie changed her name to Zadie - it seemed right, exotic, different, while still true to herself. She always knew that there was more to a person than body and soul. There was image.

She spent much of her childhood watching Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers and the great old movie musicals and saying to herself, "One day that's going to be me". Eventually she realised she was fooling herself. She probably wouldn't make the grade, and anyway she was a child out of time - they had stopped making those movies decades ago. So she decided on Cambridge University. "I wanted to be an academic, and all the writers I loved went there."

She seems to have mapped out her future rigorously. At 18, she was reading up about the working methods of her favourite authors. "The worst thing is to be terrorised by the way other people write, if you hear that so and so wakes up at eight in the morning, walks the dog for two hours, then stands his head, then writes 15,000 words, you think, like, shit, why don't I do that, but I've stopped thinking that way." At Cambridge she received a £250,000 advance for two novels.

Smith says she sees naked ambition all around her, and it terrifies her. But she must have been ambitious? "I have an ambition to write a great book, but that's really a competition with myself. I've noticed that a lot of young writers, people in all media, want to be famous but they don't really want to do anything. I can't think of anything less worth striving for than fame."

Smith can be coruscating about her work. She wrote a review of White Teeth in which she damned the book as the work of a precocious poser. But there are still moments, reading aloud, when she bursts out laughing. "There's one sentence somewhere near the beginning, it's something like 'Kelvin smiled, colon or semi colon, a sudden gash across his face that came and went with the violence of a fat man walking through swing doors.'" Her eyes smile with pleasure. "I liked that, and I thought no one else could have written that sentence, and it's not true of many sentences in that book."

She may be ambivalent about what she has written so far, but she seems to have supreme confidence about what she will go on to write. Has she got a great book in her? "If you didn't believe that you did, at some point, even if it's when I'm 60, then why would you do it?"

I say that people can write for lots of reasons - to make money, to communicate, to express themselves, to unburden themselves. She looks at me with something approaching contempt. "I express myself with my friends and my family. In my diary if I had one, that's expressing yourself. Novels are not about expressing yourself, they're about something beautiful, funny, clever and organic. Self-expression ? Go and ring a bell in a yard if you want to express yourself." She can be wonderfully haughty. But I don't believe that she believes what she's just said. I bet she'll hate it if she reads it. You sense that she's so used to thinking on her feet, always having a sharp answer, that this is the first thing that came into her head.

Smith is part way through her second novel, which is about an obsessive autograph hunter, but has written hardly any fiction this year. She's not had time. She says how worried she is about not having written for so long, and suddenly she seems to be talking herself through a therapy session. "I've been so terrified you know because White Teeth is such a naive book. I didn't have any expectations of it, didn't worry about the critics, I just wrote, and it was happy, lalalalala, and then there was a book, and that's not going to be true anymore. So the question is am I going to write some horrible difficult second novel that everybody hates? I hope not. But the stuff I'm reading at the moment, and some of the other writers I've been lucky enough to talk to, and get advice from, I know I'm OK . . . I can't show you any proof, but I just kind of feel it."

As we wind up, she returns to something we talked about earlier, something bothering her. I'd said people had told me she was a bighead. "I'm one of those people who find it impossible to ignore what people think of me, I find it really really depressing. I hate to be not liked, I hate that . . . I don't know . . I think all writers are pretty bloody vain one way or another."

Does she think she's been too successful? "By a long way." Why? "If you love a young writer, maybe the best thing you can do is give them a little bit of space."

Zadie Smith is a precious talent, one that needs nurturing, perhaps even cocooning. In the new year she's going to lock herself away for five months and write.

I ask about the new hair. She says it's just hair extensions, that her Afro's expanding underneath, and next week it's back to normal. And the specs? She smashed them, and is waiting for a new pair. The makeover seems to be a passing phase.

webTitle: Bulmer insures against United's success

fields.headline: Bulmer insures against United's success
fields.trailText: Cider maker HP Bulmer has taken out insurance against its sponsor, soccer club Leeds United, being too successful, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Cider maker HP Bulmer has taken out insurance against Leeds United being too successful on the pitch.

The drinks company, which sponsors the football team, has made the move to protect it against paying out heavy bonuses in the case of a series of trophy wins.

At the start of the season Bulmer signed a £5m, three-season deal to sponsor the club, splashing its Strongbow cider brand on the players' shirts.

However, as part of the deal Bulmer is liable to pay Leeds win bonuses of around £700,000 a year. It took out an insurance policy to cover any extra payments.

The move now looks enlightened as Leeds last week continued their lucrative run in the Champions League with a win ovre Italian champions Lazio.

At Bulmer's interim results today, chief executive Mike Hughes told a news briefing that Bulmer had taken out a policy with an annual premium of £80,000 to insure against Leeds' success.

He said this was proving a success as Bulmer would have been currently £300,000 "out of pocket".

Bulmer is also insured against Leeds doing better than expected in the Premier League and the FA Cup.

webTitle: Arthur Andersen hires Bowman

fields.headline: Arthur Andersen swoops for KPMG's Bowman
fields.trailText: Arthur Andersen has poached Eddie Bowman from KPMG to head up its marketing department, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Arthur Andersen has poached Eddie Bowman, head of the global marketing communications group at KPMG, to head up its marketing department.

Mr Bowman joins the consultancy as UK director of marketing and communications, and will be responsible for marketing strategy in the UK.

He will head up the Arthur Andersen's 85-strong UK marketing team, replacing Colin Bayley, who left to head up the marketing department at rivals Stephenson Harwood.

Before joining KPMG Mr Bowman spent 14 years with the ad agency Ogilvy & Mather, where he rose to become head of client services.

Eric Hagman, senior partner at Arthur Andersen, said: "Eddie's experience in devising marketing strategy in the new economy and expertise in brand management are exactly the right skills and background for the role."

webTitle: Inquiry into 'racist' unlawful arrests

fields.headline: Inquiry into 'racist' unlawful arrests
fields.standfirst:
Senior officers find couple have been subject of 93 intelligence reports

Special report: policing crime
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Senior officers find couple have been subject of 93 intelligence reports
fields.body:
Details of an inquiry into police behaviour towards a black north London couple Sonia and Delroy Lindo have revealed a devastating catalogue of unlawful arrests, racist attitudes and shortfalls in Crown Prosecution Service procedures.

Since 1996 Delroy Lindo has been charged 17 times and cleared 17 times of a series of offences including assaults on police officers and public order offences. His wife Sonia has been charged and cleared of two offences.

The internal inquiry, which is unprecedented, was set up in July by the newly-formed Metropolitan Police Authority after concerns raised about police behaviour towards the Lindos by Lee Jasper, equality and policing adviser to Ken Livingstone at the Greater London Assembly. The inquiry has been conducted by senior Metropolitan police officers.

The couple have been the subject of 93 separate intelligence reports by the Metropolitan police although they are not prominent suspects for anything at all.

Perhaps most serious of all is the finding that not just the Metropolitan police but the Crown Prosecution Service and the courts along with the Police Complaints Authority have failed to behave properly towards the Lindos.

A Metropolitan police spokesman said that the report was an attempt at "organisational planning" and did not have the status to discipline individual officers if concerns were raised about them in the inquiry. webTitle: 'I was charged with assault to a police shirt'

fields.headline: 'I was charged with assault to a police shirt'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Sonia and Delroy Lindo stand in the foyer of Hornsey police station, north London. They are making a complaint about police behaviour and they are weary. The process takes so long, usually about three hours, and in their case because it happens so often.
fields.body:
Sonia and Delroy Lindo stand in the foyer of Hornsey police station, north London. They are making a complaint about police behaviour and they are weary. The process takes so long, usually about three hours, and in their case because it happens so often.

Sometimes they feel as if most of their lives over the last few years have been spent in a police station, either making a complaint or languishing in a cell after being arrested on spurious grounds.

Delroy has been the main target with 37 stop and searches since 1992, plus countless unofficial stops and 17 criminal charges, many for public order offences and assault on officers, all of which he has been cleared of in court.

It is because of the discrepancy between the amount of police attention lavished on the Lindos and the lack of crimes committed that an unprecedented inquiry was launched into their case in July - just two days after the Metropolitan police authority was launched and five days after an arrest too far for Mr Lindo when he was detained in a cell for five hours for allegedly sucking his teeth at an officer.

The inquiry is the first to be held by the new authority. A team of 18 officers are investigating every scrap of police interaction with the Lindos over eight years.

While the experience of unwarranted attentions from the police is one with which many law-abiding black people can identify, the Lindos believe that there is an extra reason why they have been targeted. They are close friends of Winston Silcott, who was convicted of the murder of PC Keith Blakelock during the Broadwater Farm riots in Tottenham in 1985.

Delroy and Winston Silcott had grown up together, went on to run a business, and Silcott was the best man at Delroy and Sonia's wedding. When Silcott was convicted of PC Blakelock's murder, Delroy was determined to prove him innocent, a campaign that succeeded when Silcott's conviction was overturned. Silcott is still serving a life sentence for the murder of Anthony Smith, whom he calims he stabbed in self-defence after Smith and two other armed men attacked him.

Both Silcott and Lindo were known to the police for two reasons. They had a couple of convictions to their name - though it is almost 20 years since Lindo was convicted - and both were vocal campaigners against police harassment.

Following Silcott's arrest the police started to harass Lindo, first arresting him in a jobcentre and then trying to break the door of his house down. "The police just kept saying to me, 'We're going to get you like we got Winston'."

The inquiry report finds no evidence of a conspiracy against Delroy because of the Silcott connection but does flag up concerns about the fact that four officers who stopped Delroy were based at the Broadwater Farm Estate and one was in attendance on the night when PC Blakelock was murdered. That officer was one of the officers who unlawfully arrested Mr Lindo and is facing disciplinary procedures.

For Delroy and Sonia their dealings with the police blur into a single nightmare but the most gruesome events remain emblazoned in ghoulish technicolour. One of the unlawful arrests relates to an incident in 1997 when police were half-way up a ladder rescuing an elderly woman who had fallen and was trapped on the first floor of her home. An officer glimpsed Delroy driving past and flagged him down. Delroy was dragged out of the car and says he was beaten up.

"We had just returned from a funeral. I had one officer on my back with his hand round my neck and I could feel myself suffocating. Passers by had gathered to watch. At that point they released their hold on me. I was badly injured and have the pictures to prove it. I was charged with assault to a police shirt!"

Not only has Delroy Lindo had to face down dubious charge after dubious charge, he has also had to stand in the dock as his character has been assassinated. At his last court appearance, when he was again charged with assaulting police officers, Pc Michael Aldridge described Lindo as the "most violent man I have encountered in 11 years of policing". The evidence was refuted in the same witness box not only by the defence but also by Pc Martin Lycett, who admitted that Delroy had been calm and peaceable when arrested.

Sonia and Delroy have provided each other with extraordinary support. "We work as a team," says Sonia. "Yes, when I am too tired to take things any further Sonia takes over and I do the same for her," he says"

Delroy was unable to continue his job as a housing manager as defending himself against the police onslaught became his more than full-time job.

Sonia has had to take sick leave from her job as a housing manager because of the stress. She breaks down when she talks about how the harassment has affected their three children, how they have begun acting out the police attacks in their games.

"But hatred isn't the way forward," says Delroy. "We have to sit down with the police. We can't get change unless we're willing to sit down and talk. It's a hard decision to make to take on the police, because it means you have no life left. All I dream of is to have a normal life. It was my birthday yesterday but we haven't celebrated that for four years."

webTitle: Wnston Silcott in jail for life

fields.headline: 'We looked out for each other. That's what you do when you're black ...'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Winston Silcott, in jail since 1985, still claims he's innocent
fields.body:
It is the tail end of visiting time at Stocken Prison, in Leicestershire, and we sit on gaudy plastic chairs while fathers on the surrounding tables cuddle their partners and children for one last time with an air of quiet desperation.

Winston Silcott's family have not come to visit today but Sonia and Delroy Lindo are just as close as family.

We have been assigned a table closest to the prison officers who keep a suspicious eye on our group.

With his ever lengthening beard wrapped up neatly in a cotton bundle and positioned to one side of his chin, Winston looks different to the other prisoners.

The beard, he says, will stay until he is freed from a sentence he says he should not be serving. He was convicted of the murder of PC Keith Blakelock during the Broadwater Farm riots, in north London, in 1985. His conviction was overturned, but he is serving a life sentence for the murder of Anthony Smith.

Silcott claims Smith was armed with a knife and that he and two other armed men attacked him. Silcott says he stabbed Smith in self-defence. His parole is due in a couple of months but Silcott is pessimistic because he refuses to admit he murdered Smith.

"I was defending my life as anyone else would do in those circumstances."

Silcott hopes that as a result of the inquiry into the treatment of the Lindos that those who have acted in a racist and unlawful manner will be punished.

He, Delroy and Sonia have known each other since they were children. "Our friendship has always been 150%," he says. "Delroy and I lived round the corner from each other and went to school together. We always looked out for each other because that's what you have to do when you're black in England."

webTitle: Blair defends Nice deal in parliament

fields.headline: Blair defends Nice deal in parliament
fields.trailText: A confident Tony Blair used a Commons statement this afternoon to defend his decision to surrender some veto powers in Europe during the recent Nice summit.
fields.body:
A confident Tony Blair used a Commons statement this afternoon to defend his decision to surrender some veto powers in Europe during the recent Nice summit.

Arguing that the Nice agreement will produce a "more rational way of decision making" within the EU, the prime minister fended off attacks from William Hague.

The Tory leader argued that the government had signed up to "three more major steps to a European superstate" and pledged that an incoming Conservative government would not ratify the treaty as it stood.

He challenged Mr Blair to hold a referendum on the question of ratification.

Mr Hague said that Mr Blair had "signed away" Britain's veto in 23 areas, giving European institutions an opportunity to impose further integration against Britain's will.

Responding, the prime minister mocked the opposition for a stance which would endanger enlargement of the EU, describing Mr Hague's proposal as "full rounded idiocy".

webTitle: Sol the Turncoat,  Erik the Chef, and  John-Paul the Pope

fields.headline: Sol the Turncoat,  Erik the Chef, and  John-Paul the Pope
fields.trailText: CAMP-BALLS
fields.body:
CAMP-BALLS

The Fiver was shocked - nay, stunned - to read reports which suggested top Premiership defender Sol Campbell may join Arsenal after his contract with arch-rivals Tottenham Hotspur runs out this summer. Why, if that happens, we thought, it'll cause the biggest media scrum in north London since Crouch End resident Neil Morrissey accidentally left his Homebase discount card round Les Dennis's house.

Campbell, who will not discuss a new contract with Arsenal's George Graham, the boss of Tottenham, had been expected to defect to Manchester United. But with Alex Ferguson's interest cooling - he is said to be happy with the defenders he has - Arsenal have been installed as the new favourites for Sol's signature. They would certainly prefer a free Campbell to £20m Bayer Leverkusen defender Jens Nowotny, and Arsene Wenger has already stated that the big Spurs man is "the only ready-made young centre-half capable of stepping into Tony Adams's boots".

Although Campbell could sign for a foreign club on New Year's Day, it is thought he wants to stay in dear old Blighty. And as he's desperate for honours, a controversial move to the Arse isn't as far out as it may seem. Predictably, these rumours have seen ye olde north London turncoats Terry Neill and Pat Jennings crawl from the woodwork to give Sol the benefit of their advice. Using phrases like "immense problems", "big challenge" and "intense". And not much else.

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 11: Click here

HISTORY REPEATS ITSELF

When the Fiver heard that Liverpool had sold one of their strikers, a thousand thoughts rushed through our minds. Well, three. Had Titi Camara finally stormed out to join Celtic? Perhaps Robbie Fowler has moved to a wealthy club in west London for £15m. Or maybe Nick Barmby has joined Manchester United just to get on everyone's tit end. So imagine our relief when we ascertained the truth: big Dutch galoot Erik Meijer has joined Hamburg on a free transfer.

Mad Erik's unexpected move came after a weekend of secret talks. Meijer had been preparing to clump around Deepdale in a Preston shirt against Burnley, but he pulled out at the last minute to discuss terms with the interested Bundesliga club instead. The offer of top-flight first-team football was too much for the former Dutch international (one cap) to turn down, and he was soon on his way.

The man who scored 0 Premiership goals is no stranger to football in Germany, having spent four finger-lickin' years at KFC Uerdingen and Bayer Leverkusen, so he knows his history. "Hamburg is a club which has a connection with Liverpool," explained Erik, perhaps wisely avoiding the one about clubs that have won Big Cup but won't be winning it again too soon. "Some curly-headed guy, who also played for England, played for them!" he smiled. "I think his name was..." Well, thanks very much, Erik, we'd only just managed to forget about that badger-haired buffoon.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I think now what I did in my four years in charge of Sheffield Wednesday is gaining more recognition by the day or by the year. I think it is fair to say that my credibility has risen since I left Wednesday!" - We wouldn't bet on it, Trevor Francis.

THE PONTIFF AND A TIFF

At the Vatican today, his supreme holiness Pope John Paul II spoke to the sinners, and the corrupters, and those who have taken bribes. And he urged Fifa officials to use their "immense power" to promote "the good of the human family. As a sport shared by people of different ethnic, racial, economic and social backgrounds," the pontiff explained without once keeling over, "football is an excellent means of promoting solidarity." And Sepp Blatter and co nodded their heads piously, for they had heard the word, and the word was God. And good.

Meanwhile outside, Diego Maradona and Edson Arantes do Nascimento (or Pele to Mrs Pele) continued their spat ahead of tonight's Fifa of the Century of the Award. Today it was the turn of Pele - the man who once claimed that "boys and girls confined to wheelchairs start walking again after I visit them in hospitals" - to have a pop back at the septum-damaged one, claiming modestly: "As early as 1958 I was awarded the title 'O Rey' (The King) and that's enough for me."

But with Argentinian sports paper Ole claiming that "Pele and all of Brazil are crying because Maradona has won the election", and Brazil threatening to nuke the Argies (OK, we made that bit up), it was clear that something needed to be done to avert a minor border skirmish. So hats off to Fifa chief Sepp Blatter, who after listening to the Pope's wise words, has found an ingenious solution to the problem. At the gala ceremony tonight there will be two winners - one voted for by ordinary plebs on Fifa's website, and one decided by Fifa officials. Brilliant, eh? Which means all egos will be satisfied, Argentina and Brazil won't go to war, and the great wheel of capitalism will keep on rolling. And the Fiver says a loud "Amen" to that.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea's Marcel Desailly has been linked with a £15m move to Paris St Germain.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is prepared to offload England midfielder Kieron Dyer to Leeds, but only if David O'Leary gives him £10m.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Alan Curbishley has asked the FA to give him clarification over what role they want him to play in the new England set-up. Rumours persist that Sven-Goran Eriksson wants Curbishley as a coach, but the Charlton manager explained: "The position has not been sorted out. I need to sit down with the FA and this looks like a good week to do that. I must find out exactly what they want from me."

Proposals to expand Euro-Vase into a four-team mini league will be discussed by Uefa later this week. The plan would lead to most Premiership games being played on Sundays.

Manchester United are likely to award Teddy Sheringham and Denis Irwin one-year contract extensions.

Arsene Wenger has given Dennis Bergkamp until February to sign a new contract.

Hibs' final match in front of the old Easter Road main stand against Dundee on January 2 will be an all-ticket affair.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (11.30pm)
All the goals from all the games you've already seen.

Football Extra (12.35am)
All the goals from all the games you've already seen, if you've watched Sky's Football League Review.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (3.25am)
Last week Roda JC played PSV Eindhoven. Eight days later, Channel 5 stumble onto the case. Poor show. Yellow card to Channel 5!

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11.30pm SS3)
Three repeats in one day? Yellow card to Sky!

World Football Show (7.30pm)
Yellow card!

You're on Sky Sports (10pm)
You're off!

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11.30pm)
Who needs ten Temazepam when Bore-o-Mooro is droning on?

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10.15pm)
Can Cailungo close the gap on Folgore at the top of the San Marino first division? No, we don't care either.

webTitle: Unions plan strike at Hackney over cuts in working conditions

fields.headline: Unions plan strike at Hackney over cuts in working conditions
fields.trailText: The London borough of Hackney is set for a series of crippling strikes as staff fight back against budget cuts designed to balance the ailing council's books.
fields.body:
The London borough of Hackney is set for a series of crippling strikes as staff fight back against budget cuts designed to balance the ailing council's books.

Members of the Unison, GMB and Transport and General Workers (TGWU) unions today voted to take industrial action, beginning with a walkout on 20th December.

They believe they can effectively shut the council down, and claim they can bring the entire workforce out on strike.

Hackney currently faces a deficit that the Audit Commission believes could reach £40m by the end of the financial year.

In an attempt to cut costs by £4.5m by March, the borough last month announced plans to scrap around 250 positions, with only statutory minimum severance payments. The borough says compulsory redundancies will not be this high, because some staff will relocate within the council.

The unions want to persuade the council not to cut the payments, to drop plans for compulsory redundancies, and to maintain current terms and conditions, which the borough plans to review as part of the savings package.

TGWU organiser Paul Fawcett said: "None of us want to see strikes happen. We know about the mess they're in, but you've got to look at who's to blame, and it isn't the workforce."

Hackney's recent best value inspection report pushed the borough to seek staff and budget cuts, calling on the council to "reduce its direct service management workload and the size of its workforce accordingly".

webTitle: Governor of Bank of England welcomes signs of US slowdown

fields.headline: Sir Eddie welcomes signs of US slowdown
fields.trailText: Governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, yesterday welcomed signs that the US economy was slowing and warned against exaggerating the risks of a US recession.
fields.body:
Governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, yesterday welcomed signs that the US economy was slowing and warned against exaggerating the risks of a US recession.

In an interview on BBC Breakfast with Frost, Sir Eddie pronounced the British economy to be in "very good shape", adding that a rise in the value of the euro would be "helpful".

The governor said that, given the single currency's weakness, it would have been unwise to lock in the pound at recent exchange rates. A strengthening of the euro would allow the five economic tests laid down by the chancellor to be applied, he said, but refused to be drawn on whether Britain would join the single currency.

"That's a political decision and not one for me," he said.

The governor said the biggest question for the international economy was what was happening in the US.

"If [the US economy] hadn't begun to slow down, I think we would be looking at a bigger problem. As inflationary pressures built up, we would be looking at a bigger problem further down the track, so it's a good thing the US economy is slowing down."

Echoing comments from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan last week, Sir Eddie said he was not concerned at present that the slowdown was "excessive", but accepted that a careful watch would have to be kept on emerging economic data.

But he warned against over reaction. "Central bankers always look at the risks and I think the risk of the economy growing too strongly was greater three, six months ago and now people have seen the change and there's a great tendency you know to exaggerate this thing and to move from the need for slowdown to downturn to recession to meltdown. I mean that happens very quickly, I think."

Sir Eddie said that Britain had enjoyed a long period of steady growth, with unemployment as low as it had been for a quarter of a century and the expectation that progress would be maintained for the next couple of years.

"The problem has been imbalance with some sectors doing very well and other sectors under pressure," he said.

The euro's weakness has often added to this pressure and Sir Eddie said there was little that could be done. "We either continue to direct ourselves at the overall macroeconomic situation or we try to shelter some of the adversely affected sectors by paying more attention to the exchange rate than we already do in which case we could put at risk the stability in the economy as well."

webTitle: December 8-10 ratings

fields.headline: Coronation Street's 40th boosts ITV viewing figures
fields.trailText: 4.15pm TV overnights: ITV enjoyed bumper ratings as Coronation Street's 40th anniversary pulled in nearly 16m viewers, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The live Coronation Street 40th anniversary special proved more popular than the repeat of the soap's first ever episode on Friday night, but the real winner was ITV, which enjoyed another bumper ratings haul.

The 60-minute live soap special, which featured a walk-on from Prince Charles as well as Ken Barlow leading the fight to save the street's cobbles from being replaced by Tarmac, averaged a whopping 15.6m - over 60% of the available audience - from 8pm last night.

Earlier in the evening, the first ever episode of Coronation Street - repeated in all its black-and-white glory - attracted plenty of interest from 21st century viewers, pulling in 10.4m and a 48% share.

Overall, ITV had 43% of the peak-time audience (6pm-10.30pm) on Friday night, up from 37.5% the previous week. BBC1 was down by 2.7 percentage points week on week, to 24.9%.

BBC1 shows suffering from the Corrie effect were a Ground Force repeat, battered down to just 3.5m from 8pm, and Castaway Diaries, which averaged only 3m - and a 12% share - from 8.30pm.

On Sunday night, BBC1's Sports Personality of the Year pulled in a steady 7.2m and 28% audience share over nearly two-and-a-half hours from 7pm.

But it only outrated ITV for one quarter-hour segment from 9pm-9.15pm, when 9.8m tuned in to see the climax of the show as five times Olympic gold medal winner Steve Redgrave collected the Sports Personality of the Year award.

The previous evening The Record of the Year, ITV's Denise Van Outen-presented boy and girl band-fest, had 6.9m and a 31% of viewing from 7.50pm-9pm.

The main instalment of the ITV pop showcase lost out to BBC1's Casualty, which averaged 8.9m and a 39% share from 8.10pm-9pm.

But later in the evening, The Record of the Year - Result show averaged 9m and a 42% share from 10pm-10.30pm.

There was little to choose between the BBC2 and Channel 4 theme nights - on David Frost and Madonna, respectively - in the popularity stakes on Saturday night.

The highest rating segment of BBC2's Frost Night, a repeat showing of one of the legendary TV interviewer and satirist's favourite films, Funeral in Berlin, averaged 2.2m from 8.55pm-10.35pm.

The biggest audience for Channel 4's Madonna Night came from 9pm, when documentary Who's That Girl attracted 2m viewers.

webTitle: Big Brother's Melanie to front Chained on E4

fields.headline: Big Brother's Melanie to front E4's Chained
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Big Brother star Melanie Hill is to front Chained, the first reality show on Channel 4's digital entertainment channel, E4. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Big Brother star Melanie Hill is to front Chained, the first reality show on Channel 4's new digital entertainment channel, E4.

Ms Hill, who gained notoriety in Channel 4's hugely popular Big Brother after snogging two male contestants, will present the new show, which will air from March 2001.

Chained will feature six contestants chained together day and night.

One contestant will be selected as the "picker", choosing which contestant they want to remove from the mix until they are left with their ideal date.

The series is already being filmed, but when screened will face criticism as one of the most voyeuristic shows on TV yet. Unlike Big Brother, there is no respite for any of the contestants from their peers.

E4, which will launch in January, is the second of Channel 4's digital channels and is pitched as a competitor against Sky's Sky One.

It will feature popular comedy and drama such as Friends and ER, as well as new commissions including Banzai, a comedy game show where viewers will be invited to bet on the outcome of various situations.

webTitle: Racist abuse of most concern to viewers and listeners

fields.headline: Racist abuse of most concern to viewers and listeners
fields.trailText: 11am: The use of racist abuse on TV and radio is of increasing concern to viewers and listeners, according to a new study, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Viewers and listeners are becoming increasingly concerned about racist language, a study by TV and advertising watchdogs revealed today.

Over the past two years racist abuse has shot up in the league of offensive words.

In a disturbing twist, however, some racist words are not even considered offensive by a sizeable section of the public.

The report, Delete Expletives?, found that while swearing and offensive language on TV and radio and in print and poster advertising, remains a serious issue with most adults, the use of racist abuse was identified as an area to which respondents were increasingly sensitive.

In 1998 "Nigger" was ranked as the 11th most offensive word in the English language.

Two years on it is considered an extreme term of abuse, moving up to fifth position in the severity rankings.

"Paki" was similarly deemed a middle-ranking term of abuse, ranking number 17 in 1998. But it is now considered the 10th most offensive word.

However, the table, which was published by the BBC and broadcasting and advertising regulators, shows that as many as 40% of respondents consider the word "paki" inoffensive, regarding it as either "quite mild" or "not swearing".

And 32% didn't have a problem with the word 'nigger'. This was in stark contrast to the C-word, with only 1% considering it not to be a swear word.

And elsewhere in the report, only 50% deemed "paki" and "nigger' unacceptable for TV broadcast at any time. By contrast, there was minimal movement in sentiment towards other words considered "very severe" between 1998 and 2000.

The use of swear words and terms of abuse in TV shows was considered generally unacceptable before the 9pm watershed by respondents.

But swearing was regarded as more acceptable in "adult" programming such as drama, film, comedy and documentary dealing with controversial subjects, provided it was scheduled appropriately.

The use of swear words was also more likely to be accepted if it was felt to be editorially justified.

Respondents expected BBC1, of all terrestrial and pay-TV channels, to show the most responsible attitude to the use of swearing and offensive language, because it was paid for by the licence fee.

Stephen Whittle, Broadcasting Standards Commission director, said: "Although there is an acceptance that swearing and offensive language is used in daily life and may be appropriate if a programme is aimed at adults, they would prefer their homes to remain an expletive deleted zone for children."

The use of swearing in TV and poster advertising was considered even less acceptable than in TV programmes, with 81% of respondents saying that TV ads should not contain strong language even if transmitted after the watershed.

Strong language was said to be less acceptable in poster ads than other media because it could not be avoided, according to 86% of respondents to the survey.

Consumers were more willing to accept swearing and offensive language in press advertising.

But more than two-thirds of those canvassed in the study felt there should be equivalent rules for both broadcast and non-broadcast advertisements.

Christopher Graham, Advertising Standards Authority director general, said: "This research will help advertisers to distinguish between what might be acceptable in targeted media such as magazines and what causes offence on posters in the high street."

 Delete Expletives? was researched by NOP for the Advertising Standards Authority, BBC, Broadcasting Standards Commission and Independent Television Commission.
