webTitle: Globalisation paper pits government against activists

fields.headline: Globalisation paper pits government against activists
fields.standfirst:
Talk to Clare Short online on Tuesday 5 December

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: A controversial policy document published this afternoon has pitted the government against anti-poverty activists in the battle to help the world's poor.
fields.body:
A controversial policy document published this afternoon has pitted the government against anti-poverty activists in the battle to help the world's poor.

The government white paper, Making Globalisation Work, has the backing of the secretary of state for international development, Clare Short, and has been published by her Department for International Development (DFID).

It commits the government to backing a string of development targets for the third world, including the introduction of universal primary education by 2015 and halving the number of people living in poverty by the same date.

To achieve this, the paper argues, governments and activists must work with, rather than against, the grain of globalisation. According to Ms Short, the injustices commonly associated with commercial development in the third world can be overcome by work on healthcare, education and fair trade laws.

This sets her department at odds with many campaign groups in the field. They argue that, while globalisation often benefits the west, it rarely helps poorer countries.

Barry Coates, director of anti-poverty campaigners the World Development Movement, warned that the white paper must not be a "pro-poor whitewash to cover old-style exploitative globalisation".

"Globalisation has enriched a few and excluded the majority of the world," he says. "Not only is inequality increasing, but the numbers of people living in absolute poverty are still rising after years of globalisation."

However, the DFID points to success stories such as Mozambique to back its case. There, foreign direct investment has grown by six times since 1994.

webTitle: The new Vauxhall Corsa

fields.headline: Par for the Corsa
fields.standfirst: It'll take more than Griff Rhys Jones in a fake ginger beard to get Giles Smith excited by the new Vauxhall Corsa
fields.trailText: It'll take more than Griff Rhys Jones in a fake ginger beard to get Giles Smith excited by the new Vauxhall Corsa.
fields.body:
Very few cars these days seem entirely happy to be themselves. Manufacturers - looking to play the market as broadly as they can - confront you with vehicles that appear to be in the middle of an identity crisis, which those vehicles endure with varying degrees of fortitude and cheerfulness: an all-terrain estate car miserably imprisoned in the body of a hatchback; an executive saloon that yearns to free the sports car within; a people carrier that knows it should have been a bread van and will become one as soon as the surgery is possible.

Even the Vauxhall Corsa - a phenomenally popular car with good reason to be content with itself - is, in its latest form, partly hassled by anxieties about what it isn't, and in a way that will be familiar to children: it's a small car that wishes it were big.

You may have seen some of Vauxhall's extensive advertising for the Corsa, which pursues this theme, and in which Griff Rhys Jones, as some sort of alarmingly bearded über-nerd, attempts to convince himself - and us - that, although the Corsa doesn't share the stretch limo's capacity for a Jacuzzi and a cocktail bar, it is actually roomy enough for the kind of life you are likely to lead in it, if only you would stop dreaming.

Translated into bare terms, the message of the campaign is that the new Corsa is perfectly adequate. But you can see how "The Vauxhall Corsa: it'll do" wouldn't necessarily have heated public enthusiasm to the kind of levels that Vauxhall probably has in mind. Hence Rhys Jones and the babe-strewn Jacuzzi, working comic overtime.

It will probably, however, take more than a comedian in a ginger beard to imbue the Corsa with animal magnetism. It's just not that kind of vehicle - as quick as its high- powered, light body might fly, and as coolly grooved as its front bonnet might be. It's the car your parents might buy you, when what you really wanted was a Renault Clio. Or a moped.

And you would understand their logic. It's not necessarily going to be the first target for hot-wirers. It's packed full of safety furniture, including that canny Vauxhall mechanism that disengages the pedals to spare your feet and legs in a crunch. It doesn't have the kind of features or profile that are likely to make its drivers feel that they are either Jenson Button at Imola or Dan Aykroyd in The Blues Brothers. You'll be home by midnight. It's a sensible option.

And hats off to Vauxhall for producing what I believe to be the first car to turn to television for influence in a key aspect of its design. Not to programmes seen on television, you understand, but to the set itself. Vauxhall claims that the rear window of the car has "something of a modern TV-screen look". Part Vauxhall, part 48-inch Panasonic: now, there's a hybrid worth thinking about.

The back view offers by far the car's most handsome angle. The rear lights bracket the window, which means that the brake lights are hoisted up high, like flags of surrender. By rights, buses and lorries should see you brake and thus fail to run into you. But on those occasions when people don't see you stopping, the design remains a smart idea: you won't be spending money replacing cracked lights because these are well removed from the likely biffing zone.

Seen from almost any other angle, however, the car's shape is unlikely to leap out at you screaming: "Adore me!" It's one of those quiet everycars, a bubble of European steel - for which, of course, there is a substantial market, most people having little or no ambition to own a car that turns heads. The three-door model is more pleasant to look at than the five-door, on which they have squeezed in a third side-window that is roughly the shape of the badge denoting crew membership on the SS Enterprise. So much does it resemble an afterthought that people may well think you put it in yourself, post-purchase, in an unguarded act of DIY.

It is true, as Rhys Jones intimates, that the car feels roomy. It is slightly wider and taller than previous versions and you won't need to arm wrestle your passenger for possession of the gearstick. There seems to be a little more light and air around than there is in the regular hatchback. However, whether this necessarily justifies the installation of big-car gimmicks, such as the satellite navigation system that was blinking away in the model I drove, is not entirely clear. Given the kind of jobs one is likely to use the Corsa for, I'm not sure how often one would need to be in touch with a satellite for guidance. When was the last time you got lost coming home from the supermarket?

Other cars, of course, manage to be small without minding. Consider the sunny disposition of the Fiat Punto. The dependable Corsa has little of the Punto's affable spark. But purchasers who share Rhys Jones's utilitarian disposition may readily sacrifice that for a few extra centimetres of elbow room.

The lowdown

Vauxhall Corsa 1.2i

Price: £8,495

Top speed: 106.2 mph

Acceleration: 0-60 in 12 seconds

Consumption: 44.8 mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Jack Straw's son

On the stereo: Eminem

En route for: Marks & Spencer

You may have seen some of Vauxhall's extensive advertising for the Corsa, which pursues this theme, and in which Griff Rhys Jones, as some sort of alarmingly bearded über-nerd, attempts to convince himself - and us - that, although the Corsa doesn't share the stretch limo's capacity for a Jacuzzi and a cocktail bar, it is actually roomy enough for the kind of life you are likely to lead in it, if only you would stop dreaming. Translated into bare terms, the message of the campaign is that the new Corsa is perfectly adequate. But you can see how "The Vauxhall Corsa: it'll do" wouldn't necessarily have heated public enthusiasm to the kind of levels that Vauxhall probably has in mind. Hence Rhys Jones and the babe-strewn Jacuzzi, working comic overtime. It will probably, however, take more than a comedian in a ginger beard to imbue the Corsa with animal magnetism. It's just not that kind of vehicle - as quick as its high- powered, light body might fly, and as coolly grooved as its front bonnet might be. It's the car your parents might buy you, when what you really wanted was a Renault Clio. Or a moped. And you would understand their logic. It's not necessarily going to be the first target for hot-wirers. It's packed full of safety furniture, including that canny Vauxhall mechanism that disengages the pedals to spare your feet and legs in a crunch. It doesn't have the kind of features or profile that are likely to make its drivers feel that they are either Jenson Button at Imola or Dan Aykroyd in The Blues Brothers. You'll be home by midnight. It's a sensible option. And hats off to Vauxhall for producing what I believe to be the first car to turn to television for influence in a key aspect of its design. Not to programmes seen on television, you understand, but to the set itself. Vauxhall claims that the rear window of the car has "something of a modern TV-screen look". Part Vauxhall, part 48-inch Panasonic: now, there's a hybrid worth thinking about. The back view offers by far the car's most handsome angle. The rear lights bracket the window, which means that the brake lights are hoisted up high, like flags of surrender. By rights, buses and lorries should see you brake and thus fail to run into you. But on those occasions when people don't see you stopping, the design remains a smart idea: you won't be spending money replacing cracked lights because these are well removed from the likely biffing zone. Seen from almost any other angle, however, the car's shape is unlikely to leap out at you screaming: "Adore me!" It's one of those quiet everycars, a bubble of European steel - for which, of course, there is a substantial market, most people having little or no ambition to own a car that turns heads. The three-door model is more pleasant to look at than the five-door, on which they have squeezed in a third side-window that is roughly the shape of the badge denoting crew membership on the SS Enterprise. So much does it resemble an afterthought that people may well think you put it in yourself, post-purchase, in an unguarded act of DIY. It is true, as Rhys Jones intimates, that the car feels roomy. It is slightly wider and taller than previous versions and you won't need to arm wrestle your passenger for possession of the gearstick. There seems to be a little more light and air around than there is in the regular hatchback. However, whether this necessarily justifies the installation of big-car gimmicks, such as the satellite navigation system that was blinking away in the model I drove, is not entirely clear. Given the kind of jobs one is likely to use the Corsa for, I'm not sure how often one would need to be in touch with a satellite for guidance. When was the last time you got lost coming home from the supermarket? Other cars, of course, manage to be small without minding. Consider the sunny disposition of the Fiat Punto. The dependable Corsa has little of the Punto's affable spark. But purchasers who share Rhys Jones's utilitarian disposition may readily sacrifice that for a few extra centimetres of elbow room. webTitle: BMA criticisms of NHS plan miss the point

fields.headline: BMA criticisms of NHS plan miss the point
fields.standfirst: Demanding more doctors is an excuse for inaction, argues Nigel Edwards.  What the NHS needs most is an injection of imaginative new approaches to delivering health care
fields.trailText: Demanding more doctors is an excuse for inaction, argues Nigel Edwards. What the NHS needs most is an injection of imaginative new approaches to delivering health care
fields.body:
The pace of change in the health service following the launch of the NHS plan is slower than the British Medical Association (BMA) would like, as its recent criticisms have made clear.

But the BMA's constant refrain that the NHS plan will fail because the NHS needs an urgent injection of large numbers of additional doctors seriously misses the point of the reforms.

Because of the time it takes to train a doctor, simply demanding more is at best a long term solution and at worst an excuse for inaction.

Rather than calling for something that is out of reach, the NHS needs imaginative solutions and lateral thinking to deal with the problems that face it now; we don't just want more of the same, we need new approaches to delivering health care.

The authors of the NHS plan appear to have grasped the fundamental insight of quality improvement - that every system is perfectly designed to get the results it achieves.

To change the results you have to change the system, as more effort simply produces more of the same. The example of the railways shows how working the system harder can achieve short term success followed by medium term failure.

Unlike previous reforms, the redesign of the NHS can not be mandated by ministerial fiat nor is it possible to produce a one size fits all solution.

Change has to be designed locally and depends on the commitment and imagination of clinical staff professionals and managers.

Stunning examples of this type of change have been achieved by GP practices working with Dr John Oldham's national primary care development team. It has transformed waiting times for appointments, often with almost no increase in resources, by local effort and imagination, not top down direction.

There are many obstacles to change. Most dangerous is the temptation to try to command change from the top to achieve quick results - this will drive out initiative and build resistance.

Secondly, the notion that management is something done to clinicians rather than a key part of their job and that management is a cost rather than an important investment has left some key parts of the NHS, such as outpatients, with virtually no management at all.

Being an excellent clinician is not just about clinical skills, it means being able to lead, monitor quality, improve and redesign services and manage resources.

The third obstacle is a simplistic idea that all we need is more. More is not enough.

The BMA and other professional bodies have the chance to work with colleagues to take a lead, provide vision and to define this new direction.

Many leaders of the professions understand this; but they need support to be courageous enough to seize this unique opportunity.

 Nigel Edwards is a policy director at the NHS Confederation

Has the BMA missed the point about the NHS plan? Do we need more doctors, or can the NHS cope simply by redesigning the way doctors work? Send your comments to: editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: Dissatisfaction with NHS is rising

fields.headline: Dissatisfaction with NHS is rising
fields.standfirst: British Medical Association poll findings and response
fields.trailText: Public dissatisfaction with the NHS is growing, according to a new independent opinion poll. Almost as many people believe the Labour government is responsible for the current state of the NHS as believe the Conservative government is.
fields.body:
Public dissatisfaction with the NHS is growing, according to a new independent opinion poll. Almost as many people believe the Labour government is responsible for the current state of the NHS as believe the Conservative government is.

The poll, by Mori for the BMA, involved questioning more than 2,000 people throughout Great Britain between November 23 and 28.

The findings show that the proportion of people very or fairly dissatisfied with the NHS rose from 17% in January 1998 to 28% last month, while those satisfied with the service fell from 72 to 58%.

Only 13% said they were "very satisfied" with the NHS, down from 24%. A massive 94% said that the NHS was in need of much or some improvement.

When asked who or what was most responsible for the current state of the NHS, 44% of the unprompted replies referred to "the government" - 20% to the Conservative government and 11% to the Labour government.

Some 16% replied that NHS managers or people running hospitals were responsible, while only 2% said doctors and 1% said doctors going into private healthcare.

When prompted, 51% replied the Conservative government, 48% the Labour government, 46% NHS managers and 9% doctors. Forty per cent said people abusing the service.

Commenting on the results, Dr Ian Bogle, chairman of the BMA, said: "The message from the public is clear. Despite increased spending on the NHS, politicians in this government and the last have failed to fulfil the public's expectations. Although doctors are working hard and doing their best in difficult circumstances, their dedication is not enough.

"The NHS plan does promise a welcome step in the right direction with its promise of greatly increased funding. We intend to work with the government to try to achieve many of the aspirations in the document. But the reality is that Britain needs increased recruitment of doctors and that will require continued, sustained investment."

 For question on satisfaction with the NHS, results have been compared with Mori's 50th NHS anniversary poll, conducted in January 1998.

webTitle: Unions call for local government pay rise

fields.headline: Unions call for local government pay rise
fields.trailText: Town hall unions have called for a £1,000 pay rise for all local government staff that could cost employers more than £800m in extra wages. By Simon Parker
fields.body:
Town hall unions have called for a £1,000 pay rise for all local government staff that could cost employers more than £800m in extra wages.

Unison, the Transport and General Workers union and the GMB made the call as the opening gambit in their latest round of pay negotiations with authorities.

Preliminary costing from the local government Employers Organisation suggests the claim would mean wage increases of between 3%-11%.

The average increase would be about 6.4%, but councils would have to dig deep to cover the £800m bill.

A spokesman for the Employers Organisation said: "The unions have admitted this is a big claim, and we'd echo that."

The unions claim the increase will help councils deal with staffing problems - more than three-quarters have reported recruitment difficulties.

The move could also help tackle the gender pay gap and beat low wages by giving staff a minimum rate of £5.11 an hour.

GMB national public service secretary Mick Graham said: "In the 21st century a minimum weekly wage of £200 is warranted and realistic for local government workers. These people are the backbone of our country."

The union emphasised, however, that Scottish-style industrial action is not on the cards if the unions do not get their way.

The Employers Organisation will consult councils on the increase over the coming months, before final details of next year's pay settlement are thrashed out in February and March.

webTitle: Diana Memorial Fund announces grant winners

fields.headline: Diana Memorial Fund announces grant winners
fields.trailText: Today the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund announces the winners of this year's round of grant awards.Young people will be the key beneficiaries, with money going to twenty voluntary organisations tackling problems faced by disadvantaged youths.
fields.body:
Today the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund announces the winners of this year's round of grant awards.Young people will be the key beneficiaries, with money going to twenty voluntary organisations tackling problems faced by disadvantaged youths.

Four of the awards go to Scotland and one to Wales. A £100,000 grant for Children in Scotland, will help young people with learning difficulties to participate in the policy making of the new Scottish parliament.

The UK-based Young Minds Trust wins £150,500 to conduct research in six in-patient units for young people and to make recommendations regarding the future development of emergency child and adolescent mental health services.

The fund received double the amount of applications for this year's round of grant making and the money awarded brings the total to £35m in the three years since it began.

In Wales, Scope Cymru is to receive nearly £200,000 to provide training and support for young people with learning disabilities to gain vocational qualifications.

A CD-ROM for young lesbian and bisexual women will be developed with the help of a £22,000 grant by the Healthy Gay Living Centre with the aim of reducing their vulnerability to mental illness.

Chief executive of the fund, Andrew Purkis, said: "Diana, Princess of Wales herself reached out to all kinds of people suffering stigma and disadvantage. It is precisely in this spirit that these grants are being awarded."

webTitle: EMI unveils two internet deals

fields.headline: EMI announces two internet deals
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: EMI has sought to reverse the financial woes at its new media division by announcing two internet deals. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EMI has sought to reverse the financial woes surrounding its new media division by announcing two Internet deals.

The UK music group, which is negotiating a merger with German rival Bertelsmann, is teaming up with web companies IchooseTV and Musicbrigade.com to send its music videos over the net.

The dot.coms have signed a licensing deal for the video content, with EMI taking a small stake in both companies.

Last month, EMI said earnings from its new-media activities had slipped from £23.9m to £ 6.1m, and described revenues from e-commerce ventures as "lumpy".

EMI has announced 28 web ventures over the last 18 months.

Jay Samit, head of new media for EMI, said: "By signing these licence agreements with IchooseTV and Musicbrigade.com we are building on our momentum in the European online music environment, placing our artists' music at the heart of this emerging new media."

EMI is still in merger talks with Bertelsmann's BMG music subsidiary, which could lead to the German company switching its music assets into EMI.

Bertelsmann has taken an aggressive lead in the internet music industry, after signing a deal with rogue music website Napster.

It is also buying space on European mobile phone networks in order to send its records to customers' handsets.

webTitle: Future cancels consumer computer title before launch

fields.headline: Future cancels consumer computer title before launch
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Future Network has cancelled its computer magazine launch leaving 16 journalists facing redundancy, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Future Network has canned its long-planned consumer computer magazine launch, leaving 16 journalists facing redundancy.

The magazine, codenamed Project Click, has been in gestation since the beginning of the year and would have been backed by a £2m plus above-the-line advertising campaign.

It was to be launched as a rival to the successful VNU magazine Computeractive.

Future Network, the Bath-based IT publisher that recently expanded into lifestyle publishing and has Elisabeth Murdoch as a non-executive director, poached four journalists from the VNU title for the high-profile launch.

Former Computeractive deputy editor Dylan Armbrust was lured away to be the launch editor of the new magazine, as were reviews editor Andy Shaw, workshops editor Linley Oram and production editor Anthony Green.

A Future Network spokeswoman said the company would try to relocate the staff within the company, but insiders say few journalists expect to be given jobs.

The spokeswoman said: "We've been observing a volatile marketplace. A lot of players in the IT sector, including Dell and Gateway, have given profit warnings, and that signalled a potential downturn in advertising revenue.

"With a mass consumer launch like this, we want to make sure the conditions are right."

She added that the company would put all its focus into its existing computer titles, including PC Format and .net.

Meanwhile, reports that VNU has put a block on the recruitment of any staff from the collapsed magazine have been denied by Computeractive editor James Harding.

Mr Harding said: "When people leave companies, sometimes they burn bridges, sometimes they don't. There may be a HR policy about taking people back from Future that I don't know about. Personally I don't have a problem with it."

The value of Future Network's shares tumbled last month after the discovery of a £4.2m hole in the accounts of its French division.

webTitle: Tory regeneration plans look to the past

fields.headline: Tory regeneration plans look to the past
fields.standfirst: At the heart of the Conservative's policy for regenerating our cities is a return to the 1980s, writes Brian Robson
fields.trailText: Comment: At the heart of the Conservative's policy for regenerating our cities is a return to the 1980s, writes Brian Robson
fields.body:
There is no great mystery about what needs to be done to help revive our cities or to build on their patchy rehabilitation. Urban policies, from both parties, have produced three decades of regeneration experiments in Britain and endless evaluation studies of their impact, so the models that have some chance of success are now well known.

Unfortunately for politicians, success costs money and demands consistent priorities. The solution rests on the long-term targeting of resources, involving co-ordinated partnerships of departments and agencies, with strong ownership by local authorities and local residents and a mix of social and economic initiatives.

Ideally, given the critical importance of our towns and cities, these should not be the subject of adversarial party politics. Indeed, there now appears more agreement between the political parties on the need for a more social dimension to urban policy, but inevitably the means for achieving this remain a great barrier.

This is starkly apparent in the Conservative's most recent foray into the urban arena. Launched at the party's annual conference earlier this year, the policy document Believing in our Cities sets out many impeccable (but uncosted) ends, which are undercut by means that are dubious or lack sufficient detail to establish their credibility.

For example, the Conservative proposal for a minister for regeneration with a single cross-departmental budget could address the need for co-ordination, but how this would improve on existing efforts at joined-up government needs to be spelled out.

The document's emphasis on environmental improvement - with its attention to local nuisances, to graffiti and the like - is welcome, but another statutory obligation on local authorities is unlikely to help unless properly financed. The suggestion to allow councils to retain money from fines seems a rather feeble joke given the huge arrears in collecting fines experienced by most courts.

Other ideas - "progress centres" for children having difficulty with mainstream education, or the return of visible police properly trained to help local communities - are all refreshing proposals from a party whose leader once claimed that "there was no such thing as society".

But the overall framework looks like a return to the unsuccessful experiments of the 1980s: faith in the private sector, in bricks and mortar and in a strong hand from the centre. Even though there is concern about education, health and housing, the sharpest focus remains on physical regeneration and on control from the centre. Local authorities would, in essence, be by-passed and the principal drivers would be central government and the private sector.

One of the merits of the government's urban regeneration companies - currently being piloted in Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield - is that they have at their heart a strong role for local authorities. In contrast, the regeneration companies proposed by the Conservatives have more than an echo of the failed urban development companies of the 1980s.

They would be private-sector led, with little local accountability and with an almost inevitable focus on physical regeneration. Moreover, they would operate in the context of the abolition of regional development agencies, which - even though unproven - have the potential to move control away from Whitehall and could co-ordinate their resources on the big cities where most problems exist. The regeneration companies would also have a role in schooling and policing; yet in both areas the greatest need is for local accountability - not for autonomous chief constables and private-sector run schools.

The stress the Conservatives place on physical solutions - knocking down high-rise housing, re-introducing simplified planning zones, setting yet higher targets for brownfield development (although without any clear sense of the necessary fiscal incentives) will signify little unless priority is given to strengthening community-led civic responsibility.

The key to regeneration is the combination of enterprise with responsibility. The latter is a long haul. It means putting greater trust in the hands of local authorities, voluntary sector bodies and local communities. These Tory proposals, though espousing the right outcomes, seem still to lack the will or, more importantly, the heart needed to achieve them.

 Professor Brian Robson is director of the Centre for Urban Policy Studies at the University of Manchester.
fields.bodyText: There is no great mystery about what needs to be done to help revive our cities or to build on their patchy rehabilitation. Urban policies, from both parties, have produced three decades of regeneration experiments in Britain and endless evaluation studies of their impact, so the models that have some chance of success are now well known. Unfortunately for politicians, success costs money and demands consistent priorities. The solution rests on the long-term targeting of resources, involving co-ordinated partnerships of departments and agencies, with strong ownership by local authorities and local residents and a mix of social and economic initiatives. Ideally, given the critical importance of our towns and cities, these should not be the subject of adversarial party politics. Indeed, there now appears more agreement between the political parties on the need for a more social dimension to urban policy, but inevitably the means for achieving this remain a great barrier. This is starkly apparent in the Conservative's most recent foray into the urban arena. Launched at the party's annual conference earlier this year, the policy document Believing in our Cities sets out many impeccable (but uncosted) ends, which are undercut by means that are dubious or lack sufficient detail to establish their credibility. For example, the Conservative proposal for a minister for regeneration with a single cross-departmental budget could address the need for co-ordination, but how this would improve on existing efforts at joined-up government needs to be spelled out. The document's emphasis on environmental improvement - with its attention to local nuisances, to graffiti and the like - is welcome, but another statutory obligation on local authorities is unlikely to help unless properly financed. The suggestion to allow councils to retain money from fines seems a rather feeble joke given the huge arrears in collecting fines experienced by most courts. Other ideas - "progress centres" for children having difficulty with mainstream education, or the return of visible police properly trained to help local communities - are all refreshing proposals from a party whose leader once claimed that "there was no such thing as society". But the overall framework looks like a return to the unsuccessful experiments of the 1980s: faith in the private sector, in bricks and mortar and in a strong hand from the centre. Even though there is concern about education, health and housing, the sharpest focus remains on physical regeneration and on control from the centre. Local authorities would, in essence, be by-passed and the principal drivers would be central government and the private sector. One of the merits of the government's urban regeneration companies - currently being piloted in Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield - is that they have at their heart a strong role for local authorities. In contrast, the regeneration companies proposed by the Conservatives have more than an echo of the failed urban development companies of the 1980s. They would be private-sector led, with little local accountability and with an almost inevitable focus on physical regeneration. Moreover, they would operate in the context of the abolition of regional development agencies, which - even though unproven - have the potential to move control away from Whitehall and could co-ordinate their resources on the big cities where most problems exist. The regeneration companies would also have a role in schooling and policing; yet in both areas the greatest need is for local accountability - not for autonomous chief constables and private-sector run schools. The stress the Conservatives place on physical solutions - knocking down high-rise housing, re-introducing simplified planning zones, setting yet higher targets for brownfield development (although without any clear sense of the necessary fiscal incentives) will signify little unless priority is given to strengthening community-led civic responsibility. The key to regeneration is the combination of enterprise with responsibility. The latter is a long haul. It means putting greater trust in the hands of local authorities, voluntary sector bodies and local communities. webTitle: Vodafone and BT vie for Japanese phone market

fields.headline: Vodafone and BT battle over Japanese market
fields.standfirst: Dec 11: Vodafone in £12m cricket sponsorship
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Vodafone and BT are going head-to-head in a battle for the Japanese market in next-generation mobile phones. by Dan Milmo

Dec 11: Vodafone in £12m cricket sponsorship
fields.body:
Vodafone and BT are going head-to-head in a battle for the Japanese market in next-generation mobile phones.

According to reports, Vodafone has agreed to pay £1.7bn for a 15% stake in Japan Telecom, giving it 26% in the company's J-Phone mobile phone subsidiary.

BT is the next largest shareholder in a company that could threaten NTT DoCoMo's stranglehold on the Japanese mobile phone market. Vodafone declined to comment on the reports.

Japan is the most lucrative market in the mobile phone industry and is seen as an ideal testing ground for 3G networks, which will provide faster audio and video services.

DoCoMo's iMode product has proved far more popular than Wap in connecting users to the web, signing up over 7m subscribers.

Both J-Phone and NTT DoCoMo will launch their 3G services next year.

BT owns 15% of Japan Telecom and is said to be interested in building its stake in the company by buying shares off American operator AT&T.

Peter Bonfield, BT chief executive, has earmarked Japan as a key market despite announcing a cutback in international operations.

Nigel Hawkins, telecoms analyst at Williams de Broe, said: "There is a fair amount to be learned from entering the Japanese market, and it is also one of the leading places for 3G networks."

Next-generation mobile phone networks will have to succeed if European telecoms companies are to pay off their mounting debts, created by bidding for 3G licences on the continent.

BT's deficit is set to hit £30bn next year, and UK watchdog the Financial Services Authority has reminded banks to keep a close eye on borrowing from the telecoms sector.

webTitle: BBC rushes out Prince William show

fields.headline: Prince William at centre of TV ratings war
fields.trailText: 2.15pm The BBC has ordered a last-minute change to its peak-time schedule tonight to broadcast a Prince William special that ends just as ITV's own programme on the prince begins, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The BBC has ordered a last-minute change to its peak-time schedule tonight as the media becomes saturated with sudden coverage of Prince William's exploits in Patagonia.

BBC1 is to screen a 30-minute Prince William special at 7.30pm in a clear ratings strike against ITV, which has scheduled its own Prince William in Chile Special at 8pm.

The decision was taken by BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey and was announced the day after ITV revealed it was clearing the decks for its own special on the prince.

The BBC's programme will be fronted by royal correspondent, Jennie Bond and will ironically use footage captured by an ITN cameraman who was given exclusive TV access to the Prince.

A BBC spokesman said the programme had been scheduled after "much debate" and "due to the huge amount of public interest". He said the show would try to put the pictures "into context".

The prince's activities on a Raleigh International project in southern Chile have received blanket coverage in the national press over the past two days and heavy coverage by both main broadcasters.

Television pictures have shown the prince teaching English, shifting logs and larking around with his colleagues, reflecting what appears like a concerted effort to portray the young Prince as an "ordinary citizen".

The photographs, which could have been taken from an action man calender, combined with Prince Charles' appearance on Coronation Street on Friday night, convey an image of a monarchy that is in touch.

The footage was filmed over three days by ITN cameraman Eugene Campbell, who also filmed William at Eton in the run-up to his 18th birthday in the summer.

webTitle: Palace's PR campaign takes media by storm

fields.headline: Palace's PR campaign takes media by storm
fields.standfirst: Dec 11: William at centre of ratings war
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: Blanket press coverage and TV specials of Prince William are the result of a PR campaign planned with military precision by St James's Palace, writes Daniel Rogers.

Dec 11: William at centre of ratings war
fields.body:
For two days running tabloid newspapers have given blanket coverage to Prince William's trip to Patagonia.

The action shots have been a tabloid editor's dream - combining an "insight" into the personality of Prince Diana's hitherto media-shy son and a new earthy with a fun image for the monarchy.

They also provided newspapers with a a wholesome pin-up of the royals' best-looking member.

Front pages in the national press yesterday and today and tonight's TV specials on both BBC and ITV are the ultimate results of a PR campaign that has been planned with military precision by St James's Palace over the past two months.

The impact was instant and returns positive. "Tall, handsome, sensitive, artistic, and cool" were the adjectives used by the Sun alone. Others variously refered to the prince as "athletic, "chisel-jawed" and "sensitive".

The Mirror said "a large of dollop of cynicism" should be applied to the eulogies, but it still thought the picture of William cleaning a toilet worthy of the front page and evidence that the prince could be the first royal to understand the lives of his subjects.

Millions more will be bombarded with pictures tonight after the BBC rearranged its schedule to slot in a Prince William special on BBC1 this evening at 7.30pm, pre-empting ITV's own Prince William in Chile show at 8pm.

It is the second time in a year that "at home" footage of the prince has been screened. When he turned 18, footage of Prince William cooking and playing rugby was released to TV stations.

That footage was taken by ITN cameraman Eugene Campbell in a pooled arrangement.

"The prince knew Eugene well from the birthday celebration and they got on well. That was why he was chosen," said a spokeswoman for St James's Palace.

This time pictures are equally as controlled with Mr Campbell chosen to fly to Chile for the assignment.

The campaign clearly sets out to present Prince William as a man of the people and plays up his humility as well as his sense of humour.

PR sources were split on the ultimate wisdom of the campaign.

Max Clifford described it as a "brilliant success playing on Prince William's instinctive handling of the media that he has inherited from his mother".

Mark Borkowski, who did the PR for Hollywood child star Macaulay Culkin, said: "Prince William is now collateral. He is signing a Faustian pact with the media. Do they ever learn?"

Journalists too were unhappy with the limited access to the prince. One described it as "terribly controlled and a very cautious move by the palace".

"They had us over a barrel. It was a pooled arrangement or nothing," he added.

St James's Palace also insisted on tight control over the local press, preventing any spoilers.

Only three British journalists were granted access to the prince's activities - ITN cameraman Eugene Campbell and a reporter and photographer from the Press Association.

The reaction is in contrast to the stand-off between royals and media in recent months, including a complaint to the Press Complaints Commission from the palace concerning coverage of the Prince's South Africa trip

St James's Palace denies that the project was an attempt to improve the image of the royal family.

"Our only concern is allowing coverage without invading the princes' privacy," said a spokesman.

webTitle: Hashimoto: the comeback king

fields.headline: Hashimoto: the comeback king
fields.standfirst: Ryutaro Hashimoto is poised to regain the prime minister's job after returning to the cabinet, reports Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Ryutaro Hashimoto is poised to regain the prime minister's job after returning to the cabinet, reports Jonathan Watts in Tokyo.
fields.body:
The bryll-creamed quiff is back on top in Japanese politics.

Two years after he was unceremoniously dumped from the premiership, Elvis Presley-lookalike Ryutaro Hashimoto made a surprise return to the cabinet last week, and many predict he will regain the top job next year.

In a first for Japan, Hashimoto is one of three prime ministers (one current, two former) in a reshuffled administration that has left many observers asking who is really running the country.

It certainly does not appear to be the gaffe-prone prime minister, Mr Mori, who only narrowly survived a rebellion within the ruling Liberal Democratic party last month.

With a disapproval rating of about 70%, Mr Mori is one of the most unpopular premiers in history and many LDP politicians fear a meltdown in next summer's upper house election if he stays at the helm.

Mr Hashimoto, meanwhile, has clearly emerged as the winner from the recent turmoil that has shaken the LDP. His appointment as minister in charge of administrative reform marks a remarkable comeback for a politician whose name was dirt just two years ago.

Mr Hashimoto was forced to resign as prime minister in 1998 after the LDP was punished in the polls for a deep recession that was widely blamed on his decision to force through a rise in the consumption tax.

After a brief period in the political wilderness, he returned to the limelight last spring when he inherited the leadership of the LDP's largest faction after the death of former prime minister Keizo Obuchi.

His enthusiasm for improving the nation's finances is also back in fashion. Successive administrations' attempts to spend their way out of recession have left Japan with one of the biggest public debts in world history. This was the central issue in the revolt last month by Koichi Kato, who demanded that the government rein back spending before the country goes bankrupt.

Mr Hashimoto agrees with Mr Kato, who was formerly his right-hand man, but he refused to condone a rebellion within the LDP. Instead, he won kudos within the party for remaining loyal, while his supporters made clear that he was not entirely happy with Mr Mori.

"The prime minister may have won the no-confidence vote, but he should not make the mistake of thinking that this means we have confidence in him," said Hiromu Nonaka, a senior member of the Hashimoto faction.

Such a comment might sound peculiar in Britain, but in Japan, prime ministers have often been more of a figurehead than a leader, while the real power is traditionally exercised behind the scenes by LDP elders. But the death of three senior party officials this year has confused the already blurred chain of command within the party and left the door open for Mr Hashimoto.

The kendo-export has already demonstrated his clout by having a strong say in the latest cabinet line-up. Mr Hashimoto won plum jobs for members of his faction and blocked Mr Mori's one attempt to demonstrate independence: choosing Makiko Tanaka - one of the most popular politicians in Japan - as a minister.

His new job will make him one of the powerful members of the cabinet, alongside another former prime minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, who retains the finance portfolio, and his strongest rival to become the next premier, Yohei Kono, the foreign minister.

It will also allow him to complete some unfinished business. Next month, he will oversee a major reorganisation of the government that he initiated as prime minister. There is every chance that he could be in the same job again before the project is completed.

webTitle: Libel verdict 'invalid' says Hamilton lawyer

fields.headline: Libel verdict 'invalid' says Hamilton lawyer
fields.standfirst: Special report: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel case
fields.trailText: The "gross impropriety" of Mohamed Al Fayed's behaviour at the time of Neil Hamilton's crushing cash for questions libel defeat was enough to invalidate the trial, the court of appeal heard today.
fields.body:
The "gross impropriety" of Mohamed Al Fayed's behaviour at the time of Neil Hamilton's crushing cash for questions libel defeat was enough to invalidate the trial, the court of appeal heard today.

The former MP and his wife Christine were in court to hear their lawyer Anthony Boswood QC begin a bid to set aside the jury's verdict, which concluded a vicious five week hearing a year ago.

The former MP for Tatton had sued over claims made by Mr Al Fayed in a Channel 4 Dispatches programme in January 1997 that he had corruptly demanded and accepted cash payments, gift vouchers and a free holiday at the Paris Ritz in return for asking parliamentary questions on behalf of Harrods.

Mr Hamilton, who dismissed the allegations as a pack of lies, faced an estimated £2m costs bill at the end of the case.

Mr Al Fayed was not present today, but is expected to be called to face questioning from Mr Hamilton's lawyers over allegations that he was involved in paying £10,000 for stolen legal documents, taken from rubbish bags outside the chambers of Mr Hamilton's counsel, Desmond Browne QC.

Mr Boswood told Lord Phillips, the master of the rolls, Lord Justice Sedley and Lady Justice Hale that the verdict seemed to have brought finality to Mr Hamilton's "long battle" with the Harrods boss.

"And, in the wake of that finality, complete disaster and personal ruin for Mr Hamilton but, as you know, facts have now come to light which cast grave and we say very possibly fatal - because unresolveable - doubt on the fairness of the trial and therefore on the validity of the jury's verdict and the judge's order, " he said.

Mr Boswood added: "We submit that the mere fact of the gross impropriety of their behaviour is sufficient to invalidate the trial."

Mr Hamilton's QC, who at this stage is seeking permission to bring the appeal, said that the court knew that there was "cogent and compelling evidence" that highly confidential privileged documents were taken from Mr Browne's chambers and conveyed in return for a "handsome cash reward and the promise of more" to Mr Al Fayed's camp.

He said that the documents were originally obtained by Benjamin Pell, who made a business of taking such material from rubbish bags of firms of solicitors and barristers, and given to a freelance journalist, Mark Hollingsworth, who had frequently worked for Mr Al Fayed.

Mr Hollingsworth had, in October 1999, been engaged by Mr Al Fayed and his head of security, John Macnamara, to assist in the litigation, the court heard.

It was an engagement, said Mr Boswood, which was, it seemed, kept secret from others in the Al Fayed camp - notably his legal team.

Mr Hollingsworth took the documents supplied by Mr Pell to Mr Macnamara who accepted them "gratefully" and Mr Hollingsworth was paid £10,000 in cash with the promise of a further £10,000 to come, he told the court.

Mr Boswood insisted that Mr Al Fayed must have known about the arrangement. "Even if he had not been, he was manifestly not unaware of it. It's not conceivable that it could have happened without his knowledge - and even if it had, he would clearly have to assume responsibility for it as Macnamara was clearly acting on his behalf.

"That this took place - and there may well have been more than one - is not open to serious doubt," Mr Boswood said.

Mr Boswood said Mr Al Fayed had deliberately chosen not to have Mr Hollingsworth available for cross-examination and Mr Macnamara, "who as so often was at the centre of things", had not denied it.

"In the face of the silence of Mr Hollingsworth and Mr Macnamara, the bare denial of Mr Al Fayed can surely carry little weight."

He added: "The book of bad things people have said about Mr Al Fayed is a weighty volume and it's hardly necessary for me to add to its pages."

Mr Boswood said it should be presumed that Mr Al Fayed did make use of the material. "It is precisely the kind of case where the law does presume, in the strongest terms, against the wrongdoer."

He said that it was a major misrepresentation to say that the evidence about the stolen documents - which consisted of drafts of cross-examination material and witness statements - went solely to credit.

"Heavens above! It goes to demonstrate flagrant abuse of process and conduct which should have debarred Mr Al Fayed from defending the case at all."

He submitted that if the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, had been told of the evidence, he would in all probability have discharged the jury, investigated the matter, and then struck out Mr Al Fayed's case.

Even if the trial had continued, Mr Al Fayed's credibility would have been "truly destroyed at the very outset".

He disputed the claim that Mr Hamilton would inevitably have lost the action anyway because the outcome did not turn on anything said by Mr Al Fayed - but on the corroborative evidence of others and on the allegation that Mr Hamilton had corruptly demanded a payment from Mobil for tabling an amendment.

He said that the evidence of the corroborative witnesses would have been devalued if it was known about the stolen documents and it was "nonsense" to suggest that the Mobil allegation was so overwhelmingly strong.

The hearing continues.

It's not conceivable that it could have happened without his knowledge - and even if it had, he would clearly have to assume responsibility for it as Macnamara was clearly acting on his behalf. "That this took place - and there may well have been more than one - is not open to serious doubt," Mr Boswood said. Mr Boswood said Mr Al Fayed had deliberately chosen not to have Mr Hollingsworth available for cross-examination and Mr Macnamara, "who as so often was at the centre of things", had not denied it. "In the face of the silence of Mr Hollingsworth and Mr Macnamara, the bare denial of Mr Al Fayed can surely carry little weight." He added: "The book of bad things people have said about Mr Al Fayed is a weighty volume and it's hardly necessary for me to add to its pages." Mr Boswood said it should be presumed that Mr Al Fayed did make use of the material. "It is precisely the kind of case where the law does presume, in the strongest terms, against the wrongdoer." He said that it was a major misrepresentation to say that the evidence about the stolen documents - which consisted of drafts of cross-examination material and witness statements - went solely to credit. "Heavens above! It goes to demonstrate flagrant abuse of process and conduct which should have debarred Mr Al Fayed from defending the case at all." He submitted that if the trial judge, Mr Justice Morland, had been told of the evidence, he would in all probability have discharged the jury, investigated the matter, and then struck out Mr Al Fayed's case. Even if the trial had continued, Mr Al Fayed's credibility would have been "truly destroyed at the very outset". He disputed the claim that Mr Hamilton would inevitably have lost the action anyway because the outcome did not turn on anything said by Mr Al Fayed - but on the corroborative evidence of others and on the allegation that Mr Hamilton had corruptly demanded a payment from Mobil for tabling an amendment. He said that the evidence of the corroborative witnesses would have been devalued if it was known about the stolen documents and it was "nonsense" to suggest that the Mobil allegation was so overwhelmingly strong. The hearing continues. webTitle: Morning after pill to go on sale

fields.headline: Morning after pill to go on sale
fields.standfirst: But women going to pharmacists for emergency contraception will still face questions
fields.trailText: The morning after pill is to be available at high street chemists from the new year, but the second sexual revolution which will put women's fertility completely in their own hands is some distance off yet.
fields.body:
The morning after pill is to be available at high street chemists from the new year, but the second sexual revolution which will put women's fertility completely in their own hands is some distance off yet.

From January, those pharmacies with sufficient stocks of emergency contraception will be able to dispense pills to any woman who turns up without a prescription.

No longer will a woman who has had unprotected sex and fears she might become pregnant need to go to a GP.

The pills are safe and they work, provided they are taken within 72 hours.

The committee on the safety of medicines has recommended that pharmacists be permitted to dispense them. But the moral debate on contraception and abortion has tested efforts of the Department of Health and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society to make what some consider a simple medical matter acceptable to middle England.

Some women may find they have exchanged the interrogation of a GP for the cross-questioning of a pharmacist. Under political pressure from a government nervous of moral majorities, the Royal Pharmaceutical Society has agreed that its members will ask questions of the women who seek their help to establish, among other things, whether they have had unprotected sex.

The society insists that some questions are necessary. "There is a raft of information that the pharmacists will need to satisfy themselves of," a spokeswoman said.

The Department of Health has said pharmacists must not supply emergency contraception to under-16s or to women who are pregnant - even though the pill will not affect a pregnancy and certainly will not induce an abortion. But there might be women who wrongly think it will end a pregnancy, the spokeswoman for the Royal Pharmaceutical Society said, and so the question must be asked. The pills prevent a fertilised egg implanting - once that point is passed they have no effect. She added that it was not enough to inform women verbally or in writing because it might be appropriate to refer them to someone else if they were seeking a termination.

The conversations that will take place in pharmacies need not be embarrassing, she said. "You'd be surprised, the sorts of issues people are perfectly prepared to talk about in pharmacies," she said. "What we've got here is a sort of normalised, non-stigmatised healthcare intervention. I think pharmacies will manage this product sensibly and safely but sensitively as well."

Family planning experts wholeheartedly applauded the move to pharmacy sales, which all agree is a big step towards giving women complete control of their fertility. If the day when the emergency pill is as much a part of the family medical cabinet as aspirins and sticking plaster is not yet here, they believe it must still be the logical progression.

"That's really where we need to be, because if it is most effective when used 24 hours after unprotected sex (its effectiveness is reduced to 58% after 48 hours), we need women to have it to hand," said Ann Furedi of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service. "We're hoping it will come to be used as just another pharmacy product."

She believed there would be many women who asked the pharmacist for a packet in case they ever needed it, although most of those would be older, more affluent women since the cost will be £20 for the course of four pills, which are taken in pairs 12 hours apart. Under the guidelines being drawn up, unless women lie they are likely to be refused. She saw no place for interrogation of customers.

There have been two pilot projects, in Manchester and London, run by the Royal Pharmaceutical Society, in which demand for the pills was so great that the pharmacies were afraid to advertise their services in case they ran out of stocks. Exactly what the pharmacist will ask has still not been established. The society is setting up workshops for its members, and said they were likely to be told what information they needed to elicit, rather than what they should ask.

There was an immediate outcry yesterday to the revelation that pharmacists would be permitted to hand out the pill. "It does not at all sit in with my moral views as to what should happen," said Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary. "There are also very good questions healthwise as to whether it will encourage ever more teenage sexual activity, whether it will encourage people into unprotected sexual activity."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said he was alarmed and appalled. "Making the morning after pill available to all girls over 16 in this way sends the wrong message about the need for responsible sexual activity," he said.

But Jenny Tong, the Liberal Democrat MP for Richmond Park, said the announcement was excellent news which was long overdue. "As a family planning doctor for over 20 years before I came in to parliament I have campaigned long and hard for women to be able to control their fertility in this safe and effective way.

"It is not an abortion. It is very safe, and I hope it will prevent many unplanned pregnancies in the future."

webTitle: BBC to double spending on original kids' programmes

fields.headline: BBC to double spending on original kids' programmes
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC has promised to double spending on original children's programming to £100m a year, writes Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
The BBC has promised to double spending on original children's programming to £100m a year to support the expansion into two dedicated children's channels.

And the corporation stepped up lobbying this week for an early government go-ahead for the controversial plans.

A public consultation over its proposals, which would see a pre-school channel for the under-sixes launch in June or July, has found strong public support for the plans.

Up to 88% of adults back the concept of advertising-free UK-originated services, say corporation sources.

However, the channel proposals are subject to industry consultation, with heavy lobbying from dedicated commercial children's networks being led by the Disney channel's Paul Robinson.

This stiffer-than-expected opposition has clearly shaken the BBC.

A decision from culture secretary Chris Smith, whose approval is required, is expected in the new year.

The BBC's creative leader, Alan Yentob, CBBC controller Nigel Pickard, and editors of key programmes such as Blue Peter and Newsround held a reception at 4 Millbank this week to lobby for MPs' support.

The event took place on the evening of the Queen's speech in the presence of inflatable character guests including Bob the Builder, Big Ears, Noddy and Postman Pat, all due to figure prominiently in the new plans.

Mr Yentob and Mr Pickard point out that more than 50% of UK children live in multi-channel homes, where the electronic programme guide carries a separate children's category.

A BBC statement said: "They are being offered an endless diet of American programmes and constant repeats of American cartioons and sitcoms on predominantly US-owned channels.

"In this world of greater choice, the BBC believes children and their parents should have the option of choosing advertising-free programmes made in the UK for UK children".

The BBC points out that its investment in UK children's programmes dwarfs that of its rivals.

Mr Pickard said the new channels were designed to expand choice and capitalise on domestic production.

The pre-school channel is promising to screen at least 90% UK output, while the older channel will show 78%.

Teletubbies, Tweenies, Noddy, Postman Pat, Fireman Sam and Angelmouse will be buttressed with new programmes based on storytelling, music, 'make-and-do' craft ideas, puzzles, factual and natural history.

The older channel, which will take longer to prepare for launch, will have a twice-daily topical Newsround programme, a daily Blue Peter with spin-off formats such as Here's One I Made Earlier, and a big interactive element.

It will also repeat some of the best of the corporation's archive drama, including classics such as The Tales of Narnia,The Box of Delights and The Phoenix and the Carpet.

New ideas will be shared between the BBC1 and the new channels.

In the longer term, BBC2 is expected to discontinue its successful breakfast time repeats, and the 6-7pm kids' zone will also go.

webTitle: The final countdown

fields.headline: The final countdown
fields.standfirst: A decision seems to be imminent and the US press are still squabbling over where the election leaves the future of American democracy
fields.trailText: A decision seems to be imminent and Derek Brown finds the US press still squabbling over where the election leaves the future of American democracy.
fields.body:
The leader writers of America awoke this morning knowing that maybe, just maybe, they have had their last crack at pronouncing on the election rather than its outcome. They have made the best of it.

The Chicago Sun Times leaves no doubt where its heart lies, in congratulating the supreme court for stepping in to halt the recount: "The US supreme court fortunately has acted to rein in the out-of-control Florida soap opera. The divided 5-4 decision reflects the national divisions over the presidential race. But four justices of the Florida supreme court had left the nation's highest court with no choice.

"The 4-3 Florida decision had set off a mad scramble for dimpled chads, pregnant chads, hanging chads, this chad, that chad and any chad to determine who won the state's vital electoral votes. The Florida justices had recklessly ignored higher legal authority and the law to plunge the election and the future of the presidency into uncertainty and perhaps a constitutional crisis."

The Boston Globe, however, is deeply shocked by the supreme court's order to halt the recount: "When the stop order came, Florida judges and other personnel were busy reviewing ballots on which the machine counts had not recorded a vote for president.

"In a calm and orderly process - not the chaos that some republicans alleged - the recounters found that most of the ballots did indeed contain no presidential vote, or markings that were uncertain. But many scores of ballots did contain clear evidence of the voter's intent. Some were for Bush and some for Gore. That the supreme court would suddenly stop this most basic of democratic functions is shocking."

The paper says its confidence in the legal process has been shaken, and concludes, sadly: "When people are afraid to count the votes, democracy is in trouble."

The New York Post puts a robust tabloid boot in to the vice president, with a strident call to the supreme court to end the affair, one and for all: "This whole madness, after all, could have been avoided had Gore respected the results of the Nov 7 election, which showed Gov. George W. Bush as the winner. Or had Gore honored the machine recount, which reaffirmed those results.

"Or even the wrongly extended Nov 26 count, which also showed that Gore lost and which was subsequently certified by the state of Florida. Gore refused to honor those results. Instead, he called in his beloved lawyers and dragged the election into the courts, which he believed would help him whitewash his theft of the White House.

More mildly, the Miami Herald believes the court can bring "closure" to the election, and allow the nation to get on with its business: "Let's be clear. We aren't a nation in crisis. Our chief executive hasn't resigned as in Israel. We don't have a quarter of our country under the control of guerrillas as in Colombia.

"Nor are we trying to reinvent ourselves as in Russia. Despite competing interests and political ideologies, we are nothing in America if not a nation of laws. With a clear, well-reasoned decision the court can bring an end to the election and confirm our faith in the process."

Commenting from the heart of the electoral controversy, the Palm Beach Post urges the court to allow Florida officials to complete their examination of votes not yet counted. It chides republican lawyers for their double standards: "The final irony, of course, is that Mr Bush, who went to court first, has been so critical of 'letting the courts decide the election.' If he gets his way today, he will have placed his trust in the courts, not the voters."

The Washington Post points out, rather alarmingly, that it's not just Florida where US votes get overlooked: "For all the attention lavished on Florida, the drama of uncounted ballots also exists elsewhere. Across the country, some 2.5m ballots went uncounted in the presidential election, either because they were spoiled deliberately or because of some unintended error.

"Until this year, no presidential election had been disrupted by this fallout, and maybe no election will be this close again. But it would be wrong to rely on that; even without another dead-heat contest, the now widespread knowledge that about 2% of ballots get ignored hardly will encourage voter turnout.

"Add in evidence that ballots are most likely to be discounted in poor areas where the voting machinery is rickety, and you have strong reasons to worry about the nation's electoral mechanics."

webTitle: BBC news chief on shortlist for top Covent Garden job

fields.headline: BBC news chief on shortlist for top Covent Garden job
fields.standfirst:
Surprise contender for post of Royal Opera House executive director

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The head of BBC News, Tony Hall, has emerged as a surprise contender for the position of executive director at the Royal Opera House, write Tania Branigan and Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The head of BBC News, Tony Hall, has emerged as a surprise contender for the position of executive director at the Royal Opera House, thought by some to be a plum job but seen by others as a poisoned chalice.

He is understood to be on the shortlist drawn up by Covent Garden bosses after a lengthy and very public search for a head to replace Michael Kaiser, who leaves on Friday after only two years. Mr Kaiser's predecessors lasted just seven and five months.

High-profile figures, including John Tusa, who runs the Barbican, were mooted as possible replacements over the last few months, but Mr Hall's name only emerged yesterday. No one at Covent Garden would comment but a BBC spokeswoman yesterday confirmed he had been approached.

Mr Hall is thought to be tempted by the challenge after eight years in his present role. He applied for the job of director-general at the BBC last year, but was defeated by Greg Dyke. Although the two are said to get on well, insiders believe he may feel out of place in the new regime, prompting speculation that he planned to leave after the next election.

But aides said he would not necessarily take the job even if it were offered to him. "It would be pointless to deny there have been conversations, but Tony is happy doing the job he is doing," a BBC spokeswoman said.

"He gets a number of approaches from different organisations although not all of them are so high profile. It's no secret that he loves opera."

She added: "The notion of ill-feeling between him and Greg is nonsense. They enjoy an extremely good relationship."

Mr Hall leads a workforce of 2,500 in the BBC's largest department and is said to be extremely good at coping with pressure. Although he lacks the artistic background of the other candidates thought to be shortlisted, the opera house position is largely administrative and will become more so with the arrival of the musical director Antonio Pappano in 2002. Mr Pappano accepted the job on the condition that he was given total artistic control.

A spokesman for the opera house confirmed that a shortlist had been drawn up, but refused to say who was on it. The Sunday Times yesterday claimed that the other candidates were Pierre Audi, who founded London's Almeida Theatre but has spent the last 12 years as artistic director of the Netherlands Opera; Rudolf Berger of Strasbourg Opera; and Richard Lyttelton, president of EMI Classics.

Mr Lyttelton is an Old Etonian, known for commercial nous and his knowledge of classical music, and was responsible for signing Queen to EMI. He is said to be respected by Sir Colin Southgate, chairman of Covent Garden, who was chairman of EMI until 1999.

Sir Colin will work closely with whoever is appointed and there were rumours that he had clashed repeatedly with Mr Kaiser, hastening the latter's departure, although both sides have denied this.

Mr Kaiser's resignation to join the Kennedy Centre in Washington was a blow for the opera house, which seemed to be settling down after an turbulent patch in its affairs.

He cut prices and helped attract audiences to what has traditionally been seen as an elitist institution. Tensions remain within the organisation between those who want to widen its appeal and those who fear it may be "dumbed down".

The Opera House's spokes-man was yesterday coy about its deliberations, but said the final decision would "hopefully" be made by Christmas.

The board has not decided whether an interim appointment will be made, as even if the favoured candidate cannot join immediately, other staff may take over the executive director's responsibilities.

webTitle: BSkyB launches digital teletext service

fields.headline: BSkyB launches digital teletext service
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: BSkyB has launched its digital teletext service, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BSkyB has today launched its digital teletext service, more than two years after it first launched its digital TV service.

The necessary software to view the service, called Sky Text, was sent down to digital subscribers' boxes over the weekend.

BSkyB's 4m digital viewers should be able to access Sky Digital's text service simply by pressing the text button on their remote control.

Going against the grain, BSkyB has built its digital text service on Wap software, which partly accounts for why the launch was delayed.

Explaining the move, a spokesman for BSkyB said it was an easy way to add an interactive component to the basic text service.

"It's not a bells-and-whistles service but it shows the potential of screen-based Wap," he said.

Part of Sky Text's advantage over other digital teletext services is its return path, which, like Open, uses the telephone line to dial up at speeds of 28kb per second.

This has enabled Sky Digital to develop an on-screen betting service which will enable viewers to bet on sporting events while simultanously watching television.

While the service is based on Wap internet protocols, viewers will not be allowed to leave the confined space of the Sky Text pages and browse the rest of the web.

However, Sky Text will offer more than 1,200 pages of news, sport, entertainment and information, and eventually email.

Jon Florsheim, BSkyB group director of sales and distribution, said: "By integrating online services within the broadcast environment, the launch of Sky Text and TV betting brings a new dimension to Sky digital's interactive offering."

On the interactive TV side, Sky Digital now has four separate services: Open, Sky Sports Active, Sky News Active and Sky Text.

webTitle: Vodafone renews cricket sponsorship deal

fields.headline: Vodafone in £12m English cricket sponsorship deal
fields.trailText: 2pm: Vodafone has renewed its sponsorship deal with English cricket in a deal worth £12m, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Vodafone has agreed to plough at least £12m into English cricket over the next four years after renewing its sponsorship of the national cricket team.

The mobile phone company has sponsored English cricket for since 1996 and has put money into the England women's team and the County Challenge matches as well as the England A team.

Tim Brown, Vodafone director of corporate affairs, said: "The close co-operation that we have enjoyed with the English team and management over the past three years has been a key factor in the extensive media exposure that we have received."

Terry Blake, commercial director at the England Cricket Board, added: "The involvement of a company the size and standing of Vodafone in the game of cricket is very important to us.

"Their support enables vital funding of new initiatives and existing programmes which will help English cricket to compete at the very highest level over the next few years."

The new contract comes into effect on October 1 2001 and runs until 2005. It will cover two Ashes series and one World Cup.

webTitle: Clinton and Blair to visit Warwick University

fields.headline: Clinton and Blair to visit Warwick University
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton will visit Warwick University this Thursday as part of his last visit to the UK as US president.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton will visit Warwick University this Thursday as part of his last visit to the UK as US president.

Accompanied by the First Lady and Senator Elect Hillary Clinton and their daughter Chelsea Clinton, the president selected Warwick on the advice of officials at Number 10 Downing street.

During a recent White house briefing, the president's national security adviser, Sandy Berger, said: "Warwick University is one of Britain's newest and finest research universities, singled out by Prime Minister Blair as a model both of academic excellence and independence from the government."

It is also understood that the prime minister will join Clinton at Warwick, after the leaders have finished their meeting at Chequers.

Unusually for a UK university, Warwick puts as much focus on attracting income from private sources such as business, charities and postgraduate fees, as it does from government funding schemes. The university last month appointed the US born Professor David VandeLinde as its next vice-chancellor.

The Clinton family has strong connections with Oxford university, with rumours that the president's daughter Chelsea Clinton will follow her father and study at the country's oldest institution.

The president will address an invited audience in the university's arts centre, the largest performing and visual arts venue outside of London. It is understood that Clinton will speak about debt relief and the AIDS epidemic.

webTitle: Walker states 'time has come' to quit

fields.headline: Walker reveals 'gut feeling' behind retirement
fields.standfirst:
Dec 11: Voice of Formula One to retire
Comment: 50 years in motorsport
fields.trailText:
Dec 11: Murray Walker, the voice of Formula One on TV, said his decision to retire came from a gut feeling that "the time had come". By Jason Deans.

Dec 11: Voice of Formula One to retire

Comment: 50 years in motorsport
fields.body:
Murray Walker, the voice of Formula One on TV, said his decision to retire from ITV's motor-racing commentary team came from a gut feeling that "the time had come".

Mr Walker said today of his decision to stop commentating on Formula One at the end of the 2001 season: "I just woke up one morning recently and thought 'that's it, the time has come'.

"I will be 78 years old at the end of the 2001 season. I will have been commentating on Formula One and other motor sport for 52 years. I just felt now is the time to stop."

Mr Walker said the decision had nothing to do with his health, although he has had both hips replaced.

He said: "I like to think I'm always ahead of the game mentally, though I know a lot of people think I'm not."

Brian Barwick, ITV controller of sport, said Mr Walker's Formula One commentary colleague James Allen would be given the "first opportunity" to fill the veteran broadcaster's boots.

Mr Allen, who does pit lane reports for ITV on Grand Prix days, stood in for Mr Walker as the main race commentator during the French Grand Prix earlier this year.

Mr Barwick said: "James Allen picked up the baton at short notice and did a great job. He will get his opportunity next year ahead of, and above and beyond, any other candidate we may wish to consider."

He also hinted that Mr Walker may continue to be part of the ITV F1 presentation team after next year.

"I hope not to lose Murray totally from our coverage. I hope his wealth of knowledge will pop up elsewhere, outside the commentary box," he added.

Mr Barwick also paid tribute to Mr Walker, saying: "We are losing a unique character, someone who has been synonymous with his sport. ITV Sport owes a debt of gratitude to Murray."

Mr Walker said that after he retired from the ITV commentary team he hoped to write a book about his experiences.
