webTitle: Sunshine greets a productive day

fields.headline: Sunshine greets a productive day
fields.standfirst: GP Prue Peart describes the makeshift camps, which offer sanctuary to rising tide of refugees, in her lastest diary entry
fields.trailText: GP Prue Peart describes the makeshift camps, which offer sanctuary to rising tide of refugees, in her lastest diary entry
fields.body:
December 3, 2000
High winds during the night have cleared away the cloud, making way for bright morning sunshine. Engineer Baqi, one of Ockenden's full-time Afghan employees, arrives back in Herat this morning after travelling for four days from Peshawar in Pakistan; it makes me appreciate how lucky I was to be able to jump on a plane.

There are no delays in getting a truck and two labourers for the distribution of kitchen sets to Rawazabagh camp. The Danish Afghan Committee responsible for helping to run the camp has already distributed kitchen sets (a cooking pot and a large mixing bowl) to 539 families, but has run out, so asks us for help.

At the camp each family has a laminated card detailing the number of children, whether there is a working man in the family, the number of disabled people, etc. A man with a loudspeaker announces each family and someone comes forward, gives a thumbprint and can then collect their pots. A large number of women and children gather with the men to observe the proceedings. If a woman holds up the card she is not asked for her thumb print as this would mean being touched by a man, but is handed the pots after a man has "signed" for her. It is a great feeling to see the women and children taking their pots and heading towards their tents. Wandering around the camp later I see many of the families in the tents that have become their refuge and can see why they are so keen to get what we have to offer; for many the only other cooking utensils they have are old tins, far too small for the average family of seven.

Having seen the smooth organisation of the distribution of kitchen sets, Stuart and I go to a meeting with the agencies involved at Mazalagh camp to talk about registration there. It is unclear how many families are presently in Mazalagh, but one thing that is certain is that the number is growing daily. There are thought to be around 2,000 families there, but this is only an estimate.

We also talk about the problems the UN is having trying to get wheat into Herat. We are on the western border of a land-locked country so the wheat, brought in through Pakistan, can take more than two weeks to reach Herat. There are many informal taxes asked for along the way and it is getting increasingly difficult to negotiate with the drivers taking wheat across the country.

This afternoon I attend a World Health Organisation meeting where all the agencies involved in healthcare in the camps present their findings for the week. The clinics try to keep records of what diseases they see. There have been a few cases of measles, bloody diarrhoea and some severe malnutrition identified. There was a break out of cholera, but this has now all been contained. There is a system of referral to the local hospital for emergencies and displaced people are treated for free; some good news, at least.

webTitle: Relief work starts in earnest

fields.headline: Relief work starts in earnest
fields.standfirst: Missile threat feels very real as thoughts turn to providing shelter and warmth, GP Prue Peart writes in her lastest diary entry
fields.trailText:
November 29, 2000
Back at home in Islamabad, I am awoken at 2.15am by an unexpected phone call from a confused friend in Manchester who mumbles, "Oh, I'm sorry, I forgot about the time difference." After getting back to sleep, the alarm clock then wakes me a few short hours later and I get ready for my second trip into Afghanistan.
fields.body:
November 29, 2000
Back at home in Islamabad, I am awoken at 2.15am by an unexpected phone call from a confused friend in Manchester who mumbles, "Oh, I'm sorry, I forgot about the time difference." After getting back to sleep, the alarm clock then wakes me a few short hours later and I get ready for my second trip into Afghanistan.

Although it is still dark outside, the nearby mosque has already called for fasting to begin on the fourth day of Ramazan (Ramadan). The Pakistani newspaper in Islamabad is carrying headlines about the Russians helping the Americans to launch a missile attack on Afghanistan, and there is also a piece about the Taliban stopping all flights in and out of the country a few days before. This is a great start! Security remains the highest priority for people working in Afghanistan, and the threat of missiles feels very real to me as I get ready to travel across the border.

Despite the headlines, the flight with the UN is straightforward - two hours to Kandahar, an airport with the cleanest bathroom in Afghanistan. And then another hour across featureless desert and snowy mountains to Herat. I am the only woman on the flight.

Once in Herat I am met by a driver and a member of Ockenden's field staff who updates me on the relief programme. Since I left, the team has managed to find a woman prepared to work with Ockenden, but she has not yet started as none of the men are able to speak to her. This will be one of my first tasks.

Ockenden's approach is to establish work that will provide money and/or food to those who have moved from other parts of Afghanistan to escape the drought. The work is based on producing quilts and shelters to keep people warm as they try to sleep in makeshift camps in below zero temperatures.

I am told that there are already four tailors busy sewing in Mazlagh camp (the newest UN camp to be established and where we are doing most of the shelter building) producing quilt covers. A number of covers are now waiting for women to be given the job of filling them. But it will take a woman to get women involved in this way, so there is a bit of a hold-up here, too.

We are aiming to complete 5,000 quilts within the next six weeks, but we are coming up against seemingly simple dilemmas, such as: how big should each one be? The cloth we are buying locally is 2.5m wide, but not much is available in the bazaar. So can we make do with material that is 1.5m wide instead and buy twice as much? It sounds ridiculous, but these are the practical issues that can slow down the implementation of a plan. And while the decisions are being made, the price in Herat continues to increase as the traders realise there are lots of aid agencies looking for cloth. Even here market forces have an important part to play.

As for cotton, which is used as the stuffing, even that is in short supply as a direct result of the drought. We are currently waiting for some poorer quality Russian cotton - we need 18 metric tonnes to fill the 5,000 quilts - and feel this is the only practical option open to us.

When I arrived this morning Stuart Templeton, Ockenden's relief programme manager, and all the field officers were away, busy distributing 1,000 stoves and 1,000 jerry-cans (each containing 10 litres of kerosene) to some of the families in Mazlagh camp. The ministry of martyrs and refugees (MMR) worked hard to see that the distribution was done as fairly as possible. When I finally see the team they are exhausted but pleased to see things finally moving.

So, my first evening back in Afghanistan is spent like the rest will probably be, huddled around a smelly heater - our only source of heat and light - catching up with news and stories.

We have an early start tomorrow and plan to take cooking pots and buckets to Rawabagh camp for distribution.

webTitle: Murray Walker to retire

fields.headline: Voice of Formula One to retire
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Murray Walker, the voice of Formula One, is to retire from his job at the end of the 2001 season, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Murray Walker, the voice of Formula One, is to retire from his job at the end of the 2001 season.

He had become as famous for his television malapropisms as for his encyclopaedic knowledge of the sport, with remarks such as, "Do my eyes deceive me or is Senna's car sounding a bit rough?".

But critics have claimed he has become worse in the past few years and suggested he should retire.

Walker, who has been covering the sport for 51 years, reacted bitterly to a recent article in the Daily Mail which accused him of being like Albert Steptoe.

Mr Walker worked for the BBC for 40 years before shocking the TV establishment by joining ITV when it bought the rights to Grand Prix racing three years ago.

After fighting in the second world war, he worked in the advertising industry where he worked as a copywriter for petfood and confectionery products.

ITV is to announce the name of his replacement today.

webTitle: Deepening food crisis heightens sense of urgency

fields.headline: Deepening food crisis heightens sense of urgency
fields.standfirst: Radio mention of charity's progress helps boost morale as ongoing daily frustrations continue to hamper programme, writes Prue Peart
fields.trailText: Radio mention of charity's progress helps boost morale as ongoing daily frustrations continue to hamper programme, writes Prue Peart
fields.body:
December 4, 2000
I had a bit of a panic in the middle of the night when I woke up with slight stomach pain and convinced myself it must be appendicitis. I spent some time trying to think about whether the International Committee of the Red Cross would medi-vac me or whether I would have to brave an operation in Herat hospital - not a comforting thought! Some of this hysteria may have been caused by the previous evening of chatting to the Medicins sans Frontiere doctor about conditions on Herat's paediatric ward.

Also the UN security man has just returned from leave, so everyone was talking about security here and the problems with leaving. However, I must have gone back to sleep because I wake up again at 7.15am with my stomach feeling fine!!

Visit Shadhee and Minaret 1 & 2 camps this morning with a field officer and the brother of one of the female health workers working with Ockenden. It is a preliminary visit to seek permission for the quilt-making to take place and to ask if the names of four tailors in each camp can be found along with around 200 women to help stuff the quilts. Shadhee camp, a very bumpy 25-minute drive away, is run by MMR (the Ministry of Martyrs and Refugees) because it is simply too big for other specialist agencies.

Shadhee is a chaotic camp, which recently had an outbreak of cholera (well-contained by the MSF cholera camp) but it is difficult to get accurate figures on the numbers living in the camps as there is still movement between them. Estimates range between 2,000 and 3,000 families living in this particular camp.

Have a discussion with the man in charge of the camp but do not make much progress and he asks us to return tomorrow to speak to the elders; he does not think we are planning on using enough people to stuff the number of quilts needed.

When we reach the Minaret camps, which are both small camps inside the city, I am advised to stay in the car as the Taliban in charge does not want me to get out. We are also asked to return later today to talk to the man with responsibility for the camp. Yet another frustrating result.

There is one piece of good news, however. Radio Herat - the only radio station available - last night broadcast the details of Ockenden International's distributions in the camps so far. This is a real boost to our morale and is taken as a sign of approval of our efforts.

Since I have been here a member of Ockenden's team has gone regularly to see the cotton seller to find out if the stuffing has arrived from Russia. Without it the project will not progress at the rate we would like. Every day he comes back empty handed.

At least there is better news on the blanket front. After 10 days of promises the blanket merchant finally turns up to see us. So on Thursday we are planning a distribution of 625 blankets to Rawazabagh camp. Progress at last.

Later in the day I learn that I will be leaving Herat on a Red Cross plane tomorrow morning. A UN flight is more convenient as they fly from Islamabad, but they charge for each journey. The advantage of flying with the Red Cross is that we will not be charged for the trip, but the disadvantage is that I will end up in Peshawar rather than Islamabad. So I will have another journey (a good three hours by road) ahead of me before reaching the relative comfort of home.

Finally I attend the weekly UN co-ordination meeting with Stuart. The meeting is chaired by another newcomer to Herat, the third in less than six weeks, and inevitably there has been criticism of the lack of co-ordination and response from UN agencies.

In the meeting, we discuss a range of topics from problems within specific camps to the huge shortage of food in Afghanistan. The World Health Programme is not receiving wheat from a variety of governments around the world and the existing stocks will run out in February, five months before the next harvest is due. The general feeling is that there are simply not enough resources being put into preventing a huge disaster here.

Families continue to arrive daily from the drought stricken areas, and are all heading for camps in Herat because they hear of the food being given by the UN. Their struggle for survival is natural, but it is exacerbating the problem. Solutions need to be found quickly.

 Look out for Prue's next diary report and follow her progress in Afghanistan

Estimates range between 2,000 and 3,000 families living in this particular camp. Have a discussion with the man in charge of the camp but do not make much progress and he asks us to return tomorrow to speak to the elders; he does not think we are planning on using enough people to stuff the number of quilts needed. When we reach the Minaret camps, which are both small camps inside the city, I am advised to stay in the car as the Taliban in charge does not want me to get out. We are also asked to return later today to talk to the man with responsibility for the camp. Yet another frustrating result. There is one piece of good news, however. Radio Herat - the only radio station available - last night broadcast the details of Ockenden International's distributions in the camps so far. This is a real boost to our morale and is taken as a sign of approval of our efforts. Since I have been here a member of Ockenden's team has gone regularly to see the cotton seller to find out if the stuffing has arrived from Russia. Without it the project will not progress at the rate we would like. Every day he comes back empty handed. At least there is better news on the blanket front. After 10 days of promises the blanket merchant finally turns up to see us. So on Thursday we are planning a distribution of 625 blankets to Rawazabagh camp. Progress at last. Later in the day I learn that I will be leaving Herat on a Red Cross plane tomorrow morning. A UN flight is more convenient as they fly from Islamabad, but they charge for each journey. The advantage of flying with the Red Cross is that we will not be charged for the trip, but the disadvantage is that I will end up in Peshawar rather than Islamabad. So I will have another journey (a good three hours by road) ahead of me before reaching the relative comfort of home. Finally I attend the weekly UN co-ordination meeting with Stuart. The World Health Programme is not receiving wheat from a variety of governments around the world and the existing stocks will run out in February, five months before the next harvest is due. The general feeling is that there are simply not enough resources being put into preventing a huge disaster here. Families continue to arrive daily from the drought stricken areas, and are all heading for camps in Herat because they hear of the food being given by the UN. Their struggle for survival is natural, but it is exacerbating the problem. Solutions need to be found quickly.  Look out for Prue's next diary report and follow her progress in Afghanistan

webTitle: Walker: more than 50 years in commentating

fields.headline: Walker: half a century in commentating
fields.standfirst:
Dec 11: Walker reveals 'gut feeling' behind retirement
Dec 11: Voice of Formula One to retire
fields.trailText:
December 11: Murray Walker cut his teeth as a sports commentator back in 1949, covering the British Grand Prix at Silverstone for BBC Radio. By Jessica Hodgson.

December 11: Walker reveals 'gut feeling' behind retirement

Dec 11: Voice of Formula One to retire
fields.body:
Murray Walker cut his teeth as a sports commentator back in 1949, covering the British Grand Prix at Silverstone for BBC Radio.

From this point, the ever-growing crescendo of his high-pitched voice has been as central to the sport as the screeching of tyres on tarmac.

Mr Walker was born into a family of motor-racing fanatics - his father was also a motor-racing correspondent and they worked together until Walker senior's death in 1962.

However, after returning from a distinguished spell driving tanks during the second world war, he worked in advertising, where he was partly responsible for the Mars "Work, Rest and Play" campaign, and helped defend the market-leading bird-seed brand Trill against falling foul of the Monopolies Commission.

Mr Walker left advertising to follow in his father's footsteps, leading to a career spanning almost 51 years commentating on motor-racing and particularly Formula One.

In 1978 he entered the premier league of sports commentators when the BBC began televising every Grand Prix race, and Mr Walker's name and voice became synonymous with the BBC's coverage.

Formula One rights owner Bernie Ecclestone once gave Mr Walker a gold tie-pin, proclaiming that he "was the BBC".

His coverage of racing has been characterised by three things; his knowledge; his high-pitched voice, which becomes more excited as the tension on the track mounts; and his propensity for verbal gaffes.

Dubbed Muddly Talker, his more nonsensical remarks knock George W Bush and Danforth Quayle into a cocked hat. These included "I imagine that the conditions in those cars today are totally unimaginable," and "The atmosphere is so tense you could cut it with a cricket stump".

It was a shock, both to Mr Walker and to motor-racing fans, when ITV scooped the rights to the sport three years ago.

He has defended himself robustly against recent claims in the Daily Mail that his verbal gaffes were getting worse, but at the age of 77, the time was right to hand over to a younger man.

Saying his official goodbye at today's press conference, Mr Walker said his most glorious moments in motor-racing were watching British drivers such as James Hunt take the Grand Prix.

His replacement at ITV, James Allen, faces an uphill struggle. Maybe the next generation of motor racing commentators can carve out a niche for coherent reportage free from malapropisms. But the Muddly Talker will be sadly missed.

webTitle: Media Guardian: Trinity Mirror launches showbiz wesbite

fields.headline: Do we need 24-hour gossip?
fields.standfirst:
Trinity Mirror is launching a showbiz website that will have no qualms about scooping its own newspapers. But can it succeed where others failed? Jessica Hodgson reports

Net news
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror is launching a showbiz website that will have no qualms about scooping its own newspapers. But can it succeed where others failed? Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
OK! magazine's injunction on Hello! in the Douglas/Zeta Jones pictures row could become an anachronism if the hunger for showbiz gossip starts to creep into cyberspace. If your rival has beaten you to the big picture exclusive, all you have to do is publish online. At least that's the hope that Trinity Mirror executives are pinning on their new showbiz website, icShowbiz.

icShowbiz.com is the second of Trinity Mirror's portals within the ic network, and the first major marketing splash for any of the websites within the network. For Rebecca St Johnston, managing director of content, it's a case of filling a "gaping hole" in the UK market. "Sites such as Eonline and Mr Showbiz are immensely popular in the US. Some sites here focus exhaustively on film or music and others take the view that celebrity means the upper-crust celebrity gossip column circuit. But there hasn't been a compelling celebrity gossip site in the UK until now."

icShowbiz.com apes the successful stateside gossip sites rather than Trinity Mirror's newspaper brands. The 3AM column is there, with a Daily Record gossip section called Off The Record and Charlie Catchpole's TV reviews. There are bespoke columns from Jonathan Ross, therapist to the stars Susan Quilliam, and extra content from Mirror writers such as Jessica Mellor and Ian Hyland, and the People's Sean O'Brien. But, stylistically, icShowbiz.com borrows more from OK! and Hello! than the newspapers.

Jane Procter, managing director of gossip website Peoplenews, and Tatler editor for nine years, has also staked her livelihood on the belief that the desire for celebrity gossip in magazines and newspapers will translate to cyberspace. Procter is something of a celebrity gossip evangelist. "Research shows that 40% of people between 20 and 30 would postpone their own wedding to go to a celebrity party. They say because we haven't got a cold war on, all people care about is Catherine Zeta-Jones."

Procter says the "epiphany" that brought home the importance of the internet in the showbiz wars was the announcement of Madonna's pregnancy earlier this year. "I remember thinking 'If the Sun has got it and they're putting it on the web at 2.40 in the afternoon then they've obviously taken a calculated decision that it's not going to damage sales'".

St Johnston and Trinity Mirror Digital's managing director, David Clarke, feel that the ability to update the site 24 hours a day gives them a unique ability to capitalise on readers' interest in the day's breaking celebrity news.

"There's no limit to the amount of space we use," says St Johnston. "So if the Mirror is running a picture exclusive on a 12-page feature, they may only be able to run two pages of pictures - in which case we can run the rest." She adds that icShowbiz.com is prepared to fight for the right to break big showbiz exclusives on the site, at the risk of scooping the Trinity Mirror national papers.

It's worth noting that in spite of Procter's optimism about the market for celebrity gossip, Peoplenews axed its chief executive, Kelly Moulton, two editorial staff and several technical staff in November. Although she claims the venture is on target to make profit very soon, there is speculation that funding may have dried up.

Johnston also believes developments in mobile services will dovetail nicely with the growing appetite for gossip. "People waiting for the bus want something to fill in the time. Mobile is the ultimate time killer."

Trinity Mirror's huge regional newspaper network, with access to the archives of papers including the Daily Record and Scottish Mail, the Birmingham Post and Mail, and Liverpool Echo, adds opportunities not just for compelling local content but for e-commerce partnerships. "If you want to find out where your nearest ATM is, or you want to book a table at a Chinese restaurant, mobile is excellent, and we can provide really compelling local content."

ic24 has excellent mapping and directory facilities, allowing users, for example, to look for cinema listings for their area, then search for an online map and directions for how to get there from their home address.

But whether this strategy will translate itself into online audiences, and more importantly, online revenues, remains to be seen. Ben Hedges, former head of sales for what was Trinity Mirror New Media and now managing director for new media training consultancy It Counts, adds that although celebrity is a big audience pull, it doesn't necessarily translate into cash.

"I can see there's a good argument for having 24-hour, constantly updated information about showbiz online. But at the end of the day, if I've got an update on what Posh and Becks are calling their next baby - so what? How are you going to make money from that? OK! and Hello! have built their success on appealing to very aspirational, lifestyle advertisers who aren't interested in online at the moment."

In the wake of high-profile dot.com failures many newspaper groups have retreated from previously bullish internet strategies, cutting back online operations to the point where many have little more than an online marketing presence.

And with the exception of Mega Star, now floating in a no-man's land in United Business Media amid speculation that it may be sold off, there's little competition from Trinity Mirror's tabloid rivals.

Trinity Mirror was the last of the big newspaper groups to jump into the digital fray. Earlier this year, it trumpeted a £150m investment into ic24, an ISP which aims to be the "people's doorway to the internet", a friendly, handholding service with a one-size-fits-all brand.

Last month Trinity Mirror unveiled the first of its long-touted portals, icScotland. The 16 promised when the investment was announced have dwindled to four, with icSports, icChoice and icRegional to follow next year.

But after the spectacular rise and fall of Currantbun.com and the ensuing chaos of News International's digital strategy, the logic of launching another "welcome to the internet" portal is being questioned. Clarke defends the strategy. "We have to be able to provide everything we want in one set of sites," he says.

The silence from Trinity Mirror's key competitors in this space, News International and Express Newspapers, is deafening. No one from News International would speak to the Guardian about the company's online operations.

But one anonymous News International executive is sceptical about Trinity Mirror's strategy. "I'd question the viability of any content-driven website relying on advertising revenue," he says. "News International's online presence is purely a marketing tool - we want to encourage people to buy the papers. The Trinity Mirror strategy is to create a new online brand and generate revenue."

Given News International's failure to capitalise on its early lead in online plus rumours that auction site Fired up and recruitment service Revolver are facing the axe, this could be seen as sour grapes. But people who know how advertisers behave online are also dubious about Trinity Mirror's approach.

Nick Suckley, managing director of digital media agency Beyond Interactive (formerly Media21) believes Trinity Mirror is missing a trick by failing to use its best asset - its newspaper brands. "You have to ask 'What does the Daily Mirror stand for?' and everyone will have a view on that. Instead they're saying 'Let's launch into a very competitive market with a product no one's heard of.' There's a lot of consumer goodwill towards the Mirror but they're not capitalising on it."

Clarke is adamant that Trinity Mirror has to look at the longer haul and invest in a coherent online brand. "If we went down the road of having newspaper branded sites all the sites would look different to the different sets of users," he says. "The demographics of the Mirror - which is our best-known brand - don't fit the demographics of online users. At the moment most users are ABC1, although that is going to change. The Mirror's audience is largely C2."

He adds that for Trinity Mirror's business model - split revenues from advertising and e-commerce but with advertising initially accounting for over 90% - it's important to be able to sell across a network of identically-branded sites. "We have seen from examples in the US that the bigger advertising and e-commerce deals migrate to the people with the biggest volume of traffic. Independent sites tend to struggle if you take them out of the larger mix."

He concludes that only when the network of sites is up and running will Trinity Mirror be able to make a decision on whether the approach has been successful, although he is adamant that the business will be in profit when the funding runs out at the end of 2002.

At least that's the hope that Trinity Mirror executives are pinning on their new showbiz website, icShowbiz.com. icShowbiz.com is the second of Trinity Mirror's portals within the ic network, and the first major marketing splash for any of the websites within the network. For Rebecca St Johnston, managing director of content, it's a case of filling a "gaping hole" in the UK market. "Sites such as Eonline and Mr Showbiz are immensely popular in the US. Some sites here focus exhaustively on film or music and others take the view that celebrity means the upper-crust celebrity gossip column circuit. But there hasn't been a compelling celebrity gossip site in the UK until now." icShowbiz.com apes the successful stateside gossip sites rather than Trinity Mirror's newspaper brands. The 3AM column is there, with a Daily Record gossip section called Off The Record and Charlie Catchpole's TV reviews. There are bespoke columns from Jonathan Ross, therapist to the stars Susan Quilliam, and extra content from Mirror writers such as Jessica Mellor and Ian Hyland, and the People's Sean O'Brien. But, stylistically, icShowbiz.com borrows more from OK! and Hello! than the newspapers. Jane Procter, managing director of gossip website Peoplenews, and Tatler editor for nine years, has also staked her livelihood on the belief that the desire for celebrity gossip in magazines and newspapers will translate to cyberspace. Procter is something of a celebrity gossip evangelist. "Research shows that 40% of people between 20 and 30 would postpone their own wedding to go to a celebrity party. They say because we haven't got a cold war on, all people care about is Catherine Zeta-Jones." Procter says the "epiphany" that brought home the importance of the internet in the showbiz wars was the announcement of Madonna's pregnancy earlier this year. "I remember thinking 'If the Sun has got it and they're putting it on the web at 2.40 in the afternoon then they've obviously taken a calculated decision that it's not going to damage sales'". St Johnston and Trinity Mirror Digital's managing director, David Clarke, feel that the ability to update the site 24 hours a day gives them a unique ability to capitalise on readers' interest in the day's breaking celebrity news. "There's no limit to the amount of space we use," says St Johnston. "So if the Mirror is running a picture exclusive on a 12-page feature, they may only be able to run two pages of pictures - in which case we can run the rest." She adds that icShowbiz.com is prepared to fight for the right to break big showbiz exclusives on the site, at the risk of scooping the Trinity Mirror national papers. It's worth noting that in spite of Procter's optimism about the market for celebrity gossip, Peoplenews axed its chief executive, Kelly Moulton, two editorial staff and several technical staff in November. Although she claims the venture is on target to make profit very soon, there is speculation that funding may have dried up. Johnston also believes developments in mobile services will dovetail nicely with the growing appetite for gossip. "People waiting for the bus want something to fill in the time. Mobile is the ultimate time killer." Trinity Mirror's huge regional newspaper network, with access to the archives of papers including the Daily Record and Scottish Mail, the Birmingham Post and Mail, and Liverpool Echo, adds opportunities not just for compelling local content but for e-commerce partnerships. "If you want to find out where your nearest ATM is, or you want to book a table at a Chinese restaurant, mobile is excellent, and we can provide really compelling local content." ic24 has excellent mapping and directory facilities, allowing users, for example, to look for cinema listings for their area, then search for an online map and directions for how to get there from their home address. But whether this strategy will translate itself into online audiences, and more importantly, online revenues, remains to be seen. Ben Hedges, former head of sales for what was Trinity Mirror New Media and now managing director for new media training consultancy It Counts, adds that although celebrity is a big audience pull, it doesn't necessarily translate into cash. "I can see there's a good argument for having 24-hour, constantly updated information about showbiz online. But at the end of the day, if I've got an update on what Posh and Becks are calling their next baby - so what? How are you going to make money from that? OK! and Hello! have built their success on appealing to very aspirational, lifestyle advertisers who aren't interested in online at the moment." In the wake of high-profile dot.com failures many newspaper groups have retreated from previously bullish internet strategies, cutting back online operations to the point where many have little more than an online marketing presence. And with the exception of Mega Star, now floating in a no-man's land in United Business Media amid speculation that it may be sold off, there's little competition from Trinity Mirror's tabloid rivals. Trinity Mirror was the last of the big newspaper groups to jump into the digital fray. Earlier this year, it trumpeted a £150m investment into ic24, an ISP which aims to be the "people's doorway to the internet", a friendly, handholding service with a one-size-fits-all brand. Last month Trinity Mirror unveiled the first of its long-touted portals, icScotland. The 16 promised when the investment was announced have dwindled to four, with icSports, icChoice and icRegional to follow next year. But after the spectacular rise and fall of Currantbun.com and the ensuing chaos of News International's digital strategy, the logic of launching another "welcome to the internet" portal is being questioned. Clarke defends the strategy. "We have to be able to provide everything we want in one set of sites," he says. The silence from Trinity Mirror's key competitors in this space, News International and Express Newspapers, is deafening. No one from News International would speak to the Guardian about the company's online operations. But one anonymous News International executive is sceptical about Trinity Mirror's strategy. "I'd question the viability of any content-driven website relying on advertising revenue," he says. "News International's online presence is purely a marketing tool - we want to encourage people to buy the papers. The Trinity Mirror strategy is to create a new online brand and generate revenue." Given News International's failure to capitalise on its early lead in online plus rumours that auction site Firedup.com and recruitment service Revolver.com are facing the axe, this could be seen as sour grapes. But people who know how advertisers behave online are also dubious about Trinity Mirror's approach. Nick Suckley, managing director of digital media agency Beyond Interactive (formerly Media21) believes Trinity Mirror is missing a trick by failing to use its best asset - its newspaper brands. "You have to ask 'What does the Daily Mirror stand for?' and everyone will have a view on that. Instead they're saying 'Let's launch into a very competitive market with a product no one's heard of.' There's a lot of consumer goodwill towards the Mirror but they're not capitalising on it." Clarke is adamant that Trinity Mirror has to look at the longer haul and invest in a coherent online brand. "If we went down the road of having newspaper branded sites all the sites would look different to the different sets of users," he says. "The demographics of the Mirror - which is our best-known brand - don't fit the demographics of online users. At the moment most users are ABC1, although that is going to change. The Mirror's audience is largely C2." He adds that for Trinity Mirror's business model - split revenues from advertising and e-commerce but with advertising initially accounting for over 90% - it's important to be able to sell across a network of identically-branded sites. "We have seen from examples in the US that the bigger advertising and e-commerce deals migrate to the people with the biggest volume of traffic. Independent sites tend to struggle if you take them out of the larger mix." He concludes that only when the network of sites is up and running will Trinity Mirror be able to make a decision on whether the approach has been successful, although he is adamant that the business will be in profit when the funding runs out at the end of 2002.

webTitle: Relief effort battles dogma and drought

fields.headline: Relief effort battles dogma and drought
fields.standfirst: In the first of a series of diary reports, 31-year-old GP Prue Peart describes the hope and frustration she encounters working for a charity relief programme in a drought-stricken Taliban controlled region of Afghanistan
fields.trailText: In the first of a series of diary reports, 31-year-old GP Prue Peart describes the hope and frustration she encounters working for a charity relief programme in a drought-stricken Taliban controlled region of Afghanistan
fields.body:
Preliminary visit
My contract in Herat - a Taliban-controlled region of western Afghanistan - is with UK charity Ockenden International and follows my year working as a GP in Islamabad. Herat is suffering its worst drought in living memory and I am one of a team working to ensure that Ockenden's emergency aid reaches the people who need it most.

I first went to Herat three weeks ago with Stuart Templeton, who is overseeing Ockenden International's relief programme. The programme is aiming to prevent this drought developing into a major crisis. If it is not successful, so much good work will be undone in a country whose people have already suffered so much.

This first visit was filled with frustration. Most of the time was spent trying to find an Afghan woman with whom to work. I failed. I did meet a number of women who would have been great, but the Afghan authorities have very strict rules on women working and it is very difficult to overcome these. The women themselves, of course, are also nervous of breaking the law.

Even if one of the women I met did agree to work with me, she would have been unable to come to the office or travel with me in an Ockenden vehicle. And she would have to be accompanied by a male relative aged over 15. The logistics would have been a nightmare, so I soon realised I would have to go it alone, getting help along the way.

Indeed, if a woman is from an educated family still living in Herat, there is little chance of her having any unemployed male relatives who would be able to accompany her. Ockenden (and the other agencies working here) all say how difficult it is to recruit skilled personnel in Herat. As well as the shortage of resources such as water, electricity, gas and petrol, skills are also in short supply, hindering the development and rejuvenation of Afghanistan.

During my first visit I was able to talk to a number of women in their homes. That's the real privilege of being a foreign woman in Afghanistan - you get to see a little bit of both "sides". I also met one young woman at her English class. The English teacher had been suggested as a possible woman to work with, but it came to nothing. However, one of her students expressed an interest so I went to the class to meet her. But I did not expect to hold our rather covert conversation in front of the rest of the class - who thought it would be a good way to practise their English! But then this was Afghanistan, and stranger things happen.

webTitle: Interview with BBC2 controller Jane Root

fields.headline: And now on 2...
fields.standfirst:
The wind of change is blowing through BBC2. Maggie Brown asks controller Jane Root about her future plans

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The wind of change is blowing through BBC2. Maggie Brown asks controller Jane Root about her future plans
fields.body:
So BBC2 is being repositioned?

Yes. We're in the process of thinking about the whole suite of BBC channels, in terms of the digital future, where channels will have to be clearer propositions.

So what will BBC2 be?

Clever, sophisticated, upmarket, an enjoyable channel_

Aimed at the over-35s?

Thirty-five will be the centre of gravity for BBC2, in time. It will be a gradual transition.

Two, three years?

Possibly more. In time we will stop doing youth niche programmes, young-skewed music programmes. Choice has already taken over World Clubbing from us, which would traditionally have been a BBC2 programme.

In a four-channel world, BBC2 was a minority channel; it mopped up what BBC1 didn't do. In a 505-channel world we're a big, mainstream channel. If you look at what the US networks get in terms of audience share, we'd be a network. Millionaire in America gets a 20% share, Weakest Link gets a 36% share here. So it means rethinking ourselves as a big, important part of broadcasting, rather than being on the edge, which is how we used to think of ourselves.

Which programmes fit the changing BBC2?

We've had an incredibly successful autumn: Horizon, History of Britain, Andes to Amazons, What the Romans Did for Us, Home Front, Jamie Oliver, Gardener's World. The piece are all there. We're not looking at a radically different BBC2, but one that is clear about what it's aiming at.

What about alternative comedy?

BBC2 will continue to run new comedy, with more of an eye on transfers to BBC1. BBC2 has arguably launched more ground-breaking entertainment than any other channel - Monty Python, Not the Nine O'Clock News, Ab Fab, Mrs Merton, The Royle Family - and that will continue to be our job.

But a lot of your top comedy - The League of Gentlemen, Never Mind the Buzzcocks - appeals to the under-35s.

No it doesn't. League of Gentlemen's core audience is in its 30s and older. It's not a youth show by any means. Never Mind the Buzzcocks doesn't work for people in their 20s: the bands they talk about have a nostalgia factor. It's not a youth show. Jamie Oliver is loved by women in their 40s, 50s, 60s, though there's a 20-year-old audience there as well. Alan Partridge stays; Coupling, Gimme Gimme, they're clever, sophisticated. What you won't get is late-night raucous strands, the tits-and-bums programmes that Channel 4 does. Channel 4 and BBC2 are going in different directions. Channel 4's biggest audience gains are among the young - they've made huge leaps in the 16-24 age group. Stuart Murphy [who runs BBC Choice, to be rebranded BBC3] will think youth niche. We don't want programmes that say, "Go away if you're over 25."

Was it galling to be stripped of your most successful show, Have I Got News for You?

Not at all. The biggest problem you have on BBC2 is that you have a lot of very successful long-running programmes which give you little room for manoeuvre. I've always thought we should have graduation parties - it is a cause for the BBC to celebrate.

What about trendy dramas - This Life, and now Attachments? Surely they don't appeal to over-35s-plus audiences?

Tony Garnett will always have a place on BBC2 if he wants one.

How do you justify keeping Robot Wars on a channel for 35-year-olds? And what happens to the children's programmes, The Simpsons, Star Trek?

The BBC is still thinking about the long-term future of children's programmes, and is hoping to launch two new channels. Again, it's not about the next three years. It's a transition. We can't suddenly take something like Robot Wars away from terrestrial viewers, there would be a riot. We'll see how fast digital take-up happens.

Will you survive the transition as controller of BBC2? You've had a hurtful autumn, awash with rumours about your position.

When you're thinking hard about where you're taking a channel, you have to do a lot of tough talking. There were leaked documents, focus groups, research. Being a television controller is about being decisive, forward-looking, and not about recommissioning every programme people would like to recommission.

What are you doing with factual programmes? It seems history is on almost every night of the week.

We're looking at that. Friday night will be our history zone. People seem to like our new Friday strategy, with Conquistadors and Behind the Wire. You can see the enthusiasm in the ratings.

So what happens to Saturday night, the old History Zone?

The 70s nights worked really well, they attracted 3.5m. In the New Year, we start on 80s nights. Many of my friends who find themselves at home with small children on Saturdays tell me the 70s nights saved their marriages.

You've won an extra £25m a year in spending. Where is it going?

The lion's share will go on big factual series, for example, How to Build a Human Being, which looks at near- future technology using digital techniques. Also, Land of Plenty is a classic example of the new drama for BBC2. Big, bold, enjoyable drama, 10 parts. Stephen Poliakoff's forthcoming Family Tree, and a new series, The Men Who Changed Football, fit with the new strategy. I've just commissioned a drama series based on Keith, the taxi driver in Marion & Geoff.

What about religion and arts? Is Everyman coming to you?

I don't know yet, it's being worked out. BBC2 is going to do high-profile religious programmes. Looking at religion seriously is going to be a big area for us. For historical reasons, certain programmes have been on one channel rather than another, and they don't get the love and attention - that's one of the things we are trying to remedy. BBC2 is a more natural home for arts, too.

What is BBC2 doing to cater for minority groups?

We could, we should and we're trying very hard to do more. I'm looking at a lot of new programmes, and am in the final stages of talking about them. Hard to say more.

The repositioned BBC2 is being labelled Home Counties TV by critics. Is this fair?

That's a negative way of looking at it. Is History of Britain a Home Counties programme? The big thing about History of Britain was that it used reconstruction carefully, made you feel exactly what it would be like to stand at the Battle of Hastings. Exciting techniques, that's the real breakthrough. I think it comes back to enjoyment. Enjoyment. Substance. They're the key words for BBC2.

webTitle: VFG believes local TV will be a ratings winner

fields.headline: VFG believes local TV will be a ratings winner
fields.standfirst: Dec 11: VFG launches local TV stations
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Local TV network company VFG believes regional TV will be a ratings winner, reports Dan Milmo
Dec 11: VFG launches local TV stations
fields.body:
VFG, the company that today launched an ambitious local television network, believes it is sitting on a ratings winner.

VFG has set up its Local Broadcasting Group to run 36 regional TV station licences, which could reach a potential audience of 4m.

David Stamp, chief executive of VFG, said: "The Independent Television Commission's own research shows that local information is the top need for viewers. This is exactly what we will be providing."

Mr Stamp added that the channels will be run like local newspapers, with everything from traffic news to coverage of the local village fete.

In a novel twist, VFG plans to introduce broadcasts of events such as school nativity plays.

"We will carry everything from bus timetables to who won the award for biggest marrow at the local fete," said Mr Stamp.

The majority of revenue will come from a local advertising market which generates an income of around £4bn a year. VFG's licences stretch from Edinburgh to East Anglia.

VFG's plans will be paid for by a £50m fundraising round, and £4m has already been raised from a telecoms investment company.

Mr Stamp said that his company could afford the remaining 27 licences, but would not be drawn on the possibility of buying them.

webTitle: In brief: Courtney Love to play prohibition speakeasy queen

fields.headline: Courtney Love to play prohibition speakeasy queen
fields.standfirst: Plus: Hank Azaria ready to replace Robert Downey Jr; Eddie Izzard may be the one for the Oscars; Zhang Ziyi ready for Rush Hour 2; Philip Seymour Hoffman to tread the boards with Streep and Kline; Elizabeth director to helm cult teen novel
fields.trailText: Plus: Hank Azaria ready to replace Robert Downey Jr; Eddie Izzard may be the one for the Oscars; Zhang Ziyi ready for Rush Hour 2; Philip Seymour Hoffman to tread the boards with Streep and Kline; Elizabeth director to helm cult teen novel
fields.body:
 Courtney Love (pictured) has signed up to play real-life showgirl and actress Texas Guinan in Hello Suckers, according to Reuters.The role would seem to be a perfect fit for the controversial widow of Kurt Cobain, as Guinan was one of New York's great characters of the 1920s, not only appearing on Broadway, but also running a speakeasy during the prohibition era.

 Hank Azaria is in talks to replace Robert Downey Jr in the forthcoming comedy America's Sweethearts. As reported in our earlier story, Downey Jr, who may face a jail term after being arrested last month on renewed drug charges, has been sacked from his role as Catherine Zeta-Jones's lover, but Mr Showbiz reports that the Godzilla star is ready to step in.

 British comedian and actor Eddie Izzard is reportedly among the names being considered to host next year's Oscars. Following the news that regular presenter Billy Crystal has ruled himself out due to work commitments, organisers of the show are searching for a new presenter. Crystal himself suggested Jim Carrey, but insiders claim that the Academy is looking at candidates who have proven presenting skills. Veteran presenter Regis Philbin and comedian Chris Rock are reportedly also on the short list, but Eddie is considered a promising outsider.

 The Hollywood Reporter reports that Chinese actress Zhang Ziyi, currently starring in Ang Lee's critically acclaimed Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, is in negotiations to play a villain in Brett Ratner's Rush Hour 2, alongside Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker. The four-month filming schedule starts today in Los Angeles before moving to Hong Kong and Las Vegas.

 Philip Seymour Hoffman is in final negotiations to appear in Mike Nichols' adaptation of Chekhov's The Seagull with Meryl Streep and Kevin Kline, according to Variety. The production was originally due to be staged in the open air in Central Park, but the actors are now considering housing the production in a theatre, possibly on Broadway. The magazine also reports that Hoffman may work again with Magnolia director Paul Thomas Anderson in an untitled comedy which will also star Adam Sandler and Emily Watson.

 Aint't it cool news reports that Shekhar Kapur, the director of Elizabeth, is in final negotiations to make a film adaptation of the teen sci-fi book The Giver, described as "a Brave New World for teenagers." The book describes a seemingly perfect world where there is no poverty, no crime, no sickness and no unemployment. That is until a 12-year-old boy uncovers the truth behind this utopia. Haley Joel Osment, of the Sixth Sense and Steven Spielberg's forthcoming AI, is in the frame to play the boy.

webTitle: UPC eases money problems with £860m share issue

fields.headline: UPC eases financial worries with £860m share issue
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: UPC, Europe's largest cable company, has eased its financial problems with a £860m share issue. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UPC, Europe's largest cable company, has eased its financial problems with a £860m share issue.

The company, which owns 25% of UK rival Telewest, has sunk into the red owing to an ambitious expansion strategy, which has seen it establish cable networks in 17 countries.

Market confidence in the company has been damaged by fears over the company's debt situation and the collapse of a planned merger between its Chello broadband business and internet portal Excite@Home.

The collapse of the proposed deal has forced UPC to look elsewhere for finance.

Analysts said that UPC still needs up to £360m from a market which is loath to pour more cash into the troubled telecoms, media and technology sectors.

Mark Schneider, chairman and CEO of UPC, said: "The completion of this financing, which includes a notable combination of industry and financial players, strengthens UPC's balance sheet and provides significant capital for the continued execution of our core 'triple-play' broadband business in Europe."

webTitle: Breathe faces £2.5m bill after scrapping unmetered service

fields.headline: Breathe faces £2.5m bill after ditching unmetered service
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Internet firm Breathe is facing a bill of £2.5m to reimburse users after scrapping its unmetered service last week, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet firm Breathe is facing a bill of £2.5m to reimburse users after scrapping its unmetered service last week.

The news coincides with rumours that the internet service provider's owner, Martin Dawes, is talking to corporate bankers about a possible sale of the ISP business.

According to reports yesterday, Breathe is so strapped for cash that it faces going into receivership within weeks if it fails to attract a buyer.

Consumers have reacted with anger at the company's failure to state its position on the £50 one-off fee it pocketed from 'Lifetime Plan' users when it launched the unmetered service earlier in the summer.

Breathe has refused to say whether it will reimburse consumers after reports over the weekend said that it was being investigated by trading standards officers.

Users voiced their frustrations in a discussion forum on ISP website Net4nowt.co.uk.

One Breathe subscriber, Andy Gibson, said: "We should all pull together and do what we can against Breathe. If we all pull together we can at least get our money back."

If the ISP does not reimburse subscribers, it could be reprimanded under the Trade Descriptions Act of 1968 if it is found that the company was aware the scheme was not viable,

Only four months ago, Breathe was talking about floating for around £100m and was running a critically acclaimed TV ad campaign.

The company, which was set up by Martin Dawes Communications two years ago, is 35% owned by a consortium of Chase Capital Partners, 3i and US investor Flatiron Partners, which invested £20m in February this year.

With 500,000 subscribers Breathe is one of the largest ISPs in the UK. News of its sale should send warning signals through the internet access market, particularly following the sale of Britain's biggest ISP, Freeserve, and the news that LineOne is up for sale.

However, there are no shortage of buyers; Italian ISP Tiscali is still on the market for an ISP and T-Online is said to be still looking to expand into the UK.

A spokesman for Breathe said he hoped there would be an announcement this week.

webTitle: UK team of astronomers find three new planets

fields.headline: UK team of astronomers find three new planets
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: British, Australian and American astronomers have discovered three new planets orbiting distant stars in the southern skies.
fields.body:
British, Australian and American astronomers have discovered three new planets orbiting distant stars in the southern skies.

They are the first to be discovered by a British-funded instrument, the Anglo-Australian Telescope at Siding Springs in New South Wales, and the first to be found by a group of British observers.

"I'm lost for words. We are opening up a whole new world. It is like being Captain Cook, exploring the South Seas," said Alan Penny, one of the British team, from the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Oxfordshire. "I've always wanted to be an explorer, and being an astronomer was second best. But now I'm back to being an explorer and finding new worlds."

Life as we know it could not survive on these planets. The smallest of the three planets is 88 light years away. It has a mass of about 84% of Jupiter, and is only 6m km from HD 179949, a star in the constellation Sagittarius.

This is very close - a tenth of the distance between Mercury and the sun - and it orbits its parent star every three days.

Another, orbiting the star epsilon Reticulum 59 light years away in the constellation of Altar, is 1.26 times the mass of Jupiter. This one lies at about the Earth's distance from the sun, and like the earth, it has a near circular orbit of 426 days.

The biggest planet weighs at least 1.86 Jupiter masses, and crawls round its star, mu Ara, 50 light years away in the constellation of the Net, once every 743 days. It is a bit further from its star than Mars is from the sun.

Jupiter is more than 100 times bigger than the earth. Like Earth it is a prisoner of the sun's gravitational field. But Jupiter's mass is so great that it also exerts a detectable gravitational tug on the sun. Such a tug from a giant planet could cause a star to wobble at the rate of perhaps 100 metres a second. And changes in the light caused by this wobble can be detected with sensitive instruments many light years away.

The researchers were led by Paul Butler, of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, one of a partnership that pioneered a technique for detecting the gravitational "wobble", and Chris Tinney of the AngloAustralian Observatory.

Three Britons were also on the team. "It is a major step in Britain's participation in the extrasolar planet-hunting business," said Hugh Jones of Liverpool John Moores University.

Until five years ago, Earth and its neighbours in the solar system were the only known planets in a galaxy of 100bn stars, in a universe containing at least 100bn galaxies. So far, planet-hunters have identified 49 new worlds, in a bubble of space with a radius of 100 light years. With other planetary systems to study, they can now begin testing theories of how planets form.

But the technique they use can detect only massive planets - likely to be gas giants such as Jupiter -close to the parent star. The hunt is on for ways of detecting solar systems with the big planets farther out, and a selection of small rocky planets nearer the source of heat; these are the only ones likely to retain liquid water and become a home for life.

A British satellite called Eddington could be launched by the European Space Agency as early as 2008 to begin taking a closer look at the light from 100,000 faraway stars, in the hope of seeing them flicker as planets cross in front of them.

webTitle: Gerry Adams' silver tongue

fields.headline: Gerry Adams' silver tongue
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sweet-talking Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams' ability to attract jobs to Northern Ireland is revealed in a personal letter sent to Bill Clinton by one of the businessmen on the trip.
fields.body:
Sweet-talking Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams' ability to attract jobs to Northern Ireland is revealed in a personal letter sent to Bill Clinton by one of the businessmen on the trip.

Max Martin, president of hi-tech company TriniTech in Largo, Florida, writes: "I wish to bring attention to the impact Mr Gerry Adams [pictured] of Sinn Fein had on me personally when he called upon my company specifically to help with meeting the needs of rampant ... unemployment problems there through offering training opportunities, thus helping to facilitate future skilled technicians.

"I have to admit, originally, when making my plans for this trip, my visions were upon opening another branch operation. Because of Mr Adams' eagerness and heartfelt appeal to meet this important economical and community need, my focus and vision has now a dual purpose, in that I am reconstructing my emphasis to incorporate a training aspect along with product marketing."

Another company boss, Arun Bhumitra, the chief executive of California-based Arjay Telecom, wrote to William Daley, US commerce secretary, with a shopping list of investments he had decided to make in Belfast, Portadown, Londonderry and Sligo in the Republic of Ireland.

webTitle: Ranieri's formation starts to make sense

fields.headline: Ranieri's formation starts to make sense
fields.trailText: Chelsea 4 - 1 Derby
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri is a difficult man to please. True, Chelsea's coach clapped enthusiastically at his side's four goals. Yet there were many more occasions when he turned dramatically towards the dugout in disgust. Sometimes his men had made no obvious mistake. But perhaps they do not fully appreciate the beauty of his 3-4-2-1 system.

The Italian's stratagem was still far too potent for down- trodden Derby, whose manager Jim Smith conceded Ranieri's formation "was a little bit different from what we thought. But we never got to grips with it." Even more puzzlingly, after Derby's recent shut-outs, was Horacio Carbonari's and Taribo West's conspicuously poor grasp of defensive basics.

For most spectators, however, it was an easy-on-the-eye spectacle even if it died a death as a contest after only 16 minutes, by which time the primary striker, the strong and mobile 22-year-old Icelander Eidur Gudjohnsen, had plundered two goals. Ranieri must have given an overall seal of approval because his post-match mouthpiece, the captain Dennis Wise, kept saying various aspects were "very pleasing".

Everything was going swimmingly - Europe is still very much on the horizon, Wise insisted - until the M-word was mentioned. "We need to get something at Middlesbrough," said the captain as he peered towards next Saturday. "I think it will be very difficult because of Terry Venables. He's very cute and very clever."

Connoisseurs of tactics might already be purring over this Anglo-Italian battle of minds but it threatens to be more a crude struggle of will, with the cornered beast of the North-east growing more desperate with each passing Saturday. The perverse thought occurred: have Chelsea, looking so good here, set themselves up for the big fall?

Their feeble away record suggests they leave their heart at home, but at least they should have a lot of gas to run on at the Riverside, when Gudjohnsen will again be the spearhead with Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink still suspended. Not that Ranieri's team eased up too obviously against Derby as they peppered Mart Poom with long shots towards the end, the goalkeeper's late acrobatics and early home misses sparing Smith's team utter humiliation.

Derby have not won at Stamford Bridge in the top flight for a quarter of a century and they signed off last season here with a 4-0 thrashing on a hot May day. Now in the December chill the familiar pattern unfolded: dreadful collective defending let in Gudjohnsen for an angled shot; then "a schoolboy goal", according to Smith, saw West lose possession and the eager Icelander toe-poke home his second.

Gustavo Poyet headed the third, despite the proximity of three defenders, and Gianfranco Zola emphatically drove in the fourth with the hour still not up.

It was scant consolation for Derby that their rearguard, reshaped after Carbonari's loss with a minor head injury, limited further damage and that the promising Chris Riggott retaliated with a header from Lilian Martin's free-kick.

Derby urgently need the defiance typically demonstrated by Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates in his acerbic match programme column. Headlined "Crisis - what crisis?" he insisted all was well on and off the Stamford Bridge pitch, gleefully noting that the latest report ranks Chelsea as "the fourth richest club in the world - Arsenal are tenth!"

And, after a wearying week, he found time to appear on his club's own TV channel to answer his Wembley critics. The overlord's blunt message echoed that of his column: "The knockers are just wasting their time."

webTitle: Dailly joins Southgate on loadsamoney Harry's wish list

fields.headline: Dailly joins Southgate on loadsamoney Harry's wish list
fields.standfirst: West Ham 1 - 1 Aston Villa
fields.trailText: West Ham 1 - 1 Aston Villa
fields.body:
There was never much chance of Harry Redknapp sitting around with £18m in his pocket, and sure enough Blackburn and Aston Villa can expect calls this week. The West Ham manager has identified Christian Dailly and Gareth Southgate as top targets as he sets about rebuilding his defence.

Redknapp hopes to negotiate a deal of around £2.5m for the 27-year-old Dailly, a Scotland international who has started recent Blackburn games on the bench. He also sounds keen to discover whether Aston Villa are willing to drop their £10m asking price for Southgate.

"I would love to have Gareth Southgate," he said. "He's great friends with Stuart Pearce and he would fit in very well but I wouldn't be allowed to spend £10m on a 30-year-old. If I could I certainly would. He would be ideal for us."

Never one to waste a chance to wheel and deal, Redknapp yesterday flew to Spain to scout and expressed an interest in Henning Berg, who is on loan at Blackburn from Manchester United. The Norwegian, he admits, could be tough to land. The same goes for Southgate.

Villa's captain is an obvious replacement for Rio Ferdinand but West Ham are unlikely to go above £6m and should not bank on finding Southgate in the Christmas sales. After seeing Ferdinand move for £18m, Villa's chairman Doug Ellis must be tempted to add another nought to the valuation.

"I think Aston Villa have decided they're going to hold out for a large fee for me and I don't think I will be moving anywhere for a while," Southgate said. In any event he is unlikely to fancy Upton Park. The England midfielder (©Kevin Keegan) wants a transfer to win trophies or, at the very least, to play in the Champions League. West Ham looks a sideways step at best.

Villa's third successive draw confirmed they need a prolific striker. Their record of five de feats in 37 league games is bettered only by Manchester United but 16 draws have let them down. Their manager John Gregory shot off abroad after the match and awaits news on Celta Vigo's Benni McCarthy.

Villa's first-team coach, Steve Harrison said: "It was a good, honest, wholehearted performance by us. We couldn't have asked for any more. At the moment we are just grinding out results, but there is plenty of potential there and we can get better."

After Lee Hendrie's well struck 37th-minute equaliser Villa created nothing. Dion Dublin laboured alone and David Ginola was stifled by the excellent Rigobert Song, who delayed his departure for a funeral in Cameroon to play. With better finishing West Ham would have won.

After Michael Carrick - "a certainty to play for England," according to Redknapp - had scored from 20 yards, Paolo di Canio and the impressive Frédéric Kanouté wasted chances. Redknapp might like a goalscorer to go with his revamped back line.

webTitle: The Nice treaty

fields.headline: The Nice treaty
fields.standfirst: European leaders have spent five days deciding how they will decide things in the future. Their compromise will have far-reaching effects, as we explain
fields.trailText: European leaders have spent five days deciding how they will decide things in the future. Their compromise will have far-reaching effects, as Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
What was the main issue?
How the EU makes its decisions has always been fraught with controversy. Contrary to what the Europhobes say, real power in the Union is vested not in the european commission in Brussels, but in the national capitals. When the old EEC was formed, important decisions were made unanimously by the six founder states. As the community expanded, the national governments grudgingly moved to a system of qualified majority voting (QMV) to prevent logjams of unresolved business.

How does it work?
Each member state has a number of votes, based roughly on their populations. Up to now the big four powers, Germany, Britain, France and Italy, each had 10 votes. The others had fewer, but even tiny Luxembourg had the minimum three votes. That meant that the smaller states, if they ganged up on the big ones, could block any new legislation they found offensive.

Did it work well?
After a fashion. The big players were generally able to recruit enough of the small fry to push through their favourite projects, while the smaller nations had the diplomatic comfort of knowing they could not be coerced against their will. And in most areas judged vital to national interests, all member states could fall back on their jealously guarded national veto.

If it wasn't broke, why did they fix it?
Because the EU is poised for another big expansion, with no fewer than 12 new members wanting to join the existing 15. If all new members were given votes on the current weighting, the system would have ground to a halt. Also, Germany has been growling for years that because it has had more than 80m citizens since reunification, it should have more votes than France, Italy and Britain, which each have around 60m.

Sounds fair - did they get their way?
Non. Sorry, no. The French were adamantly opposed. They see the Franco-German axis is the main pillar of Europe, but they insist it must be a partnership of equals. Their sensitivity on the subject is informed, of course, by the collective memory of two 20th century German invasions.

So what did they come up with?
A rather ingenious formula which reapportions voting power, eroding some of the influence of the smaller countries but still giving them proportionally more influence than their size merits. The new system gives Germany, France, Italy and Britain 29 votes each. Spain will have 27 votes; the Netherlands, 13; Greece, Belgium and Portugal, 12; Sweden and Austria, 10; Denmark, Finland and Ireland, seven, and Luxembourg, four. The smaller countries are not best pleased. Belgium and Portugal in particular fear their voices could be drowned out in future negotiations. But they have gone along with the new formula in the knowledge that they will soon have new allies with a vested interest in protecting the cause of the smaller member states.

Ah yes, what of the new members?
They have already been allocated their voting strengths. Poland, the biggest applicant by far, will have 18 votes. Romania will have 14; the Czech Republic and Hungary, 11; Bulgaria, nine; Slovakia and Lithuania, seven; and Latvia, Slovenia, Estonia, Cyprus and Malta, three each.

Is the expansion cut and dried?
Not exactly. The applicant states, which are already deeply miffed about being kept hanging around on the EU doorstep, will have to endure years more detailed negotiations over the terms of entry, and years more after that of what Brussels laughably calls "convergence". But the process is now at least firmly under way, setting the stage for a Union stretching from the Atlantic to the borders of Belarus and Ukraine that will eliminate the last vestiges of Europe's Cold War division.

Surely such a huge enterprise will have to dispense with the national veto?
You'd think so, but Tony Blair for one sees it differently. He fought tooth and nail during the marathon summit to retain Britain's "sovereign" power over taxation and social security. And he won - though he did agree to QMV on a raft of other, mostly piffling, areas of policymaking.

Where does the European commission stand on all this?
As usual, on the sidelines. If there is one thing that unites the Council of Ministers, it is that their fixed belief the commission must never get too big for its boots. Obviously, with a putative membership of 27, the Brussels bureaucracy is set to burgeon (the translation and interpretation service, on its own, will be a mega-industry). The bigger four countries, ever wary of any empire-building in Brussels, have agreed to give up their right to appoint two commissioners. From 2005, each will send just one big cat to Brussels. The smaller fry will have to wait their turn to fill the remaining seats, on a rotation basis.

And the European parliament?
As ever, it will be collectively puce with rage that it has still been given nothing useful to do. But expansion means lots more MEPs, with Germany, as a sop to its argument that size matters, having the biggest representation.

webTitle: Court decision brings good and bad news for DiCaprio

fields.headline: Court decision brings good and bad news for DiCaprio
fields.trailText: Although the Titanic star has been cleared of assaulting a screenwriter after a fracas at a New York restaurant, he still faces charges of aiding and abetting
fields.body:
A New York court has given the go-ahead for a $45m (£31.1m) lawsuit to be filed against Leonardo DiCaprio by screenwriter and actor, Roger Wilson, regarding an alleged fight that took place over the actress Elizabeth Berkley.

Wilson claims that the 26-year-old actor, currently linked to supermodel Gisele, encouraged several of his friends to make advances to Showgirls actress Berkley on his behalf and when Wilson confronted them, he was beaten up outside a restaurant in Manhattan in March 1998.

The court dismissed the allegation of assault against DiCaprio, but sustained a charge of "aiding and abetting an assault and battery." According to the prosecution, DiCaprio incited his friends to attack Wilson. At the time, one source quoted the Titanic star as shouting, "Let's go kick his ass."

The New York Daily News reports that Wilson claims his singing career was brought to an end by a blow to his throat from one of DiCaprio's pals. Wilson's lawyer, Richard Zuckerman, told the paper he expects depositions in the case to start soon after the Christmas holidays.

DiCaprio's lawyer, Paul Callen, praised the court for dismissing the allegation of assault. Callen added that, "The remaining claim of aiding and abetting an assault is utterly false" before announcing that he planned a "vigorous defence" for his client.

webTitle: Vinnie Jones answers your questions

fields.headline: Vinnie Jones answers your questions
fields.trailText: He came, he saw, and then - after a whistle-stop visit to London to launch his new video and, as it turned out, make a surprise appearance on This Is Your Life - Vinnie Jones went back to LA. But before he went he very kindly had time to answer your questions.
fields.body:
He came, he saw, and then - after a whistle-stop visit to London to launch his new video and, as it turned out, make a surprise appearance on This Is Your Life - Vinnie Jones went back to LA. But before he went he very kindly had time to answer your questions.

We would a like to thank the hundreds of you who emailed in questions for him. So give yourselves a hearty pat on the back - actually, make that two if you didn't ask what Gazza's testicles felt like - and enjoy the verbal sparring that takes place when soccer hardman and Hollywood star Vincent Jones goes head-to-head with the best Football Unlimited readers can muster. Let battle commence!

1. Do you think the reputation you had as a hardman of football perhaps masked your footballing talent? And if it did, do you care? - George Davidson

I had a great time when I was playing football and I think my tough reputation did go before me, but that is no bad thing as a lot of the game is down to a state of mind. Half the job of winning is down to making an opponent think he has already lost before he even steps onto the pitch. It's not for me to comment on my footballing talent but I can't complain about my achievements.

2. What pleased you more - winning the FA Cup final in 1988 or receiving rave reviews for Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels? - Alexandre Gontijo

Winning the final with Wimbledon was one of the most amazing things ever and nothing can take away from that. The previous question asked if I felt my hardman reputation masked by talent, well you don't win the Cup with just reputation.

It was great to get recognition for all the work that I put into Lock, Stock. Guy Ritchie was a great director and his strong belief that I had what it took really inspired me. When the reviews came in I was really touched to see that all the hard work I put into the part wasn't in vain - and it has spurred me on even more in Snatch, Gone in Sixty Seconds and the films I am working on now.

3. Have you ever committed a foul and thought, "Shit, I've gone too far here?" If so, when and where? - Jack Saunders

Not really. Every player knew what they were going up against when they stepped on to the pitch with me. I wasn't the only 'bad boy' out there anyway. There were tons of other players doing what I did and it still goes on now. The referees just kept watching me more than other players.

4. Exactly what possessed you to feel Paul Gascoigne's package? - Neil Butler

He was annoying me and wouldn't stop and I thought I'd stop him once and for all. Simple as that!

5. At a time when the football club with whom you were earning your wages, QPR, were in real dire straits, financially, mentally and generally, why did you publicly mock our club on the late night TV show McCoist and McCauley? And why did you never apologise to QPR fans for not wanting to play for our club? - Tracy Stent

There were things happening behind the scenes that I won't go into. This is all a long time ago and I've changed since then. I am sorry if the fans were offended but they have had their fair share of goes at me.

6. At the end of last season you offered to take the Wimbledon job for £200,000 a year. Do you still fancy becoming a football manager? If you do, which formation would you play and why? - Alex Clarke

I'm really committed to my film career and am putting all of my effort into it so I don't have much time for the game - at the moment. Who knows what the future holds, though?

7. Which opposition player did you look forward to meeting on a Saturday, and which player did you hate playing against? Why? - KB8MPO@bolton.ac.uk

Some things are better left unsaid. My fans will probably know the answer to this already.

8. Now you're spending six months of the year in Hollywood can you tell us: does anyone down to earth and normal (besides yourself) actually live in that God-forsaken hell hole? - Mark Bridges

You can get strange people wherever you are in the world. I have got a great place in LA and quite enjoy it out there. It is obviously very different to home, and I miss the UK a lot, but it is where I need to be for my film career right now.

9. What's your juiciest piece of Hollywood gossip? - Lawrence Booth

I'm not really in with the Hollywood party circuit. I prefer to spend time with my family and friends that come over from home, so I am not really the person to ask for hot gossip.

10. Why does America use an electoral college system in the Presidential election? Why don't they just tally up the votes of the nation as a whole? - julian@gluemedia.com

Better ask an American.

The competition winners were: Richard Snoxell, Gregory Manberg, Martin Delaney, Rory McKerrell and Lisa Noonan. They all win a copy of Vinnie's new video: Vinnie's Revenge, which is out in all good shops now.
