webTitle: Blair hails landmark EU deal

fields.headline: Blair hails landmark EU deal
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: the Nice treaty
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has hailed today's landmark deal on a new EU treaty as a major boost for Britain's interests and a turning point for Europe.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has hailed today's landmark deal on a new EU treaty as a major boost for Britain's interests and a turning point for Europe.

Five days of talks in Nice between Mr Blair and his 14 fellow EU leaders produced a deal designed to pave the way for the union's enlargement from 15 to 27 or 28 countries, with agreement on reforms to the union's institutions and voting structures.

Mr Blair claimed victory in securing the retention of the UK veto in key decision-making areas such as taxation and social security, while increasing Britain's relative voting strength in the decision-making Council of Europe.

The talks, which began on Thursday evening, ended at 3.25am after a night of hectic negotiating in which the smaller countries staged a revolt against the bigger states.

The debate centred on the relative weight to be given to each country's vote in the decision-making European Council, and how many nations would need to work together to block any measure they disagreed with.

Big players such as the UK, Germany, France and Italy had wanted to keep a stranglehold on voting in the council, but on several occasions during the often heated negotiations the smaller nations threatened to stage a walkout to scupper the summit unless their demands were met.

Mr Blair told reporters later: "It was of course a very difficult and complicated negotiation but I'm pleased it has had an outcome which is satisfactory and paves the way for enlargement.

The prime minister agreed to give up one of the UK's two commissioners in future - in exchange for a "substantial" reweighting of the UK's voting power.

"Ever since Britain joined the European Community, our relative voting strength has declined," the prime minister said. "The advantage in this statement now is that for us that relative voting strength increases. It puts us in a far stronger position."

Mr Blair said the UK had willingly agreed to move from unanimity to qualified majority voting in 23 key policy areas where it was to Britain's advantage - but had held firm on taxation and social security to protect Britain's "national interest".

Mr Blair added: "Ever since I became prime minister, at every single summit I have attended there have been dire warnings of disasters that would befall us.

"When we came to this summit we were told we would lose on defence, lose on social security and come under pressure on tax.

"In fact the whole of this summit has been an exercise in getting the best out of Europe for Britain."

The final Treaty of Nice, to be signed next year, leaves out all Britain's "no-go" areas on surrendering the veto. An agreement earlier at the meeting established plans for a European Rapid Reaction Force in line with the UK's wishes that it should not drive a wedge between the EU and Nato.

Mr Blair is expected to make a statement in the House of Commons about the outcome of the summit later today.

The talks - the longest ever meeting of EU leaders - had been stalled for one and half days by an increasingly bitter row over the voting strengths of many of the smaller EU countries, including those which will join in the next few years.

Mr Blair rejected suggestions that the final outcome amounted to a stitch-up in which the bigger members retain control: "Some people may fear this is the big countries taking charge of Europe. I don't see it like that at all. I have never seen this as big versus small."

The summit agreed that future decisions by qualified majority vote would require a 73% share of the total votes, plus a 62% minimum representation of the total EU population. Smaller countries will still struggle to hold their own against the largest.

Shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude said that he would not have agreed to sign the Nice Treaty, which he said would delay the enlargement of the EU.

Mr Maude told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "What's so disappointing about all this is it all goes in one direction.

"It is all more political integration, deepening and tightening the integration of Europe, which is the wrong agenda.

"To have more areas where the majority can impose their will on the minority is divisive [] It breeds division not unity.

"This has done absolutely nothing to make early enlargement of the EU possible. There is no date set for enlargement and the big thing standing in the way of enlargement - the common agricultural policy - hasn't been tackled at all.

"We wouldn't have signed it. We would have shown some leadership on the agenda in the previous months, which Tony Blair has signally failed to do."

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Arsenal and Chelsea are fighting to sign Tottenham captain Sol Campbell, according to The Mirror. Manchester United were favourites to sign Campbell, but Sir Alex Ferguson is said to be happy with his defenders and has no plans to add to his squad. Campbell, whose current contract expires at the end of the season, could sign for a foreign club on January 1, but is thought to prefer to stay in London.
fields.body:
Arsenal and Chelsea are fighting to sign Tottenham captain Sol Campbell, according to The Mirror. Manchester United were favourites to sign Campbell, but Sir Alex Ferguson is said to be happy with his defenders and has no plans to add to his squad. Campbell, whose current contract expires at the end of the season, could sign for a foreign club on January 1, but is thought to prefer to stay in London.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is prepared to sell England midfielder Kieron Dyer, but will demand over £10m for his service, reports The Mirror. Robson is looking to strengthen his squad following Saturday's 5-0 drubbing at Arsenal, but Newcastle chairman Freddy Shepherd has told him he must sell before he can buy. Leeds have been repeatedly linked with Dyer and could offer out-of-favour striker Michael Bridges in part exchange.

Harry Redknapp wants Gareth Southgate as a replacement for Rio Ferdinand, but fears Aston Villa are pricing him out of a move. "He's a great player and I'd love to bring him here," acknowledged Redknapp after the sides' 1-1 draw on Saturday. webTitle: Diana Memorial Fund announces grant winners

fields.headline: Diana Memorial Fund announces grant winners
fields.trailText: Today the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund announces the winners of this year's round of grant awards.Young people will be the key beneficiaries, with money going to twenty voluntary organisations tackling problems faced by disadvantaged youths.
fields.body:
Today the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund announces the winners of this year's round of grant awards.Young people will be the key beneficiaries, with money going to twenty voluntary organisations tackling problems faced by disadvantaged youths.

Four of the awards go to Scotland and one to Wales. A £100,000 grant for Children in Scotland, will help young people with learning difficulties to participate in the policy making of the new Scottish parliament.

The UK-based Young Minds Trust wins £150,500 to conduct research in six in-patient units for young people and to make recommendations regarding the future development of emergency child and adolescent mental health services.

The fund received double the amount of applications for this year's round of grant making and the money awarded brings the total to £35m in the three years since it began.

In Wales, Scope Cymru is to receive nearly £200,000 to provide training and support for young people with learning disabilities to gain vocational qualifications.

A CD-ROM for young lesbian and bisexual women will be developed with the help of a £22,000 grant by the Healthy Gay Living Centre with the aim of reducing their vulnerability to mental illness.

Chief executive of the fund, Andrew Purkis, said: "Diana, Princess of Wales herself reached out to all kinds of people suffering stigma and disadvantage. It is precisely in this spirit that these grants are being awarded."

webTitle: NHS overspent on impotence drugs

fields.headline: NHS overspent on impotence drugs
fields.trailText: The NHS spent between £5m and £8m more than it expected on impotence drugs such as Viagra last year, despite tight prescribing guidelines, the Department of Health has revealed. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The NHS spent between £5m and £8m more than it expected on impotence drugs such as Viagra last year, despite tight prescribing guidelines, the Department of Health has revealed.

The government today announced plans to re-open consultation with patients and professional groups on the current prescribing regulations, which were put in place in July 1999.

At that time it was estimated that the cost annually to the NHS for treating men with impotence would be between £12m and £14m - but figures to July 2000 show spending was about £20m.

Ministers originally imposed tight NHS prescribing rules, including restricting the drugs to men with certain medical conditions, and advising that doctors should limit patients to one treatment a week.

But the latest figures suggest that the restrictions have not been as successful in managing the NHS patient demand for impotence treatment that the government had hoped.

The consultation, which is open until February 5, 2001, is likely to re-open the controversy over whether so-called "lifestyle" drugs such as Viagra should be met by the NHS.

The original consultation on impotence drug treatments in 1999 showed that 75 per cent of respondents favoured limits on prescribing, while 10 per cent thought it should be banned.

A DoH spokesperson insisted that ministers had no view on whether the rules should be tightened but would wait for the results of the consultation, which had been promised at the time of the original decision last year.

But a DoH statement said: "These figures [the £20m annual expenditure] indicate that the government was correct to have concerns about the potential resource implications of more widespread prescribing of these treatments."

Drugs available on the NHS to treat impotence are: Viagra, Caberject, Muse and Viridal.

Under existing regulations, GPs are allowed to prescribe impotence treatments on the NHS to men who they consider to be clinically impotent and suffer from a list of specific conditions. These are diabetes, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, poliomyelitis, prostate cancer, prostatectomy, radical pelvic surgery, renal failure caused by transplant or dialysis, sever pelvic injury, soinal cord injury, spina bifida or single gene neurological disease.

The DoH said these limits represented "a sensible balance between treating men with the distressing condition of impotence and protecting the resources of the NHS to deal with other patients", for example those with cancer or heart disease.

Men who fall outside the regulations have to pay for the drugs by taking out a private prescription from their GP.

webTitle: Grinch stays on top as Ryan and Crowe fail to pull

fields.headline: Grinch stays on top as Ryan and Crowe fail to pull
fields.trailText: The Grinch stays on course to become America's most successful film of the year, while the martial arts blockbuster Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon hits a high per screen average on just 16 screens
fields.body:
Jim Carrey's How the Grinch Stole Christmas has held on to the top box office slot in the United States for the fourth week running, making it a good contender to become the highest grossing film of the year.

The adaptation of the children's book by Dr Seuss, took another $18.5m (£12.8m) over the weekend, making a grand total of $195m (£134.9m) since its release on November 10. It has already overtaken Gladiator to become the second most successful movie of 2000 and only Mission: Impossible II, which took $215m (£148.8m), has earned more money at the box office in the past twelve months.. However Mr Showbiz predicts that the Grinch will easily surpass the takings for the Tom Cruise vehicle in about half the time.

Mountain adventure picture, Vertical Limit, starring Chris O'Donnell and Robin Tunney, went straight into the number two slot with box office earnings of $16m (£11m), while the eagerly awaited kidnap drama Proof of Life (pictured), which attracted much attention due to the off-screen romance of co-stars Russell Crowe and Meg Ryan, could only make number three with a disappointing $10.4m ($7.2m) in ticket sales.

The big screen adaptation of the fantasy role playing game, Dungeons and Dragons, despite dire reviews, took $7m (£4.8m) to claim the number five slot.

But the most impressive figures were achieved by Ang Lee's martial arts drama, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which despite opening in only 16 theatres, grossed $686,657 (£475,260). After breaking records in Asia, the highly acclaimed Chow Yun-Fat/Michelle Yeoh starrer is already being tipped as one of the frontrunners for next year's Academy Awards.

For the complete top 10, go to Screen Daily.

webTitle: Swinging seventies cops set for big-screen revamp

fields.headline: Swinging seventies cops set for big-screen revamp
fields.trailText: After the huge success of Charlie's Angels, the trio's male equivalents in big-haired bravado, Starsky and Hutch are being lined up for a movie transfer, but this time with the original stars back in the roles that made them famous
fields.body:
Legendary 1970s TV detectives, Starsky and Hutch may make a comeback in a film which will see the sartorially-challenged pair reunited 20 years on, but this time on different sides of the law.

In a strange turn of events, the movie, which is still in the early planning stages, would see Paul Michael Glaser (Starsky) as a security chief for a major corporation and David Soul (Hutch) as a leading activist for green causes.

Soul, who has been living in Britain for the last five years, but was in Seattle on the first anniversary of last year's World Trade Organisation riots, told the Daily Express that the two actors are very keen to get the project off the ground. "Starsky and Hutch obviously can't move as fast but it would be terrific. We envisage them meeting at the WTO talks, but on either side of the barriers. Starsky would be a private security officer for a major corporation coming into town, I would be with the environmentalists. A woman would have separated them all those years ago."

Neither Glaser nor Soul, both now in their late fifties, managed to maintain the success that they achieved in the hit detective series, although they have continued to work in the entertainment world. Glaser has moved into direction, while Soul has established a solid career in the theatre,

Soul has given considerable thought to the way that life might have have progressed for Hutch over the last 20 years. "My character will have done everything - driving new Mercedes from England to Arabia for thousands of pounds, joining the Green movement, and trying to be a writer," he said. "He will have been married three times."

For more information about the classic TV series, go to the Starsky and Hutch Webring.

webTitle: Lamplugh body hunt begins

fields.headline: Lamplugh body hunt begins
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the abduction and murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh 14 years ago have begun searching a small area in Worcestershire to try and find her body, Scotland Yard confirmed today.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the abduction and murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh 14 years ago have begun searching a small area in Worcestershire to try and find her body, Scotland Yard confirmed today.

Officers are digging up land near Norton Barracks "following information received and months of research", police said.

Detective Superintendent Shaun Sawyer said: "This is an important element of our enquiry, but I would like to stress that we are extremely cautious of any likelihood of any success. Obviously we would very much hope to find Suzy for her family but we have to be realistic."

A West Mercia police spokesman said its officers had met detectives from the Metropolitan police to discuss a number of sites in the Worcestershire area which might be relevant. "We will provide whatever assistance they require. It is [the Met's] inquiry," the spokesman added.

Ms Lamplugh was 25 when she vanished in 1986 after going to show a man known as "Mr Kipper" around a property near her office in Fulham, south-west London.

46-year-old John Cannan was recently questioned in connection with her death. Scotland Yard said today that he was no longer being quizzed.

webTitle: Comic book makes Pope a superhero

fields.headline: Comic book makes Pope a superhero
fields.trailText: Wearing a cape and a smile, the Pope has joined the legion of superheroes in a Vatican-approved comic book.
fields.body:
Wearing a cape and a smile, the Pope has joined the legion of superheroes in a Vatican-approved comic book.

The first issue of the real-life and adventures of John Paul II's fight against evil has sold out. The religious publisher Paolini is considering translating the four-part serial into other languages and selling it abroad.

Critics in the Vatican are afraid that it will demean the church and reinforce a cult of personality.

The Little Paper, an illustrated children's magazine, appeared on newsstands last week with the first installment of the strip "Karol Wojtyla: Pope of the Third Millennium".

Opening with his election to the papacy in 1978, it features a larger-than-life John Paul dominating St Peter's Square with white smoke swirling above him. "Our commitment is rather grandiose, dear children: telling the life of no one less than the Pope," the introduction says.

The story is told in flashback, with dialogue in bubbles, by a grandfather who is asked by his grandchildren why he is not pope. He explains that the ailing 80-year-old, who trembles from Parkinson's disease, was once a sports-mad boy called Karol who grew up in the Polish town of Wadowice.

"I got it!" shouts a knobbly-kneed Karol as he blocks a goal during a football match.

To children too young to know that the Pope has long been known as God's athlete, it is a revelation. Grandfather recalls that Karol never felt compelled to prove himself by smoking, boozing or staying out late.

The some-time amateur actor is also shown with an oversized moustache playing opposite a gorgeous leading lady in a costume drama.

"Whattttt? You want me to believe that he acted with girls?" Grandpa is asked. "Certainly," comes the reply. "And danced the waltz, the mazurka and even the tango."

The comic strip also shows Karol losing his mother and only brother by the time he was 11 - traumas which proved decisive when forging his personality.

Written by Alberto Bobbio, the comic is a sister publication of the Catholic magazine Famiglia Christiana. It follows other Vatican innovations in reaching out to young people, such as the recording of the Pope's hymns, which went platinum.

According to Italian newspaper La Repubblica, "more sober" elements in the Vatican think putting the pontiff on the same sort of level as Superman and other superheroes is a mistake.

"They turn up their noses," it says, "but they do not speak out, because to criticise in these times causes trouble."

webTitle: Comment: Madeleine Bunting on cookery books

fields.headline: Finding your inner cook
fields.standfirst: Recipe books promise to change lives. That's why we read them in bed, not the kitchen
fields.trailText: Recipe books promise to change lives. That's why we read them in bed, not the kitchen
fields.body:
Christmas for adults is all about food; either cooking it, or eating it or both. So it's entirely in order that among the presents wrapped up under the Christmas tree in millions of households, there will be a cookery book.

We buy millions of cookery books all year round, but especially in the run-up to Christmas. Over the next two weeks, hundreds of thousands of cookery books will be bought. Four out of Amazon's current top 10 fastest-selling titles are cookery books; three out of their seven bestsellers for the year are cookery books - interspersed only with Harry Potter. Most of these books are doorstoppers, beautifully designed and dripping with the most luscious of production values; photos to have you instantly salivating. Close-ups of that dew-crowned rocket, that cheese still bubbling from a hot oven, that chocolate cake, the crumbs so tantalising you feel you could steal one from the page and naughtily nibble.

The mystery is who is buying these books and why. Because the evidence is that they are not buying them to cook with. Over much the same period as Delia Smith has become a multimillionaire and Jamie Oliver has been launched on his way to becoming one, the ready-made meals market has boomed, not to mention takeaways and restaurant eating. Between 1993 and 1997, sales of ready-made meals grew by 27% and the market is now worth well over £1.2bn a year. The fastest-selling frozen product was complete meals with chips.

Chilled ready-made meals - 35% increase in the past five years - go from strength to strength, reaping huge profits for supermarkets as customers fork out large sums to have someone in a vast production line cook their pasta, stir-fry or curry. We end up with the absurdity of having cookery books on the kitchen shelf as we munch a complete meal with chips in front of a TV cookery programme.

It would be a very serious misunderstanding to think cookery books are being bought simply because people like cooking - our mothers might have done that, not so today. No, cookery books have become the favourite bedtime reading of a swath of middle England. It's foreign territory to me, owning only a dog-eared Delia Smith borrowed from my mother a decade ago and a rarely used Nigel Slater; the idea of taking either to bed seems daft. But a trawl through a bookshop, shelves groaning with Nigella Lawson, Nigel Slater, Rowley Leigh, Jamie Oliver, the River Cafe et al, was a revelation. The ambitions of these books are vast. They have gone beyond the addition of literary prowess made by a previous generation of cookery writers such as Elizabeth David and wrap cooking up with philosophy-cum-therapy plus a smattering of confessional biographical detail. Cookery books have an appeal much like The Little Book of Calm: it's the feel-good market with plenty of comforting advice on how to live your life.

A potted version of cookery-book wisdom runs as follows. First, it's all about Passion. It seems almost obligatory for authors of cookery books to announce how passionate they are about food. Food is the one area of life in which people happily confess to being passionate; sex is much too complicated.

Nigel Slater is evangelical on this point. "Cooking can be as passionate, creative, life-enhancing, uplifting, satisfying and as exhilarating as anything else you can do with your life," he writes in his introduction to Appetite. "If you go through life without cooking, you are missing out on something very, very special ... you are losing out on one of the greatest pleasures you can have with your clothes on." Cooking for others is "one of the greatest joys known to man" After making a pie, Lawson declares: "I felt suffused with heady satisfaction." This is akin to how a 17th-century nun described a mystical vision; perhaps this is as close to claims of transcendental experience as our culture gets.

The key principle here is to lose yourself in the experience of cooking and eating. Total absorption is the prescription. "Get floury, sticky, wholly involved," writes Lawson. "Lunch is a suspension of time and an opportunity for pure pleasure," advocates Rowley Leigh. Experiencing something intensely is about getting your hands dirty, kneading the dough and making a mess. It is both tactile and playful: the opposite of the computer-dominated office where virtually the only things you touch are smooth plastic, and there's no time to muck about and play because you know your targets and you're being monitored on whether you're achieving them.

Corporate gurus claim we are moving into the experience economy and a new generation of consumers are not interested in acquiring possessions, but experiences. Food is central to the experience market and worth billions; the world is being trawled for exotic tastes and cuisines. Status is having kumquats and truffles in your fridge. Jamie Oliver is targeted perfectly at this market: the minimalist warehouse appartment and the fancy cooker. The philosophy is hedonistic: life is for pleasure, rather than purpose. Forget the political idealism and ambition of the 20th century, just snuggle down with that dreamy recipe for cheesecake.

But all this passionate experience would be intimidating - can the reader summon up that emotional intensity? - if it wasn't mixed with two things. First, a nostalgic back to basics. This is behind the trend for seasonality; the novelty of strawberries in December has worn off as the cognoscenti turn their back on the global food market. Bad luck on the Kenyan bean farmer, but the farmers' markets are where it's at. Think local, think mud, think small scale.

The introduction to the River Cafe Book Green (all recipes are seasonal) captures this perfectly, describing how friends and acquaintances began turning up with wild produce such as mushrooms and sorrel they had gathered from their allotments. Hunter-gatherers in London. Rick Stein has us weeping into our cod at the decline of our fishing communities.

Second, these books are intimate. They are full of confidential chitchat. They are full of encouragement and confidence-building. "Go on, have a try, you can do it ..." Instead of being made to feel inadequate in a consumer culture of perfect bodies and fast-changing technological gadgetry, we have these nice people like Ainsley Harriott on our side. Lawson knows all about this: in line with her other mystical leanings, she makes it clear that she wants you to feel she is with you. In the introduction to How To Eat, she writes: "I have tried to talk you through a recipe as much as possible. I have wanted to make you feel that I am there, with you in the kitchen as you cook. They lay claim to a kind of innocent experience in an otherwise cynical world, offering uplifting visions of pleasure for the future. The reality is, of course, no such thing. It is BSE, bankrupt farmers, rising incidence of obesity and millions of complete meals with chips.

webTitle: Australian reconciliation off the cards

fields.headline: Australian reconciliation off the cards
fields.standfirst: The process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and white Australians was dealt a blow last week, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and white Australians was dealt a blow last week, writes Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
The year 2000 was supposed to have been the year that white and indigenous Australians were reconciled.

But last week, the government body given the task of determining what "reconciliation" should be was disbanded, with its final recommendations rejected by Australian prime minister John Howard.

"Reconciliation is and should be an unstoppable force," said Mr Howard in an upbeat address at the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation's closing conference last Thursday, where the council delivered its final recommendations.

Both Mr Howard and the council were keen to emphasise the progress towards reconciliation. In the years since parliament voted to create the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in 1991, there has emerged a clear acknowledgement of the existence of the "stolen generation" - those Aboriginal children forcibly detached from their parents and their culture to be brought up in white children's homes and foster homes.

Mr Howard's position on reconciliation has also softened, from hostility to acceptance, in recognition that he was out of step with the majority of Australians. One million people joined reconciliation marches this year, a greater proportion of the population than those whose protests mobilised the black civil rights movement in America in the 1960s.

Mr Howard and the council agreed that reconciliation - reducing the inequalities between white and black Australians as well as healing the wounds from 212 years of white settlement - is not something that could or should be definitively completed.

A private organisation, Reconciliation Australia, is to be established with A$5.5m (£2.07m) of government money to continue the process next year. A reconciliation "mall" will also be built in Canberra, containing a memorial to the stolen generation.

But Aden Ridgeway, Australia's only Aboriginal senator, criticised the decision to shift reconciliation to a private body. "The government is the one responsible for showing leadership, it's the one that's got to provide the backup and the resources and it's also got to give the legislative guarantees," he said.

Legislative guarantees, and a formal apology, are two things Mr Howard's government steadfastly refuses to give.

Reconciliation began in 1991 with calls for a treaty between the government and its indigenous citizens, and ended again on Thursday with another call for a treaty, which Mr Howard flatly rejected.

Admired by some for his pragmatism and vilified by others for his lack of imagination, the Australian prime minister preaches "practical" reconciliation, improving Aborigines' health and employment prospects.

He is suspicious of treaties, fearing they are divisive. "You make treaties with other countries, you don't make treaties with each other," he once said.

Statistics suggest that Aborigines already live in another country. They can expect to live 20 years less than white Australians, while Aboriginal men are 15 times more likely to spend time in jail than their white counterparts.

Years of practical multibillion dollar welfare programmes have yet to solve these problems. In areas such as Cape York, Aborigines' health is getting worse, according to every available measure, bar infant mortality.

The government points to an 18% increase in the number of Aborigines undertaking tertiary education since 1996, but levels of indigenous unemployment remain as bad as ever: 26% compared to 8% for the general Australian population.

With his hand on the tiller of a stalled reconciliation process, Mr Howard refuses to acknowledge the connection between symbolic and practical reconciliation. He says that an apology and a treaty won't solve practical problems. But his opponents argue it could only help.

A treaty, such as Canada has with its indigenous people, would provide "some formal settlement of the issues created by our shared history, where Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were dispossessed of their lands without treaty or consent," said Evelyn Scott, chairwoman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

Even some of Mr Howard's allies suggest that a treaty, by providing a framework of rights and obligations for the government and Aborigines, could bolster practical reconciliation and make government welfare a more positive, rights-driven process.

Noel Pearson, an influential Aboriginal lawyer from Cape York, has stimulated much debate - and approving glances from Mr Howard's government - on how to reduce welfare dependency among Aborigines.

As he says: "The Cape York people and communities are traumatised. The social conditions and problems which they face are directly related to the history of their removal from land and the treatment that they and the land have received."

But the argument that a treaty could be an education in itself, conferring respect, rights and status which could help banish a passive acceptance of welfare or ill-health, appears to be one that Mr Howard does not want to hear.

webTitle: Future investment

fields.headline: Future investment
fields.trailText: The Government's Green Paper on parental leave deserves a powerful welcome
fields.body:
Children are a collective good. The vitality of our society and economy depends upon a well-parented, well-educated, healthy generation to replace those currently in work as they retire. Moreover, the most important time to make an intervention in a child's life is soon after birth. The evidence that subsequent emotional, intellectual and physical development is closely related to the quality of the first 12 months of life is overwhelming.These are the months in which the lifelong bonds associating child and parent are formed.

That is why the Government's Green Paper on parental leave deserves a powerful welcome. Britain's approach is the meanest in the industrialised world after the US. One reason that so many children from poorer homes are so disadvantaged is early neglect. The prospect of extending paid maternity leave to 26 weeks with the opportunity for a further six months off or working reduced hours will be of extraordinary benefit to low-paid women workers and, therefore, their children. So will creating paid paternity leave of two weeks. Even for the better paid, recognition of the fathers' role in parenting is a significant cultural breakthrough.

Most employer groups have reacted with caution verging on scepticism, despite the customary concessions promised to small business. British business resisted the introduction of women's lavatories after the First World War as an intolerable cost. The Government dismissed this opposition 80 years ago and should do the same over parental leave.

We realise that the right for parents to take paid time off to be with their newly-born babies risks coming under challenge from the childless. Some believe that they shoulder an undue burden in supporting what is a matter of choice - having children. But there is no reason why the childless should not enjoy the same right to have periodic sabbaticals to pursue their own choices. The Government should extend the principle of parental leave so that it becomes a component of what would become a universal entitlement.

webTitle: Over the counter in 25 minutes

fields.headline: Over the counter in 25 minutes
fields.trailText: It would have taken 25 minutes and three questions to get the morning-after pill over the counter in a supermarket on a Sunday afternoon in central Manchester.
fields.body:
It would have taken 25 minutes and three questions to get the morning-after pill over the counter in a supermarket on a Sunday afternoon in central Manchester.

This is not the pill that will go on sale for around £20 in chemists from the new year, but a free morning-after pill paid for by the NHS and provided over the counter by pharmacists to women as young as 13. It is a health action zone pilot scheme in Manchester, Salford and Trafford, which began on Christmas Eve last year. Women have driven from as far away as Buckinghamshire to get it.

The first hurdle was getting through to an operator on the NHS Direct helpline who could list Manchester chemists open on a Sunday. This took 10 minutes. An operator gave phone numbers of three local supermarkets open until 5pm. The nearest was five minutes' drive.

Beside a display of table sauces, Christmas peanut barrels and a special offer on 24-can packs of Carling Black Label, stood the sympathetic supermarket pharmacist who took women behind the counter to a secluded pine stool beside a shelf of Waspeze and E45 cream.

He asked about menstrual cycles, other medication taken, and the hours that had passed since sex. For audit reasons, he also asked if any form of contraception had been used.

He did not ask for the name of a GP, and said this pill would not be put on the patient's medical records. The pharmacist did ask for a name, but, as he said: "There is nothing to stop you saying you're called Mickey Mouse." All details and notes taken were countersigned by the patient and would go no further. The "consultation" was free and took 10 minutes.

Around 120 chemists in Greater Manchester offer this service and 6,600 women aged between 13 and 56 got the pill over the counter in Manchester this year. August figures were down on July, because of the large demand from the student population of 78,000 who go home for the holidays.

"Some women come in, answer all the questions then break down and admit they have never had sex, but want to keep the morning-after pill at home in case they do. Obviously we will not give it out in situations like that. It's not a form of contraception," the pharmacist said.

"I worry that once the morning after pill is available at a price over the counter the health professional's control in dispensing it will disappear. A woman would not have to buy it in person herself, which means a rapist or abuser could come in and buy it. We would lose valuable contact with the victim."

webTitle: VFG to create network of local TV stations

fields.headline: VFG to create network of local TV stations
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Video and film company VFG is planning a new network of local TV stations, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
VFG, the UK video and film facilities company, is planning to create a new national network of local television stations after acquiring 36 restricted service licences.

VFG has set up a company, Local Broadcasting Group, which has completed or agreed in principle to buy RSLs representing more than 55% of licences issued by the Independent Television Commission, for £7.4m in cash and shares.

VFG owns 46.4% of LBG.

The LBG management team includes former Yorkshire Television director David Lowen, who has come on board as chief executive, and veteran TV producer and distributor Richard Price, who is the chairman.

VFG chief executive David Stamp is to be vice-chairman.

The RSLs acquired by LGB include the 22 licences held by Herts TV in the home counties, East Anglia and Scotland; City Television's seven RSL franchises in the south-west; Glasgow's Own Television Channel, On Ayr Television and Channel 6 Television's Edinburgh and Aberdeen licences.

LBG has also secured options to acquire RSLs for York, Firth of Clyde and Inverness.

The potential audience for these stations is more than four million.

VFG has invested £4.75m in LBG, £4m of which came from a loan from a telecoms sector company. LGB is seeking to raise up to £50m to complete the roll-out of existing RSL stations within the group and fund the acquisition of other licences.

The outfit is planning to employ up to 750 people in its existing RSLs once they are fully operational.

The UK government has sold off surplus analogue spectrum over the last three years to create 63 RSLs, which allow operators to put out a service in a strictly defined geographical area.

webTitle: Nursing exodus 'hits target hopes'

fields.headline: Nursing exodus 'hits target hopes'
fields.trailText: At current rates 90,000 nurses will have left the NHS by 2004, bringing the total number of new nurses needed to 110,000, over five times the current government recruitment target, a study claims.
fields.body:
At current rates 90,000 nurses will have left the NHS by 2004, bringing the total number of new nurses needed to 110,000, over five times the current government recruitment target, a study claims.

Making Up the Difference, an independent report commissioned by the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) says the flood of nurses leaving the NHS must be halted if the target is to be met.

The government has confirmed that its target of recruiting 20,000 nurses by 2004 included part-time nurses and did not mean 20,000 full-time equivalent posts, which implied a larger number of recruits.

The college said the target was "highly ambitious" but "achievable", provided NHS Executives stuck to their pledge to implement its recommendations to recruit and retain nurses. These include an above-inflation pay rise, and mortgage subsidy schemes in areas with high living costs.

Paul Burstow, the Liberal Democrat health spokesman, yesterday published his own research showing the NHS faces a nursing crisis as its ageing workforce approaches retirement. Mr Burstow said the colleges report "confirms the results of our own research."

He said: "Poor planning under the Tories, and Labour's failure to recognise the scale of the problem, has meant young people have not been attracted into nursing. "The NHS plan has failed to address the stark fact that without better pay and conditions, younger nurses will not be persuaded to join the NHS."

A Department of Health spokesman said the health service had 16,000 more nurses than when the government took power.

But the shadow health secretary Liam Fox said that the report had masked the true situation, by failing to differentiate between full and part-time nurses. "The college is confirming what wehae all suspected - that the government pledge on urse numbers is a complete fabrication," said Dr Fox.

The health department spokesman said: "We are investing bilions to get more staff into the NHS. We have always been very clear that our figures involve the number of nurses, not the number of full time equivalents."

These include an above-inflation pay rise, and mortgage subsidy schemes in areas with high living costs. Paul Burstow, the Liberal Democrat health spokesman, yesterday published his own research showing the NHS faces a nursing crisis as its ageing workforce approaches retirement. Mr Burstow said the colleges report "confirms the results of our own research." He said: "Poor planning under the Tories, and Labour's failure to recognise the scale of the problem, has meant young people have not been attracted into nursing. "The NHS plan has failed to address the stark fact that without better pay and conditions, younger nurses will not be persuaded to join the NHS." A Department of Health spokesman said the health service had 16,000 more nurses than when the government took power. But the shadow health secretary Liam Fox said that the report had masked the true situation, by failing to differentiate between full and part-time nurses. "The college is confirming what wehae all suspected - that the government pledge on urse numbers is a complete fabrication," said Dr Fox. The health department spokesman said: "We are investing bilions to get more staff into the NHS. We have always been very clear that our figures involve the number of nurses, not the number of full time equivalents."

webTitle: Interview: Edward Fitzgerald QC

fields.headline: The great defender
fields.standfirst: His clients include public hate-figures such as Myra Hindley and one of James Bulger's killers. So why haven't you heard of Edward Fitzgerald QC? Because, Natasha Joffe finds, he is so sweet and unassuming - outside the courtroom.
fields.trailText: His clients include public hate-figures such as Myra Hindley and one of James Bulger's killers. So why haven't you heard of Edward Fitzgerald QC? Because, Natasha Joffe finds, he is so sweet and unassuming - outside the courtroom
fields.body:
It was the beef stroganoff that made me decide Edward Fitzgerald QC was probably the nicest man at the English Bar. We are sitting in a cavernous hotel dining room which is serving what must be the worst buffet lunch in London. Fitzgerald suggested the place in response to my request for somewhere quiet and then looks mortified when confronted by pans of vegetables treading water. The beef looks like curly bits of old tyre scattered on rice but when the waiter crosses an acre of floor to ask how it is - there were no other customers - Fitzgerald replies, feigning enthusiasm, "It's delicious", in case the waiter's feelings might be hurt.

It probably helps to be as nice as Fitzgerald if your clients include Myra Hindley and other lifers, Jon Venables (one of the two boys who killed James Bulger) various IRA prisoners - a good cross section of society's demons - if only to disarm a few critics. If you haven't heard of Fitzgerald that is most likely down to his niceness, too. He is clearly embarrassed about being interviewed at all but becomes animated at the end of the interview when he thinks of half a dozen worthier folk I might talk to (and write about instead "if it all turns out to be rubbish; I won't be offended") and numerous charitable organisations that "could use a bit of a plug". As one of the solicitors who briefs him says: "He does 20 times more human rights work than [he names another well known barrister] but he doesn't blow his own trumpet."

Hindley's former solicitor, Andrew McCooey, describes Fitzgerald as "a legal genius". The human rights lawyer Parvez Jabbar says: "Not only has he helped develop to the criminal jurisprudence of the English-speaking Commonwealth, he has saved lives."

When Fitzgerald won an award two years ago for his contribution to criminal justice, Lord Justice Schiemann said: "He could have made a fortune had he chosen to devote his talents to other fields of practice."

His attic room at Doughty Street chambers has the feeling of finely harnessed chaos that very clever, very busy people maintain. Vertiginous stacks of papers and ring binders line the walls. Here and there, a white tongue of A4 paper sticks out with a client's name printed in large letters. This, apparently, is a reform introduced by his personal assistant. I have the feeling Fitzgerald knew where everything was anyway.

His path to the bar was slightly meandering, perhaps because he was not initially persuaded that it was the best way to pursue his interests in prisoners' rights and young offenders. After qualifying, he spent six months as a drama master at the approved school once attended by Derek Bentley, later his posthumous client. He returned to the bar for pupillage and then did an MPhil in criminology before being lured back to work on Caribbean death-row cases. He has been working on prisoners' rights ever since. Along the way he married Lady Antonia Fraser's daughter, Rebecca, and had three daughters. His grandfather-in-law, coincidentally, is Lord Longford, the long-term activist for Hindley.

Fitzgerald is deeply apologetic about the fact that his duty not to discuss ongoing cases means he can't say anything much about Hindley, who is now challenging at the European Court of Human Rights the decision of successive home secretaries that, in her case, life means life. Or the Bulger case, in which Robert Thompson and Jon Venables await a decision on their application for an injunction to prevent disclosure of their identities after release.

He is happy, however, to talk to me about lifers generally and his reasons for challenging the mandatory imposition of a life sentence in murder cases. He sees the lack of discretion over sentencing as a clumsy tool which serves neither those sentenced nor their victims. What he would like to see is a far more highly developed sentencing phase to trials with the prosecution playing an active role in calling evidence, particularly in relation to the likely future dangerousness of the defendant and the impact of the crime on the victim's family. Then judges could make informed findings on such matters which would later help parole boards. And if victims' families were seen to have an input into the sentence, some of the anger generated in high-profile cases might be defused.

What is striking about Fitzgerald's proposals, and his views generally, is a sense of balance. He has represented the victims of crime (including Jayne Zito, whose husband was killed a by schizophrenic) as well as criminals, and his emphasis on the role of the prosecution and the rights of victims might surprise the Hindley-hating public. Nor does he deny that there are those for whom a life sentence should mean life: "The option of indefinite detention is a necessary one because there are people whose future dangerousness is very great."

What seems to underpin Fitzgerald's work is not a philosophical objection to punishment - "expiation is OK" - but a profound faith in the possibility of reform, particularly in the case of child offenders: "It's a very positive thing to represent a child because they can change and do change. A child that young tends to be a totally different person 10 years down the line."

It is a faith which sadly the great British public doesn't seem to share, if the hysteria generated by the likely release of Thompson and Venables is anything to go by. Even the likes of Hindley are capable of reform, as Fitzgerald told the House of Lords: "There is no dispute that her crimes were of the utmost gravity and deserving of punishment. But there is uncontradictable evidence that she has reformed and presents no danger to society."

Fitzgerald also makes what should be the obvious point that the law is failing child defendants when it tries under-14s in adult courts. He would like to see reforms beyond those he has already won in the Bulger case. In particular, he thinks under-14s should be tried in private and possibly without a jury.

In the case of child killers there should be, he believes, complete discretion in relation to sentencing: "There might have to be indefinite detention in some cases but the punitive element should be minimal. The sole issues should be are they reformed and are they safe and society is quite entitled to say we're not going to take any risks."

The only death row clients Fitzgerald himself has "lost" are the nine Trinidadian members of the Dole Chadee drugs gang whose final appeal to the privy council was rejected last year. He is wry about the often surreal logic that informs the argument in death penalty cases. He has argued that hanging is a "cruel and unusual" punishment but death by lethal injection would not be, to try to prevent executions in a jurisdiction where only hanging is authorised. But he is heartened by his successes. One former client is now a bus driver in Belize City, another a football player. There are close calls, including the occasion on which he got a stay of execution 20 minutes before a client was due to be executed: "I remember thinking then, if we don't get this stay I'm going to resign from the bar because it's so awful."

He seems slightly baffled by the suggestion from right-wing tabloid newspapers (and some judges) that the new Human Rights Act is a bean- feast for lawyers. "I'd rather there was litigation about human rights than medical negligence or libel. It's good that we are focusing on the big issues rather than small ones."

Fitzgerald is ambivalent about his judicial aspirations. He is 47, an age when the bench begins to beckon for many barristers. "The thing I like about the idea of being a judge is that your task on a daily basis is to try and do the right thing. Sometimes as an advocate you are exercising your ingenuity in ways which you might feel doesn't produce the result you necessarily agree with." On the other hand, though: "If you're a judge you've got to play by the rules of the game. You can't be a one-man maverick. That does pose problems."

Surprisingly, in view of the awards and accolades - one of his solicitors tells me Fitzgerald has been sent letters of thanks by law lords after appearing in the House of Lords - his first application to be a part-time judge was turned down. One wonders whether this might have anything to do with his advocacy on behalf of unpopular clients or his failure to publicise himself. Either way it is our loss.

webTitle: My New Media: Leon de Costa

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst:
Leon de Costa

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Leon de Costa
fields.body:
Favourite sites? ebay.com which I liken to a giant worldwide flea market. It's the world's biggest auction site. The items range in price from 10 cents up to 10m dollars and it has more than one and a half million items for auction. You can search for anything. As a joke my wife searched for antique Argentinian barbed wire and they had it. It's a phenomenal site, albeit that 99% is rubbish.

Last online purchase? I buy quite a lot online. The last thing was a vintage movie poster of Rasputin which I bought from a gallery in New York. Everything arrived perfectly.

Most recent technological faux pas? I needed to make a small change to the site but I couldn't get hold of our programmers. So I thought I'd try my HTML skills. The result was that I took our site off the air for three days for netscape users, until someone pointed out that the site wasn't available on that browser.

Main news sources on the web? The news feed I use most often is Yahoo and Altavista. It delivers the sort of news I need, such as developments in legal services and changes in the law.

Most persistent spam emailer? I don't get spam. I've got 2,500 emails in my outlook at the moment and not one is spam.

Time spent on the web? It's on from the moment I arrive at work until the moment I leave.

Next boo.com? I think it's going to be any site that places heavy reliance on WAP technology. Unless the information being delivered by WAP is simple, such as share prices or football scores, I can't see how WAP can deliver information in a manageable form.

Least useful site on web? Any site that asks you to fill in a form before you go any further. I immediately log off. Nobody asks you to fill in a questionnaire in a shop before you can go further. It's absurd.

Most useful site? Google - it's difficult to beat as a research tool.

Which screensaver do you use? I'm having a bespoke screensaver built at the moment. It's a little monk walking around the screen with a bag of posters. He pastes them on the screen like billboards - they are adverts for our website.

Most irritating things about the web? The noise of the modem when you dial up from home.

Do you bother with old media? Yes - I'm a media junkie. I buy the Times and the London Evening Standard every day, the Guardian and Sunday Business at the weekend.

Leon de Costa is chief executive of www.freelawyer.co.uk.

fields.headline: The future may be delayed
fields.trailText: I spent last week sipping margaritas and sunbathing with 10,000 of my closest colleagues at the Western Cable Show in LA. The things I do for Telewest. The title for the cable gabfest was Broadbandwagon - Into the Future.
fields.body:
I spent last week sipping margaritas and sunbathing with 10,000 of my closest colleagues at the Western Cable Show in LA. The things I do for Telewest. The title for the cable gabfest was Broadbandwagon - Into the Future.

Now, I know the cynics among you think that the broadbandwagon was suddenly unveiled as a shiny new idea when the narrowbandwagon was shown to have fewer legs than Long John Silver. The truth is, though, the future is sneaking up on us just at the moment when the markets are playing pass the tech stocks. The future just can't come quickly enough for some people.

Admittedly, narrowband internet was a bugger's muddle. Slow, inefficient dial-up, crap content, ISPs filling BT's bloated coffers with undeserved cash, and more plug-ins than an S&M club. The web produced trash economics where everything was free and nothing was valued. And yet, buried under the blizzard of vc guano the original vision still sparkles. There is a world of wonders where producers and consumers can meet without intermediaries; there are self-sustaining communities of interest who can create their own media using inexpensive digital devices. I can get what I want, when I want it. And the internet will be a space in which our best creative minds will invent new forms of content.

At the show, Barry Diller, one of the wise men of US media, proclaimed "everything of value takes time to mature". This echoes the views of many economists that just as the railways took 30 years to create a self-sustaining boom, as did the rise of computing, so the internet's effects on our lives and economies must be seen as a long-run benefit. Broadband will be like electricity - fundamental to our lives, but we'll never give it a thought until it is turned off.

Although broadband content and services are in their infancy, the show demonstrated that the race for dominant providers is on for real. At the hundreds of stands in the cavernous LA conference centre, the big guys were rolling out their product like honey traps for the cable operators. There were at least 10 interactive programme guides that make the EPGs here look like medieval road maps. The interactive handsets on display were intuitive and functional. Equally, it was clear that games were the new black, with demonstrations of everything from simple set top box quizzes, such as Playalong with Jeopardy, to Playstation2 driving games to turn you into an urban ram-raider.

At the sheer fun end of the spectrum, Disney had an instant animation feature which turned a digital picture of delegates into Toons and dropped them into a live show. Watching George W Bush, it seemed that someone had found an early use for this technology.

However, what struck me most about the displays wasn't the emerging content ideas, because I think we are still in the process of inventing those, it was the concept of wireless home networking.

The idea that all the devices with screens in your house will be linked together, and that high quality content and services will be available at high speed to an always-on connection will, if the evangelists at the stands are to be believed, transform the type of media and services we consume. I'm writing this at my desk surrounded by my digital music jukebox, CD, radio, TV, MP3, printer and electronic keyboard. The pile of wires at my feet looks like the intestines of an elephant. Wireless broadband networking frees us up.

I keep hearing the theme tune to 2001 when I make statements like this; God knows we've been hearing something like this for 10 years. Digital was supposed to do it, then the internet and now broadband. What's different this time? At the show, John Malone, one of cable's big cahunas, made the point that the media industry is like a cross country skier climbing a hill. When you look up, it seems a long climb, but when you look down you're amazed by how far you've come.

DSL (digital subscriber line) and early broadband cable are merely the beginning. Both promise to make the internet fast and begin to deliver proper multi-media content. But all of us are planning a world beyond this. BT is working on high-speed VDSL which may deliver multiple megabits of capacity, and at Telewest we're preparing for a 30-megabit world. At this point, delivering on demand everything is a breeze.

UK cable operators, unlike their US counterparts - who were hanging round the free popcorn stands and queuing to have their digital picture snapped with the pneumatic "model" at interactive erotic - have a built-in advantage. UK cable is new and ideally suited to the broadband future. And that was the other big message coming out of the Western Cable Show. Europe is ahead of the curve with interactive TV. Let's hope with the coming white paper, the government will promote this advantage, otherwise the future might be a longer time coming.

 David Docherty is managing director of broadband content at Telewest.

webTitle: The success of the Jewish Telegraph

fields.headline: All hands on deck
fields.standfirst:
It started with £50 and a borrowed typewriter. Fifty years on, the Jewish Telegraph has successfully seen off the competition. But it was a stormy ride, says editor Paul Harris

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It started with £50 and a borrowed typewriter. Fifty years on, the Jewish Telegraph has successfully seen off the competition.
fields.body:
If you will it, it is no dream, Theodor Herzl, the father of Zionism, pledged in the opening words of his novel, Old-New Land, in 1902. His dream was a Jewish homeland, which was eventually born in 1948. Two years later, a London Jew, my father Frank Harris, had his own, not unconnected aspiration - to provide the large Manchester Jewish community with its own paid-for newspaper.

The realisation of his dream was to lead to the birth of the Jewish Telegraph, which today produces four separate editions from offices in Manchester, Leeds, Liverpool and Glasgow.

My father and mother, Vivienne, with a borrowed typewriter and £50 capital, set about competing with the free Jewish Gazette and the London Jewish Chronicle, which circulated widely amongst the Jewish communities of the north.

Manchester Jewry immediately took to the Telegraph and it was no coincidence that its instant success came in the fledgling years of the state of Israel. Israel was big news. Even a member of the local community flying there made the front page.

But the growth of the Telegraph had not escaped the attention of the Jewish Chronicle, which felt the backlash and decided to act. In 1960 it acquired the ailing Jewish Gazette, installed it in smart city centre offices and started a Leeds edition. It poached the Telegraph's contract printer, which promptly gave six weeks' notice. The Telegraph, not for the first or last time, seemed doomed. But the London big boys had got it all wrong. By moving the Gazette from the heart of the community, they alienated it further, and the Gazette, which by now had become a paid title, saw its circulation continually slipping. By the early 1960s the Telegraph was selling twice as many copies as the Gazette and more than the Gazette and Chronicle combined in Manchester.

In 1976 a Leeds edition was launched. Five years later the monthly Liverpool Jewish Gazette was acquired and became a weekly, incorporated into the Telegraph, and then in 1991, as the Glasgow Jewish Echo collapsed, the Telegraph moved in at a few days notice with its own Scottish edition. In between my father had died suddenly on press day in July 1979 and it was left to me, with nine years' experience in the family business, to take the helm at the age of 28.

Not only was I editing and sub-editing the paper alone, but also acting as advertisement manager and even helping deliver the paper to wholesalers, such was the unpredictability of our production.

The 1980s should have spelt the end. By this time new backers had injected money into the Jewish Gazette, which not only reverted to free distribution, but also offered free advertising to those who guaranteed not to take space in the Telegraph. Its losses were far greater than ours. Only the support of its bank guaranteed the continuation of the Telegraph, whose sales continued to grow but whose annual losses were mounting. Undoubtedly, it was the final fight with the unions that saw the introduction of direct input that saved the company. Even that, with limited resources, meant that I had to design a system, since we could not afford to invest in any of the off-the-shelf packages.

Try telling our staff about over-manning and they would be amused. Our arts editor also edits the Leeds and Liverpool editions and the sports pages. And did I mention my deputy? He edits the Glasgow edition, the foreign supplement and the diary pages, too. All three of us are heavily involved in the Telegraph's hugely successful year-old website, as is the entire production staff.

If anyone doubts that the paper will pass to the third generation, my 18-year-old son, Robert, taught my staff Quark Xpress (the computer program used to design pages) before his teens. He has twice been involved with Manchester Grammar School's award winning newspaper, whilst his older brother, Alex, 21, who works in the computer industry, is the Telegraph's IT manager and is heavily involved with the website.

In 50 years, the Telegraph has had just two editors who between them have written every leader column. Is there a newspaper in this country, or in any other, that can match that . . . or a handwritten letter of congratulation from Michael Jackson?

webTitle: On the press

fields.headline: On the press
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Without phoning a friend, try this quiz. What do these stories which appeared in papers on November 30 suggest about education secretary David Blunkett's statements at an Institute for Public Policy Research seminar?
fields.body:
Without phoning a friend, try this quiz. What do these stories which appeared in papers on November 30 suggest about education secretary David Blunkett's statements at an Institute for Public Policy Research seminar?

1. Daily Express, under a picture of a boy laying flowers at the spot where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor died: "Cabinet minister David Blunkett yesterday condemned the money-mad culture exemplified by TVs Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?" 2. Daily Star, under the headline "Blunkett 'blames quiz show'", said he was "at the centre of a storm last night when he appeared to link Damilola's death to TV quiz show Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?" 3. The Independent, in a story which nosed off on the Damilola killing, claimed that Blunkett "singled out" the quiz for "cultivating a popular culture reminiscent of the yuppy era". 4. The Times, again in its Damilola story, quoted Blunkett as criticising the programme.

There is no prize because the answer is obvious. Blunkett clearly made a link between the boy's murder and the TV programme. The papers said so. It must be true. Yet it was far from the truth. Before his prepared speech, Blunkett did indeed refer to Damilola's killing, urging the creation of a society in which people don't walk on by when confronted by trouble. He then delivered his prepared text about the relationship between government and people, before a question-and-answer session. The first question was about the influence of consumer capitalism to which Blunkett replied: "In the 80s, yuppyism was seen as being the end of civilisation. We are back to Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? now. The people who produce programmes have a pretty low view of the rest of the world." This somewhat flip, but quite reasonable, response had nothing whatsoever to do with Blunkett's views on the murder of Damilola. Yet the Press Association report wired to newspapers made just that link. By juxtaposing his remarks on Damilola with those on the TV quiz, it looked as if he was suggesting that the programme was somehow responsible for the killing.

Alerted to the error during the afternoon, Blunkett's office contacted PA and urged the agency to amend its report. It later did so, filing a substitute story which deleted references to Damilola. By now, a reporter had also contacted the show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, to obtain his comments. But these, of course, were based on the false assumption of Blunkett's linkage between the death and the show. To make matters worse, PA's substitute was not accompanied by a note ordering the previous story to be killed, so some newspapers didn't realise that Blunkett's remarks were not linked. PA news editor Jonathan Grun says: "Directly we realised there should be no linkage we issued a new story. Blunkett's office seemed happy with that, which is why we didn't add an advisory note. Our watchwords here are 'accuracy and fairness'. The quotes were accurate. But we are happy to accept that it wasn't Mr Blunkett's intention to have his comments linked."

But IPPR director Matthew Taylor, who chaired the seminar, thought the PA story "highly tendentious". Quite apart from the false link, the millionaire remark was an off-the-cuff reply to a question. Not a single word of Blunkett's thought-provoking speech was reported. If the story had come and gone, perhaps none of this would have mattered. Instead, as is common now in a journalistic world dominated by columnists rather than reporters, Blunkett was subjected to days of ill-informed comment.

The Sun's Richard Littlejohn was vicious. The Daily Telegraph's Alice Thomson, the Daily Express's Martin Samuels, the News of the World's Michael Winner and the Sunday People's Sue Crawford all took Blunkett to task for making a link he had not made. Even a special PA note to editors which stated that it "would like to make clear" that the remarks were not linked was evidently ignored. Days later, Mick Hume in the Times was still criticising Blunkett. By now, it had featured also in the rest of the media, on BBC TV's Question Time and Radio 4's Today. Regional papers, such as the Scotsman - which accused Blunkett of "moralistic waffle" - had also weighed in.

Never truer was that maxim about a lie being halfway round the world before the truth is out. Though some papers, such as the Times, later ran apologies and several others carried letters, it is highly likely that most people still believe Blunkett blamed Damilola's murder on a gameshow.

Even if the error began at PA, it would be wrong to view the agency as the sole villain. This attitude about what constitutes a story stems from the current journalistic culture. It demeans all of us who work in newspapers.

Perhaps it would be carrying things too far to claim that falling journalistic standards are one of the reasons for declining sales. Anyway, whatever the reason, they continued their downward path again last month, as our chart below illustrates. It is noticeable though that broadsheet papers are doing much better than the tabloids. Despite slight losses by the Daily Telegraph and the Times, the overall picture for serious daily papers is bright.

It is too early yet to tell whether the new ownership of the Daily Express and Daily Star is having an impact, but the scale of Richard Desmond's task is clear. The Express sold only 823,432 copies at its full cover price in November compared to 2.2m sold by the Daily Mail. Of the Sundays, the figure that stands out is undoubtedly the Observer, up by 7.58% year on year. It needs to curb its quota of bulk sales, but these pale in comparison with the Independent on Sunday's 40,000-plus which account for more than 15% of its total.

One final note about the two Sunday sports papers which have done so well. Sport First enjoyed its fifth successive sales increase, up to 85,775 copies. The Non-League Paper also sold a creditable 42,216.

 Source: ABC

webTitle: American series on British TV under threat

fields.headline: Is the party over?
fields.standfirst:
Could you live without a weekly dose of ER or Friends? And could Channel 4 survive their loss? Fiona Morrow on how a threatened strike by American writers and actors could lead to a season of repeats on British television

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Fiona Morrow on how a threatened strike by American writers and actors could lead to a season of repeats on British television.
fields.body:
At a recent television press junket in the United States the first topic on everyone's lips was, of course, the presidential election. The second was the possibility of a strike by members of the Writers Guild of America, not to mention the possibility that actors might turn tail at the studio gates if their unions, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, are so mandated.

If that happens a host of American series might vanish from our screens. We're talking ER, we're talking The Sopranos, Buffy, X Files, The Simpsons - the whole bedrock of cult and essential telly as we know it.

On the Warner Brothers' lot in Los Angeles everyone is optimistic that it will all blow over, while simultaneously furrowing their brows and cranking their production schedules into overdrive. The story is much the same over at Fox, where the traditional hiatus periods - breaks of a week or more during the shooting periods - are under threat.

The producer of the moment, John Wells (ER, The West Wing, Third Watch) does his best to lighten the mood: "We're just working the writers into the ground before it happens," he jokes. And certainly Aaron Sorkin, the much feted writer of Wells' current hit The West Wing, is nowhere to be seen on the set.

The actors' unions tentatively flexed their muscles last week in a first meeting with studio chief executives, and alongside the likes of Holly Hunter, Edward Norton, Tobey Maguire and Ed Asner sat a representative of the small screen, ER's Noah Wyle. If the surface mood at least is still convivial, there's no doubt that a strike could quickly cause chaos. Television production in the US is such a tight ship that a hiccup can fast develop into a major trauma. An American series run typically consists of around 22 episodes, that's six months worth of programmes, each shot in around a week. Then they come to the UK for screening, still well before the entire run has been completed. In British TV production the episodes are screened almost as soon as they are finished, with a lag of only a few weeks.

The prospects are sad indeed: you will have no sooner completely reorganised your life around Buffy's spooky shenanigans or Dr Carter's struggle with drugs, than up will pop a voice announcing that due to unforeseen circumstances, they won't be back next week and nobody knows when they will return.

But it won't really have been unforeseen, because anyone connected with American programming over here has been keeping a close eye on developments.

Penny Harris, controller of acquisitions for Sky One, is frank about the potential disruption: "If there is a strike, we will be hit, just as all the other channels will." She's quick to stress Sky One's increasing move into home-produced programming, but admits that for profile and popularity it is the American shows that count.

The possibility of a strike has been a topic of much conversation between Sky One and Fox - its parent company and main supplier: "We are keeping a close eye on developments, but we have absolute faith that Fox will get us the programmes somehow," says Harris. She's hopeful, but has contingency plans just in case: "We are lucky to have a great deal of shows in stock already and, in the case of a strike, we can fall back on classic repeats."

Although Harris is taking the threat seriously, Sky One is perhaps in a slightly less difficult position than the terrestrial broadcasters, particularly Channel 4. It isn't unusual, after all, for repeats to turn up mid-run on Sky - subscribers know to watch out for "all-new episodes". The schedules are not as flexible at C4 where large audience shares for the likes of ER and Friends are crucial, and have cost the channel a great deal of their programme budget. And the viewers of these flagship shows are not necessarily core C4 viewers who will stick around to watch alter-native scheduling.
