webTitle: Battle of the ad breaks

fields.headline: Trailer wars
fields.standfirst: In an increasingly competitive TV marketplace, the big guns are having to become more agressive in promoting their programmesMediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: In an increasingly competitive TV marketplace, the big guns are having to become more agressive in promoting their programmes
fields.body:
At the end of Friday night's repeat of the first ever episode of Coro-nation Street, Bill Roache did a live link to camera from outside the Rovers Return, trailing the ITV schedule for the rest of the evening, including the live 40th-anniversary special of the venerable soap in which he was also to feature.

This may not exactly have seemed like a contender for the top 100 TV moments. But it was an important first for ITV, which, along with the other terrestrial broadcasters, is having to adopt more and more sophisticated trail techniques and strategies to catch and keep the attention of viewers in an ever more competitive multi-channel environment.

The practice of trailing upcoming goodies, whether through 30-second promos or continuity announcements between shows, has been around for a long time. But viewers are no longer willing to hang around while a broadcaster sticks its evening schedule on screen and the announcer takes a leisurely verbal stroll through the line-up. A click on the remote, and they're gone.

Craig Austin, ITV network presentation manager, says: "Multi-channel audiences are educated in fast-moving images, and the remote and the EPG are very much part and parcel of the viewing experience."

In the past couple of years the BBC, ITV and Channel 4 have responded to the growing competition from the upstart Channel 5 and the cable and satellite sector by adopting the interlopers' more sophisticated, marketing-led on-air promotional strategies.

In the process, the emphasis has moved towards trailing fewer shows more heavily. In an average week, BBC1 will trail around 15 upcoming shows, while Channel 4 focuses on 10-12 and BBC2 and Channel 5 just 10. In some cases, this has led to the number of programmes trailed each week on a channel dropping by half.

ITV is still trailing 20-24 forthcoming shows per week, but Austin says this number is currently under review and is likely to be reduced to 12-15 a week for individual programme campaigns.

Marketing folk justify this move as a more efficient use of airtime which, in the case of commercial broadcasters, could otherwise be sold to bring in advertising revenue. The value of Channel 4 airtime given over annu ally to programme promos has been estimated at £60-70m, while the ITV figure is £700m and the BBC's £1bn.

Techniques used in media planning for advertising campaigns are increasingly being imported into on-air programme promotion, with broadcasters also hiring staff from this commercial background into their marketing and presentation departments. People are trained to look at what audience demographic a show needs to attract and then draw up a pattern of promo spots to hit that target audience.

Jim Hytner, marketing and commercial director at Channel 5, says each show is treated "like an FMCG product" when it comes to on-air promotion. "You work in terms of coverage and frequency for the trails," Hytner adds. "With returning shows like House Doctor or Night Fever you need coverage and only a little frequency, because you only have to tell people it's coming back once.

"But with a new soap, you need maximum coverage and frequency, because you have to get people interested in something that's new to them over a period of time."

There are times with big Channel 5 event programmes, such as blockbuster movie premieres or live football, when viewers do not need much persuading to come and watch a show, but Hytner says it will be heavily trailed anyway for channel branding purposes. "We want to use known product to reinforce the channel's growing status."

Alan James, head of media planning in BBC Television's presentation department, says the key is to "prioritise", because "there are only so many messages people can take in".

"We try to work on the basis of effective frequency," he adds. "People need to see a message a certain number of times to decide if they are interested or not. At the end of a trails campaign, they will be able to see the benefits of watching that programme, or reject it."

BBC on-air campaigns may start up to three weeks before a show's transmission, though two weeks is more usual. For a new costume drama, James says up to four different trails may be produced, aimed at different parts of the target audience.

At ITV, the production of programme trails was handled by the individual regional companies in a system widely regarded as antiquated and inefficient, until just over two years ago when the Network Promotions Unit was set up in ITV's Grays Inn Road HQ in London.

Austin only came on board six weeks ago, with a remit to look at "junction management" - the area of handing over from one programme to the next, including on-air trails and continuity announcements. While he admits ITV has a "little bit of catching up" to do on this front, he says the aim now is to "get ahead of the opposition", importing techniques from more ferociously competitive TV markets such as the US and Australia.

Things, such as Bill Roache's live piece to camera in front of the Rovers Return on Friday night, are already beginning to happen. The previous Saturday, at the end of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? and Stars in Their Eyes Live Final, Chris Tarrant and Matthew Kelly had delivered trails for the shows that followed.

As part of ITV's recent news scheduling deal with the ITC, the broadcaster was given the freedom to do centre-break trails during shows for the first time. These slots are already being used for what Austin calls "countdown promos" - 20- second trails that tell the viewer that there are 45, 25 and 10 minutes to go before the next programme. Another US presentation tactic being adopted by ITV is end-credit promos, where the screen is split vertically, with the end credits to a show running down one side and a trail for an upcoming programme down the other.

Austin says ECPs have been tested successfully after Emmerdale and Coronation Street, and will be rolled out to other ITV ratings bankers in the new year. "We've got to coordinate continuity, presentation and promotion. We're hoping to take the audience through two or three programmes in a row."

While ITV - and the other mass-audience channel, BBC1 - are to a large extent looking to keep the same viewers watching their programmes through a whole evening, for Channel 4 the trails game is slightly different. As Felix Pearce, Channel 4 media strategy manager, explains, the broadcaster has a lot of "appointment to view" programming, with different types of audience dipping in for particular shows. So for Channel 4 the promos effort is more focused on directing viewers watching one show to similar types of programme in different slots across the week.

One of Pearce's key concerns is to reduce wastage of airtime on ineffective campaigns. At the moment, Channel 4 relies on software that uses 10-day old Barb statistics to analyse whether promos have been seen by more or less of the target audience than was planned. But the broadcaster is developing a system that will use overnight data, so Pearce and his colleagues will be able to adjust campaigns, adding or taking away trail spots, while they are still running.

Looking to the future, James reckons with the growth of digital media platforms offering consumers everything from TV and radio to computer games, on-screen trails and cross-promotion of shows and services is going to become an even more important weapon for the BBC and other broadcasters.

"Cross-promotion is going to be the lifeblood for anyone, like the BBC, with a sizeable portfolio of media outlets," says James. "Otherwise we just won't survive - we haven't got the cash to spend off air."

Stay tuned: battle of the breaks

ITV

ITV has recently been experimenting with removing the 12 black frames between commercials, as Channel 4 and Sky already do, in order to quicken the pace of ad breaks. In another initiative, the break between a Saturday night Millionaire and the following show, The Knock, was scrapped altogether in a bid to increase audience flow from the blockbuster quiz show to the customs drama. Other initiatives have included a special two- minute promo for returning sitcom Barbara.

BBC1

EastEnders during the week and Casualty and the National Lottery on Saturday night are the two most obvious places where the audience profile is constant week in, week out and peak-time shows can be trailed. Other reliable promotional slots include the Monday night comedy hour (other comedy and entertainment), Sunday night dramas, news bulletins (for factual shows) and Changing Rooms (leisure).

Channel 4

C4 gives around eight minutes a night over to trails, most of them in peak time. From this month onwards, around 6% of its promotional airtime will be devoted to cross-promoting FilmFour and its new pay-TV channel, E4.

Channel 4 has begun cross- promoting between Brookside and Hollyoaks, hoping to attract a younger audience to Brookie and an older one to the teen soap. As part of the drive to raise its age profile, Hollyoaks has also been trailed around adult-oriented shows such as The Sopranos, Ally McBeal and the late-night strand 4Music.

Channel 5

The 9pm movie provides Channel 5's biggest regular promotional slot, which is used in particular for trailing male- skewed documentaries such as The Moors Murders. Other slots with a known regular audience and which are therefore useful as trail positions include House Doctor, Night Fever and the Keith Floyd food shows.

webTitle: Carlton offloads Technicolor in £1.43bn deal

fields.headline: Carlton sells Technicolor for £1.43bn
fields.trailText: 9am: Carlton has confirmed the sale of its Technicolor film business to France's Thomson Multimedia in a £1.43bn deal, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications has confirmed the sale of its Technicolor film imaging and processing business to France's Thomson Multimedia in a cash and share deal worth around £1.43bn.

As part of the deal, Carlton will take a 5.5% stake in Thomson.

The two companies have also formed a strategic alliance covering digital interactive television, which will see the UK group invest £10m in TAK, Thomson's interactive TV joint venture with Microsoft.

Thomson will pay £934m in cash and Carlton will also receive 15.5m shares in the company, which will be released after one year.

webTitle: US and UK courtroom culture compared

fields.headline: More trade than profession
fields.standfirst:
Why do American courtrooms welcome reporters while British ones despise them? Duncan Campbell compares two cultures

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Why do American courtrooms welcome reporters while British ones despise them? Duncan Campbell compares two cultures.
fields.body:
'Objection, your honour!" "Objection over-ruled!" So familiar is the language of the American courtroom from countless films, television dramas and news reports that any Briton reporting from an American court feels instantly at home. Here is the pugnacious defence lawyer delivering an uppercut to a floundering witness, there is the robed judge looking down over his bi-focals and asking the duelling attorneys to address the bench.

But how much real difference is there in covering the judicial process in the land of the first amendment? The view from the press benches in the courtrooms in Florida and California over the past couple of months suggests that the difference is as great as the distance between the bowels of the Old Bailey where the press are quartered like the below-stairs staff and the foyer of the courtrooms of Tallahassee from where they venture forth to civic receptions laid on in their honour.

While in British courts, the staff often take a quiet pleasure in ensuring that only a limited number of journalists can get access in a big trial, here the efforts of the staff were dedicated to trying to squeeze in as many journalists as possible, allowing them to stand at the back of the court, clamber over each other into the jury box - and position camera crews and photographers in such a way that their view was not obstructed.

Who was N Sanders Sauls, we all asked when the judge was chosen to hear the case. A court official, apologetic that she did not have a full biography of the judge, provided the names and telephone numbers of eight lawyers who would know his work and background and had agreed to be quoted about it. So we learned that he drank in the 4th Quarter - where the owner confirmed that many other judges drank there and insisted on giving us a free beer - and that he had been voted the most intellectual boy in his school year and the most likely to succeed. Seeking similar instant information about a judge in a British court would lead usually either to a disdainful look or a contempt of court charge.

As each session ended, lawyers from both sides would brief journalists on the session. Here again was an acceptance by the lawyers that some of the arcane detail in court might have been lost on the layman. They took questions from the press, they elucidated, they went on the record. There are certainly lawyers like that in British courts but they are very much in the minority.

In Britain, the press is regarded by the legal profession as trade, while in America it is considered a profession. This has its good and bad sides. In Britain, the relevation that George W Bush was a convicted drunk driver who had dissembled about his conviction would have been a splash in every newspaper and would possibly have cost him the election. In the US, many newspapers found it almost below their dignity to report it.

But it is in the courts that the different attitudes are most striking. Catching up on a trial in San Diego, I rang the court and asked if I could talk to someone who would know what stage it was at. I was put through to a court clerk speaking in such hushed tones that I wondered if she had some voice impediment. In fact, I had been put through to the courtroom itself where the judge was beginning his summing up. Not only did the clerk not tell me to get off the line but she summarised what the judge had said so far, gave me the genders of the jury and asked if there was anything else I needed to know. If, perchance, you had come through with similar impertinent question to a British court in session, you would have had your ear bitten off and spat back at you down the line.

In access to prisoners, too, the two systems differ. In the US, under the first amendment a prisoner who wants to be interviewed has a consitutional right to be visited by a reporter. This attitude spreads to the police who offer ride-along facilities to journalists who want to sit in the back of a patrol car for a night's reporting. Out for a night with the New York police, I had been asked by a senior officer not to take a camera but the two officers, both Italian Americans from Long Island, insisted on stopping to buy me an instant camera at a drug store.

And, finally, some evidence of the joys of court reporting in the US for which there can be no accounting. A few years ago, on a mission to report on the Bronx county court in New York and compare it to Tom Wolfe's Bonfire of the Vanities, I came across two lawyers, a defence attorney and his prosecuting counterpart, in a huddle. The judge came out of his chambers and saw them together: "Hey, what are you two doin' - collaboratin'?" "Sure, judge," replied one. "What you gonna do about it - shave our heads?"

Not only did the clerk not tell me to get off the line but she summarised what the judge had said so far, gave me the genders of the jury and asked if there was anything else I needed to know. If, perchance, you had come through with similar impertinent question to a British court in session, you would have had your ear bitten off and spat back at you down the line. In access to prisoners, too, the two systems differ. In the US, under the first amendment a prisoner who wants to be interviewed has a consitutional right to be visited by a reporter. This attitude spreads to the police who offer ride-along facilities to journalists who want to sit in the back of a patrol car for a night's reporting. Out for a night with the New York police, I had been asked by a senior officer not to take a camera but the two officers, both Italian Americans from Long Island, insisted on stopping to buy me an instant camera at a drug store. And, finally, some evidence of the joys of court reporting in the US for which there can be no accounting. A few years ago, on a mission to report on the Bronx county court in New York and compare it to Tom Wolfe's Bonfire of the Vanities, I came across two lawyers, a defence attorney and his prosecuting counterpart, in a huddle. The judge came out of his chambers and saw them together: "Hey, what are you two doin' - collaboratin'?" "Sure, judge," replied one. "What you gonna do about it - shave our heads?"

webTitle: My media: Peter Hitchens

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst:
Peter Hitchens

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Peter Hitchens
fields.body:
Newspapers: The Express, Daily Mail, Telegraph, Guardian, Times, Sun and Herald Tribune are essential. On Sunday, the Mail, Express, Independent, Telegraph, and I quite like the Observer.

Magazines: I'm fond of the Spectator, but American magazines such as National Review, Weekly Standard and National Interest give me more of a boost. Conservatism is much more confident there than in Britain. I also read New Statesman and Prospect.

Television: As little as possible. So much of it seems to have coarse language or a tedious concentration on sex.

Radio: I used to listen to the World Service, but I can't get it where I live. Radio 4 for the Today programme, the World Tonight, Moral Maze and Any Questions. And 5 Live and Classic FM.

Books: I'm reading CP Snow's The New Men, about the development of the British nuclear bomb. I recently read The Isles by Norman Davies. My all-time favourites are A Tale Of Two Cities and Great Expectations.

Films: I recently saw Galaxy Quest. It's aimed at Trekkies and is very funny. I saw What Lies Beneath when I was in Washington and couldn't watch the end. My best films are The Third Man and Farenheit 451, about a society in which books are illegal, based on a Ray Bradbury novel.

Adverts: I've come to hate lots of advertising. It makes life so coarse. The FCUK campaign in particular has lowered the tone of the country. A lot of advertising seems deliberately designed to make laddishness and bad language mainstream.

New media: I'm not exactly a fan of the internet - it's useful but not as miraculous as it's cracked up to be. I like being able to read US papers and magazines online and I check the British Library catalogue for books. Like all vain authors, I check Amazon to see how my sales are going. And I like to see the nasty things people have written about me. It's true, I confess, it's irresistible.

 Express columnist Peter Hitchens was signed up last week by the Mail on Sunday.

webTitle: Tombs loses out in BBC scheduling shake-up

fields.headline: Tombs loses out in BBC scheduling shake-up
fields.trailText: 8am: The reorganisation of the BBC TV scheduling department has left BBC1 scheduler Matt Tombs without a job, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The management reorganisation has finally been completed in the BBC television scheduling department, leaving BBC1 scheduler Matt Tombs without a job.

Mr Tombs' position has become part of the responsibilities of former head of scheduling Adam MacDonald, who has taken the newly created post of head of planning and scheduling for BBC1.

He has been offered other posts within the BBC, including special assistant to BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey, but is said to be considering his options.

Mr Tombs was a drama script editor before moving into scheduling - where he was responsible for BBC2 before stepping up to the BBC1 job in January 1999.

It is thought he may move back to drama. He previously worked on sci-fi action series Bugs and the Kevin Whately vehicle the Broker's Man.

He is currently on leave while he considers his next career move.

Mr MacDonald, who previously oversaw the scheduling team for BBC1 and BBC2, will concentrate solely on the BBC's flagship channel. He is a former scheduler of BBC1 and BBC2.

But a BBC spokeswoman denied that the move back to BBC1 was an effective demotion for Mr MacDonald.

She said: "This is absolutely not a downgrading. It is a reconfiguration of scheduling and planning to give a more dedicated focus to each of the channels.

"BBC1 is the biggest and best job and Adam is our most experienced scheduler."

Mr MacDonald will oversee both scheduling, which looks up to nine months ahead, and planning, which covers periods of two years and beyond.

He reports to BBC Television head of operations Mark Thomas, who has risen swiftly within the corporation under new director-general Greg Dyke in the last year.

Mr Thomas, who was a protege of deputy director of TV David Docherty, was appointed to his current post in July.

He worked on Mr Dyke's plan for the BBC corporate structure and then director of television Mark Thompson's new commissioning structure.

As part of the overhaul of BBC scheduling, BBC 2 scheduler Liam Keelan is staying put and adding the channel planning brief to his responsibilities.

webTitle: BBC warned over cash for new sports channel

fields.headline: BBC warned over cash for new sports channel
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC must pass a series of tough tests before it is allowed to launch a subscription-based sports channel, Whitehall officials warned yesterday. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC must pass a series of tough tests before it is allowed to launch a subscription-based sports channel, Whitehall officials warned yesterday.

The culture department insisted that the corporation must not use licence fee money to cross-subsidise the new channel, which the BBC said yesterday could be on air by the end of next year.

Peter Salmon, the corporation's director of sport, said he was determined to put BBC Sport back on the map after years of humiliating decline. With an increased budget and new revenue from subscriptions, the BBC plans to mount serious bids to regain some of the sports rights it has lost.

Mr Salmon pledged to recapture rights to Premiership football highlights and England's Six Nations rugby matches.

He has already signed a deal to show boxing matches on Saturday afternoons. The return of boxing to BBC1's Grandstand is a major boost. The loss of football highlights was also a significant blow.

Over the past few year s, BBC Sport has lost a number of significant sports rights: Test cricket, the Derby, the Ryder Cup, formula one motor racing, England's Six Nations matches and Premiership highlights have all slipped away.

But the BBC has shown signs of a reversal of fortunes - the Derby is coming back to the BBC, along with the FA Cup.

Mr Salmon believes a combination of the BBC's access to big audiences and the new injection of cash will tempt back sports rights holders. He said in an interview with the Observer yesterday: "There needs to be a mix of cash, profile and exposure. They aren't going to give us the sports. We have to have enough cash. But at the same time we do offer extraordinary exposure."

He said Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, had held talks with the Rugby Football Union about England's Six Nations matches returning to the BBC. While the RFU's deal with Sky is lucrative, the matches have been seen by relatively small audiences. Mr Salmon said: "Between 500,000 and 700,000 people see England on Sky. On the BBC it would be 8m."

Any plans to start a new subscription sports channel would have to be approved by the culture secretary, Chris Smith. A spokesman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport said Mr Smith would have to be satisfied that there was no cross-subsidy between licence fee-funded services and the new channel.

He said: "What they must do, and what Chris Smith will not permit them to do, is to use licence money to subsidise the channel. Clearly they are going to be using the invaluable archive that the BBC has, as well as BBC presenters and production staff. That's all fine, so long as the new channel pays the market rate for these services and people."

The BBC confirmed yesterday that it had been in talks with a number of potential commercial partners for the new venture. It is understood that a firm proposal could be put to Mr Smith by Easter, and the channel launched as early as next autumn.

A BBC spokesman said: "It is well known that BBC Sport has ambitions to develop, in some way, a sports channel and has been talking to a variety of potential partners.

"That remains the situation and, in an interview, the director of sport has indicated that the ambition has moved slightly closer and that there is a possibility that matters will develop."

webTitle: Should the Today programme be independent?

fields.headline: Tame the rottweilers
fields.standfirst:
Recent controversies about BBC Radio 4's Today programme raise the question of whether it should remain independent or be a government noticeboard.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Recent controversies about BBC Radio 4's Today programme raise the question of whether it should remain independent or be a government noticeboard.
fields.body:
Rod Liddle has no hobbies, interests, hinterland or, indeed, personality. At least, that is what the editor of the Today programme would have us believe, since these words conclude his potted biography on the show's website. But if he were being interviewed by his own personal rottweiler, John Humphrys, you can imagine that he would not be allowed to get away with such a mischievous misrepresentation of the truth.

In fact, Liddle is one of the programme's most charismatic editors. He is variously described as an iconoclast, a self-publicist, a bit of an oddball, an outsider, an irritant, a genius. He named his son Wat, after Wat Tyler, leader of the peasants' revolt. He has, it is said, played in a rock band; although since Tony Blair admitted to a similar heritage, that's not quite such a cool boast as it once was. He has many interests and hobbies, one of which is his delight in being different. Since he took over on the Today programme two years ago he has certainly stirred things up: that is, after all, what Britain's most influential broadcast news programme is all about.

But now, it seems, the knives are out for Today. And that doesn't mean Alistair Campbell has been on the phone again - or indeed the accusations of bias in the eurosceptic press over the past week - this time, it is insiders at the BBC who seem to be having trouble with Today.

For a long time, Today has worked outside the usual scheme of things at the BBC. It does its own thing, and stands on toes all over the organisation. But its journalistic brilliance and place at the heart of the nation's political consciousness has been so great that its position has, and always will be, protected. From time to time, however, something comes up that really raises the hackles of Today's detractors, and lands the programme in trouble. And every time Today is in trouble, it is not just a bowl of hot water, but a great swirl of molten lava.

This time, the snipers have turned their fire on a recent report about the European Union. The report, by Andrew Gilligan, highlighted a debate about whether discussions to codify the EU's various treaties amounted to a putative constitution for a European super-state. A euro scare-story, said Downing Street (which childishly and perhaps libellously branded its author "gullible" Gilligan); yet the programme was "endemically biased in favour of the euro", said Lord Pearson of Rannoch, a leading eurosceptic who had an on-air row with James Naughtie.

The political spat was hardly surprising. Liddle says it is a typical trick of Today's opponents: Campbell will rubbish the story at the morning briefing to political journalists at Downing Street and the story becomes "BBC bias", helpfully obscuring the original scoop and stamping on any sensible debate on whether there is going to be an EU constitution or not.

But what has raised eyebrows is the reaction of some within the corporation. One senior member of the editorial staff on another Radio 4 news programme expressed serious reservations about the report. It had gone too far, the source alleged, and threatened to undermine the BBC's treasured reputation for impartiality. "It was damaging to the BBC brand."

It was alleged that the report misrepresented the true position: EU spokesmen insist in public that the treaty codification does not amount to a constitution.

Liddle and Gilligan stand by the piece, and on the Today programme on Friday, Michel Barnier, the commissioner who is responsible for EU enlargement, said moves towards "a fundamental and constitutional treaty" should be welcomed. Gilligan says: "The BBC management went over it with an electron microscope and nobody has been able to fault a single word."

Yet what is at issue is not whether the report was a misrepresentation. The far more interesting debate is the internal hand-wringing over Today. There is, says one insider at the programme, a "battle for the soul of Today", being waged between the "Pathe News tendency" who believe that the programme should be the noticeboard of government, and those who believe it should be something more ambitious. Liddle is most definitely in the second camp.

Outside Today, this has not gone unnoticed. "What makes people annoyed is that Rod thinks his job is to stir things up, and to hell with everyone else," says the senior journalist from the rival Radio 4 programme. "I can't tell you how enraged people are." Another member of BBC radio's editorial staff adds: "I think there is a feeling around the place that some of them push things a bit too far in an effort to make something sound new."

Some have also raised concerns about the programme's presenters: John Humphrys has expressed Eurosceptic views in a Sunday Times column, while critics accuse James Naughtie of being close to Labour's leadership. However, no one has ever come up with evidence that either has allowed his personal opinions to influence a broadcast.

One Liddle admirer, and former Today programme journalist, says he will not be cowed. "I think there are two very clear dichotomies in BBC news and current affairs. There are those who think that Today is superb, and there are those who think it has got too big for its boots. And there is another dichotomy between those who think that Rod is a wild self-publicist, and those who regard him as a genius."

Certainly, Liddle encourages his reporters to "push things". In this sense, he works in the same way as any Fleet Street editor. His reporters are encouraged to originate stories rather than follow the daily agenda, and are given the time and space to do so. Under his direction, Today has built up its own network of corre spondents - Gilligan is one of them - who work outside the grinding mill of the BBC's newsgathering division. Inevitably, those who are not given such a privileged position are irritated. The BBC Brussels office was furious that it was not consulted over the EU report, and made its views clear to managers at BBC news. Such was the ferocity of the complaints, from within and outside the BBC, that the issue made its way right up the line to the director of news, Tony Hall. It is understood that, even after a fine tooth-comb examination, Today was exonerated.

There was also concern about a recent story about the NHS, which claimed that health trusts were worried about their ability to cope this winter. Again, some of the BBC's specialist health journalists were concerned; the trusts denied the report, although Today appeared to be vindicated last week when ministers warned of impending problems in the health service.

Today is in an unenviable position, in that it can't answer internal critics in public. Yet there are some at Today who are equally scathing. "Can you name me one story that is broken by BBC newsgathering? Our lot are breaking stories all the time," says a Today source, pointing out that a report by a Brussels correspondent - not a Today reporter - attracted one of the programme's few reprimands from the corporation's programme complaints unit.

Today insists that its success is built on journalistic rigour, not hype. Those who work on the programme point out that it secured the only interview with the struck-off gynaecologist Rodney Ledwood; made the law courts with an interview with Bobby Kelly, the teenager who ran away with a cult; revealed that only 5% of the targets of Nato bombs dropped on Kosovo could be verified; and was first with the damning Deloitte Touche report on the Dome. "I think there is some jealousy at our journalistic success. We don't need to try to get into the papers because we do that anyway," says one.

Gilligan says: "21 of my stories have been followed up by newspapers. We do not overspin stories - the papers wouldn't follow up over spun stories." Stephen Mitchell, the BBC's head of radio news and a staunch supporter of Liddle, says the internal debate is nothing new. "It's not a new story, and it's normal. There is always healthy journalistic discussion between reporters about the merits or otherwise of a story. A lot of that goes on within the BBC, just as I'm sure it goes on in the Guardian. Today's brief is to be very ambitious journalistically, and in being journalistically ambitious, you are going to make waves within and outside the BBC."

Mitchell concedes that there are tensions between BBC's newsgathering division - whose job is to supply all the BBC's news outlets - and the special requirements of Today and Radio 4's other main news programmes. He carefully points out that, in following the daily diary, newsgathering reporters are performing a vital task.

He also stresses that many newsgathering journalists, including social affairs editor Niall Dickson and political editor Andrew Marr, regularly appear on Today. And to ease concerns, he has appointed a senior editor from Radio 4 and a senior editor from newsgathering to meet regularly to discuss the various needs.

Liddle is sanguine about the row, and backs Gilligan to the hilt. "I'm hugely proud of our journalists and what they have done. In any huge corporation there are always those who carp and cavil, but I still believe in everything we have done. I think it's a febrile political atmosphere at the moment and a programme as hugely high profile as Today is going to be under the microscope."

Liddle knows that the pressure will intensify as the next election approaches. But, given his track record, he is unlikely to bow to his detractors. Still, the Lord Rannochs of this world are unlikely to be mollified.

In the huge machine that is Today, there are bound to be misjudgments from time to time. "We are not above criticism, we are accountable," Liddle says. But criticisms need to be seen in perspective, he insists. "We make mistakes. For instance, I don't think we did enough on the murder of Damilola Taylor. But no one complained about that to me."

* One of the most criticised - and best-loved - characteristics of the Today programme is its abrasive interviewers: John Humphrys is only the latest in a long line of breakfast rottweilers.

*Humphrys' style was criticised by the BBC's programme complaints unit this year when he was deemed to have overstepped the mark in an interview with the Nato chief, Lord Robertson.

*The literary ambitions of all three principal Today presenters have raised eyebrows. Sue MacGregor is to receive a reported £250,000 for her autobiography; that of John Humphrys was scathing about BBC management; and James Naughtie is to write an unauthorised account of the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown.

*The revamping of Thought for the Day was a source of controversy when regular contributors were "rested".

*Generations of Today presenters have struggled to impart the time of day to listeners: Jack de Manio famously got it wrong on a regular basis, and Humphrys is lampooned on the Dead Ringers impressionist show for his time-telling skills.

*Margaret Thatcher once phoned the programme live when she wanted to talk about the cancellation of Mikhail Gorbachev's trip to Britain.

*Both Labour and the Conservatives have been accused of attempting to rig the programme's Personality of the Year contest in favour of their leaders.

Our lot are breaking stories all the time," says a Today source, pointing out that a report by a Brussels correspondent - not a Today reporter - attracted one of the programme's few reprimands from the corporation's programme complaints unit. Today insists that its success is built on journalistic rigour, not hype. Those who work on the programme point out that it secured the only interview with the struck-off gynaecologist Rodney Ledwood; made the law courts with an interview with Bobby Kelly, the teenager who ran away with a cult; revealed that only 5% of the targets of Nato bombs dropped on Kosovo could be verified; and was first with the damning Deloitte Touche report on the Dome. "I think there is some jealousy at our journalistic success. We don't need to try to get into the papers because we do that anyway," says one. Gilligan says: "21 of my stories have been followed up by newspapers. We do not overspin stories - the papers wouldn't follow up over spun stories." Stephen Mitchell, the BBC's head of radio news and a staunch supporter of Liddle, says the internal debate is nothing new. "It's not a new story, and it's normal. There is always healthy journalistic discussion between reporters about the merits or otherwise of a story. A lot of that goes on within the BBC, just as I'm sure it goes on in the Guardian. Today's brief is to be very ambitious journalistically, and in being journalistically ambitious, you are going to make waves within and outside the BBC." Mitchell concedes that there are tensions between BBC's newsgathering division - whose job is to supply all the BBC's news outlets - and the special requirements of Today and Radio 4's other main news programmes. He carefully points out that, in following the daily diary, newsgathering reporters are performing a vital task. He also stresses that many newsgathering journalists, including social affairs editor Niall Dickson and political editor Andrew Marr, regularly appear on Today. And to ease concerns, he has appointed a senior editor from Radio 4 and a senior editor from newsgathering to meet regularly to discuss the various needs. Liddle is sanguine about the row, and backs Gilligan to the hilt. "I'm hugely proud of our journalists and what they have done. In any huge corporation there are always those who carp and cavil, but I still believe in everything we have done. I think it's a febrile political atmosphere at the moment and a programme as hugely high profile as Today is going to be under the microscope." Liddle knows that the pressure will intensify as the next election approaches. But, given his track record, he is unlikely to bow to his detractors. Still, the Lord Rannochs of this world are unlikely to be mollified. In the huge machine that is Today, there are bound to be misjudgments from time to time. "We are not above criticism, we are accountable," Liddle says. But criticisms need to be seen in perspective, he insists. "We make mistakes. For instance, I don't think we did enough on the murder of Damilola Taylor. But no one complained about that to me." * One of the most criticised - and best-loved - characteristics of the Today programme is its abrasive interviewers: John Humphrys is only the latest in a long line of breakfast rottweilers. *Humphrys' style was criticised by the BBC's programme complaints unit this year when he was deemed to have overstepped the mark in an interview with the Nato chief, Lord Robertson. *The literary ambitions of all three principal Today presenters have raised eyebrows. Sue MacGregor is to receive a reported £250,000 for her autobiography; that of John Humphrys was scathing about BBC management; and James Naughtie is to write an unauthorised account of the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. *The revamping of Thought for the Day was a source of controversy when regular contributors were "rested". *Generations of Today presenters have struggled to impart the time of day to listeners: Jack de Manio famously got it wrong on a regular basis, and Humphrys is lampooned on the Dead Ringers impressionist show for his time-telling skills. *Margaret Thatcher once phoned the programme live when she wanted to talk about the cancellation of Mikhail Gorbachev's trip to Britain. *Both Labour and the Conservatives have been accused of attempting to rig the programme's Personality of the Year contest in favour of their leaders.

webTitle: 'Help squad' to sort out housing benefit chaos

fields.headline: 'Help squad' to sort out housing benefit chaos
fields.trailText: Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, will today crack the whip against local authorities that have brought the £11bn housing benefit system close to collapse.
fields.body:
Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, will today crack the whip against local authorities that have brought the £11bn housing benefit system close to collapse.

After evidence that tenants were being evicted because administrative chaos was causing them to fall into rent arrears, he will admit that the system is "failing miserably" in some areas.

Mr Darling will appoint a "help squad" to sort out the worst bottlenecks. And the government will simplify the benefit rules to help claimants, particularly young people whose chances in the jobs market are being blighted by lack of stable accommodation.

The changes follow censure by the Commons social services committee. It told the government in July to simplify rules that were confusing claimants in nearly 5m households and causing chaos in many areas.

Edward Osmotherley, the local government ombudsman, called in the chief executives of four London boroughs where problems were severe. He said there were 1,669 complaints of maladministration of housing benefit in the London region during the last financial year and 60% were in Lambeth, Islington, Hackney and Southwark, where the service was run by private contractors.

Mr Darling's team will go into the struggling authorities to shake up their administrative systems and set targets for improvement. The team will include management specialists and representatives from councils that are managing the present system well.

webTitle: Battle for US presidency reaches supreme court

fields.headline: Battle for US presidency reaches supreme court
fields.standfirst:
Bush and Gore fight in supreme court

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Two of America's most senior judges, both nominated to the US supreme court by the Republican president Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, hold the future of the 2000 election dispute between George W Bush and Al Gore in their hands in Washington today.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and Julian Borger in Tallahassee
fields.body:
Two of America's most senior judges, both nominated to the US supreme court by the Republican president Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, hold the future of the 2000 election dispute between George W Bush and Al Gore in their hands in Washington today.

Sandra Day O'Connor, the first woman to serve on the court, and Anthony Kennedy, a judge with a reputation as a consensus builder, are the prime targets of Mr Gore's lawyers as they seek to swing just one vote their way in the deeply divided nine-member court today.

If the Gore lawyers can persuade either of the two traditionally pivotal judges to join the four liberals who opposed Saturday's halting of the Florida recount then the counts will begin again, perhaps as early as this evening, and Mr Gore will still be in with a chance of snatching the White House.

If they fail, as many American observers again expect them to do, Mr Gore will have nowhere else to go in his five-week effort to get all the disputed votes counted in Florida, his lead lawyer, David Boies, said yesterday.

"If no votes are counted, then I think that's the end of the road," Mr Boies said in a television interview. The nine justices of the supreme court "have the power to decide this", he added.

Mr Boies refused to say if he thought Mr Gore would concede the election in the event of losing the supreme court, but Richard Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House of Representatives, said: "I believe he will."

Both sides were scheduled to file their written arguments, limited to 50 pages each, by 4pm yesterday in advance of today's 90 minutes of argument in the case which could, in effect, decide the outcome of the November 7 election.

Appropriately, the case set down for hearing today is called simply but tellingly "George W Bush v Albert Gore" on the court list.

No timetable has been announced for the court to issue its ruling, which could come at any time once the arguments are completed.

After the dramas of Friday, when the Florida supreme court reignited Mr Gore's hopes by ordering a count of 40,000 or more disputed ballots, and Saturday, when the US supreme court intervened 5-4 to stop the count in its tracks, yesterday was an eerily quiet day in America's constitutional drama. Both Mr Bush and Mr Gore remained out of the public eye.

There was brief flurry of excitement in Tallahassee when reports suggested that the ballot papers from Miami-Dade county that are at the heart of the argument had been moved to Washington to be entered as evidence.

The Florida supreme court later announced that the ballots remained in Tallahassee and were thus available for officials to resume counting if the US supreme court so ruled.

Expectations that Mr Bush will win centred on the fact that the court had issued Saturday's stay, which requires a high legal test to be satisfied before such a move is made.

"It suffices to say that the issuance of the stay suggests that a majority of the court, while not deciding the issues presented, believe that the petitioner [Mr Bush] has a substantial probability of success," the conservative justice Antonin Scalia wrote in an opinion issued with the order.

webTitle: C4's Angel rescheduled to adult slot

fields.headline: C4's Angel rescheduled to adult slot
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Channel 4 has been forced to reschedule supernatural drama Angel to a post-watershed slot amid concerns about the show's 'dark tone', writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has been forced to reschedule supernatural drama Angel to a post-watershed slot amid concerns about the show's "dark tone".

The Independent Television Commission received complaints from 86 viewers.

Many were concerned about the violence and adult tone of Angel, which had been going out at 6pm.

But some fans of the show were dismayed about the amount of editing required to make the show suitable for the early evening slot.

After being made aware of the ITC's concerns, Channel 4 moved the show to a post-9pm slot in late November.

Angel is a spin-off from Buffy the Vampire Slayer and centres around a reformed vampire fighting evil supernatural forces in modern-day Los Angeles.

Initially Channel 4 defended its scheduling of the show, saying that "through appropriate editing, younger as well as older viewers could watch it in an early evening slot".

But the ITC said that after viewing the series, it was concerned "about the dark tone of Angel's world which often involved adult situations that many children could find disturbing".

Even with editing, the regulator considered three episodes "were unsuitable for this early evening slot".

These episodes featured, respectively, "scenes of torture and paedophile references", a stalker and "images more reminiscent of a late-night horror film", and a "harrowing storyline with a mother bricking up her son alive".

The ruling is included in the ITC's Programme Complaints and Findings report for November 2000.

webTitle: Standalone future of UK commercial radio 'in danger'

fields.headline: Standalone future of UK commercial radio 'in danger'
fields.trailText: 8am: The future of the UK commercial radio sector as a standalone industry is in danger, according to the boss of market leader GWR, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The future of the UK commercial radio sector as a standalone industry is in danger, according to the boss of market leader GWR.

Ralph Bernard made his comments ahead of this week's publication of the communications white paper, amid fears that the radio industry will be sidelined by the attention given to the future of ITV.

Mr Bernard said the current points system, which allocates units according to the size of the station, was out of date and was letting inexperienced players into the market.

He said: "The UK has overtaken the US in terms of quality because radio-only companies are running the industry, but that will stop if we are not allowed to grow. As a standalone industry it is absolutely in danger."

Mr Bernard added that it was "no secret" that GWR would be at the forefront of industry consolidation if the white paper opens the floodgates by allowing companies to snap up far greater market share.

GWR owns 38 local radio licences, as well as the popular Classic FM station.

"There are half a dozen major radio companies and each one wants to be a consolidator, so something must give sooner or later," he said.

SMG, owner of Virgin Radio, made the first move towards industry consolidation last week by taking a 14.9% stake in Scottish Radio Holdings.

The pre-emptive strike is likely to draw other bidders into the fray, including Emap, Capital Radio and GWR.

It is widely believed within the commercial radio sector that ownership restrictions have inflated the price tags for companies, and prevented increased investment in digital networks.

The companies are bemoaning the fact that arcane regulations have held back development of digital and internet radio.

Mr Bernard added: "Around £72m has been spent on big acquisitions in commercial radio this year. If the companies had put half of that into digital radio, we would have had a uniquely different situation."

webTitle: UDV lines up pitches to relaunch Pimms No 1

fields.headline: UDV lines up pitches to relaunch Pimms No 1
fields.trailText: 8am: United Distillers & Vintners has invited pitches for a relaunch of its summer drink, Pimms No 1, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Pimms No 1, the drink synonymous with the summer and days out at Wimbledon, is about to get a relaunch.

Advertising executives at parent company United Distillers & Vintners have lined up four advertising agencies to pitch for the account.

The agencies, which at this stage are all thought to be roster companies, will be briefed about the relaunch on December 18 with new advertising due out in the new year.

One insider said UDV was keen to broader the brand's appeal from its image of the 'toff's tipple'.

James Pimm devised the famous drink back in the 1820s, in his shellfish shop in London. He later opened an oyster bar and concocted the drink as an accompaniment. It became so popular that in 1859 he began bottling it.

In 1988 UDV lowered the drink's alcoholic content and sales have steadily increased along with the brand's advertising budget.

Roster agencies include Bartle Bogle Hegarty, Saatchi & Saatchi, Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy, Leo Burnett, J Walter Thompson and Burkitt DDB.

webTitle: Burns wooed for top JWT job

fields.headline: Burns wooed for top JWT job
fields.trailText: 8am: Alison Burns, the UK-born president of Fallon in New York, has been approached to take the helm at J Walter Thompson in the UK. By Claire Cozens
fields.body:
Alison Burns, the British-born president of Fallon in New York, has been approached to take over as chief executive of J Walter Thompson in the UK.

Ms Burns is understood to have emerged as the favourite candidate to replace Stephen Carter at the helm of JWT after he left to become chief operating officer at NTL.

She joins Sue Farr, the former marketing director of the BBC, on the list of external candidates, but her experience of running an ad agency is said to make her more appealing to JWT's senior executives.

Ms Burns joined Fallon in 1998 from KTNY, the New York arm of the UK headhunters, Kendall Tarrant. Before setting up KTNY she was vice-president, marketing at PepsiCo Worldwide where she worked on the Pizza Hut brand.

She began her advertising career at BMP in London in 1984 and worked as an account director at Bartle Bogle Hegarty from 1988 until 1992. She then joined Young & Rubicam in London as head of account management.

However, a number of internal candidates are also being lined up for the job. JWT has long maintained a practice of promoting talent from within and some industry sources have expressed doubt as to the likelihood of an external appointment.

Whoever gets the job will take control of the UK's third largest ad agency. JWT counts some of the UK's biggest spenders among its clients, including Unilever, UDV, Kellogg's and Boots.

webTitle: War dance over alcopop TV ad

fields.headline: War dance over alcopop TV ad
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A brewery has had to drop a multimillion-pound TV advertising campaign for an alcoholic fruit drink after a row with the New Zealand government, writes Keith Perry.
fields.body:
A brewery has had to drop a multimillion-pound TV advertising campaign for an alcoholic fruit drink after a row with the New Zealand government.

The advert for Reef alcopop featured eight women in bikinis on a beach performing a version of the haka and suggested that drinkers "go native".

The New Zealand high commission in London wrote an angry letter to Reef's manufacturer, Bass, saying the advert was culturally insensitive because the haka, a traditional Maori war dance, was not performed by women.

Last year the Spice Girls were also criticised for performing the dance while on holiday in Bali, although the latest portrayal was considered far more offensive because of the alcohol.

Bass has said the advert will be withdrawn by January 4, but dissatisfied New Zealand officials replied that it should be dropped immediately.

Last night the high commission said it had been deluged with complaints from expatriates. In the New Zealand Herald newspaper, the ad was branded "demeaning and racist". A high commission spokesman, Rob Hole, said: "The haka is a revered ceremony, and is certainly not associated with the selling of booze. The advert shows great disrespect to our country and traditions. I am not happy the ad will carry on until January, and we are demanding that it is pulled now." While a number of Pacific islands have versions of the haka, Mr Hole said the ad was clearly identifiable as a Maori haka.

A Bass spokesman, Scott Wilson, said the company respected global traditions and cultures, and had decided to withdraw the ad, part of a £7m campaign to promote Reef.

"As an experienced international company, we are culturally aware and certainly did not set out to offend anybody. The advert is about portraying free-thinking British women. It was not set in New Zealand, it was shot in Brazil.

"We wouldn't deny that it takes inspiration from the haka, but we are not trying to claim that this is New Zealand women doing the haka. It is a very eclectic group of ladies, and they are certainly not trying to ape New Zealand culture. Obviously we have taken complaints on board. The advert will be off air on January 4." He confirmed there had been a call to stop before then, and said Bass was reviewing its plans.

webTitle: The stability of euro weakness

fields.headline: The stability of euro weakness
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: So far only the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has had a good word for the weakness of the euro, which has lost nearly a quarter of its value in dollars since it was launched at the beginning of 1999.
fields.body:
So far only the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has had a good word for the weakness of the euro, which has lost nearly a quarter of its value in dollars since it was launched at the beginning of 1999.

Earlier this year, he said that it helped German exporters. But Germany's rising exports owe more to rising demand in economies outside the eurozone. Moreover, any revival of inflation because of the euro's depreciation is unlikely since imports only contribute 11% of eurozone GDP.

A greater benefit of a weak euro is that it discourages the cross-border financial inflows that inflated the east Asian (and the Russian) markets to bursting point.

The largest international investment funds are based in the United States and Britain. The euro's depreciation has devalued their eurozone investments in terms of their home currency.

But for the euro's depreciation, there would have been larger portfolio inflows into eurozone financial asset markets. If the boom got out of hand, it could be followed by a collapse in prices and a catastrophic outflow of funds.

European Central Bank spokesmen have been trying to talk up the euro, using its exchange rate as an indicator of its success.

But this reflects inadequate understanding of how financial securities' inflation affects financial stability. In their view additional capital in proportion to risky assets makes banks prudent and solvent. However, when stock markets are booming, capital is plentiful and does not constrain banks to lend prudently.

A financial asset bubble can be prevented by imposing liquidity requirements on fiduciary investment portfolios (pension and insurance funds). The obligation to hold a minimum proportion of their assets in bank deposits could be more effective and stabilising than the requirement on Britain's pension funds to hold a minimum proportion of their liabilities in the depleting stock of government bonds. Raising slightly the minimum liquidity requirement would reduce excess liquidity in the capital markets. In a world of free capital movements, a minimum liquidity requirement is best operated jointly by all countries. webTitle: Damilola: a victim of Britain's knife culture

fields.headline: Damilola: a victim of Britain's knife culture
fields.trailText: Tracy McVeigh and Paul Harris find armed child gangs causing havoc in cities across the country.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating claims that a boy the same age as Damilola Taylor may have been responsible for the 10-year-old's murder in an attempt to win 'ratings' - points scored for the number of wounds inflicted on other children.

The disclosure, which will heighten concerns about the violent youth culture in Britain's sink estates, comes as an Observer investigation reveals the staggering scale of the use of knives among young Britons, many of whom believe they must arm themselves to survive.

In inner-city housing estates where childhoods are scarred by parental abuse and neglect, drugs, crime, failing schools and under-resourced social services, youths are arming themselves with a remarkable array of knives.

In Peckham, where Damilola was found dying from stab wounds to his leg 10 days ago, knives are so common that youngsters hide blades behind brickwork or in liftshafts - within easy reach should unforeseen circumstances arise.

Police searching the immediate area where Damilola was stabbed found four knives, none of which is thought to be the murder weapon. In the Metropolitan area crimes involving the use of knives leapt from 13,184 in 1998/99 to 15,527 in 1999/00.

For 18-year-old Robbie, a father-of-one living in Peckham, knives and knife fights are a part of everyday life.

'You carry a weapon even if you don't want to use it. You get a tool just in case,' said Robbie, whose personal 'ratings' made him a VIP, a leader among youths and a veteran of many stabbings.

Robbie took The Observer for a tour of north Peckham, ending at Hordle West, the ugly concrete block where Damilola tried to escape his attackers, crawling up a decaying stairwell where he was found, bleeding to death, by demolition workers.

Robbie shook his head as he stared down the stairwell to the recently scrubbed dusty concrete landing. He has his own theory about who killed the schoolboy.

'I know it's a young, young kid,' said Robbie.

'It makes me sick. Ten-year-olds stabbing 10-year-olds. Man, that's too young. When you're 13, 14, you maybe make a little kid like that run, a little kid who do his schoolwork and be nice to his mum, but stabbing him will get you no respect.

'But younger boys want to see what the older boys doing. The people be saying "we smashed up a youth" then the little ones want to have a go.

'When the young ones start stabbing, they stab in the leg, most famous as a safe place to stab. When I started stabbing, I stab in the leg. You're young, you're frightened at what you're doing, you don't really want to do it.

'Older, you stab in throat, belly. I wanted a name. I knew I had to start stabbing when I was 13, 14.'

Robbie, whose single mother 'tried to work to take care of me', was excluded from school at 12 for swearing at a teacher. He had not learnt to read or write and carved a living through extortion and cannabis dealing.

'Mostly all you want is to chill, smoke some weed, see some girls. Some robbing up west. Maybe 40 of us crash into a shop take what we get and run again, maybe one gets caught, so what?

'But there is always someone with a stinking attitude and then you have to sort it out. And girls call out they want the bad boys and the young ones want to impress.'

He also dismisses theories that Damilola interrupted a crack deal or that racism was a motive.

'Most of the crack dealers around here don't smoke it, they just deal it. They not off their heads, they are not going to be standing out here. Class A drugs are not smart with the kids round here, you know.

'Even the Yardies that sell drugs in Peckham, they tell little kids to run on home. Racism is not a fighting thing in Peckham. I've got African brethren and you might be saying "stupid African, stupid rice and peas Jamaican" but we all mix. You'd be surprised how many white boys mingling,' he said.

But it's not just in south London that children are picking up the violent culture of the knife.

In the North End estates of Birkenhead, gangs of youths, many still in their teens, have reduced other residents to prisoners in their homes. Many of the young boys carry knives and often engage in fights on the streets in this slum area of Merseyside, dubbed 'Birkenhell'. Between stretches of wasteland, stand isolated groups of houses, most with boarded up windows, some burnt out by the youths that prowl the streets at night.

'You don't dare go out at night. They are so young but they are not afraid of anything,' said Doris Jones, 60, who was recently threatened by a gang of young boys ransacking a delivery van outside her home in broad daylight.

The child gangs are so vicious that workmen on the estate laying a sewage pipe earlier this year had to build special escape tunnels if they came under attack. Some youths even poured lighter fuel into their diggings and tried to set them on fire. In another attack they rammed a stolen car into the base of a crane and tried to set it ablaze even though there were terrified labourers still working on it. Eventually the workers had to hire private security and put up signs saying 'Danger! Beware of children in this area.'

On one of the walls a mis-spelt graffito seems to sum up the despair. 'Merry Exmas?,' it reads.

In Manchester's infamous Moss Side district, youths have become so enamoured of the drugs culture that when Martin Bennett, a convicted drugs trafficker with strong links to the local crime scene, was shot dead in a street, they turned the spot into a makeshift shrine.

In Newcastle's roughest estates, the arson of cars and buildings by youngsters is now so common that local police and the fire brigade have set up a task force to tackle the problem in an area with one of the highest arson rates in Europe.

In Peckham the problems are not so visual. No one is rioting. The damaged and desperate children who stab each other under cover of darkness could long have gone unnoticed had not a 10-year-old Nigerian boy from a decent family died on a lonely stairwell.

webTitle: View from Paris: Hit the road Jacques

fields.headline: Hit the road Jacques
fields.standfirst:
Jacques Chirac's handling of the EU summit in Nice this weekend failed to impress fellow leaders, writes Jon Henley

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Jacques Chirac's handling of the EU summit in Nice this weekend failed to impress fellow leaders, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
He had not done himself many favours before it started, and by the time the longest summit in EU history was finally over, French President Jacques Chirac, its host, had managed to infuriate just about every non-French politician, diplomat and journalist with whom he came into contact.

France, of course, went into the Nice marathon with one main objective in mind: to prevent Germany, its historic partner in postwar European integration, from gaining more votes than itself, even though the Germans have 20m more citizens since reunification.

Secondary concerns were to protect French culture from the ravages of invading Anglo-Saxon influences, and (almost as an afterthought) to arrive at a sound treaty that would make European Union decision-making more efficient and transparent in the runup to enlargement.

In the event, Mr Chirac, variously dubbed mercurial, arrogant, inconsiderate, self-interested, insensitive, a bully and a bull in a chinashop during the four-day meeting, made sure Paris got more or less what it wanted - at least on the surface - on the first two points.

On the third, the general opinion seems to be that the much enfeebled text that finally emerged at Nice came about despite, rather than thanks to, the admittedly strenuous efforts of the French president.

He aroused the ire of just about everyone by wasting much of the first two days of the summit by going over positions that had already been well rehearsed during his tour of EU capitals over the previous weeks.

"This guy, he talks, he talks, he talks," Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, said to his Danish colleague Poul Nyrup Rasmussen at one stage, before he realised the TV cameras were still rolling. "And do you think he's understood a single word of what we've said around this table? He just doesn't listen."

Wim Kok, the Dutch prime minister, was equally outspoken. "It's really getting serious," he said. "I'm very worried by this bad atmosphere. If it continues, we're really going to be in crisis."

Nor was Mr Chirac's approach greatly appreciated during the so-called bilateral "confessionals" of Friday night, when each member state was expected to lay out their hopes, fears and bottom-line negotiating positions in a tete-a-tete with the French leader.

"It was horrible," said Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, only half joking. "You heard the swish of the whips and the screams of the tortured. But seriously: if you're Catholic, you know very well that nothing happens in a confessional beyond an exchange of words, and then at the end there's absolution."

The first French text to emerge from the confessionals exasperated smaller states by its clear assumption that their voices really did not count for very much. "This," complained Antonio Guterres, the Portuguese prime minister, "is an institutional coup d'etat."

The Belgians, again, were infuriated: "So France gets to keep the same number of votes as Germany, while we lose out to Holland," said Brussels' foreign affairs minister, Louis Michel. "There is no logic in this, and what's more we're being presented with a compromise solution that we have already rejected countless times."

But Mr Chirac also succeeded in exasperating the British with his continued attempts to force them to drop their tax veto demands, and in winding up his German counterpart, Gerhard Schröder, doing further damage to already faltering Franco-German relations. "Good relations? What good relations?" asked Mr Schröder at one point.

A German diplomat, who wished to remain nameless, went further: "This whole thing, this summit, is being run according to the rules of a Middle-Eastern bazaar," he said. "There is no guiding light, no overriding principle, no effective chairmanship."

Leaving no stone unturned, Mr Chirac also deeply offended the president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, by shutting him out of key bilateral meetings and berating him in front of fellow leaders for alleged mismanagement of the mad cow crisis.

The French leader may yet suffer on the domestic stage once the French public realises that the compromise rule that was finally agreed with Germany leaves Berlin able to block all EU decisions by allying itself with any two of the other big states - able, in other words, to play Italy and Britain off against France.

But an agreement, of sorts, has been achieved and for that the French president can, and no doubt will, claim plaudits. The solutions contained in the treaty of Nice are not, however, long term. Nothing has been sorted out for good. The problems have merely been postponed and the EU decision-making process has become, if anything, even more complex and obscure.

The Nice summit, in fact, was pretty much in the image of the man who chaired it: illogical and irrational, given to outbursts of temper, bereft of any grand vision of Europe, keen to score political points wherever possible, and excessively preoccupied with national concerns. Jacques Chirac, take a bow.

webTitle: 'Unclear picture' on poverty figures

fields.headline: 'Unclear picture' on poverty figures
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will go into the election without evidence to show whether policies to reduce poverty are working, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will go into the election without evidence to show whether policies to reduce poverty are working, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Analysis of 50 poverty indicators showed that nine had worsened since last year, while 17 had improved. But time lags in the publication of official data prevent any clear picture emerging of the impact of the minimum wage and working families tax credit, introduced last year. Preliminary data on the minimum wage has been withheld because the office for national statistics doubts its accuracy.

If, as expected, the prime minister calls an election in May, the key poverty indicator, dating from surveys in 1998, will show there are 14m adults in households with less than half average income. This is nearly 1m more than in the early 1990s, and more than double the number in the early 1980s.

They include 8m adults in homes where disposable income was less than 40% of the national average - 500,000 more than in 1996/7 during the last full year of the Conservative government.

More recent statistics showed disadvantaged families were benefiting from rising standards of education in schools and falling unemployment. But there was no evidence of a reduction in inequalities of health.

Children of manual workers were twice as likely to die in accidents, and girls in such families were five times as likely to become teenage mothers.

Guy Palmer, co-director of the National Policy Institute, which conducted the research, said: "Clearly, many of the problems of poverty and social exclusion continue unabated.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said the report was "devastating evidence of the gap between Labour's rhetoric on poverty and the grim reality".

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said: "Real progress is being made to combat the legacy of poverty this government inherited. It took many years to build, and will take time to eradicate."

webTitle: Clinton invests in Irish peace

fields.headline: Clinton invests in Irish peace
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson hopes the president's visit will lead US business to increase further its presence in Northern Ireland

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Mandelson hopes the president's visit will lead US business to increase further its presence in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, will be greeting Bill Clinton, with tremendous enthusiasm when he arrives in Belfast tomorrow - and it will not be just because the peace process needs a helping hand.

He will be hoping that what he calls "a wall of American investment" will rush into the province - as soon as the US is assured that the situation is really stable. And, while the talks will concentrate on peace, the underlying hope is that Mr Clinton's personal commitment to the "Celtic tiger" economy will pay huge financial dividends.

Mr Mandelson - a fervent admirer of Mr Clinton - says the president has "a computer brain" when it comes to tackling problems - and he is expecting the president to sign up more business.

The Clinton administration has aimed to boost US investment in the divided country in an attempt to foster prosperity and support the movement towards peace. It is one of the key planks of US policy towards Ireland - a belief that people are less likely to go to war if they have a job and the economy is thriving.

A White House spokesman said: "There is no doubt that the fast-growing economies in Ireland and Northern Ireland are linked to the people's decision to pursue a course towards peace."

US companies are the biggest investors in Northern Ireland and have created thousands of jobs, according to the US Department of Commerce. The number of US firms in the province has more than doubled in the past five years to in excess of 100, including corporations, such as Dupont, Ford Motor, Emerson Electric, Fruit of the Loom, and 3M.

Mr Clinton's last visit to Northern Ireland took place over three days in September 1998. Documents released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act show how members of Mr Clinton's retinue sought to bring yet more US investment into Ireland during that visit.

The ground had been prepared by William Daley, the then US Commerce Secretary (and Al Gore's campaign manager), who went on his own visit with US business executives to Northern Ireland in June of that year.

Before his trip, he asked Mr Clinton to speak to this business delegation to "energise" them by "emphasising the importance of trade and investment to the success of the peace process."

On August 14, Mr Daley wrote to the president to inform about his "very successful trade mission ... as you prepare for your incoming trip to Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland."

Mr Daley and senior executives had held meetings with a succession of political leaders, including Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern and the then Northern Ireland minister Mo Mowlam. "All of them expressed gratitude for the key role you played in the peace process and the presence of a prominent business delegation on the ground to promote trade and investment in the region."

Mr Daley was accompanied by executives from 16 US companies, covering the aerospace, agriculture, environment, health, computing and food sectors.

He commented: "My impression is that there is a strong sense of entrepreneurship, which, combined with the strong work ethic and educational foundation and technology training, will position Northern Ireland to compete successfully in the 21st century."

Mr Daley built on this trip when he and his staff joined Mr Clinton on his visit to Northern Ireland and Ireland. The main aim of Mr Clinton's visit was to pay his respects to the 29 people killed in the Omagh bomb the month before.

Meanwhile, Mr Daley held a blizzard of meetings with politicians and companies on both sides of the Irish border. In Dublin, for instance, he had a business breakfast with Irish companies hosted by the Allied Irish Bank.

Before the meeting, Mr Daley noted: "Having just visited Moscow, I am struck by the contrast in economic fortunes between the economic plight in Russia and the prosperity in Ireland today."

He also pointed out that the economies in Asia were struggling.

He admits that George Bush may find it difficult to match Clinton's enthusiasm for revitalising the Northern Irish economy.

He will be hoping that what he calls "a wall of American investment" will rush into the province - as soon as the US is assured that the situation is really stable. And, while the talks will concentrate on peace, the underlying hope is that Mr Clinton's personal commitment to the "Celtic tiger" economy will pay huge financial dividends. Mr Mandelson - a fervent admirer of Mr Clinton - says the president has "a computer brain" when it comes to tackling problems - and he is expecting the president to sign up more business. The Clinton administration has aimed to boost US investment in the divided country in an attempt to foster prosperity and support the movement towards peace. It is one of the key planks of US policy towards Ireland - a belief that people are less likely to go to war if they have a job and the economy is thriving. The number of US firms in the province has more than doubled in the past five years to in excess of 100, including corporations, such as Dupont, Ford Motor, Emerson Electric, Fruit of the Loom, and 3M.
