webTitle: Tories abandon 'Tony Martin law'

fields.headline: Tories abandon 'Tony Martin law'
fields.standfirst:
Widdecombe u-turn implies new rift with Hague

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe has abandoned a Tory pledge to change the law to offer greater protection to the likes of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who was jailed for the murder of a teenage intruder.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe has abandoned a Tory pledge to change the law to offer greater protection to the likes of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who was jailed for the murder of a teenage intruder.

Weeks after being forced to jettison a plan to fine all cannabis users, the shadow home secretary omitted the controversial "self-defence" plan from her proposals for the Queen's speech.

The move will fuel speculation of a new rift between William Hague, who first proposed a change in the law after Martin was jailed, and Miss Widdecombe, who opposed the idea.

The Tory leader dominated the headlines for days in April when he pledged to "overhaul" the law to give greater protection to people who are forced to defend their homes against intruders. In a populist move which played well in the run-up to the local elections, Mr Hague said he would introduce into the law a "strong presumption" in favour of the likes of Martin, who was jailed for life in April for the shooting of Fred Barras, 16, at Bleak House farm.

Miss Widdecombe, who said she saw no need for a change in the law a week before Mr Hague's speech, has now quietly abandoned his policy. In a five page document, in which she outlined her alternative proposals for the Queen's speech, there is no mention of the plan.

A spokesman for Miss Widdecombe insisted yesterday that there had been no U-turn but admitted that the Tories were no longer planning to change the law.

"This is about a change in attitudes so that the imbalance can be readdressed in favour of the victim or a presumption of reasonable force in favour of someone whose house has been broken into," the spokesman said.

Mr Hague said last April that the Martin case had "lit a touch paper that has led to an explosion of anger".' He pledged that a Conservative government would "overhaul the law" to help people protect their homes against criminals.

The change in policy will be seized on by Labour as a sign that the Tories have a habit of latching on to populist ideas, only to abandon them at a later date when they become impracticable. Mr Hague famously abandoned his "tax guarantee" earlier this year, while Miss Widdecombe faced an uncomfortable time at the Tory conference when her plan to fine all cannabis users fell apart.

She admitted yesterday that her controversial cannabis policy was now dead in the water. Speaking on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, she said: "If a policy runs into those sorts of troubled waters you stop and you say, 'Can we approach this in a different way?'"

Miss Widdecombe clashed with Jack Straw, the home secretary, later in the day when he admitted that the government had made a mistake on child curfews. He is introducing a bill for curfews on young people under the age of 16 after the government's initial plans to control the movements of children under the age of 10 failed.

Speaking on BBC1's On the Record, Mr Straw said he had been wrong to limit curfews to the younger age group. "Yes, it was a mistake," he said. "The result is - you have to keep learning in government - an error."

Miss Widdecombe said: "This is a long overdue climbdown. I hope history will not repeat itself."

webTitle: Blair holds on to UK's key vetoes

fields.headline: Blair holds on to UK's key vetoes
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was claiming a quiet triumph at the Nice summit last night after French proposals to drop national vetoes on tax and social security were abandoned as the EU's tortuous negotiations headed towards a fifth nerve-wracking day.
fields.byline: Ian Black and Michael White in Nice
fields.body:
Tony Blair was claiming a quiet triumph at the Nice summit last night after French proposals to drop national vetoes on tax and social security were abandoned as the EU's tortuous negotiations headed towards a fifth nerve-wracking day.

With nervousness mounting at what became the EU's longest ever-summit, the 15 leaders edged towards a crucial agreement on reweighting key votes between the large and small states, the issue which absorbed most of yesterday's emotional energy.

It helped the prime minister to preserve the "red lines" he had pledged to defend in the face of Tory and media scepticism in Britain - six months ahead of the expected election. Radical European integrationists were last night already calling the Nice compromises a "betrayal" and a failure of political will, warning that the European parliament might refuse to ratify the agreement.

But significant progress was made to curb other veto powers and ensure the EU can make swift and effective decisions when up to 12 nations start joining in five years' time. "Britain has invested an awful lot in this and there is general agreement that our arguments have won," a spokesman said.

French ministers said a deal was "on the table" to redistribute voting weights in the council of ministers. But complications emerged amid resentment by smaller countries at the dominance secured by Germany, Britain and France, "the big three" as the Downing Street spokesman described them at one point.

Special computer software programmes were brought into play for the haggling over votes, population size and the thresholds required to secure a new balance of power. But hopes for far-reaching reforms - never strong - faded completely when France also got its way over trade and services, maintaining its cherished veto on culture and audiovisual items, threatened by a Hollywood-led invasion.

In a high-stakes endgame, agreement was also close on the size of the European commission, with the larger countries surrendering their right to two commissioners each before moving to a rotational system after 2005. Reformers had hoped to trim the 20-member supranational executive to ensure greater efficiency when the EU grows.

Mr Blair secured a further victory when the French presidency dropped a proposal to allow military initiatives on a "flexible" basis, after insisting that the idea would weaken Nato and the EU's existing fragile defence efforts.

British officials were delighted when the call for majority voting on tax and social security clauses was dropped in last night's final draft document, designed to lead to a Treaty of Nice to be signed next year.

The tax issue is not dead, however. It will be discussed in 2004 when a future inter-governmental conference, capable of reforming the treaty, has been agreed.

The prime minister accepted as part of the round of negotiations in four years' time a review of the controversial charter of fundamental rights, but only on the condition that the process would not delay enlargement.

"Having opened the way for enlargement, the conference calls for a deeper and wider debate about the future development of the European Union," a statement rubber-stamped last night said.

Among the areas where member states agreed to lose national vetoes in favour of qualified majority voting were those Whitehall wants, including free movement of professionals such as lawyers and engineers within the EU, reforms of the EU court and budget reforms needed as part of Neil Kinnock's clean-up portfolio.

Every issue is highly complex, with new draft proposals emerging every few hours. Shorn of their detail, the disagreements are about how power will be distributed after the union enlarges to 27 or 28 countries within 10 years.

Diplomats and leaders from the 15 current EU members were braced for another long night of talks with some predicting the meeting might not end until tomorrow night. Others were not ruling out total breakdown.

Last night, Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, protested: "More commissioners, like more MEPs, means more red tape, more bureaucracy and slower decision-making. Extraordinarily, it is now looking like we will have a treaty which will make enlargement no less easy and maybe more difficult."

webTitle: Analysis: UK ethical foreign policy and Europe

fields.headline: Realpolitik rules
fields.standfirst:
The Blair government's desire for an ethical foreign policy is not shared by its continental partners. They want to boost their arms sales

Special report: European integration
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The Blair government's desire for an ethical foreign policy is not shared by its continental partners. They want to boost their arms sales
fields.body:
Schooled by an insular press, our offshore mind has tended to read the Nice summit as "us" against them. But "they" are of course far from solid. The run-up to Nice was characterised by Franco-German tension. In the fallout, that cliche of the Eurosceptics about the motor of European integration being a trans-Rhine juggernaut will look even more threadbare.

For all their ideological kinship, Gerhard Schröder and Lionel Jospin are not close; relations between Mr Schröder and Jacques Chirac are correct but short on Zärtlichkeit (tenderness). The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, tries to conceal his contempt for his German interlocutor, Joschka Fischer, but cannot quite do so. The one warmish relationship is that between the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, and his counterpart in Berlin, Hans Eichel. Indeed, they are planning a joint trip to Asia to sell the merits of the euro.

On the way, they are likely to boost European exports, among them the products of the EU's extensive armaments industry. The chart shows how international arms sales are dominated by former cold-war rivals, the United States and Russia, with the Ukrainians picking up some business on the side and the ostensibly pacific Canadians making their appearance in the top 10. The other big players are European. The Dutch and Italians may have no great reputation for their military prowess in the modern era but they are keen sellers of the machinery of war. The French head the list of EU arms exporters, some way ahead of the UK and Germany. Among top importers of arms are the Greeks, who bought $4bn worth of arms in the four years to 1999. Purchases by EU aspirant Turkey were worth $6.5bn.

Arms sales were not an issue in Nice, except indirectly. Subfusc, the debate about an EU rapid reaction force is about arms manufacturing. Officially it is about strengthening logistical capability, which in practice means jobs for makers of planes and arms in EU member countries rather than in Seattle or elsewhere in the US.

All of which raises an obvious question. Arms sales prompt moral anxiety. Where in EU deliberations about war-making - or anything else for that matter - do we see any signs of the "ethical foreign policy" that is the Blairite trademark? Robin Cook and co have backed away from that phrase but the Blairites still claim to have adopted a new kind of foreign policy. And if so, it is the first time that has happened since the end of the second world war, according to a new academic study of Labour's foreign profile*.

Arms sales have been the bugbear of the Blair-Cook line on foreign policy since the Foreign Office refashioned its mission statement at New Labour's behest back in May 1997. No sooner was the new human rights note struck than ministers were having to explain why contracts to supply military equipment to Indonesia had to be honoured. The problem is not that governments license the export of arms. That fits the "realist" version of how foreign policy is conducted: you pursue national interests and munitions sales are one of them. The problem is combining arms sales with pretensions to an ethical - human rights - commitment.

The same point applies to trade with China or "constructive engagement", as the FO puts it, with Iran. Here are classic instances of failure to join up policy. In its dealings with the EU, human rights have figured, true, but only marginally. Robin Cook might claim, for example that during the UK presidency of the EU the right noises were made in Beijing's direction. But, say the academics, "it is not clear that the 'ethical dimension' has contributed to any change in the perceptions of its European partners about the UK or its role in the processes of European integration".

As for the EU itself, that trip to the far east projected by Hans Eichel and Laurent Fabius may include China, yet another example of failure to join up rights with trade. The French and the Germans, not having enunciated new, ethical foreign policies, may be exonerated from charges of hypocrisy. Joschka Fischer may be a Green but he is not green. The French are merely cynical, being strong advocates of human rights at home in Europe, as if they had no universal dimension.

Professor Richard Little of Bristol University concludes, rather lamely, that principles need to be balanced with prudence and pragmatism. That blanket would cover Robin Cook's selective myopia over Kashmir, even UK adherence to the American line on Iraq. But it dodges the question of whether the Blair government should ever have run its flag up the ethics mast. Would it have been better, by analogy with its policy on social benefits for the poor, to have tried to conduct more principled foreign policy by stealth?

It also does not confront a tricky question raised this past weekend. If Labour's foreign stance is a moral enterprise, shouldn't it apply to the EU? Is the rapid reaction force - as Tony Blair firmly believed Nato to be in Kosovo - a force for good? If so, its putative relationship with Nato is surely secondary.

To confuse matters further, Nice has seen the UK opposing a European charter giving human rights legal backing, as if rights rhetoric is good for export beyond the confines of the EU but not for importation into the UK, at least with a Brussels stamp on it.

*Richard Little and Mark Wickham-Jones, New Labour's foreign policy, Manchester University Press

webTitle: Britain to break ranks over aid

fields.headline: Britain to break ranks over aid
fields.standfirst:
Short believes ending practice of tied donations to third world will boost markets and reduce poverty
Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Britain is breaking ranks with other rich industrialised countries by ending the decades-old practice of tying third world aid to the purchase of goods and services from British companies, in an effort to speed up progress towards an international deal.
fields.body:
Britain is breaking ranks with other rich industrialised countries by ending the decades-old practice of tying third world aid to the purchase of goods and services from British companies, in an effort to speed up progress towards an international deal.

The move will be announced today by Clare Short, the international development secretary, when she publishes her department's second white paper.

Britain's decision to cut the strings attached to aid will mean the loss of guaranteed contracts for UK business, worth around £270m last year.

However, Ms Short believes that untying aid will lead to more effective poverty reduction and to markets functioning better.

"The goal is to ensure aid is well spent and [to] help developing countries to build successful economies, not waste money on goods and services which are overpriced, unsuitable and supplied with national contracts in mind rather than the needs of the poor," Ms Short told the Guardian.

"We want aid donations to be seen as investment in the future of developing countries, not charity," she said.

Since the election, the government has reduced the amount of financial aid tied to the purchase of British goods and services from 30% to 8.5%, equivalent to just under £70m last year. However, Britain also provides a lot of technical assistance which is tied, although strenuous efforts are made to employ local consultants where possible. In 1999, the value of tied consultancy work was £200m.

Ms Short will announce that from April all financial aid and technical assistance will be fully untied, giving Britain significant leverage in efforts to reach an agreement in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, a grouping of the world's richest 29 industrialised countries.

The OECD discussions, which have been rumbling on since the late 60s, are now limited to the provision of unilateral financial aid to the least developed countries, but France and Japan, which tie a high proportion of their aid, have been blocking a deal.

The US provides very little financial aid to the poorest countries and the French and Japanese fear a popular backlash if their domestic industries are forced to shoulder the burden of untying aid.

Britain's move will also give it extra clout in the EU, where Action Aid and 900 other development organisations have launched a legal challenge on the grounds that tied aid contravenes competition policy. webTitle: Sticking points

fields.headline: Sticking points
fields.standfirst: The key issues
fields.trailText: The key issues.
fields.body:
Trade negotiations
Covering financial and other services and intellectual property rights. Paris has conceded qualified majority voting in principle but with exemptions which can only be triggered by certain agreed "keys" that might in reality extend the national veto, not curb it.

Tax matters
Indirect taxes and company tax. Change justified by the need to curb fraud and evasion. But Britain regards tax structures - there is no current demand to set the rates - as crucial to sovereignty and has refused to cross this "red line". The French EU presidency compromise is to make the shift only after five years, subject to a report of a "taxation committee". Thin end of the EU wedge, says London. Ireland and Luxembourg agree.

Asylum and border controls
Important to Germany, with millions of poor east Europeans along its own border, and to Britain as an island state outside the EU's Schengen agreement on open borders and with no internal identity card traditions. Last night the Germans had got their way - leaving no problems for Tony Blair.

Social security
The second of Britain's most important red lines, because it impinges on crucial fiscal decisions and because Britain does things differently, including health care free at point of use. The Danes accepted a revised text on Friday, leading to a "dirty tricks" row when London claimed Denmark had left itself open to paying benefits to "third country nationals", e.g. refugees.

European Commission
Britain and other big states keep two commissioners until 2005. Then all member states get one commissioner each. When EU has 27 member states a decision to be taken to establish the final number, which must be less than 27 with a rotation system based on principle of equality. President wins powers to create internal hierarchy.

Enhanced cooperation
"Two speed Europe" in EU jargon. Treaty deal allows minimum of eight states to go ahead with their own projects as long as they do not affect the single market or currency issues. British victory removes French inspired reference to action with military implications after worries about potential for rivalry with Nato by Franco-German Eurocorps.

European parliament seats
Re-weighting designed to accommodate enlargement candidates. Germany comes out on top with 99 and then parity at 74 (down from 87) for Britain, France and Italy down to five for Malta. Total of 738 exceeds Amsterdam treaty threshold of 700 seats.

webTitle: Leader:  EU summiteers betray a lack of vision

fields.headline: EU summiteers betray a lack of vision
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The Nice summit of the European Union has presented a dismaying prospect to those who favour a stronger, more democratic enlarged community.
fields.body:
The Nice summit of the European Union has presented a dismaying prospect to those who favour a stronger, more democratic enlarged community. At every stage of the prolonged negotiation, raw national interest has overshadowed the broader vision. This has been most fully demonstrated by the frequently inept manoeuvrings of the French presidency, whose job it is to promote the big picture.

A series of drafts, deals and supposed compromises revealed, on closer scrutiny, the deep, primary attachment of President Jacques Chirac to his country's own agenda, his own political standing and, by remove, his own re-election prospects in 2002. But Mr Chirac was far from alone in failing to seize the European moment. Tony Blair, that self-proclaimed champion of enlargement, seemed for the most part preoccupied with his "red lines" on matters such as tax and social security harmonisation. This may save him from a more serious mauling by British Eurosceptics, in the short term at least, but it will do little to impress candidate nations such as Poland and the Czech republic that have pinned much hope on Britain.

Only Germany's Gerhard Schröder appeared strong or disinterested enough to make a significant gesture towards "Europeanism" - by agreeing to France's intrinsically illogical but obsessive insistence on voting parity.

On all the main issues under discussion, the EU's leaders have defined themselves first and foremost as national politicians rather than European statesmen. The biggest row - over the reweighting of votes in the council of ministers - has seen largely irrational, essentially historic rivalries swamping the shared interest. Thus not only were France, Germany and Italy accused of trying to humiliate members with smaller populations but Portugal was to be heard complaining vociferously about unfair voting disparities with Spain.

A similar spat erupted between Belgium and the Netherlands. The summiteers fudged plans to limit the size of the European Commission, dodged and dived around each others' veto sensibilities, and nearly failed their first real test of enhanced cooperation (on defence, after a last-minute row between Britain and France over the relationship of the EU's new rapid reaction force to Nato).

Mr Blair will probably be able to emerge from Nice claiming that British interests have been upheld. Apart from the RRF, for example, and British veto rights, the charter of rights was merely declared, as Britain had insisted, rather than bound in law. Nor were interchangeable Tory and tabloid predictions that the the prime minister would be "isolated" or "mugged" on the Riviera borne out. This will comfort those on the Labour side who most feared negative Nice fallout in an election year.

But there is scant solace to be found in this descent towards lowest common denominators for those who would see genuine reform. The agreement to hold yet another intergovernmental conference in 2004 will merely encourage cynics and be seen by east Europeans as another excuse for delaying expansion. The summit's results are unlikely to do much for the still weak euro, either. For while Nice definitively demonstrates how far away Europe's nations are, in reality, from forming a superstate, Mr Blair's Warsaw ideal of a European superpower remains equally distant. Still, despite these many disappointments, Nice does look like producing some modest steps forward in joint policy and decision-making. And it has certainly opened up a vigorous debate that will not now be stilled.

webTitle: Europe's big four pull rank on minnows

fields.headline: Europe's big four pull rank on minnows
fields.standfirst: Reweighting EU giants win crucial battle over allocation of votes
fields.trailText: Reweighting EU giants win crucial battle over allocation of votes.
fields.body:
Germany, Britain, France and Italy were last night poised to seal their dominance of the European Union by winning a hefty reweighting of votes that ensures they cannot be beaten by any combination of smaller countries.

In the most bitterly contested of the power-plays at the Nice summit the vote reweighting deal was edging painfully towards agreement after hours of furious haggling. Crucially, leaders fixed on 30 votes each for the big four, even though Germany, with a population of 82m, has over 20m more people than either Britain, France or Italy.

Spain looked set to win its hard-fought demand for recognition as a medium-sized country, with 28 votes in the decision-making council of ministers, still the union's most powerful institution.

Poland, with a similar population of about 40m, and expected to be the first former communist country to join the EU in a few years, was heading for parity with Spain.

But the difficulty was underlined when France's first proposal gave Poland only 26 votes out of a total of 339.

Last night's emerging compromise would mean that a minority of 91 votes or 61% of the total EU population - equal to three big states and perhaps one small one - could block any council decision.

"Four will make up a blocking minority," confirmed the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, "and that is faithful to the history of the union."

A senior British official said: "This would be a way of ensuring that the three biggest member states couldn't be outvoted, and given their weight in the union that's only right and proper."

But smaller countries, led by Portugal, had sought to raise that threshold to 104, giving themselves more influence and making it harder for the large states to block decisions.

As the EU expands to take in up to 12 new members in the coming years, the bigger countries, under-represented in relation to their population under the current system, fear they could be outvoted by a coalition of smaller nations.

And there was angry criticism last night that the big four were becoming a bullying "directory" whose combined voting power would strengtheninter-governmentalism at the expense of the community spirit and slow down integration.

Big states offered to surrender one of their two members of the 20-strong European commission in a bargain that would appease smaller members who are anxious to keep their own single place on it rather than face a rotation system.

"The big four have stood back and watched the small states shed blood all over the carpet," one diplomat said. "The smalls have been led up the garden path over the commission. They've taken the bait and expended an enormous amount of political capital so there is moral pressure on them to accept a substantial reweighting."

However, problems lingered. Portugal, with 11 votes was unhappy at Spain's 28. The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, calling for consistency, said he had no problem with the Netherlands getting more votes than Belgium since its 15.8m population was 50% more than Belgium's.

But using the logic of the population yardstick, he argued, Germany should then get more votes than France. "Between Germany and France, the population difference is more than 20m. In one case we say they are the same. In the other case, we make a difference," he complained.

Ireland, with seven votes, was resisting linkage with Lithuania which was offered just five votes despite having an almost identical population.

Pierre Moscovici, France's minister for Europe, said that a deal was "on the table". But he added: "It's a very careful construction, like a house of cards. Twitch one element and you bring it crashing down."

Germany won compensation on voting weights by getting 99 seats in the European parliament, serving as a sort of consolation prize, while Britain, France and Italy were each slated to get 74. But leaders were forced to abandon their previous threshold of 700 seats for the parliament, raising it to 740 to accommodate last-minute bargains.

webTitle: Leader: supreme court makes an ass of itself

fields.headline: The supreme court makes an ass of itself
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The decision of the US supreme court to halt the Florida recounts is wrong in law, wrong in respect of the constitution, and wrong in terms of plain common sense.
fields.body:
The decision of the US supreme court to halt the Florida recounts is wrong in law, wrong in respect of the constitution, and wrong in terms of plain common sense. Justice John Paul Stevens, in his dissenting opinion, made the point that in ordering the recounts to resume last Friday, Florida's top court acted in accordance with state law and precedent.

"The Florida code provides elaborate procedures for ensuring that every eligible voter has a full and fair opportunity to cast a ballot and that every ballot so cast is counted. The statutory provision relating to damaged and defective ballots states that 'no vote shall be declared invalid or void if there is a clear indication of the intent of the voter'," he wrote. This is the nub of the legal dispute that has bedevilled the presidential election since chads and dimples first raised their ugly heads on November 7. Justice Stevens was entirely correct to say the majority "acted unwisely" in halting efforts to achieve a full, accurate tally.

The central claim by George W Bush that the Florida court was rewriting the rules after the event thus simply does not hold water. His later claims that the process was being unfairly manipulated to favour Al Gore, and that the month-old ballots have somehow "degraded", are lacking in merit. There is no just reason here why the hand recount of 43,000 "missed" ballots in both Democrat and Republican counties cannot proceed under strict court supervision, as proposed.

In deciding to intervene in this arbitrary, divisive manner, the supreme court cited the possibility of "irreparable harm" to the democratic system. The institution now as likely as any other to suffer such damage, however, is the court itself. It revealed itself to be split down the middle, like the country at large, yet in thrall to a narrow Republican caucus.

It imperiously overruled not only the Florida court but also the federal appeals court in Atlanta. It ignored the option of allowing the recounts to continue while it heard Mr Bush's appeal. Reckless of the constitutional and practical implications, it also ignored the certainty that its ruling will be widely seen as reactionary and partisan, as have so many of its actions during the tenure of Chief Justice William Rehnquist. Worst of all, it turned a blind eye to the obvious. In elections, all votes must count and be counted. The court meets today. It still has time to reverse itself and let the Florida counting resume. It should do so without delay.

webTitle: No great hopes over Clinton's Irish swansong

fields.headline: No great hopes over Clinton's Irish swansong
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: President Clinton starts a two-day visit to Ireland tomorrow with little expectation he can achieve a breakthrough in the beleaguered Northern Irish political process.
fields.body:
President Clinton starts a two-day visit to Ireland tomorrow with little expectation he can achieve a breakthrough in the beleaguered Northern Irish political process.

The outgoing president and Tony Blair will hold three hours of talks with the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, and other key politicians at Stormont in Belfast on Wednesday.

Accompanied by his wife, Hillary, daughter, Chelsea, and Hillary's mother, Dorothy Rodham, Mr Clinton will also address crowds in Belfast's new £91m showpiece Odyssey sports arena on Wednesday afternoon, and in Dundalk, Co Louth, just south of the border, on Tuesday night.

Sources previously flagged the Stormont discussions as a focal point in the row over lack of progress on IRA disarmament which has led to the first minister Mr Trimble banning Sinn Fein from cross-border ministerial meetings. Republicans will challenge the veto in court on Friday.

Mr Clinton, on his third visit, is the only serving US president ever to go to Northern Ireland. He received a rapturous welcome in Belfast, Derry and Armagh on his first trip in 1995 and comforted victims of the Omagh bomb in 1998.

He has a heartfelt interest in peace process, phoning all sides with advice at crucial times, including the critical hours just before the Good Friday agreement was signed. But Washington, London and Dublin are now downplaying the president's role to one of encouragement rather than nitty-gritty negotiation.

A senior British source admitted talks to try and overcome the deadlock were still primarily between government officials rather than republicans and unionists.

Mr Trimble, under severe pressure from internal hardliners led by the Lagan Valley MP Jeffrey Donaldson, will face new calls to quit Stormont, at a crunch meeting of his party's ruling council in January.

He said that expecting major progress in three hours at Stormont was too optimistic."I hope the president will use the influence he undoubtedly has with republicans," Mr Trimble said, a reminder it was the Clinton administration which helped bring Sinn Fein in from the cold by first offering Gerry Adams a US visa in 1994.

However, a republican source insisted Mr Trimble was dreaming if he thought the Provisionals would jump to a unionist-imposed timetable.

Mr Clinton's valedictory tour comes at a time when the peace process is under new strain from a spate of tit-for-tat sectarian shootings, which have left two men dead and two others seriously injured in the past week. A taxi driver is critical after the latest incident in the Protestant Waterside area of Derry yesterday.

Renegade republicans are being blamed for the murder of a Protestant north Belfast taxi driver, Trevor Kell, which spurred loyalists to shoot dead Gary Moore, a Catholic in Dungiven. There are suggestions IRA and Ulster Defence Association members sanctioned the killings, which could draw mainstream paramilitaries back into a spiral of violence.

The government is to contest the sentence review commission's decision to free the Ulster Freedom Fighters boss, Johnny Adair, whom the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, put back behind bars in August because of his supposed influence on the internecine loyalist feud, which has claimed seven lives since.

Mr Mandelson and security chiefs have also warned of the possibility of a dissident republican pre-Christmas bombing blitz in Great Britain.

Mr Trimble urged Mr Clinton to place the dissident Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bomb, on the US list of international terrorist groups.

Republicans will challenge the veto in court on Friday. Mr Clinton, on his third visit, is the only serving US president ever to go to Northern Ireland. He received a rapturous welcome in Belfast, Derry and Armagh on his first trip in 1995 and comforted victims of the Omagh bomb in 1998. He has a heartfelt interest in peace process, phoning all sides with advice at crucial times, including the critical hours just before the Good Friday agreement was signed. But Washington, London and Dublin are now downplaying the president's role to one of encouragement rather than nitty-gritty negotiation. A senior British source admitted talks to try and overcome the deadlock were still primarily between government officials rather than republicans and unionists. Mr Trimble, under severe pressure from internal hardliners led by the Lagan Valley MP Jeffrey Donaldson, will face new calls to quit Stormont, at a crunch meeting of his party's ruling council in January. He said that expecting major progress in three hours at Stormont was too optimistic."I hope the president will use the influence he undoubtedly has with republicans," Mr Trimble said, a reminder it was the Clinton administration which helped bring Sinn Fein in from the cold by first offering Gerry Adams a US visa in 1994. However, a republican source insisted Mr Trimble was dreaming if he thought the Provisionals would jump to a unionist-imposed timetable. Mr Clinton's valedictory tour comes at a time when the peace process is under new strain from a spate of tit-for-tat sectarian shootings, which have left two men dead and two others seriously injured in the past week. A taxi driver is critical after the latest incident in the Protestant Waterside area of Derry yesterday. Renegade republicans are being blamed for the murder of a Protestant north Belfast taxi driver, Trevor Kell, which spurred loyalists to shoot dead Gary Moore, a Catholic in Dungiven. There are suggestions IRA and Ulster Defence Association members sanctioned the killings, which could draw mainstream paramilitaries back into a spiral of violence. The government is to contest the sentence review commission's decision to free the Ulster Freedom Fighters boss, Johnny Adair, whom the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, put back behind bars in August because of his supposed influence on the internecine loyalist feud, which has claimed seven lives since. Mr Mandelson and security chiefs have also warned of the possibility of a dissident republican pre-Christmas bombing blitz in Great Britain. Mr Trimble urged Mr Clinton to place the dissident Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bomb, on the US list of international terrorist groups.

webTitle: Comment: Beatrix Campbell blasts the monarchy

fields.headline: A feminist republican
fields.standfirst:
We continue our campaign for a referendum on the monarchy with a blast from Beatrix Campbell
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: We continue our campaign for a referendum on the monarchy with a blast from Beatrix Campbell
fields.body:
What - short of storming the gates of Buckingham Palace - has to happen before Britain allows itself a decent debate about the monarchy?

A feeling has settled among half the electorate that the Windsors have had it. And yet no parliamentary party has had either the courage or the confidence to sponsor the great debate. Much of Labour is doing what it did throughout the 20th century - rescuing the royals. In the progressive portion of British society, republicanism has been cauterised. Why?

Despite the radical rhetoric of recent Labour and Conservative governments, the culture of deference has seeped into their souls: our parliamentary culture not only bends its knee to the Queen, it bows and scrapes in the prime minister's court, too. The democratic deficit is palpable in the unseemly symbiosis between between the house of Windsor and the houses of parliament.

The royal family bequeaths something visceral to the body politic, a mystical discipline of sovereignty and subordination - the cult of supremacy that sponsors not only the monarchy but the modern idea of Britishness. What else would make grown men walk backwards in the company of a grown woman who thinks she has been exalted by the hand of God?

The cult's significance extends beyond the ministry of silly walks to the timbre of official society. We witnessed it recently when the masters of political culture would not even contemplate the Parekh commission's subtle ruminations on the "racial connotations" of Britishness.

We recognise it in the authoritarianism of appointments, from the lord chancellor's smoky semaphores to the authoritarian aura of drugs/schools/homelessness tsars.

But we also see its effects in the sexism of both British leftism and liberalism, smugly scoffing at the sensibilities of the mere masses, whether black Britons, Essex woman or Maida Vale man, who saw that something important had happened when a woman called a future king to account for his bad behaviour as a man - a petulant and pointless prince who would sacrifice more than one woman to his mania to be monarch.

Diana's death finally compromised the reputation of the Queen, hitherto seen as dull but dutiful, now revealed as a jealous empress, the Countrywide Alliance personified. We saw what this meant with the recent headline Queen Wrings Bird's Neck. Quite a skill, they say, particularly in a woman whose role means she doesn't need to catch a bus, bath a baby, use a switch card. However, unlike other rich people, the public performance of power over other people is the monarchy's mission.

Like Thatcher, the Queen presided over a profoundly patriarchal project at precisely that point in human history when it was losing its legitimacy. It was sexual politics that undid the becalmed consensus that protected the royal family's fortunes.

The 20th century was a bad time for British republicans. While other royal houses lost their heads, the Windsors triumphed. They were the true heirs of George III who, according to the historian Linda Colley, gave to his successors a simple mantra: be domestic but be seen and, above all, be seen to be spectacular. David Carradine's theory of the "invention of tradition" explained the monarchy's remarkable ingenuity in surviving democracy: as its powers waned the monarchy mobilised everything, from theatre to technology, to improvise sovereignty-as-spectacle.

Republicans were bored. They evacuated the territory taken by the royalists. So, neither the Windsors' cheek in expecting us to pay for the repair of their castle, nor the all-party deal giving them immunity from financial scrutiny, nor their personal belief in their supremacy and our subordination touched the national nerve.

The Charles-Diana scandal affronted popular feeling but found no echo in parliament - unlike the crisis caused by an earlier Prince of Wales, whose abuse of his wife Caroline invigorated a popular culture and brought the way men treat women into 19th-century political discourse. Then, as now, we witnessed both the potential alchemy of gender, finance and power for republicanism, and at the same time republicanism's failure to recognise its resonance.

The difficulty is compounded by the failure of misogynists to feel the zeitgeist. They misread the runes, traduce feminist republicans such as me as feminist royalists and mock sexual politics as mere "soap opera".

However, all is not lost. Everyone wonders why Charles's son should be doomed to a life spent in the service of this horrible dynasty. He can be rescued only by republicanism.

Meanwhile we have our own queens. We've got Julie Burchill and Tracey Emin who entertain and enlighten us in their salons and bedchambers. We've got real princes - that nice Naseem; David Beckham, a great footballer and by all accounts a diligent dad who enjoys sharing his wife's stardom in the kingdom of OK! And finally, the Royles' Nana: she's got the handbag, the hat and - unlike that other Queen - we know exactly what she does on the toilet.

 Beatrix Campbell is author of Diana: How Sexual Politics Shook the Monarchy (Women's Press)

webTitle: Focus turns to power split

fields.headline: Focus turns to power split
fields.standfirst: Deeper, wider debate on EU due in 2004
fields.trailText: Deeper, wider debate on EU due in 2004.
fields.body:
As delegates battled to bring the summit to a close last night, discussion had already turned to a new round of talks likely in four years' time, focusing on some of the most sensitive questions facing Europe.

The favourite bugbear of British Eurosceptics - supranationalism and integration - as well as relations between nation states within the European Union are all expected to be on the table at an inter-governmental conference (IGC) in 2004. Leaders in Nice agreed that this later meeting should draw them into a "deeper and wider" debate on the future of the EU, though they stressed it would not block enlargement to the east, due to begin in earnest at around that time.

According to a declaration on the future of the union agreed by the summit, the remit of the new IGC will be drawn up at Gothenburg at the end of the Swedish presidency next June and at Laeken when Belgium is in the rotating hot seat the following December.

Since the Netherlands is running the presidency in January 2004 the next EU treaty is likely to be signed there.

British officials said Tony Blair was content to sign up to a project which would ask "how to establish and monitor a more precise delimitation of competences between the EU and the member states, reflecting the principle of subsidiarity".

The prime minister was said to be relaxed too about looking at the Charter of Fundamental Rights, proclaimed last Thursday, but which he fought tooth and nail to keep out of the new treaty. Britain's position would not change, officials insisted.

The planned review includes the role of national parliaments, a response to the widespread desire to boost the EU's perceived "democratic deficit," given the lack of interest across the 15 in the European parliament.

It will also look at simplification of the notoriously unreadable EU treaties, "with a view to making them clearer".

Agreement on the future IGC is an important victory for Gerhard Schröder, who has come under pressure from Germany's 16 regions or länder, which want a clarification of how responsibilities are carved up at European, national and regional levels.

Reflecting the views of Britain and other more sceptical countries, the summit declaration did not include the word "constitution" and suggested that Brussels was seen as distant by many citizens.

"Having opened the way to enlargement, the conference calls for a deeper and wider debate about the future devel opment of the European Union," said the declaration, drafted by Germany, Italy and Belgium.

"The conference recognises the need to improve and to monitor the democratic legitimacy and transparency of the union and its institutions, to bring them closer to the citizens of the member states."

Crucially, the 12 candidate countries are to be associated with a debate which will mould institutional and political arrangements for a union set to change almost beyond recognition as it expands.

Elmar Brok, the European parliament's monitor on reform talks, said: "The post-Nice proposal is positive. We envisage a broad political debate starting in 2001 - bringing in civil society, national governments and parliaments and the commission."

In response to British and other objections, the declaration omitted a call to "address the further development of European integration," a phrase in an earlier draft that was seized upon by Eurosceptic media.

webTitle: Your two-hour rail trip took 10 hours? Will £7 make amends?

fields.headline: Your two-hour rail trip took 10 hours? Will £7 make amends?
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A businessman has been offered £7 compensation after his 75-mile train journey from Blackpool to Halifax took 10 hours.
fields.body:
A businessman has been offered £7 compensation after his 75-mile train journey from Blackpool to Halifax took 10 hours.

Geoff Southgate, a property investor from Bradford, had to borrow money from a stranger to buy food. The delay to the Northern Spirit service, scheduled to take one hour and 45 minutes, was one of the longest experienced by passengers in the past two months.

Mr Southgate said: "It was scandalous. I make that journey regularly and I am used to a few delays, but this was just mind-boggling."

Last month he arrived at Blackpool station for the 11.47 trans-Pennine service but was not allowed to board until noon. Then, after 15 minutes, a station attendant announced the train was not working.

He was advised to catch a bus to Preston and get a Halifax train from there. But at Preston there was no train and he was told to listen for announcements.

After five hours, he boarded a train for Halifax. It left on time, but stopped at Accrington, where it waited for an hour, and then turned round.

Back at Preston, he was advised to board a Manchester train. A buffet car steward told passengers that, although he knew they were tired and hungry, they would not be given free refreshments. Mr Southgate borrowed £10 from a stranger for food. At Manchester Piccadilly, he got on a train to Halifax and arrived at 10pm.

Mr Southgate wrote to Northern Spirit asking for compensation. He received a letter blaming flood damage and offering him £7, half the £13.90 for his ticket.

Mr Southgate said: "To offer £7 is a joke. The least they could have done is refund my fare."

A spokesman for Northern Spirit said: "This is a very regrettable incident, and obviously we apologise to Mr Southgate. We will review the level of compensation."

webTitle: A long, long weekend on the Med

fields.headline: A long, long weekend on the Med
fields.standfirst: The talks manoeuvring behind the scenes set the agenda for negotiations
fields.trailText: The talks Manoeuvring behind the scenes set the agenda for negotiations.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has never greatly enjoyed the cut and thrust of European summits. The pace is too slow, the rituals time-consuming and he wishes he could be doing something pressing at home.

In this he has an ally in the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. A double-ally in Nice yesterday as they devoted much of the day to sorting out the injured feelings of smaller EU states angry at the reweighting of voting strength.

Double because Mr Schröder and Jacques Chirac, the mercurial president of France, do not hit it off in the way that Kohl and Mitterrand did and - long years back - in the way that de Gaulle and Adenauer worked so closely to forge the postwar Bonn-Paris axis.

As head of the EU member state that currently holds the rotating presidency of the EU, Mr Chirac has been the man to make or muddle the Nice summit. Mr Schröder and Mr Blair had been puzzled as to why, after touring all the EU capitals in the past month, their 68-year-old colleague wasted much of Thursday and Friday recapping known positions.

Cunning plan
Crunch time came on Saturday morning when the French presidency circulated a new draft of the treaty's trickier bits, a Gallic equivalent of Baldrick's cunning plan which managed to infuriate everyone.

It reflected many of France's own priorities and concerns - to protect French cultural products from US trade penetration and (more puzzling to Mr Schröder) to maintain - at any cost - the same number of votes in the council of ministers as Germany, despite those extra 20m Germans acquired after the Berlin Wall fell.

Faced with widespread anger, from Britain over the tax issue by trying to kick it into the long grass ("it doesn't matter how long the grass is," said one official) and from smaller states dismayed at their dwindling power, the long summit haul suddenly loomed.

Flights were duly cancelled and hotel rooms rebooked. "We don't think four days is a long time to reach this kind of complicated and important deal," British officials told impatient reporters - and probably Mr Blair who had been housed on the Promenade des Anglais overlooking the Mediterranean, appropriately enough in the West End hotel.

The official "sherpas", who carry the heavy preparatory burdens of summitry, also reassured each other that Mr Chirac had an engagement in Paris this morning to meet Nelson Mandela, the one man in the world even a president of France would hesitate to keep waiting. The summit would run until Sunday - but no later.

Having made his position abundantly plain on giving up Britain's tax and social security veto ("No") during Friday night's "confessionals" with Mr Chirac, Mr Blair learned at breakfast time at the West End that his points had not been taken.

When the summiteers reconvened a mile away at the menacing Acropolis conference centre, the prime minister made it plain again. So did Robin Cook when he backed modestly into the media spotlight.

"We are not bluffing," Mr Cook insisted. Only around 7pm last night was his public optimism finally vindicated when Mr Chirac told the summiteers they would make no progress on that score.

They had spent most of yesterday thrashing out the "bigs" versus "smalls" voting issue in which the bigs - notably Britain and Germany - weighed in to play a helpful role having already got what they wanted.

Mr Blair's diplomatic efforts to remain "at the heart of Europe" - despite his domestic troubles on Europe - had paid off. Sweden's Goran Persson paid him a personal tribute on Saturday night.

Back at the West End, after seeing Mr Chirac and Mr Schröder for post-dinner bilaterals, Mr Blair hit the telephones. But the one meeting he did leave his suite for was across the street at the legendary Negrisco where Jose Maria Aznar, his centre-right best friend from Madrid, needed help with the big/small issue.

By the time the summiteers reconvened at 9.30 yesterday morning Mr Blair had also seen Mr Schröder and Mr Chirac (again), having briskly led his less-fit staff along the seafront on a one mile walk.

It was a cheerful walk. He had held the line on defence, would hold it on the vetoes and - provided the summit could reach agreement to allow enlargement to the east - he could go into the election claiming to have defended the national interest while remaining a good European.

Once inside, he also saw his Dutch, Danish and Italian counterparts. The UK delegation was busy enough and throughout the day would weather pressure to cave in on tax - from the commission, from Belgium and Italy. But the heat was being generated elsewhere.

Relaxed Schröder

Even the foreign secretary's sidekick, Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, was emboldened to peddle the optimistic line as he toured the cavernous press centre.

But Mr Blair was not alone. Small and medium-size countries had been offended by the way the French plan reallocated voting strengths around the ministerial council table to reinstate the dominant position of the "big four" - Germany, Britain, France and Italy, 30 votes each.

It might have been an occasion for Germany to throw its summit weight around - as Helmut Kohl sometimes did on a Saturday afternoon when he wanted to get home to Bonn and a properly baked strudel. But Mr Schröder was relaxed.

He and his foreign minister, the Green, Joschka Fischer, were working to their own agenda which included extra German seats in the Strasbourg parliament and another inter-governmental conference (IGC) after 2004 to define the powers of Brussels and get them off the back of his own regional parliaments.

Quietly they racked up victories as Mr Chirac and his hyper-sophisticated team retreated in the face of hostility, tactically at least. There was a vague awareness inside the Euro-bubble that, since their arrival, both Al Gore and George Bush had been elected president by assorted US judges, and that Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel had resigned.

Only at 3pm yesterday did the summit get off the vote weighting issue and address QMV - Mr Blair's bugbear. And it was only at around 7pm that Mr Chirac threw in the tax towel, allowing British officials to proclaim a satisfactory outcome. No one used the "game, set and match" language that a junior press spokesman used after Maastricht, "against my express instructions", John Major revealed last week.

That was uncommunitaire language, frowned upon in polite EU circles. Last night Mr Chirac was still nursing a bad back and (rumour had it) tummy trouble as they headed into the final straight. But they were still talking - politely.

Back at the West End, after seeing Mr Chirac and Mr Schröder for post-dinner bilaterals, Mr Blair hit the telephones. But the one meeting he did leave his suite for was across the street at the legendary Negrisco where Jose Maria Aznar, his centre-right best friend from Madrid, needed help with the big/small issue. By the time the summiteers reconvened at 9.30 yesterday morning Mr Blair had also seen Mr Schröder and Mr Chirac (again), having briskly led his less-fit staff along the seafront on a one mile walk. It was a cheerful walk. He had held the line on defence, would hold it on the vetoes and - provided the summit could reach agreement to allow enlargement to the east - he could go into the election claiming to have defended the national interest while remaining a good European. Once inside, he also saw his Dutch, Danish and Italian counterparts. The UK delegation was busy enough and throughout the day would weather pressure to cave in on tax - from the commission, from Belgium and Italy. But the heat was being generated elsewhere. Relaxed Schröder Even the foreign secretary's sidekick, Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, was emboldened to peddle the optimistic line as he toured the cavernous press centre. But Mr Blair was not alone. Small and medium-size countries had been offended by the way the French plan reallocated voting strengths around the ministerial council table to reinstate the dominant position of the "big four" - Germany, Britain, France and Italy, 30 votes each. It might have been an occasion for Germany to throw its summit weight around - as Helmut Kohl sometimes did on a Saturday afternoon when he wanted to get home to Bonn and a properly baked strudel. But Mr Schröder was relaxed. He and his foreign minister, the Green, Joschka Fischer, were working to their own agenda which included extra German seats in the Strasbourg parliament and another inter-governmental conference (IGC) after 2004 to define the powers of Brussels and get them off the back of his own regional parliaments. Quietly they racked up victories as Mr Chirac and his hyper-sophisticated team retreated in the face of hostility, tactically at least. There was a vague awareness inside the Euro-bubble that, since their arrival, both Al Gore and George Bush had been elected president by assorted US judges, and that Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel had resigned. Only at 3pm yesterday did the summit get off the vote weighting issue and address QMV - Mr Blair's bugbear. And it was only at around 7pm that Mr Chirac threw in the tax towel, allowing British officials to proclaim a satisfactory outcome. No one used the "game, set and match" language that a junior press spokesman used after Maastricht, "against my express instructions", John Major revealed last week. That was uncommunitaire language, frowned upon in polite EU circles. Last night Mr Chirac was still nursing a bad back and (rumour had it) tummy trouble as they headed into the final straight. But they were still talking - politely. webTitle: Second post-mortem to be carried out on Damilola

fields.headline: Second post-mortem to be carried out on Damilola
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Gallery: the CCTV shots
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the death of Damilola Taylor yesterday confirmed they were considering the possibility that the 10-year-old died as a result of an accident.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the death of Damilola Taylor yesterday confirmed they were considering the possibility that the 10-year-old died as a result of an accident.

A murder inquiry was opened after Damilola was found bleeding to death in a dank stairwell, 400 yards from his home on the North Peckham estate, south-east London, on November 27.

A postmortem examination the following day revealed the cause of death as a single stab wound to the left leg, but almost two weeks later it remains unclear exactly how the Nigerian-born boy sustained the fatal injury. Police said yesterday that a second postmortem would be carried out. But this was standard procedure in murder inquiries, to provide two independent accounts for use in court.

The team of more than 80 police officers on the inquiry has studied footage from 800 CCTV cameras and interviewed more than 100 people.

Scotland Yard said last night it was still focusing on the theory that Damilola was stabbed but it was not yet ruling out the suggestion that he fell and cut himself on his way home from an after school computer class at the local library.

A spokesman said there had been a lot of anecdotal evidence about events leading up to the boy's death, including reports that he was being bullied, but nothing conclusive.

"As far as an accident is concerned we are keeping an open mind. It would be silly of us to rule it out." But he insisted: "This is definitely a murder inquiry."

Meanwhile, detectives have spoken to the man pictured with the boy by CCTV cameras in a lift at Peckham library an hour before he died.

On Saturday, hundreds of mourners from the community rallied to stage a memorial march in honour of Damilola.

webTitle: Minimum wage to hit £4 an hour

fields.headline: Minimum wage to hit £4 an hour
fields.trailText: The government is planning to raise the national minimum wage for Britain's lowest-paid workers from £3.70 to £4 an hour next year in an attempt to woo its core voters before the general election.
fields.body:
The government is planning to raise the national minimum wage for Britain's lowest-paid workers from £3.70 to £4 an hour next year in an attempt to woo its core voters before the general election.

In a sign that ministers are preparing the ground for a poll next spring, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will give the all-clear today for an inflation-busting 8% rise. Mr Byers wants next year's rate to be linked to the growth in earnings since the introduction of the minimum wage in April 1999 in the wake of evidence that it has not cost jobs or led to higher inflation.

With Labour concerned that low turnout in its urban heartlands might erode its majority, it is eager to show that it can deliver for the low-paid. As a result, it intends to increase the hourly rate by 30p next October, three times the size of this year's increase, which was linked to inflation rather than earnings. The original minimum wage was set at £3.60, a rate criticised by some unions.

Ministers argue that the caution was justified and that they are now in a position to ensure that low-paid workers share in the rising prosperity. They are making no secret of their plans to use the minimum wage as a key campaigning tool.

The government intends to highlight Tory opposition to the minimum wage during the last election, a stance that was changed only when Michael Portillo became shadow chancellor this year.

Labour's desire to exploit the Tories' original opposition to the minimum wage is underlined by the evidence provided by the government to the low pay commission - the tripartite body of employers, unions and academics given the task of recommending a rate. The commission has been told to come up with a rate by July next year, but the terms of reference set by Mr Byers indicate that the government is happy to sanction a sizeable increase.

According to the Department of Trade and Industry, the minimum wage has led to the first narrowing of the gap between high- and low-paid since the 1970s and has been of particular help to women, part-time workers, and those living in the poorest regions.

"The minimum wage has helped to bring about a narrowing in the spread of earnings between the highest and the lowest paid," the government evidence says. "Earnings of the bottom decile [10th] increased by 4.2% in the year to April 2000 compared to an increase of 2.2% at the top. This is a reversal of the long-term trend."

In addition, the DTI says the pay differential between men and women has narrowed. In the year to April 2000, average earnings of full-time women workers rose by 3% compared with 2.1% for full-time men.

webTitle: Morning after pill to go on sale

fields.headline: Morning after pill to go on sale
fields.standfirst:
But women going to pharmacists for emergency contraception will still face questions
SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The morning after pill is to be available at high street chemists from the new year, but the second sexual revolution which will put women's fertility completely in their own hands is some distance off yet.
fields.body:
The morning after pill is to be available at high street chemists from the new year, but the second sexual revolution which will put women's fertility completely in their own hands is some distance off yet.

From January, those pharmacies with sufficient stocks of emergency contraception will be able to dispense pills to any woman who turns up without a prescription.

No longer will a woman who has had unprotected sex and fears she might become pregnant need to go to a GP.

The pills are safe and they work, provided they are taken within 72 hours.

The committee on the safety of medicines has recommended that pharmacists be permitted to dispense them. But the moral debate on contraception and abortion has tested efforts of the Department of Health and the Royal Pharmaceutical Society to make what some consider a simple medical matter acceptable to middle England.

Some women may find they have exchanged the interrogation of a GP for the cross-questioning of a pharmacist. Under political pressure from a government nervous of moral majorities, the Royal Pharmaceutical Society has agreed that its members will ask questions of the women who seek their help to establish, among other things, whether they have had unprotected sex.

The society insists that some questions are necessary. "There is a raft of information that the pharmacists will need to satisfy themselves of," a spokeswoman said.

The Department of Health has said pharmacists must not supply emergency contraception to under-16s or to women who are pregnant - even though the pill will not affect a pregnancy and certainly will not induce an abortion. But there might be women who wrongly think it will end a pregnancy, the spokeswoman for the Royal Pharmaceutical Society said, and so the question must be asked. The pills prevent a fertilised egg implanting - once that point is passed they have no effect. She added that it was not enough to inform women verbally or in writing because it might be appropriate to refer them to someone else if they were seeking a termination.

The conversations that will take place in pharmacies need not be embarrassing, she said. "You'd be surprised, the sorts of issues people are perfectly prepared to talk about in pharmacies," she said. "What we've got here is a sort of normalised, non-stigmatised healthcare intervention. I think pharmacies will manage this product sensibly and safely but sensitively as well."

Family planning experts wholeheartedly applauded the move to pharmacy sales, which all agree is a big step towards giving women complete control of their fertility. If the day when the emergency pill is as much a part of the family medical cabinet as aspirins and sticking plaster is not yet here, they believe it must still be the logical progression.

"That's really where we need to be, because if it is most effective when used 24 hours after unprotected sex (its effectiveness is reduced to 58% after 48 hours), we need women to have it to hand," said Ann Furedi of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service. "We're hoping it will come to be used as just another pharmacy product."

She believed there would be many women who asked the pharmacist for a packet in case they ever needed it, although most of those would be older, more affluent women since the cost will be £20 for the course of four pills, which are taken in pairs 12 hours apart. Under the guidelines being drawn up, unless women lie they are likely to be refused. She saw no place for interrogation of customers.

There have been two pilot projects, in Manchester and London, run by the Royal Pharmaceutical Society, in which demand for the pills was so great that the pharmacies were afraid to advertise their services in case they ran out of stocks. Exactly what the pharmacist will ask has still not been established. The society is setting up workshops for its members, and said they were likely to be told what information they needed to elicit, rather than what they should ask.

There was an immediate outcry yesterday to the revelation that pharmacists would be permitted to hand out the pill. "It does not at all sit in with my moral views as to what should happen," said Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary. "There are also very good questions healthwise as to whether it will encourage ever more teenage sexual activity, whether it will encourage people into unprotected sexual activity."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said he was alarmed and appalled. "Making the morning after pill available to all girls over 16 in this way sends the wrong message about the need for responsible sexual activity," he said.

But Jenny Tong, the Liberal Democrat MP for Richmond Park, said the announcement was excellent news which was long overdue. "As a family planning doctor for over 20 years before I came in to parliament I have campaigned long and hard for women to be able to control their fertility in this safe and effective way.

"It is not an abortion. It is very safe, and I hope it will prevent many unplanned pregnancies in the future."

webTitle: Cardinal renews call for Act of Settlement repeal

fields.headline: Cardinal renews call for Act of Settlement repeal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The leader of Scotland's Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, has called on the government to deal with the Act of Settlement "sooner rather than later".
fields.body:
The leader of Scotland's Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, has called on the government to deal with the Act of Settlement "sooner rather than later".

The cardinal has long been an outspoken critic of the act, which bans Catholics from ascending to the throne or marrying the heirs to the crown. He has branded it an insult to Catholics, and has supported moves to have it repealed.

In an article in the Sunday Herald newspaper yesterday, the cardinal used the words of former Conservative Scottish secretary, Michael Forsyth, to describe the act as a "grubby little secret" that shames the nation.

The cardinal's comments come after a call by the Guardian for the act to be abolished on the grounds that it breaks the European Convention of Human Rights.

Cardinal Winning said the time for addressing the discrimination inherent in the act was now.

"The act, passed by the narrowest of margins 300 years ago and absorbed into Scots law under the Act of Union, contains words of bigotry directed against those of a 'Popish' persuasion which, if they were included in a TV programme, would force the schedulers to broadcast it after the watershed," he wrote.

"Yet three centuries on, the act remains on the statute book - untouched and almost forgotten were it not for the determination of a group of parliamentarians from all parties to push for change on this issue."

Almost exactly a year ago, the Scottish parliament unanimously backed a motion to repeal the act after a debate initiated by the Scottish National Party.

Last week, the SNP tabled a fresh motion for abolition in the Scottish parliament and a similar Commons motion, following the launch of the Guardian's campaign.

Cardinal Winning said repeal of the act had never been the most pressing issue for Catholics, but there was widespread consensus in the church that it had to be done.

"It is quite ludicrous to suggest that if a dashing young princess from Spain or Belgium or Luxembourg were to sweep Prince William off his feet and the young couple wished to marry, that somehow the British state would be brought to its knees."

Cardinal Winning said he did not want to see the church drawn into a wider debate on the future of the monarchy or the disestablishment of the Church of England, and added: "Such issues are for the people, not the church, to decide."

webTitle: New media diary

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: * At the Boobnight Christmas party and annual awards ceremony, the invited guests were raucous to say the least and free booze was abused along with the dance floor, the door man and the award winners.
fields.body:
* At the Boobnight Christmas party and annual awards ceremony, the invited guests were raucous to say the least and free booze was abused along with the dance floor, the door man and the award winners.

Punter in receipt of most abuse was Tim Lowes from Associated New Media who picked up the award for sexiest man in new media. The crowd waited with baited breath, only to see an Ian Beale lookalike step up to collect the award. Other recipients of audience heckling were Tara Lloyd-Jones of Engage, who picked up the award for best dressed person to cries of "she could have made more of an effort". Theft of the night went to Matt Teeman from beeb.com who beat the lovely Stevey 'Dubya' Wing from Guardian Unlimited to the grand prix of media owner of the year. With only 13 votes in it, clearly Teeman's hardcore canvassing and campaign manager helped solicit the win. A blushing Jo Cox of Real Media fame was crowned as the sexiest woman for the second year and direct marketing whizz Nero Shayvard from Gecko triumphed with 60% of the vote for personality of the year. Next year expect a long, drawn out canvassing period, hustings and maybe even the odd "vote for Nero" banner. Can't wait.

*Christmas has warmed the cold, cold hearts of sarcastic e-commerce outlet ntkmart.com, which has coughed up three of its notorious "I got £80m for my dot.com idea - and all I have left is this lousy T-shirt" T-shirts, to give to Media Guardian readers. What do you have to do to get one of these must-wear sartorial lovelies? Simple. Just complete the phrase "You know your dot.com is doomed when . . . " in a witty or heart-wrenching way. The more amusing, the better. Winners will be announced in next week's diary. Prizes should be received just in time to provoke fights and/or bouts of uncontrollable weeping at office parties. Entries to the usual address.

*The truth is out. Microsoft duped us all last week when it said 9m people logged onto the Madonna webcast. It's the oldest trick in the book: throw around the term hits to confuse mainstream media and let the rest of the media copy the figures. Time to set the record straight: a hit is not an accurate gauge of anything other than server demand and is certainly not a page impression or a unique user figure. In all likelihood, if there were 9m hits for the webcast, that could mean that only 1m people (if that) actually viewed the concert. The average web page contains about seven hits and the page impressions can generally be divided by about 10% to estimate the average number of unique users. Using this metric would come up with just 130,000 users, and who's to say that all of them could actually view the webcast once they got there?

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com
amy.vickers@theguardian.com

webTitle: Letters:Take your punishment

fields.headline: Take your punishment
fields.trailText: So 84% of 1,031 parents questioned in a survey for the government think they should decide if a childminder can smack their children (Parents back right to smack, December 9). Why didn't the government also ask if they wanted capital punishment re-introduced? They would probably have got 100% in favour, but it still wouldn't make it right. Why do the British want to hit their kids? And why do they approve of a stranger doing it?
fields.body:
So 84% of 1,031 parents questioned in a survey for the government think they should decide if a childminder can smack their children (Parents back right to smack, December 9). Why didn't the government also ask if they wanted capital punishment re-introduced? They would probably have got 100% in favour, but it still wouldn't make it right. Why do the British want to hit their kids? And why do they approve of a stranger doing it?
Joe Phillips
Bingham, Notts country.joe@ntlworld.com

 I purchased one of this year's newest Christmas decorations and took it home to place on top of my tree. I was dismayed to discover from the till receipt that I had purchased a "white fury snowball".
Peter Twist
London
petertwist@tesco.net

 I note in your cricket report (Silly point catches women one short, December 8) that the England women first XI's substitute fielder is referred to as 12th man. Surely we have moved on?
Tim Reed
Uckfield, East Sussex
TimReed@aol.com

 Why is there such a fuss about octogenarian Quick Crossword solvers? Surely you should be celebrating 43-year-olds such as myself who can also solve the Quick Crossword in 10 minutes, with half the wisdom and experience of life as those featured on the letters page recently. On the other hand, could any of them tell me if the Saturday quiz gets any easier with age; I don't anticipate finishing one in the next 40 years.
Ian Thompson
Enfield, Middx
Thommo.Enfield@btinternet

 As a mere 68-year-old, I do not have too much difficulty with the Quick Crossword. To make it more of a challenge, I start with the objective of going straight through without ever returning to a clue for a second attempt. This is not as easy as it might sound:I only succeed about once a month.
George Kitchin
Penrith, Cumbria
george@gkphoto.freeserve.co.uk

 "Haslingden is a beautiful town" (Where the street is a playground for bored youngsters, December 9)? Surely one for Corrections and clarifications?
Ray Chenery
Darwen, Lancs
raychenery@hotmail.com

 Saturday's Guardian contained no less than four copies of a Greenpeace leaflet inviting me to "recycle this..."
Maurice Zeegen
Eastcote, Middx
