webTitle: Letters: Cheers for the republic

fields.headline: Cheers for the republic
fields.trailText: Your decision to initiate a debate on republicanism is historically timely. Next month will see the 225th anniversary of Britain's export of republicanism to North America. In January 1776 one of the most telling of republican manifestos was published in Philadelphia; its anonymous author was Thomas Paine, who had emigrated to the American colonies after being dismissed from his job as an exciseman for campaigning for better pay and conditions.
fields.body:
Your decision to initiate a debate on republicanism is historically timely. Next month will see the 225th anniversary of Britain's export of republicanism to North America. In January 1776 one of the most telling of republican manifestos was published in Philadelphia; its anonymous author was Thomas Paine, who had emigrated to the American colonies after being dismissed from his job as an exciseman for campaigning for better pay and conditions.

His pamphlet rapidly became a bestseller and is acknowledged to have been a major contributory factor in swinging public opinion in the colonies at all levels of society in favour of both independence and a republican form of government.

Although the historical circumstances have changed, the case for republicanism as set out in Paine's pamphlet is in large measure as applicable to present-day Britain as it was to her colonies in 18th century North America.
RW Morrell
Secretary, Thomas Paine Society

 When, through your efforts, we have dispensed with our hereditary monarchy, can we have that empty plinth in Trafalgar Square occupied by a statue to England's most influential political thinker, Thomas Paine?
VC Tomkinson
Lewes, East Sussex

 What is Anthony Scrivener (The Speaker could do it, December 7) talking about? The assertion that the (American) Declaration of Independence was a "statement of the rights of ordinary people" is utter nonsense.

The "people" in the opening declaration should be translated as: "property-owning, male whites". And "property" then included slaves - it was another 90 years before the constitution was amended to outlaw slavery.

Recent events in Florida suggest that even now, all the "ordinary people" are still not fully emancipated. The events also confirm my view that the governance of the US has always been (to paraphrase) "of the lawyers, by the lawyers, for the lawyers".

Perhaps this explains the QC's rosy view of 1775.
Don Clarke
Stafford
don.clarke@ireland.com

 Your powerful challenge to the monarchy is welcome and long overdue. Its opponents portray the case for reform as esoteric; in fact it strikes to the roots of our basic freedoms.

Reform would be of immediate benefit to almost everyone because the existence of the monarchy either directly enables, or indirectly encourages, all sorts of organisations to treat us with contempt as subjects rather than with respect as citizens.

Those organisations are the civil service, the government, local councils, utilities operators, the railway companies and many others. Because we lack fundamental rights they are able to act as "little monarchies" and brush our concerns aside, sheltering, consciously or not, behind the knock-on effect of big monarchy as they do so. If we owned those rights as citizens, they would have stronger compulsion to treat us with greater respect, to listen and to act.
Brian Basham
London

 Every child in Britain should be able to aspire to be head of state as well as head of government. It is quite undemocratic that the supreme office of state, with all the power and privilege it confers, should be automatically decided by an accident of birth and reserved for one over-indulged family. The government should offer a referendum on the issue. I could happily accept the outcome, so long as I've had the opportunity to vote.
Dominic Shelmerdine
London

webTitle: The future may be delayed

fields.headline: The future may be delayed
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: I spent last week sipping margaritas and sunbathing with 10,000 of my closest colleagues at the Western Cable Show in LA. The things I do for Telewest.
fields.body:
I spent last week sipping margaritas and sunbathing with 10,000 of my closest colleagues at the Western Cable Show in LA. The things I do for Telewest.

The title for the cable gabfest was Broadbandwagon - Into the Future. Now, I know the cynics among you think that the broadbandwagon was suddenly unveiled as a shiny new idea when the narrowbandwagon was shown to have fewer legs than Long John Silver. The truth is, though, the future is sneaking up on us just at the moment when the markets are playing pass the tech stocks. The future just can't come quickly enough for some people.

Admittedly, narrowband internet was a bugger's muddle. Slow, inefficient dial-up, crap content, ISPs filling BT's bloated coffers with undeserved cash, and more plug-ins than an S&M club. The web produced trash economics where everything was free and nothing was valued. And yet, buried under the blizzard of vc guano the original vision still sparkles. There is a world of wonders where producers and consumers can meet without intermediaries; there are self-sustaining communities of interest who can create their own media using inexpensive digital devices. I can get what I want, when I want it. And the internet will be a space in which our best creative minds will invent new forms of content.

At the show, Barry Diller, one of the wise men of US media, proclaimed "everything of value takes time to mature". This echoes the views of many economists that just as the railways took 30 years to create a self-sustaining boom, as did the rise of computing, so the internet's effects on our lives and economies must be seen as a long-run benefit. Broadband will be like electricity - fundamental to our lives, but we'll never give it a thought until it is turned off.

Although broadband content and services are in their infancy, the show demonstrated that the race for dominant providers is on for real. At the hundreds of stands in the cavernous LA conference centre, the big guys were rolling out their product like honey traps for the cable operators. There were at least 10 interactive programme guides that make the EPGs here look like medieval road maps. The interactive handsets on display were intuitive and functional. Equally, it was clear that games were the new black, with demonstrations of everything from simple set top box quizzes, such as Playalong with Jeopardy, to Playstation2 driving games to turn you into an urban ram-raider.

At the sheer fun end of the spectrum, Disney had an instant animation feature which turned a digital picture of delegates into Toons and dropped them into a live show. Watching George W Bush, it seemed that someone had found an early use for this technology.

However, what struck me most about the displays wasn't the emerging content ideas, because I think we are still in the process of inventing those, it was the concept of wireless home networking.

The idea that all the devices with screens in your house will be linked together, and that high quality content and services will be available at high speed to an always-on connection will, if the evangelists at the stands are to be believed, transform the type of media and services we consume. I'm writing this at my desk surrounded by my digital music jukebox, CD, radio, TV, MP3, printer and electronic keyboard. The pile of wires at my feet looks like the intestines of an elephant. Wireless broadband networking frees us up.

I keep hearing the theme tune to 2001 when I make statements like this; God knows we've been hearing something like this for 10 years. Digital was supposed to do it, then the internet and now broadband. What's different this time? At the show, John Malone, one of cable's big cahunas, made the point that the media industry is like a cross country skier climbing a hill. When you look up, it seems a long climb, but when you look down you're amazed by how far you've come.

DSL (digital subscriber line) and early broadband cable are merely the beginning. Both promise to make the internet fast and begin to deliver proper multi-media content. But all of us are planning a world beyond this. BT is working on high-speed VDSL which may deliver multiple megabits of capacity, and at Telewest we're preparing for a 30-megabit world. At this point, delivering on demand everything is a breeze.

UK cable operators, unlike their US counterparts - who were hanging round the free popcorn stands and queuing to have their digital picture snapped with the pneumatic "model" at interactive erotic - have a built-in advantage. UK cable is new and ideally suited to the broadband future. And that was the other big message coming out of the Western Cable Show. Europe is ahead of the curve with interactive TV. Let's hope with the coming white paper, the government will promote this advantage, otherwise the future might be a longer time coming.

 David Docherty is managing director of broadband content at Telewest.

webTitle: Media Monkey

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: * Monkey apologises for misleading readers last week. Channel 4 chief Michael Jackson was not at Madonna's gig of the year. But neither was he at the C4- sponsored Turner prize event - a witness reliably places Jackson at dinner at 11 Downing Street. Monkey is very sorry for confusing Ms Ciccone with Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
* Monkey apologises for misleading readers last week. Channel 4 chief Michael Jackson was not at Madonna's gig of the year. But neither was he at the C4- sponsored Turner prize event - a witness reliably places Jackson at dinner at 11 Downing Street. Monkey is very sorry for confusing Ms Ciccone with Gordon Brown.

*BSkyB execs at last week's RTS rubber-chicken-fest were surprised to escape a broadside from speaker Stuart Prebble, chief exec of ONdigital. After all, the OFT had just given Prebble a big stick with which to beat BSkyB - the investigation of its maligned pay-TV supply deals with the likes of ONdigital. Could Prebbo's reticence have anything to do with his rumoured impending move to ITV's digital channels, where the first item in his in-tray will be a distribution deal with Sky Digital?

*Before they'd even recovered from moving to new premises in Docklands, Independent staffers discovered that the windows of O'Reilly towers bear the alarming message: "Danger - do not open". Because Street-Porter underlings might hurl themselves out? Nope, the panes are not properly stuck in - as one unfortunate, desperate for air, discovered when the window fell out and landed on the floor.

*On arriving at the new Indy HQ, it's said, Simon Kelner's deputy Ian Birrell discovered that the office of Tristan Davies, features chief and Birrell's rival for the portly editor's ear, was a couple of feet bigger. Intolerable! Birrell's bunker was immediately extended.

*So who is to replace the Rev Ernest Rea, stepping down as the BBC's head of religion as the churches unleash an anti-Beeb crusade over its perceived failure to take spiritual matters seriously? Some insiders tip Justin Phillips, a Christian and head of BBC Heritage, but they're hardly lining up. A case of let this cup pass?

webTitle: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Creed is good
fields.trailText: Saturday / Sunday / The Space Game / Naked Ambition
fields.body:
Saturday (Channel 4, Saturday) was a clever, incisive and touching documentary which took a simple premise and ordinary people and produced something really rather wonderful. A detailed portrait of a day in the life of Manchester, it was a vivid illustration of the UK's rich and diverse social fabric, the vibrancy of city life and the still-hallowed nature of the weekend.

Focusing on individual stories teased from, among others, Manchester's 11,000 Jews, 9,000 Muslims and 4,500 gym-goers, Saturday was a delight, uncovering as it did the uniqueness of ordinary people, and making those its cameras alighted upon emblems of their communities without resorting to cliché. In doing so, it suggested that to call these people "ordinary" would be a gross understatement. It was also easy to imagine these people as little Plasticine animals made by Nick Park.

While following aerobics instructors to their meditation class, observing a Jewish family on their Sabbath, or simply letting a Muslim man opine on the state of the world, Saturday was both uplifting and saddening.

Although it was a joy to see people revelling in their faith - even if it was devotion to Man City - it was difficult not to be a tiny bit envious.

Something to believe in is a precious commodity indeed. But the documentary also sparked the thought that one day, the last person to believe in God will die and no one else will remember. Hardly a recruitment drive for old-time religion, Saturday, surprisingly, was a reminder that spirituality may not be a bad thing to think about once in a while.

Sunday (Channel 4, Sunday), meanwhile, was far from thought-provoking, lacking the narrative drive, the personalities and discipline of its predecessor. All standing stones and car boot sales (15,000 of them, don't you know), it was at least faithful to its subject. Like Sundays, it was awfully boring.

As apt names for a space ambassador go, Peggy is pretty low on the list, just above Thora and Melvin. Smelling of old ladies' face powder, freshly buttered toast and lavender, Peggy is not a name one would readily associate with the building of an international space station. Yet, as The Space Game (Discovery, Sunday) revealed, Peggy was indeed the American space ambassador who toured the world encouraging nation states to become involved in turning science fiction into science fact. She had her work cut out for her.

Charting the history - and politics - of the space race, it was two parts schools programme to one part grown-up documentary. There were arguments over the names of modules, disputes over whose technology was better, and then there was the treaty for which each of the 16 nations defined "peaceful" differently. This was essentially to satisfy the US Department of Defense - which, as we know from The X-Files, is run by rabid militarist, right-wing megalomaniacs - who wanted the opportunity to test spooky weapons on the station the American government had paid for. And all this before people actually started living on the darn thing. Can you imagine the ding-dongs then? ("I want to paint this room mauve." "Well, I want it barley white.") Bickering children on a multi-billion-dollar installation orbiting the earth. Doomed, we're all doomed.

Part of the Madonna Night, Naked Ambition (Channel 4, Saturday) profiled pre-fame Madonna with some vintage footage, photographs and contributions from "friends," "ex-boyfriends" (there were a lot of them) and people who once boogied beside her in New York's Danceteria.

Aside from the clumsy structure, Naked Ambition was interesting in that - like the Freddie Mercury biography shown on Friday - it revealed what happens to the people who brush by a rising star. They hang out in funny hats (one of Madge's exes had a hat with what looked like sliced tomatoes on) and wait for documentary crews to make them semi-famous by association. It comes of having nothing to believe in, of course. Being touched - or more accurately clambered over - by an angel is the closest some people get to having meaning in their lives.

The difference between people like that and someone like Madonna is that she would never be happy being a hanger-on, preferring instead to be the one on whom people want to be hung. Still surprising everyone, Madonna's faith is to be admired. Her faith in herself. Not a lot of people have that, not even in Manchester.

Smelling of old ladies' face powder, freshly buttered toast and lavender, Peggy is not a name one would readily associate with the building of an international space station. Yet, as The Space Game (Discovery, Sunday) revealed, Peggy was indeed the American space ambassador who toured the world encouraging nation states to become involved in turning science fiction into science fact. She had her work cut out for her. Charting the history - and politics - of the space race, it was two parts schools programme to one part grown-up documentary. There were arguments over the names of modules, disputes over whose technology was better, and then there was the treaty for which each of the 16 nations defined "peaceful" differently. This was essentially to satisfy the US Department of Defense - which, as we know from The X-Files, is run by rabid militarist, right-wing megalomaniacs - who wanted the opportunity to test spooky weapons on the station the American government had paid for. And all this before people actually started living on the darn thing. Can you imagine the ding-dongs then? ("I want to paint this room mauve." "Well, I want it barley white.") Bickering children on a multi-billion-dollar installation orbiting the earth. Doomed, we're all doomed. Part of the Madonna Night, Naked Ambition (Channel 4, Saturday) profiled pre-fame Madonna with some vintage footage, photographs and contributions from "friends," "ex-boyfriends" (there were a lot of them) and people who once boogied beside her in New York's Danceteria. Aside from the clumsy structure, Naked Ambition was interesting in that - like the Freddie Mercury biography shown on Friday - it revealed what happens to the people who brush by a rising star. They hang out in funny hats (one of Madge's exes had a hat with what looked like sliced tomatoes on) and wait for documentary crews to make them semi-famous by association. It comes of having nothing to believe in, of course. Being touched - or more accurately clambered over - by an angel is the closest some people get to having meaning in their lives. The difference between people like that and someone like Madonna is that she would never be happy being a hanger-on, preferring instead to be the one on whom people want to be hung. Still surprising everyone, Madonna's faith is to be admired. Her faith in herself. Not a lot of people have that, not even in Manchester.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: East Of Eden / Voyager / Crash / Sitcom
fields.body:
East Of Eden

(Elia Kazan, 1955)

1pm, Carlton Cinema

James Dean and Raymond Massey are locked in a filial war of attrition in Kazan's adaptation of the Steinbeck novel. Cal's relationship with his austere California lettuce-farmer father is already strained when he learns that the mother he thought dead is in fact alive and well, and living as a Monterey madam (played by Oscar-winning Jo Van Fleet). Others are drawn into the conflict: Cal's brother, Richard Davalos, and Julie Harris as his girlfriend. But Dean's tortured soul is the essence of the movie.

Voyager

(Volker Schlondorff, 1991)

9pm, Carlton Cinema

After surviving a plane crash, Sam Shephard meets Julie Delpy, sending him on course for disaster of a more personal nature. The languid pace teases out their relationship as they embark on a road trip through Europe. While the mystery that lies at its heart is less mystifying to the audience than it seems to be to the characters, this is still an intelligent, thoughtful drama.

Crash

(David Cronenberg, 1996)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Director David Cronenberg's controversial version of JG Ballard's exercise in auto-erotica sparked one of those periodic silly censorship rows in Britain. It is pretty weird, with jaded James Spader and girlfriend Deborah Unger spicing up their sex lives with orgasmic car crashes and their scarred victims - Holly Hunter's perverse widow and Rosanna Arquette in fetishistic leg braces. It's extremely seductively shot, and at heart quite sweet: a couple trying, against the odds, to make their relationship work.

Sitcom

(François Ozon, 1998)

3.40am, FilmFour

This is a wild and weird first feature from the maker of short films, François Ozon. A Buñuelian tale with a dash of John Waters, it concerns the disturbed Jean, played by François Marthouret, and a malignant pet rat that exercises a perverse sexual influence over Jean's nearest and dearest. Not exactly Terry and June, then.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Work In Progress / The Bizarre Girl
fields.body:
In this week's series of vignettes about Work In Progress (10.0am, Radio 3), Margaret Drabble (pictured) muses on the underlying theme of her latest novel, The Peppered Moth. In her final years, Ms Drabble's mother repeatedly wished she was dead. When that wish was fulfilled in 1984 her daughter had little reaction. Since then, however, she has harboured an inexplicable sense of guilt. "It seems odd at my age," Drabble comments, "to go on repenting for something when you don't know what it was you did in the first place."

In 1927 the Royal Staffordshire Pottery unveiled a new line in tableware, brightly decorated with unusual patterns and shapes. Bizarre Ware was an immediate success, and fellow workers dubbed the shopfloor worker who designed it The Bizarre Girl (10.45am, Radio 4). Clarice Cliff was on her way to lasting fame - and to marriage with the boss. Lizzie Slater's dramatised account of her brilliant career is the Woman's Hour serial.

webTitle: Work experience: Sean Young

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Sean Young in Stripes
fields.body:
Sean Young in Stripes (Ivan Reitman, 1981)

Who? Still best-known as the dead-eyed replicant Rachael in Blade Runner (1982), Young's career has been far from stellar since that promising early role. In fact she's attracted far more attention for her erratic behaviour in real life; James Woods, her co-star in my-drug-hell drama The Boost (1988), accused her of harassing him, and she lobbied for the role of Catwoman by appearing on the Joan Rivers Show in a regrettable homemade catsuit (she didn't get the part). The thriller A Kiss Before Dying (1991), where she starred opposite Matt Dillon, was inoffensive, but since then she's landed in a string of duds - has anyone seen Dr Jekyll and Ms Hyde? Or Evil Has A Face? She did appear in the hugely successful Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (1994), but only as a sexually ambiguous foil to Jim Carrey's hero. Perhaps realising that Hollywood wasn't going to offer her any decent roles, she later set up her own production company, Shonderosa Productions.

The role: Louise, a military police officer who puts up with the antics of loser new recruits John Winger (Bill Murray) and Russel Zisky (Harold Ramis).

Cringe factor: She cute, she's perky, and she looks good in uniform - so no shame there. And, let's face it, she's done a lot worse.

Other wannabes: Rotund comic John Candy, geeky Beverly Hills Cop star Judge Reinhold, and a fresh-faced Bill Paxton as "Soldier".

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin called it "funny, but eminently forgettable".

Also not starring in: The 1980 Merchant Ivory film Jane Austen In Manhattan, and the hospital soap opera spoof Young Doctors in Love in 1982.

Stripes, 8pm & 1.40am, Tuesday 12 December, Sky Cinema

webTitle: Getting the best out of our judges

fields.headline: Getting the best out of our judges
fields.trailText: Why can't the English be more like the French? Not in all ways, of course, but what I have been mulling over has to do with the appointment of judges.
fields.body:
Why can't the English be more like the French? Not in all ways, of course, but what I have been mulling over has to do with the appointment of judges.

At a fascinating meeting of the Association of Franco-British Lawyers the other day, an eminent senior French judge, Roger Errera, described the process for appointing judges and then continuing to evaluate their performance. There is, of course, the big difference that France has a mostly career judiciary.

But what was most striking was the high level of transparency in the French system. There can be no question of anyone secretly providing information, unknown to the judge or candidate being assessed. They are entitled to be told of everything that is being taken into account, and have the right to respond to anything negative. And it's all on record.

How different from our own system, where those consulted by the lord chancellor submit their comments in confidence, and candidates often have no idea why they have been rejected; nor do they have any realistic opportunity of challenging what has been said or thought about them. Sir Tom Legg, the former permanent secretary at the lord chancellor's department, defended the process with the argument that those consulted would not speak honestly and forthrightly unless their identities were protected.

That may be so, but it doesn't say much for the consultees. If they are telling the truth or conveying their genuinely held opinions, why do they need the cloak of anonymity? It seems to me that granting confidentiality encourages them to exaggerate, to relate unfounded gossip, to assert opinions they cannot support and even to disguise personal dislikes as professional assessments. That is no way to get the best judges.

Last week I quoted from the disgraceful anti-refugee letter by the solicitor Martin R Maloney which had appeared in the Law Society's Gazette. It has now published an apology for having run the letter. I can also tell you that the firm for which Maloney worked - Palis, in north-west London - got rid of him immediately, and are dismayed that they ever employed him.

I have spent much of my professional life protesting that the question "Who are the Beatles?", regularly cited as the stereotypical example of judicial ignorance, was never said by any judge. I have looked hard and never found a reference to such a remark. And no reader of this column or the others in which I have asked for help haspointed me to a source for the alleged inquiry.

Mitchell Sandler has now guided me to an item in a newspaper's Beatles commemorative supplement last month. On February 25 1964, it was reported that the magistrates' clerk at Cannock, a Mr DH Willett, had asked the question during the trial of someone charged with a motoring offence. This is the closest in 20 years that anyone has come to proving that it had been asked. But a magistrates' clerk, though a lawyer, is not a judge. So, Mitchell Sandler gets my thanks.

'Go and see the shop window at Ede and Ravenscroft," she muttered, her voice muffled and disguised by the handkerchief she had placed over the mouthpiece. You have got to understand that Ede and Ravenscroft, of Chancery Lane (established 1689), are to legal couture what Colman's is to mustard. They are the ultimate arbiters on every aspect of lawyers' accoutrements. If you want to know whether it is the third or the fourth waistcoat button that QCs must not ever do up, E&R knows.

But there in its display window, sneering at me, was the thing to which my secret informant had steered me - the dreaded gavel which, as I obsessively point out, English judges never ever use, but which keeps appearing in TV legal dramas. To see a gavel in an E&R window is to see Mr Colman opting for tomato ketchup.

"What does it matter?" you ask. But one thing leads to another. Little mistakes at first, but inaccuracy is catching. If they can commit such a gavellian solecism, next thing they will miscount the number of curls in a lord chancellor's peruke or robe a high court judge in the wrong shade of cerise.

webTitle: Television is seeking ever nastier thrills

fields.headline: Cruel intentions
fields.standfirst: Big Brother's 'Nasty' Nick Bateman is returning to TV as a game show host. Further proof, says Mark Lawson, that television is seeking ever nastier thrills - nowadays, the bad guys are the winners
fields.trailText: Big Brother's 'Nasty' Nick Bateman is returning to TV as a game show host. Further proof, says Mark Lawson, that television is seeking ever nastier thrills - nowadays, the bad guys are the winners.
fields.body:
Television critics working on their State Of The Medium addresses for the end of the year are certain to devote several paragraphs to the rise during 2000 of cruelty TV. The two biggest hits of the period - Channel 4's Big Brother and BBC1's The Weakest Link - over-turned two of the traditional elements of the television game show: the pretence that even losing guests went away happy, and the grinning sympathy of the host.

In the theatre of the 70s, when companies developed a resentment towards the sort of people who bought tickets, the German dramatist Peter Handke gave one of his plays the title Offending The Audience. This ambition might be taken as British broadcasting's motto for this year. The previous trend towards celebration of the public - manifested in the docu-soaps and other Real People TV - has been replaced by elimination and humiliation.

The game show Trust Me is post-Big Brother in both tone and host. The presenter is Nick Bateman, the biggest of the sudden celebrities created this year by the Channel 4 series in which housemates plotted and schemed against each other to win £70,000. It's appropriate to the ethical upheavals in TV this year that Bateman, the greatest beneficiary of Big Brother in terms of finance and fame, should have been a loser rather than a winner and, moreover, someone kicked off the programme for breaking the rules. The great lesson of the Clinton and OJ decade - that notoriety is just another kind of fame - has rarely been better illustrated.

The contracting of Bateman to present Trust Me is thematic casting, because this game show requires the contestants to be devious. Teams of two are sealed in sound-proofed cabins. In the opening episode, a pair of chess-players take on a poker-playing duo. These groups seem to have been chosen for similarity - a mental tendency towards scheming - but the second set of contestants seem to have been cast for contrast. Male ballet dancers take on nightclub bouncers, with the social and sexual differences seemingly intended to create tension.

But, because Trust Me has rules ludicrously complicated even by the mortgage-form standards now prevailing in television game shows, the Billy Elliots don't initially know that they are taking on the heavies or the grand masters that they are competing against poker-faces.

By feeding questions through Bateman, the inhabitants of Cabin A and Cabin B try to find out what their rivals are like. The challenges are of the kind favoured by psychological questionnaires: "What's the worst thing you've ever done?", "Why should I trust you?" The point, in a deliberate and neat perversion of the usual game show, is that there may be advantage in giving wrong answers. It may be easier to defeat your opponents if they erroneously believe you're nice and decent.

The reason for this is the way the jackpot is dispensed. At the end of the contest, each team of two votes on whether to take the prize cash alone or split it with the other pair. At this point, light entertainment really does become a maths lesson. If both cabins vote to share, they are rewarded with an increase in the kitty. If one cabin votes to take it and the other to split, the greediest win. If both vote to pocket the single cheque, they each get nothing. The makers are rumoured to be working on a second series in which the losers will be able to apply to the Florida Supreme Court.

Further clues to the other group emerge from formal inserts including Character Witness, where a relative or friend describes the person, and Home Visit, where Bateman becomes a more vicious version of Loyd Grossman on Through The Keyhole and creeps around the residence of a contestant, seeking clues to their personality. Finally, in Open Mike, the teams, though unable to see each other, can converse directly.

The format is so complicated that you feel Bateman needs as co-host an equivalent of Q in the James Bond films, consistently chivvying: "Do pay attention, 007". And, indeed, the presenter's main task is to try out a series of gadgets: lip-mike, padded headphones, a Secret Service earpiece with a squiggly lead. And, like Anne Robinson on The Weakest Link, Bateman has been encouraged to dispense with the idea of the presenter as the imaginary friend of guests and viewers. Decamping from one cabin, he snarls about the contestants: "They are really, really boring people."

The surprise of the show is that Bateman, who you assumed would be the weakest link, isn't. Nothing in his performance would alert the researchers for one of those TV Hell evenings. The drawback is the format. While series such as Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and The Weakest Link are, on the surface, repetitive in their contents, the changing questions guarantee freshness and variety. On Trust Me, the elements are virtually unchanged in each contest. And, as was demonstrated again when Tony Blair accused William Hague in parliament of being the weakest link, game shows flourish partly because of catchphrases. Asking too much of the audience, the makers of Trust Me should have phoned a few more friends.

 Trust Me, tonight, 11.35pm; Tuesday 11.30pm; Wednesday 11.35pm; Thursday 11.45pm, Channel 4

webTitle: Dennis Potter's influence on drama

fields.headline: Last testaments
fields.trailText: If the playwright Dennis Potter contemplated his legacy during the months when he knew he was dying, he might have hoped to have an influence on television drama.
fields.body:
If the playwright Dennis Potter contemplated his legacy during the months when he knew he was dying, he might have hoped to have an influence on television drama.

And this he has clearly achieved, especially in the sudden tonal shifts and fantasy sequences which now make non-naturalism a natural part of series such as The Sins and Cold Feet.

Potter, though, has also had a second and less expected effect on television: the genre of the televised last testament. Potter's morphine-swigging final interview with Melvyn Bragg broke the conventions by which sick celebrities disappeared mysteriously from view before the eventual news bulletin reference to death after a "long illness".

Following Potter's example, other stricken public figures - actor Paul Eddington, writer Rabbi Hugo Gryn - confided final thoughts to camera. And now, in My Father (Saturday, 8pm, Channel 4), the former Archbishop of Canterbury Lord Runcie speaks, in the weeks before his death, to his film-maker son James (both pictured below).

There's always a risk of sentimentality towards the recently dead, and James Runcie has the additional burden of a blood link with the subject. But the film is tough yet loving, sharply pointing out, for example, that Lord Runcie, a gifted mimic, had employed this skill socially at Oxford to modify his native Scouse accent. And the former Archbishop's reflections on God and his war record, both subjects susceptible to gush, are admirably analytical.

In an age when most Britons are not religious, broadcasters increasingly struggle to define what religious broadcasting should be. (These confusions led to the recent resignation of the BBC's Head of Religion, Ernie Rea.) My Father - a moving portrait of a complex man - suggests that the solution is personal testimony. It's not clear, however, why what feels like a perfect Christmas Day programme for the religiously inclined goes out a week early.

Potter's morphine-swigging final interview with Melvyn Bragg broke the conventions by which sick celebrities disappeared mysteriously from view before the eventual news bulletin reference to death after a "long illness". Following Potter's example, other stricken public figures - actor Paul Eddington, writer Rabbi Hugo Gryn - confided final thoughts to camera. And now, in My Father (Saturday, 8pm, Channel 4), the former Archbishop of Canterbury Lord Runcie speaks, in the weeks before his death, to his film-maker son James (both pictured below). There's always a risk of sentimentality towards the recently dead, and James Runcie has the additional burden of a blood link with the subject. But the film is tough yet loving, sharply pointing out, for example, that Lord Runcie, a gifted mimic, had employed this skill socially at Oxford to modify his native Scouse accent. And the former Archbishop's reflections on God and his war record, both subjects susceptible to gush, are admirably analytical. In an age when most Britons are not religious, broadcasters increasingly struggle to define what religious broadcasting should be. (These confusions led to the recent resignation of the BBC's Head of Religion, Ernie Rea.) My Father - a moving portrait of a complex man - suggests that the solution is personal testimony. It's not clear, however, why what feels like a perfect Christmas Day programme for the religiously inclined goes out a week early.

webTitle: The age of dissent

fields.headline: Riding for a fall
fields.trailText: The cyclists on the Heath are terrifying the life out of me and Sylvia. They whizz up behind us at top speed, in silence, and nearly slice through the dogs.
fields.body:
The cyclists on the Heath are terrifying the life out of me and Sylvia. They whizz up behind us at top speed, in silence, and nearly slice through the dogs.

We scream abuse but they couldn't give a toss. Why not ring a warning bell or observe the speed limit? So we are sick of cyclists. And now Olga has decided not to replace her old car but to cycle everywhere instead. Whenever she really needs a horrid, stinky car, she can use mine.

The car-sharing is perfect but I am not thrilled about Olga's cycling. Neither is anyone else. She doesn't mow down dogs or elderly women, but she is courting death. Last week she came visiting and we all berated her for not wearing a helmet.

She has already had one near-death experience. She was winging down the Holloway Road, HELMETLESS, when someone opened their car door without looking and knocked her into the path of a lorry, which whacked her on to the pavement. She was unhurt, but the apples in her rucksack were turned to purée.

And she wears glasses, another hazard. Fielding tells me that, although he always wears his helmet, his glasses blur in the rain at night and he must ride blind. There is nothing more frightening than driving past a wibbling, blind, bareheaded daredevil cyclist, but try telling Olga that. She feels the world is out to stop her cycling.

Last night she cycled off to dinner with some other friends, had a divine meal, got up to leave, but the friends absolutely would not allow her to ride home alone in the dark at her age. She must put her bicycle in the car and be driven home. Fine. Except that the next day, as she was cycling around with a million things to do and carrying a ton of cat food, the gears fell apart. They had received a knock the night before while her chums crammed her bike into the car boot.

Now the police have joined our Stop Olga Cycling campaign. Yesterday they sensibly stopped her and threatened her with imprisonment as she cycled the wrong way up a tiny one-way street - a favourite cyclists' short cut. Olga arrived at yoga in a fury. She tries to keep fit and save the planet, and this is her reward. Persecution.

webTitle: The bunker to save plants from extinction

fields.headline: Ground force
fields.standfirst: If you want to save animals from extinction, you create a wildlife reserve. But plants?  Jonathan Glancey  visits Britain's answer: a giant subterranean bunker
fields.trailText: If you want to save animals from extinction, you create a wildlife reserve. But plants? Jonathan Glancey visits Britain's answer: a giant subterranean bunker.
fields.body:
You will have to wait until mid-January to see Nigel Rolfe's superb Life Without Life installation at the Royal Pump Rooms, Leamington Spa. In the meantime, I advise a trip to the equally fine Millennium Seed Bank at Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, West Sussex. The two projects are related. In the first, Rolfe will be showing his collection of 162 delicate monotone images of dead and desiccated flowers, last seen in Dublin. Projected onto the Pump Room walls, these will slowly dissolve one into the other, as if fading away, petals to dust. The point of this sadly exquisite project is that all Rolfe's flowers are dead. His title, Life Without Life, is, he says, a reference to "life unworthy of life" - the Nazi phrase for those with physical deformities or mental handicaps whose lives were crushed into the mire of Hitler's Germany.

As with flowers, so with humankind. Destroy one and you destroy the other. So why are we wiping out as many plants as possible? You know the answers as well as I do. As to what we can do, well, the botanists and conservationists of Kew Gardens have been doing it for us: they have been collecting and storing seeds in the grounds of Wakehurst Place, a handsome Tudor mansion, since 1974.

The Millennium Seed Bank is a gentle, very fine new building designed by those cool, precise, measured architects Stanton Williams for the Royal Botanic Gardens. It houses an underground bunker that promises to contain samples of 10% of the world's seed-bearing flora by 2010, and is already home to examples of all 1,400 British seed-bearing species, of which 357 are currently endangered. Above, in a flowering of subtle, uncompromised modern design that reminds me more than a little of the great Louis Kahn's peerless Kimbell Art Gallery at Fort Worth, Texas (one of the greatest buildings of the 20th century), is an exhibition that tells us why it is now imperative that we collect and nurture this extraordinary biodiversity of vegetable life. This venture by the Kew Gardens team is utterly compelling. I could have taken root here.

Lottery money made the new project and the Stanton Williams building that houses it possible. The Millennium Commission provided £30m, with the rest of the £80m needed coming from the Wellcome Trust, Orange plc (as in mobile phones) and private individuals. Most of that money has been spent on what you don't see, except with special permission or through virtual tours by visitor-operated computers. Or big windows looking into laboratories. Why? Because the cash has been invested in a vast underground bunker in which seeds from all over the world rest their weary pods, safe from every pesticidal attempt to exterminate them above ground. Like Americans who pay a fortune to have their bodies frozen in the hope of being revived again, these thousands of seeds are waiting to replenish the fields, forests and flowerbeds of the future. The vault they rest in is kept at a constant temperature of -20C.

The seeds are also here to enhance our understanding of the effects of pollution, pesticides and global warming and to assist the medical industry in developing safe new drugs. They represent the fruit of a collaboration between Kew Gardens and an increasing number of countries from around the world. To date, Burkina-Faso, Kenya, Madagascar, Lebanon, South Africa and the United States have joined hands with Britain.

Yet such thoughts are probably far from most visitors' minds as they pilot their lead-free Metros, Clios and Espaces into the gates of Wakehurst Place. Here, among the birches and beeches, the rhododendrons and choruses of hypericums and skimmias, landed gently between lovingly preserved woodland, wetland and grassland, is the new Stanton Williams building. It comprises a fan of five bright, airy, barrel-vaulted concrete and glass sheds and, to one side, a matching greenhouse. This cluster of buildings is as gentle as it is clear-sighted, and the interiors are deft and subtle. The public exhibition spaces are a delight to walk through, the wintry sunlight feeling its way through the low-lying clouds and reaching into corners, none of which are prey to unsympathetic artificial lighting.

A cross between temple, art gallery, aircraft hangar, greenhouse and laboratory - you can see the boffins at work behind big glass windows - the Seed Bank is a compelling architectural flowering and the kind of place where you learn so very much and so quickly. The actual exhibition part of the project - the bit you see - has been shaped by Land Design Studio. The first thing the designers have chosen to show us is a giant, floor-to-ceiling seed wall. It looks great, while the individual seeds prove to be very beautiful as you get up close.

The interactive bit - there has to be one, doesn't there? - is actually very good, offering a virtual reality tour of the cold storage. You can open the seed jars and learn about the plants you are unearthing. What I would like to see is a speeded-up film of every single one of these seeds bursting into life; maybe this can come in time, and with another grant. To date, though, there is more than enough to keep all but the most jaded, computer-crazy visitor enchanted and engrossed.

I promised myself not to write about that wretched Millennium Experience but, compared with the Millennium Seed Bank, it has taught us nothing at all, except how to waste money in a vain attempt to make a new government look "with it". Here, in Sussex, all is calm, all is bright, and though there is little birdsong (we may soon need a Millennium Nest Bank to store the eggs of our quickly vanishing songbirds), there is a sense of something truly worthwhile being done on our behalf as we cover what's left of our countryside with natty executive housing and distribution depots full of pesticide-sprayed food.

Stanton Williams are masters of restrained modern architecture. Theirs is a chaste aesthetic, yet here the curved roofs, twisting metal stairs, big glass screens and vaults modulated to allow different plays of daylight at different times of day and year produce a building that is more than the sum of its parts. It shows, too, how well contemporary design can be implanted in mature rural settings. As do the giant seed sculptures here by Peter Randall-Page. Most of all, it should leave visitors with a sense of the sheer magic of the natural world, of how what we build and what we devour as the self-appointed master species can yet be balanced with other forms of life, so easily stepped on, brushed aside or sprayed into premature extinction. This is one of the very best of the millennium projects - architecturally, morally, intellectually, naturally - and one that will be flowering for all our sakes in hundreds of years to come.

 The Millennium Seed Bank is at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, West Sussex (01444 894066). Life Without Life is at the Royal Pump Rooms, Royal Leamington Spa (01926 742700), from January 20 to February 25.

webTitle: What really went on in Nice?

fields.headline: Jeux sans frontières
fields.standfirst:
From here it looked as though the Nice summit was all grinning group photos and lofty communiques. But what really went on in the corridors and conference rooms of the Hotel Acropolis - and on the streets outside? Acclaimed novelist Christopher Hope went to find out

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: From here it looked as though the Nice summit was all grinning group photos and lofty communiques. But what really went on in the corridors and conference rooms of the Hotel Acropolis - and on the streets outside?
fields.body:
Nice was always odd. It's odder than ever since the European Conference came to town. I got in one wet night before the summit. Only the Niçoise did not seem to be sharing the air of general excitement. Appalled perhaps by the tens of thousands of protesters who arrived at the same time as the presidents and prime ministers, the Niçoise had gone to ground. The town was in the hands of police and protesters.

The result was a curiously hemmed-in feeling. In a new Europe, that was tearing down national borders, Nice had turned into a town filled with checkpoints and border guards. An unaccompanied visitor without the right papers, and the right badges, was very exposed.

I got caught in a fracas near the station where a lot of people in Venetian carnival masks were lying on the tracks to prevent trains leaving. I had to make a diversion to get out and that took me up the road to the border with Monaco, where several anarchists told me that they planned to build a big white cardboard wall with office box-files because, they said: "The rich live in a ghetto there."

I hate walls, even cardboard walls, and building them seems an odd occupation for libertarians. I passed the LiberT'ea cafe and headed for the beach. How different a city looks when it's ringed by police. The beachfront was swept free of life though lights burned at the Westminster Hotel. The huge sweep of the Promenade des Anglais, along the Bay of Angels, was bare of tourists. The Nice seafront needs tourists. Without them, the neon palm trees and the illuminated Father Christmasses climbing the lampposts, and even the monstrous carbuncle of the Negresco Hotel, seemed forlorn.

This great stretch of the city had been changed into something called the Red Zone, and cordoned off. Presidents, prime ministers and their delegations from the 15 member states of the EU were staying there with their teams of bag-carrying lackeys. In the Red Zone, too, were the dozen heads of state of the applicant countries. A curious brooding hung over the Bay of Angels.

Odd, because this is the Cte d'Azure, the French Riviera, and it is supposed to be where you have fun. But if the delegates to the European Conference, as this EU summit is known, were enjoying the Cte d'Azure, it was a chilly, damp, Swedish fun they were having. I had to get my very own cortège to my hotel. Two outriders with blue lights. It was the only way through. At the hotel, I was given a badge and papers that would allow me past the riot police and to the summit itself, which was being held at the Acropolis across town.

Papers were not enough. What I hadn't got, I realised next morning, was a delegation. The delegates in the Red Zone travelled to the Acropolis the way they used to do in the old Soviet states of eastern Europe - in convoy, along tightly policed special corridors linking their hotels to the summit meeting rooms. Since many of the countries applying for EU membership were once Soviet satellites, this way of travelling must have brought on a flush of déjà vu .

No taxis were allowed in the Red Zone. The best thing was to walk to the Acropolis. I was joined by a man from La Stampa, the Italian newspaper, who also lacked a delegation. He was not pleased, not with Nice or Europe. I said that was the way it was, in the Midi, sometimes one had to improvise. He said no, it wasn't simply bad, it was insupportable. There was no transport, no cigarettes. It began to rain. That's when we saw the bus. The city had become a nightmare, said the driver, but we were heading more or less in the right direction. "I've been in Brussels for 20 years, covering European affairs, and this is the first time I ever went to a conference by bus," said the man from La Stampa.

I lost my Italian companion in the centre of town, when I got off to walk to the Acropolis. Riot police and demonstrators were thick around the beautiful arcades of the Gallery Lafayette. The cops wore protective armour and carried batons and teargas launchers. The demonstrators wore protective armour and carried face masks - and tools. Builders tools, sappers tools. Spades and chisels.

The last time I saw tools like that was in Berlin, in November 1989; the Wall was being taken down, stone by stone, by people with little hammers and chisels. Woodpeckers, they were called, and all night long the chink of steel on stone rang through the dark ness. In Nice, hooded protesters were using their tools to tear up cobbles and throw them through the windows of boutiques. One young man broke the glass of a bank and lit a fire in the entrance. He had the hood of his duffel coat pulled down over his face, which made it difficult to get the flames going well, but he managed. The police began firing tear gas. I walked on.

The mood inside the conference halls was striking. A sense of something unstoppable. A feeling that this summit was going to work, because too many people had too much at stake to see it fail. Europe may be a stumbling, uncertain creature, but it was going ahead.

The Nice summit looked backwards to the future. It was a kind of valedictory. The Yalta accords that carved up Europe into western and eastern fiefdoms were finished. The Berlin Wall was dead and buried. The divisions between western and eastern Europe were over. The 15 countries of the EU knew this. So did the aspiring joiners. A dozen countries wanted in and they wanted it soon. Thirteen, if you counted Turkey. Even Switzerland, that notorious non-joiner, was there.

It is not surprising that the German question has been in many ways at the heart of matter in Nice. Years ago, in the old Soviet Union, someone asked me: "If we were free to come, would you have us?" It was in Germany that this question was answered when the old line between east and west was erased. Germany chose reunification and the cost was great. But the cost of keeping out the old DDR was much greater.

Nice turns a lot of assumptions on their heads. Europe needs more Europeans; put another way, Europe needs more immigrants. There is the new scramble for Europe and members are going to squabble over the takings. That is only natural. And the auguries are muddled.

In the halls of the Acropolis, one thing seemed commonly held: it is better to fudge than fight. But no amount of fudging hid the different natures of different countries. Anyone watching the various heads of states and their retinues, effortlessly reflecting what might be called their defining tribal tics, saw that no one was going to mash them up into some sort of Euro-stew. In fact, if there was a paradox inherent in European expansion it was this: the more the union grows together, the more distinct become the national traits of its members.

Some have likened the Nice summit to a long, late-night poker game. It isn't really. Poker is sedentary. Watching Jospin and Blair and Schroder pulling up to the Acropolis in their home-grown limousines, flying their national flags, followed by their national teams of negotiators, carrying briefcases hewn from the hides of patriotic and, one supposes, entirely sane French, British and German cows, what you really see are teams of athletes fit and smiling, and ready to knock hell out of the opposing teams. Summitry is a bruising contact sport played by consenting adults. It is ice hockey for politicians.

Blair looks good on ice, he stays calm at high speeds. Maybe it helps that after years of coming to Europe and complaining, he leads a goverment that wants to amount to something in Europe instead of railing against it. Because what Nice makes clear, all over again, is that Europe, however you define it, is the only game in town.

For the rest there are vexed questions of detail. How do you adjust the machinery to open the club and still allow each country to punch at more or less its fighting weight? How to assign Germany greater clout, to reflect its central position, its numbers and its muscle, without seeing it throw that weight around? How do you stop big states ganging up, or smaller countries using their veto to block any move they don't like. What about defence? What is the point of a European Union that needs to call on the US every time a fire breaks out in its own backyard?

But these are, in a sense, minor matters. Something was happening in Nice that has not happened in Europe since, perhaps, the Middle Ages. A Europe where borders increasingly disappear. Where citizens of two dozen countries move and work where they choose. Where to make room means giving ground.

For the moment Europe is 15 strong and family photos are restricted to members only. Estonian television had been excluded from even attending the ceremony because, an official explained apologetically, "you're not in yet". "I think that's discrimination," said the Estonians. It was. And it was what this Nice summit was meant to fix. Declarations of love were all very well, but when would Europe name the day?

What was not touched upon in Nice, except by the people in the streets, were the people in the streets of the countries that make Europe. Though they made their presence felt. As the heads of government arrived for the photo shoot, as Jacques Chirac smiled (a brave move for a man whose former chief of staff had just been flung into jail on charges of siphoning off public money), the unmistakable acrid touch of tear gas wafted down the air conditioning system, and I had the rare pleasure of seeing politicians biting back tears.

One might say about tear gas what Trotsky once said about foreign policy. You may not care about it, but it cares about you.

This is the great unanswered question of summits such as Nice - where are the people in all this? Unconsulted, unpersuaded, and uncertain. Perhaps that was the good service the cagouled ones with their trenching tools did us. They reminded everyone that Europe was not made of delegations and motorcades. The politicians and the European commissioners were in their redoubt behind massed ranks of riot police, and the only people on the streets were tearing them up.

The people on the streets may not like the Europe we have but even they, to judge from their slogans and banners, want more rather than less of it. Their banners were eloquent and very European: "Free Catalonia", "Basques Forever", "Free Occitania" . . . Occitania? That's a new one. I live there and we don't, as yet, have a liberation army.

What Nice exposes is that the two-tier Europe some people talk about is here already though not in predictable form. One is governed by politicians and guarded by the police, and the other contains the people who are nowhere to be seen and whose views on these enormous events are hard to elicit.

For an instant, as I was leaving, the two Europes seemed to collide on the giant television screens in the press centre. The screens showed footage of the leaders' deliberations, beamed live from the Acropolis. On the screen, a spokesman for one of the 27 countries present was talking without sound about matters European, maybe it was the charter of human rights, the veto, the banana wars with the US, the rapid reaction force, or qualified majority voting . It did not matter, the sound was off. His suit was blue, his manner grave.

Below him, a second monitor that had been showing, for reasons unknown, old episodes of Dallas, suddenly changed the picture and we got for several glorious minutes a ripe piece of erotica. Two well-fleshed people on a rumpled bed made vigorous love; their bed trembled, the sheets fluttered, while all the time above their embrace, the blue-suited spokesman opened and closed his lips. A knot of journalists gathered around the monitor. This was more like it. Then a cameraman, entering in the spirit of things, did what came naturally, he lifted his camera and began filming the film.

Without them, the neon palm trees and the illuminated Father Christmasses climbing the lampposts, and even the monstrous carbuncle of the Negresco Hotel, seemed forlorn. This great stretch of the city had been changed into something called the Red Zone, and cordoned off. Presidents, prime ministers and their delegations from the 15 member states of the EU were staying there with their teams of bag-carrying lackeys. In the Red Zone, too, were the dozen heads of state of the applicant countries. A curious brooding hung over the Bay of Angels. Odd, because this is the Cte d'Azure, the French Riviera, and it is supposed to be where you have fun. But if the delegates to the European Conference, as this EU summit is known, were enjoying the Cte d'Azure, it was a chilly, damp, Swedish fun they were having. I had to get my very own cortège to my hotel. Two outriders with blue lights. It was the only way through. At the hotel, I was given a badge and papers that would allow me past the riot police and to the summit itself, which was being held at the Acropolis across town. Papers were not enough. What I hadn't got, I realised next morning, was a delegation. The delegates in the Red Zone travelled to the Acropolis the way they used to do in the old Soviet states of eastern Europe - in convoy, along tightly policed special corridors linking their hotels to the summit meeting rooms. Since many of the countries applying for EU membership were once Soviet satellites, this way of travelling must have brought on a flush of déjà vu . No taxis were allowed in the Red Zone. The best thing was to walk to the Acropolis. I was joined by a man from La Stampa, the Italian newspaper, who also lacked a delegation. He was not pleased, not with Nice or Europe. I said that was the way it was, in the Midi, sometimes one had to improvise. He said no, it wasn't simply bad, it was insupportable. There was no transport, no cigarettes. It began to rain. That's when we saw the bus. The city had become a nightmare, said the driver, but we were heading more or less in the right direction. "I've been in Brussels for 20 years, covering European affairs, and this is the first time I ever went to a conference by bus," said the man from La Stampa. I lost my Italian companion in the centre of town, when I got off to walk to the Acropolis. Riot police and demonstrators were thick around the beautiful arcades of the Gallery Lafayette. The cops wore protective armour and carried batons and teargas launchers. The demonstrators wore protective armour and carried face masks - and tools. Builders tools, sappers tools. Spades and chisels. The last time I saw tools like that was in Berlin, in November 1989; the Wall was being taken down, stone by stone, by people with little hammers and chisels. Woodpeckers, they were called, and all night long the chink of steel on stone rang through the dark ness. In Nice, hooded protesters were using their tools to tear up cobbles and throw them through the windows of boutiques. One young man broke the glass of a bank and lit a fire in the entrance. He had the hood of his duffel coat pulled down over his face, which made it difficult to get the flames going well, but he managed. The police began firing tear gas. I walked on. The mood inside the conference halls was striking. A sense of something unstoppable. A feeling that this summit was going to work, because too many people had too much at stake to see it fail. Europe may be a stumbling, uncertain creature, but it was going ahead. The Nice summit looked backwards to the future. It was a kind of valedictory. The Yalta accords that carved up Europe into western and eastern fiefdoms were finished. The Berlin Wall was dead and buried. The divisions between western and eastern Europe were over. The 15 countries of the EU knew this. So did the aspiring joiners. A dozen countries wanted in and they wanted it soon. Thirteen, if you counted Turkey. Even Switzerland, that notorious non-joiner, was there. It is not surprising that the German question has been in many ways at the heart of matter in Nice. Years ago, in the old Soviet Union, someone asked me: "If we were free to come, would you have us?" It was in Germany that this question was answered when the old line between east and west was erased. Germany chose reunification and the cost was great. But the cost of keeping out the old DDR was much greater. Nice turns a lot of assumptions on their heads. Europe needs more Europeans; put another way, Europe needs more immigrants. There is the new scramble for Europe and members are going to squabble over the takings. That is only natural. And the auguries are muddled. In the halls of the Acropolis, one thing seemed commonly held: it is better to fudge than fight. But no amount of fudging hid the different natures of different countries. Anyone watching the various heads of states and their retinues, effortlessly reflecting what might be called their defining tribal tics, saw that no one was going to mash them up into some sort of Euro-stew. In fact, if there was a paradox inherent in European expansion it was this: the more the union grows together, the more distinct become the national traits of its members. Some have likened the Nice summit to a long, late-night poker game. It isn't really. Poker is sedentary. Watching Jospin and Blair and Schroder pulling up to the Acropolis in their home-grown limousines, flying their national flags, followed by their national teams of negotiators, carrying briefcases hewn from the hides of patriotic and, one supposes, entirely sane French, British and German cows, what you really see are teams of athletes fit and smiling, and ready to knock hell out of the opposing teams. Summitry is a bruising contact sport played by consenting adults. It is ice hockey for politicians. Blair looks good on ice, he stays calm at high speeds. Maybe it helps that after years of coming to Europe and complaining, he leads a goverment that wants to amount to something in Europe instead of railing against it. Because what Nice makes clear, all over again, is that Europe, however you define it, is the only game in town. For the rest there are vexed questions of detail. How do you adjust the machinery to open the club and still allow each country to punch at more or less its fighting weight? How to assign Germany greater clout, to reflect its central position, its numbers and its muscle, without seeing it throw that weight around? How do you stop big states ganging up, or smaller countries using their veto to block any move they don't like. What about defence? What is the point of a European Union that needs to call on the US every time a fire breaks out in its own backyard? But these are, in a sense, minor matters. Something was happening in Nice that has not happened in Europe since, perhaps, the Middle Ages. A Europe where borders increasingly disappear. Where citizens of two dozen countries move and work where they choose. Where to make room means giving ground. For the moment Europe is 15 strong and family photos are restricted to members only. Estonian television had been excluded from even attending the ceremony because, an official explained apologetically, "you're not in yet". "I think that's discrimination," said the Estonians. It was. And it was what this Nice summit was meant to fix. Declarations of love were all very well, but when would Europe name the day? What was not touched upon in Nice, except by the people in the streets, were the people in the streets of the countries that make Europe. Though they made their presence felt. As the heads of government arrived for the photo shoot, as Jacques Chirac smiled (a brave move for a man whose former chief of staff had just been flung into jail on charges of siphoning off public money), the unmistakable acrid touch of tear gas wafted down the air conditioning system, and I had the rare pleasure of seeing politicians biting back tears. One might say about tear gas what Trotsky once said about foreign policy. You may not care about it, but it cares about you. This is the great unanswered question of summits such as Nice - where are the people in all this? Unconsulted, unpersuaded, and uncertain. Perhaps that was the good service the cagouled ones with their trenching tools did us. They reminded everyone that Europe was not made of delegations and motorcades. The politicians and the European commissioners were in their redoubt behind massed ranks of riot police, and the only people on the streets were tearing them up. The people on the streets may not like the Europe we have but even they, to judge from their slogans and banners, want more rather than less of it. Their banners were eloquent and very European: "Free Catalonia", "Basques Forever", "Free Occitania" . . . Occitania? That's a new one. I live there and we don't, as yet, have a liberation army. What Nice exposes is that the two-tier Europe some people talk about is here already though not in predictable form. One is governed by politicians and guarded by the police, and the other contains the people who are nowhere to be seen and whose views on these enormous events are hard to elicit. For an instant, as I was leaving, the two Europes seemed to collide on the giant television screens in the press centre. The screens showed footage of the leaders' deliberations, beamed live from the Acropolis. On the screen, a spokesman for one of the 27 countries present was talking without sound about matters European, maybe it was the charter of human rights, the veto, the banana wars with the US, the rapid reaction force, or qualified majority voting . It did not matter, the sound was off. His suit was blue, his manner grave. Below him, a second monitor that had been showing, for reasons unknown, old episodes of Dallas, suddenly changed the picture and we got for several glorious minutes a ripe piece of erotica. Two well-fleshed people on a rumpled bed made vigorous love; their bed trembled, the sheets fluttered, while all the time above their embrace, the blue-suited spokesman opened and closed his lips. A knot of journalists gathered around the monitor. This was more like it. Then a cameraman, entering in the spirit of things, did what came naturally, he lifted his camera and began filming the film. webTitle: Review:  Jean-Jacques Burnel

fields.headline: Pop review
fields.standfirst: Jean-Jacques Burnel Manchester University *****
fields.trailText: Jean-Jacques Burnel is one of rock's most notorious characters. In the Stranglers' authorised biography, No Mercy, 20 pages tackle the subject of "Burnel, violence".
fields.body:
Jean-Jacques Burnel is one of rock's most notorious characters. In the Stranglers' authorised biography, No Mercy, 20 pages tackle the subject of "Burnel, violence".

However, apart from outrages such as strapping a trouserless Antoine de Caunes upside down to the top of the Eiffel Tower, the London-born Frenchman has always seemed intelligent, arguing for a united Europe on his 1978 album Euroman Cometh and becoming an internationally renowned tutor of, um, karate. A rare evening with him - entitled Songs & Stories - was always likely to be entertaining.

The Strangler greeted a seated audience with a bottle of wine and an acoustic guitar, with not even a bass on hand to hit anyone with. Only when an anecdote about Manchester brought a few mock-aggressive grumblings did any hint of his notoriety appear, when he grinned: "Ah! Fighting talk!" In fact, JJ's main battle lies with his own myth. Hugely underrated as a musician, he delivered acoustic Stranglers songs, solo offerings and work in progress, including a song inspired by the Hatfield disaster, and some genuinely beautiful playing reminiscent of Peter Green. It was a real treat to hear Stranglers tunes played so minimally and passionately.

In between, Burnel explained how his violent past stemmed from a difficulty in keeping his temper as a youth confronted with racism. His eloquence was only matched by his hilarity, with reams of anecdotes about write-off Porsches and punch-ups with the Sex Pistols. What could so easily have been a punk legend trawling the hits was an enriching two hours with a fascinating man.

webTitle: Pass notes: Joseph

fields.headline: No: 1779 Joseph
fields.trailText: What, as in Joseph and Mary, of no-room-at-the-inn fame? That's the one.
fields.body:
What, as in Joseph and Mary, of no-room-at-the-inn fame? That's the one.

Oh goody! A Christmas theme. I love Christmas. Sleigh bells ringing, children singing . . . Girls getting knocked up.

I beg your pardon. That sort of language is not in keeping with the spirit of Christmas. I'd watch your mouth if I were you, laddy. Get with it gramps. This is Cool Christmas (much-awaited sequel to Cool Britannia). This year, Christmas is gonna be groovy, hip and totally down with the kids.

Well, as long as they're observing their curfews I can't see any harm. But go on, what's this all about?. Well, the BBC has an "alternative" nativity play, entitled It's a Girl!, going out on Christmas Day and Joseph, played by John Thomson (pictured above), is portrayed as a bit of a lad. We'll see him speaking more in the style of Loaded magazine, than what you might expect of the Christmas story. He has a right old moan about being blamed for Mary's pregnancy. We'll see him complaining, "My mates were saying I should just dump her."

And is it a girl? In the play, Joseph thinks it's going to be, based on what his sister Judith says. "She can tell just by the shape of the bump," says Joseph.

Presumably the tradionalists are up in arms? Of course. More evidence of BBC dumbing down they say. The Lib Dem peer, Lord Alton, says, "It is not intelligent. It is not entertaining. Why do it? It will only upset people." Dr Irene Riding, a former headmistress and a member of the Church of England's general synod, adds, "This is tosh, a missed opportunity."

And what does anyone say in the play's defence? Robert Childs, the author, said: "The language is colloquial, but he was a chippie."

Lucky he's got that technicolored dreamcoat he can sell to pay for the baby's upkeep. You ignoramus. That's a completely different Joseph. Where did you get your religious education?

From watching telly, mostly. Of course.

Not to be confused with: Men Behaving Badly Christmas special.

webTitle: Election fall-out fear on N-waste

fields.headline: Election fall-out fear on N-waste
fields.standfirst: Dispute between ministries over massive plutonium stocks delays publication of consultation paper amid fears of lost votes
fields.trailText: Dispute between ministries over massive plutonium stocks delays publication of consultation paper amid fears of lost votes
fields.body:
An acrimonious dispute between ministers over whether Britain's massive stock of plutonium should be declared a dangerous nuclear waste has led to the repeated postponement of consultation on what to do about the UK's unsolved waste problem.

So alarmed are Tony Blair's advisers about the row, and votes it could cost, that the issue is to be postponed until after the next election.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has repeatedly tried to fix a date to unveil the green paper on nuclear waste policy, believing that to duck the issue is an abdication of responsibility. The proposed launch last Friday was postponed on the orders of Downing Street.

The Department of Trade and Industry is still desperate to privatise parts of troubled British Nuclear Fuels, and -surprisingly - is considering building a new generation of nuclear stations to replace the ageing Magnox ones. The department fears its plans will be undermined by a public debate on the unsolved and expensive question of what to do with the increasing mountain of waste.

Hugh Collum, chairman of BNFL, with the backing of DTI civil servants, outlined his ambitious plans for new nuclear stations at the fifth nuclear congress. He said the company had the sites at existing Magnox stations with grid connections and in communities that "understand and are familiar with the concept of nuclear power".

Claiming that Britain could never keep up its targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions without nuclear power, he said that within the next five years critical decisions had to be taken. "Within that time we must make some very fundamental decisions if we want to keep the lights on."

The dispute over nuclear waste is a hangover from the last hours of the Conservative government in 1997 when John Gummer, the environment secretary, an hour before the general election was called, pulled the plug on the plan to bury the nation's waste below Sellafield in Cumbria by refusing planning permission for a rock laboratory under the complex. Eventually the rock laboratory would have been enlarged to take the nation's waste.

After the election, the House of Lords decided to look at the issue and the government said it would act on its findings and produce a consultation paper on what to do with 50 years of waste being stored in expensive concrete bunkers.

The paper should have been published last summer, after the exhaustive House of Lords science and technology inquiry was published in March. But it was this document that contained the advice that ministers should abandon the outdated policy of regarding plutonium as a valuable resource and should reclassify it as a dangerous waste - once a strategic reserve for nuclear weapons was placed on one side.

This was repeated by the Commons trade and industry select committee in May this year but British Nuclear Fuels, which guards the plutonium at its Sellafield site, said it was a valuable source of energy. The DTI agreed and officials are prepared to consider a plan to build two new nuclear reactors at Sellafield to burn up to 120 tonnes of plutonium as a fuel. Environmental groups would be appalled at the idea.

At the heart of the problem is the future of Sellafield. Its recent appalling safety record that led to the postponement of privatisation, and the continuing poor performance of its two nuclear fuel reprocessing plants, mean it only has a limited future.

The company has still to get orders for the £300m mothballed mixed oxide plutonium fuel plant after the falsified documents scandal which led the Japanese to demand the return of a suspect batch of fuel and a refusal to place more orders.

The government's radioactive waste management committee (RWMAC) in advice to the government last week forecast that the £1.8bn Thorp reprocessing plant only opened in 1994 would close "by 2010 through lack of orders".

The older Magnox plant, opened 50 years ago to produce plutonium for nuclear weapons and limping along after a series of breakdowns, has to close in 2012 to meet Britain's pledges to cut radioactive discharges into the sea. By then Britain would have stockpiled 120 tonnes of plutonium, according to RWMAC - enough to blow the world up several times, and a "a serious security risk".
