webTitle: Pakistan frees Sharif to exile in Saudi Arabia

fields.headline: Pakistan frees Sharif to exile in Saudi Arabia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: The deposed Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif began a new life in exile in Saudi Arabia last night after being released from prison by the military regime which toppled him from power.
fields.body:
The deposed Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif began a new life in exile in Saudi Arabia last night after being released from prison by the military regime which toppled him from power.

He flew from Pakistan early yesterday after General Pervez Musharraf's government unexpectedly announced that his life sentence had been commuted. He had been in jail since the military coup 14 months ago, convicted of kidnapping, hijacking and corruption.

He landed in Jeddah yesterday afternoon in a private jet belonging to the Saudi royal family. He was accompanied by 18 members of his family, including his wife Kulsoom, his three children and his elderly parents.

The party was immediately whisked off on a pilgrimage to Mecca. Mr Sharif was due to return to the Saudi capital, Riyadh, for a medical check-up.

"Nawaz Sharif and family have been exiled to Saudi Arabia. The decision has been taken in the best interest of the country and the people of Pakistan," the Pakistan government said in a statement.

Earlier it had said that Mr Sharif had requested permission to travel abroad for medical treatment. On Saturday he was granted a Saudi visa, causing rumours that his release was imminent.

As a condition of his exile, Mr Sharif has agreed not to take part in politics in Pakistan for 21 years. He has also forfeited property worth $8.3m (£5.7m) and agreed to pay a fine of $500,000. His brothers Abbas and Shahbaz, who were serving jail sentences for corruption, were also freed and allowed to leave.

Mr Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League revealed yesterday that an unnamed member of the Saudi royal family had negotiated his release.

"This is purely a humanitarian gesture by the kingdom and has nothing to do with politics. Mr Sharif has pledged not to undertake any political activity while in Saudi Arabia," a Saudi official said last night.

The deal is an ignominious end to Mr Sharif's political career: he is the first former prime minister of Pakistan to be exiled. His predecessor Benazir Bhutto is living in self-imposed exile in London.

As the family left Islamabad yesterday, his wife said: "We are not running away in the darkness of night. We are being expelled from this country."

She said her husband was suffering from a heart con dition and high blood pressure.

She added: "Pakistan will never be far from our hearts.We pray that our countrymen will be prosperous and whenever Nawaz Sharif's health is better, we will come back."

Mr Sharif was taken to the airport from the fort near Islamabad where he was serving his sentence. His deal with the government has dismayed many of his political allies, who only a week ago joined other parties in an alliance with the sole goal of ending military rule in Pakistan and restoring democracy. "Sharif will find it difficult to sell this to his supporters," a party source said.

But it also raises questions for the increasingly unpopular military rulers. Gen Musharraf had launched a high-profile drive to punish those guilty of corruption.

"What does this say about our judicial system, that Nawaz Sharif, who was sentenced and in judicial custody, can be allowed to leave?" Farhatullah Babar, spokesman for Ms Bhutto's Pakistan People's party, said.

Pakistani intelligence sources said Mr Sharif, whose two terms in office were marked by corruption, had handed over at least two factories to the government.

His family assets are estimated to be worth several hundred million dollars.

By the time of the coup Mr Sharif had become Pakistan's most powerful prime minister since independence in 1947, using his huge parliamentary majority to amend the constitution and increase his powers.

webTitle: Australia hijacked by one-armed bandits

fields.headline: Australia hijacked by one-armed bandits
fields.standfirst: Suburban addicts of big-dollar fruit machines are proving too much even for authorities fattened by gambling taxes
fields.trailText: Suburban addicts of big-dollar fruit machines are proving too much even for authorities fattened by gambling taxes.
fields.body:
Across the hall of the Canterbury Leagues Club the lights of hundreds of poker machines wink. Solitary men and women in suburban Sydney sip beer and quietly slip high denomination dollar notes into the themed "pokies", fruit machines with names such as Dolphin Treasure and Cash Chameleon which give the chance to win "fast bucks", "big bucks" or "super bucks".

Called by some "the lucky country", Australia has the largest number of addicted gamblers in the world, almost 2% of its people have a problem. Most plough money into pokies, 21% of which are found in Australia - most of them in New South Wales.

The state government has begun a new purge with plans to cut demand by imposing a surcharge.

It's latest "harm minimisation" package, due to come into force next year, also aims to reduce punters' losses by stopping the machines accepting A$50 (about £19) and A$100 notes and slowing the speed with they can take the gamblers' money.

"We can't stand there with bayonets and move people away from poker machines, but we can warn them about the low odds that they will win," the New South Wales premier, Bob Carr, said.

This is a delicate balancing act for Mr Carr, however. Gambling has been blessed by Australian states since the invention of government-run lotteries at the beginning of the 20th century, helping to fund public works such as the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Today Mr Carr's government looks to gambling for 10.4% of its tax revenue.

Last week the the federal legislature passed an act temporarily banning new gambling websites, although the internet accounts for only 0.6% of Australia's A$12.6bn (£4.6bn) gambling habit. But the federal government remains unwilling to encourage states such as New South Wales to combat the rise of the pokies.

"State governments are the biggest gambling addicts in the country," said Tim Costello, a leading campaigner against gambling, who attributes the proliferation of pokies to the convergence of the interests of the cash-strapped state governments and "the smooth-talking gambling industry".

Several years ago, as a local mayor in Melbourne, Mr Costello found himself approving poker machine licences to increase council funds.

"Then I started to have people ring me up with horrific stories - kids going hungry, a husband or wife losing the family home because of gambling - and I suddenly realised we had an unprecedented experiment to expose Australians to a ruthlessly efficient transfer of money from the poor to the rich."

Meanwhile the closure of many rural banks encouraged the the authorities last month to let people cash cheques of up to A$400 at clubs, a "variation on Dracula in charge of a blood bank", says Mr Costello.

"Most Australians would say gambling is fundamental to the Australian character because of our convict history. That's a load of nonsense. Australians don't gamble any more than the Chinese or Americans, but what we have in Australia is by far and away the greatest access to legalised gambling."

Most of the fruit machines are found in New South Wales's 1,500 community clubs. Any attempt to ban them would be disastrous for the club movement, the chief executive of Clubs NSW, Mark Fitzgibbon, said .

In the 50s clubs linked to local sports teams were encouraged to provide a family atmosphere to fight problem drinking. The Canterbury Leagues Club, like many others, evolved into a gambling palace. Pokies are now provided by 98% of the clubs,producing, on average, 58% of their revenue.

"The clubs are non-profit organisations. The money they generate is returned to the community," Norman Tesker of Canterbury Leagues Club said. Without pokies the communities would suffer too.

But Professor Jan McMillen of the Australian Institute for Gambling Research said that in the race to install pokies the clubs had long since lost sight of their community functions. Australia's gambling rules were effective, the said, but they had faltered in terms of the community.

"Gambling is now being run for private benefit rather than community benefit. Gambling was once organised by the local community in the local club. Now it's been corporatised and privatised."

Ten years ago Australians gambled away 1.8% of their disposable income, now it is 3.6%. Each year A$12.6bn (£4.7bn) is gambled

Punters can gamble A$100 (£37) to try to win A$10,000

"Pokies" were legalised in all states except Western Australia in 1991. In September 1999 the country had 184,526 machines

New South Wales has more than 100,500 pokies. The state government has just cut the number of machine inspectors from 90 to 57

The minimum payout is 85% - for every A$100 they spend, gamblers stand to lose A$15

webTitle: Comment: Two kinds of human rights

fields.headline: Two kinds of human rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: An unusual petition was received in 1933 by the League of Nations. It was a protest against decrees introduced by the newly elected German government to limit the freedoms of its Jewish citizens.
fields.body:
An unusual petition was received in 1933 by the League of Nations. It was a protest against decrees introduced by the newly elected German government to limit the freedoms of its Jewish citizens.

The league's German representative, a Mr Von Keller, responded. His government's philosophy, he said, was based on the concept of Volkstum: national identity based on race. Three days after the session ended, Germany permanently withdrew from the League of Nations. The aspirations of this august body ended in abject failure. It did nothing to protect millions of innocents from the inferno that was to follow.

When, in 1947, the delegates to the UN who were charged with drafting the Universal Declaration of Human Rights first met - yesterday was their 52nd anniversary - previous failures were uppermost in their minds.

In the poetic words of their preamble, such events "outraged the conscience of mankind". The holocaust of Jews, Gypsies and other minorities led to questions about the very nature of humanity, driving postwar thinkers and politicians back towards theories about "inalienable rights" that famously took the world by storm in the 18th century.

This year the people of the UK have their own Human Rights Act, based on the values in the universal declaration. But what do most of us understand by human rights? Something many foreigners lack? A set of basic legal standards to deter dictators from committing atrocities or to punish those who do? A catalogue of western-orientated liberal freedoms intended to protect individuals from oppressive governments? A scam for lawyers?

While the phrase "never again" hovered invisibly over the pens of the drafters of the universal declaration, their approach represented a fundamental shift from the path taken by the radicals of the Enlightenment.

The "first-wave" French and American bills of rights sought to set citizens free from the grip of state and church. Postwar or "second-wave" rights charters strove to create a better world for everyone. If the drafters of the universal declaration learnt a significant lesson from the descent into barbarism that galvanised their work it was this: creating mechanisms to prevent states from abusing the rights of citizens is not enough to guarantee their liberty.

Individuals require protection from tyranny, but they can also contribute to it and while states need to be fettered from oppressing their citizens, they must also take the lead in preventing rights violations by private companies and individuals.

In this spirit, the declaration was drafted as "a common standard of achievement for all peoples and all nations" as well as governments. For a rights culture to flourish we all need to be involved.

Reflecting the various beliefs of the drafters - including all the major religions, Confucianism, socialism, social democracy, and liberalism - values like dignity, equality, community and responsibility shape the declaration alongside the old familiars of liberty and justice.

The freedom sought is not the exercise of free will by isolated individuals but the practical opportunity for everyone to live the life they choose unhampered by discrimination or oppression. For this vision to materialise, the declaration does not just proclaim our rights but tells us that we all have "duties to the community" (as distinct from state) "in which alone the free and full development of personality is possible".

This balancing of collectivism and individualism is reflected in all the 50-plus international and regional human-rights treaties which developed out of the universal declaration, including the European convention on human rights now incorporated into our law.

It explains why the law lords could recently reject a claim that our drink-driving laws breach the right to a fair trial in the new Human Rights Act. Lord Bingham captured the essence of "second-wave" rights thinking when he said "the need for a fair balance between the general interest of the community and the personal rights of the individual" was "inherent in the whole of the convention".

It is because "second-wave" rights were aimed as much at establishing a basic set of ethical values for all as at setting down legal standards for states, that they are as relevant to the concerns of modern UK as they are to the killing fields of Kosovo or Rwanda. If their success is measured in how many massacres they have prevented they have not done well. But if they are to be judged by the guidance they can provide to a diverse and troubled world, they have plenty to say.

 Francesca Klug is author of Values for a Godless Age published by Penguin

webTitle: Estrada cancels death penalties

fields.headline: Estrada cancels death penalties
fields.trailText: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines tried to bolster his popularity yesterday by announcing that he planned to release all political prisoners and commute all death sentences to life imprisonment.
fields.body:
President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines tried to bolster his popularity yesterday by announcing that he planned to release all political prisoners and commute all death sentences to life imprisonment.

The announcement by the former actor, who is on trial for corruption and "amassing unexplained wealth", surprised even his closest aides.

It was welcomed by human rights groups and the Roman Catholic church but treated warily by opposition politicians and analysts, who see it as a ploy by Mr Estrada to weaken their campaign against him.

If carried out, the proposal will result in the release of more than 200 prisoners, mostly Communist guerrillas, and the reprieve of the approximately 1,200 people sentenced to death since the Philippines reintroduced the death penalty in 1994.

Speaking at a mass in the central city of Bacolod, Mr Estrada said he wanted the releases completed by Christmas. He added: "I will order tomorrow all [death sentences] will be commuted to life imprisonment on the occasion of the jubilee year," the 2,000th anniversary of Jesus' birth.

In March Mr Estrada approved a request by Catholic bishops for a moratorium on executions this year. He had previously been a strong supporter of the death penalty.

webTitle: DTI accuses companies of underinvesting

fields.headline: DTI accuses companies of underinvesting
fields.standfirst: Pharmaceutical, aerospace and defence sectors stand out as being prepared to spend on research
fields.trailText: British companies are at risk of losing out because they are not investing as much in their businesses as their international rivals, the government warned today.
fields.body:
British companies are at risk of losing out because they are not investing as much in their businesses as their international rivals, the government warned today.

A new Department of Trade and Industry survey shows that the bulk of Britain's leading manufacturing companies are outlaying proportionately less in capital expenditure than are their foreign competitors.

It concludes that Britain's manufacturing sector in general invests two thirds less, in terms of pounds per employee, than its international counterparts, reducing their ability to maintain sales. It highlights the automotive, information technology and chemical sectors as being particularly weak.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said: "Too many companies fail to recognise that research and development, capital investment and innovation are key drivers for business growth and competitiveness. Those that fail to invest will be left behind."

He said that Britain's pharmaceutical, aerospace and defence sectors showed what could be achieved. They exceed the international benchmarks for spending on capital investment (capex) and R&D and were "world leaders".

Lord Sainsbury, the science and innovation minister, said: "Our people cannot compete using yesterday's tools."

The DTI's capital expenditure scoreboard shows that greatest disparity is in the physics-based sectors - IT, electronics, hardware and engineering. Internationally these sectors accounted for 25% of all capex but only 12% in the UK.

British subsidiaries of foreign companies tend to invest more in capex terms than the average UK company.

The DTI says there was a strong link R&D and capex, with companies that invest heavily in ideas also investing heavily in production.

Norman Price, one of the industrialists seconded to the DTI's future and innovation unit, which carried out the survey, said there was a danger that companies invested in their established businesses at the expense of new activities.

Increased capital investment in mature business might bring productivity improvements, but such investment was subject to the law of diminishing returns.

He said the City should pay more attention to "transition companies" which were moving out of low growth, low risk areas into new high growth areas with higher risk.

He said such companies should be valued for what they had in the pipeline, as pharmaceutical companies are. He pointed to the success of companies such as mobile phone operator Vodafone which had grown from a medium-sized business into an international company by concentrating investment on a particular sector.

webTitle: Top-flight brand Lufthansa sticks up for British

fields.headline: Top-flight brand Lufthansa sticks up for British
fields.trailText: Lufthansa, the German national airline last night paid a fulsome tribute to the excellence of the term "British" and British Midland in particular which it said was synonymous with "quality, safety and style".
fields.body:
Lufthansa, the German national airline last night paid a fulsome tribute to the excellence of the term "British" and British Midland in particular which it said was synonymous with "quality, safety and style".

Lufthansa wishes to persuade its partner, British Midland, and its chairman, Sir Michael Bishop, not to drop "British" from the company name when it relaunches next year in time for the introduction of transatlantic flights from Manchester.

Lufthansa, which has a 20% stake in British Midland, said that it had been lobbying BM after hearing disturbing reports that it was about to call itself something unimaginative like "Bluebird".

Ulrich Wachter, Lufthansa's regional vice-president, speaking after Lufthansa's third-quarter results, said: "We think it would be unfortunate to say the least if 'British' was lost. In our view British is best. It would be a bad move if British Midland dropped it."

Mr Wachter said that the name "British" was admired for its reliability and strength. "It gives the impression of innovation and energy," he said.

"It is something which is very much respected throughout the world. We urge BM to keep it."

Another senior Lufthansa official, Thierry Antinori, said that the name was also respected in other businesses. "You may call British Telecom BT over here and British Airways BA, but abroad, the title is always spelt out and gives the companies increased respect."

Mr Antinori said that BA was now providing stronger competition under Rod Eddington, its new chief executive. He welcomed BA's decision to phase out ethnic colours from its tail fins, and to sell its low cost carrier, Go, and the French airline, Air Libérté.

British Midland denied that it had ever considered dropping the name "British" from its title.

webTitle: Teenage shoppers

fields.headline: Teenage shoppers acting just like chips off the old block
fields.trailText: Christmas appears to have come early for some lucky e-tailers this year. Our network of partners are all reporting strong sales, a fact which has been obscured by the increasing list of dot.com failures.
fields.body:
Christmas appears to have come early for some lucky e-tailers this year. Our network of partners are all reporting strong sales, a fact which has been obscured by the increasing list of dot.com failures.

Although it is true that many pure-play online retailers have been forced to close or leap into the arms of more substantial offline players, total online sales have grown substantially in the past 12 months.

The number of consumers buying online has more than doubled since last Christmas, according to Experian. Not only that, those that are buying, seem to be doing so more often.

Work by consultants at Continental Research shows that a regular internet shopper now spends £430 online in a year.

It would appear to be good news for those retailers that are still in play. The anecdotal feedback is certainly pretty bullish. One of our partners, having launched its website earlier this year, has been pleasantly surprised at the size of its early pre-Christmas rush.

It is a niche hobby retailer with a significant proportion of sales from the site to customers abroad. Longer delivery times to these customers, combined with consumers' tendency to be cautious in their assessment of online retailers' ability to deliver before Christmas, means that the company's sales uplift has started at least a month earlier than the equivalent in high street stores.

At rools we have been under a certain amount of pressure from retailers to speed up our own launch so that we can grab a slice of this e-Christmas action. However, we do not see the need to rush our service to market, a view that is backed by our investors.

A realistic assessment suggests that it is going to take some time for the bulk of inexperienced teenage online shoppers to get used to buying on the internet. For adult consumers, initial online shopping experiences typically involve a small number of tentative, testing, low-value purchases (often books).

It can take up to a year for a customer to develop sufficient confidence in the process to move from toe-dipping to being a regular - sometimes even enthusiastic - online shopper.

If the adult customer lifecycle experience is replicated among teenagers - which, broadly speaking, our research suggests that it will be - we believe that we would have needed to launch at least four months before Christmas to catch the uplift.

Meanwhile, having little time, and even less enthusiasm for fighting the crowds in high street, it is the online stores that are reaping the benefits of our own Christmas shopping spending.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of rools, a secure payment service that enables teenagers to buy online

Meanwhile, having little time, and even less enthusiasm for fighting the crowds in high street, it is the online stores that are reaping the benefits of our own Christmas shopping spending.  Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of rools, a secure payment service that enables teenagers to buy online

webTitle: Lloyds TSB board to talk about tactics on Abbey

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB board to talk about tactics on Abbey
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB executives will hold an emergency session tonight to decide whether to make another friendly takeover approach to Abbey National or launch a £20bn hostile bid.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB executives will hold an emergency session tonight to decide whether to make another friendly takeover approach to Abbey National or launch a £20bn hostile bid.

The acquisition-hungry bank is said by senior City sources to hold the key to the future of Abbey National, which has been forced to put on ice any attempt to conclude merger talks with Bank of Scotland.

After being rebuffed by Abbey National last week, Lloyds TSB's chief executive, Peter Ellwood, is expected to try to woo his target one more time before resorting to a hostile bid. Abbey, furious at the intervention by Lloyds TSB, is expected to appeal to the takeover panel today to force Lloyds TSB to show its hand quickly and publicly.

Until Lloyds TSB does make its next move apparent it has become increasingly clear that Abbey stands little chance of finishing its merger talks with BoS, which were leaked more than a month ago. While an agreement is thought to be close, attempts to conclude the talks have been stalled. "BoS is sitting tight," a Bank of Scotland spokesman said last night.

Lloyds TSB refused to confirm whether or not a board meeting would take place. Abbey National declined to comment.

The City believes that Bank of Scotland does not want to be put in a situation where it announces an agreed deal with Abbey only to find its partner on the receiving end of a hostile bid.

BoS, which a year ago was locked in a vicious head-to-head competition with local rival Royal Bank of Scotland for NatWest, is expected to resume talks with another possible suitor, National Australia Bank, if Abbey is stolen from its clutches. City sources believe Barclays may also be waiting in the wings.

The merger with BoS is thought to value each Abbey share at about £12.50. Lloyds initial offer was said to be around £12. The fresh bid by Lloyds could edge closer to £13, and crucially involve a cash component for shareholders.

A deal between Lloyds and Abbey National would lead to at least 7,000 job cuts and branch closures after two years. It is understood that in the terms being proposed by Lloyds TSB it has pledged to keep the Abbey National brand and branches alive until 2003.

City sources, however, warn that it is not all plain sailing for Lloyds TSB. It is said to face two difficulties. The first is to persuade shareholders that a takeover of Abbey is not a distraction from its pledge to expand in Europe. The second is the prospect of a full-scale competition inquiry into the acquisition. Some sources regard Abbey National as a competitor to Lloyds in both the current account and small business banking market, where Lloyds has a large share of business and Abbey a much smaller operation.

Last year when another three-way tussle was taking place over control of NatWest, the competition authorities did not intervene. This is thought to be giving some comfort to the advisers to Lloyds TSB. A merged Abbey Lloyds would have a market share of current accounts in the region of 30%, lower than the combined share of business accounts which the combined Royal Bank of Scotland and NatWest is now able to boast.

Under its present chairman, Sir Brian Pitman, who is due to retire next year, Lloyds has developed a reputation of expanding rapidly through acquisition, including Cheltenham & Gloucester, TSB and Scottish Widows. While Lloyds is expected to argue that it will be able to slash as much as £500m from Abbey National's £1.7bn cost base, a combined Abbey and BoS could be expected to argue that its deal would be about a rapid growth in revenue rather than about cutting costs.

webTitle: Obituaries: Norman Swallow

fields.headline: Norman Swallow
fields.standfirst: Pioneering television film-maker of quality documentaries who anticipated the videotape revolution
fields.trailText: Pioneering television film-maker of quality documentaries who anticipated the videotape revolution
fields.body:
Norman Swallow, who has died aged 79, was the pioneer television producer and documentary film-maker who came within an ace of revolutionising the latter role by abolishing the word "film" from it. Wouldn't it make sense, he argued, to record real life straight on to videotape, using television's more light-sensitive electronic cameras?

In 1963, the BBC had just tried out the principle in drama, with a production of TS Eliot's Murder In The Cathedral recorded in its actual location at Canterbury Cathedral. Now, for Granada, Swallow was going to put documentary to the test with a homelier subject also centred on a church, A Wedding On Saturday, featuring a young couple picked at random - colliery fitter Don Forshaw and his bride Pam, both of South Elmsall, Yorkshire.

With the help of his friend and colleague Denis Mitchell, Swallow opened up the occasion to yield what I described at the time as television's most robust, least condescending, bit of sociology ever. The production went on to win the prestigious Italia Prize, and Swallow forecast that the use of film on television would die out.

Sadly, this was not to happen. Though lightweight cameras and recording equipment were being developed, Swallow still had to use the massive apparatus of the conventional outside broadcast unit, with mobile control room, recording van and generator parked alongside the location, all needing an hour's warm-up time. It was not easy to be spontaneous.

Furthermore, editing the raw material - in A Wedding's case, 19 hours of it - was complicated and time-consuming. Swallow and Mitchell shot three more subjects in the same manner, but when, in 1966, Ken Loach used a hand-held 16mm film camera to catch his drama-documentaries Up The Junction and Cathy Come Home on the wing, the battle was lost.

Swallow was born in Eccles, Lancashire, the son of the headmaster of a Church of England-endowed school. He went to Manchester grammar school, from where he won a scholarship to Keble College, Oxford, to read history and moral philosophy. Called up for war service, he found himself in the Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry, defending Brighton power station.

He and his girlfriend, Madeline, were married in 1945, whereupon he was sent to Palestine and saw plenty of action against the Irgun Zvei Leumi terrorists. In 1947, as his demob date was approaching, he spotted a job vacancy advertisement by the BBC in Manchester. He applied immediately, but could he possibly get back in time for the interview? Despite a bomb attack on the train taking him to Haifa, he made it with 24 hours to spare, and landed the job.

At the time, BBC north region was highly influential and innovative. It was here that Swallow first met Mitchell, who had pioneered the use of the new-fangled tape recorder to capture the voices and sentiments of ordinary folk, and was about to venture into television. Swallow was, meanwhile, transferred to the Television Service in London on his own merits, starting at Alexandra Palace on the same day as David Attenborough.

By the early 1960s, he was on the then all-important current affairs show Panorama, edited by Paul Fox. He made his mark with a series of reports from India and the Far East, using Ludovic Kennedy as reporter.

His move to Granada, in 1963, set the pattern of his future career, shuttling between the two organisations he held in most esteem. For Granada, the failure of his video-documentary dream put aside, he marked the 50th anniversary of the Russian revolution with Ten Days That Shook The World, made with the cooperation of Soviet TV, and, 10 years later, pondered another long drawn-out revolution in the 13-part series, The Christians, in which Bamber Gascoigne toured historic sites.

For the BBC, he successfully edited the arts programme Omnibus, and then, in 1978, produced Clouds Of Glory, two wild and wonderful films about the lakeland poets, directed by Ken Russell, whose talent Swallow had spotted years before, when he referred him to Huw Wheldon, who set him to work on Monitor.

Swallow's last great project, in 1985, was a 13-part Granada series on television itself, called simply Television. Some how, it rarely rose to the full promise of the subject, possibly because - after a brilliant second episode on the early days - it eschewed a chronological account for a rather nervy thematic one. But, as Leslie Halliwell said, its compilation of rare, old visual material was a treat in itself.

Swallow and Madeline, or Madie as she was known, lived for many years in a Georgian house opposite Greenwich park. To the end, he was delighted to hear every Christmas from the Wedding On Saturday couple, now married for 37 years. His wife survives him.

Norman Swallow, television producer, born February 16 1921; died December 5 2000

webTitle: A listening ear for troubled children

fields.headline: A listening ear for troubled children
fields.standfirst: This month we are highlighting the work of the four charities chosen for our Christmas appeal. Today we look at the unique service offered by Place 2 Be
fields.trailText: This month we are highlighting the work of the four charities chosen for our Christmas appeal. Today we look at the unique service offered by Place 2 Be.
fields.body:
In the autumn of 1995 Femi (not his real name), eight, arrived in the UK from Nigeria with his brother, his two sisters and their parents.

The family were housed in Peckham, south-east London, and all four children found places at a local school. While his brothers and sisters settled well given the circumstances, Femi was disorientated and disturbed by his new surroundings and had trouble communicating with staff and fellow pupils.

Noticing Femi's problems but unable to spare the time to sit down and work through them with him, Femi's teacher referred him to the school's Place 2 Be counsellor. Place 2 Be, one of the winners of this year's Guardian charity award and one of four beneficiaries of our Christmas appeal, offers a service unique in British education.

Founded in 1993 it is effectively a professional mental health service within a school, providing trained counsellors who offer emotional and therapeutic support to children referred by teachers.

Entirely independent of the school and the child's home life, counsellors offer a safe and independent adult listening ear, neither parent nor teacher, to disturbed and distressed children.

"Femi was withdrawn, frightened, and found it difficult to make friends," said the teacher. "His dad expected a lot from him and was very strict. I hoped that Place 2 Be would help him be less withdrawn and better able to make friends. It would be good for him to express his feelings and be more involved with the work and me as teacher. I hoped he wouldn't be as afraid."

Femi's father proved to be receptive to the idea of his son getting help; it turned out the problems of the playground were being repeated in the home.

"Femi is a very private person," said his father. "At home he was always fighting with his brother and being very protective of his two sisters.

"He has good points; he can think for himself and is very tolerant of others, knows what is expected of him and is very neat and intelligent, but he is quiet and very sensitive to criticisms. I wanted him to go to Place 2 Be to try to be less shy and more sociable."

Femi's response to his once a week sessions with the counsellor was dramatic.

It emerged he was hugely jealous of his brother and lacked confidence in his own abilities. Through building a relationship of trust with his counsellor he was able to unburden himself.

Art therapy was also used to encourage Femi to express himself, to deal with his frustrations and gain confidence.

In the space of a year his teacher saw a marked improvement. "Femi's behaviour was much improved and I am pleased with his progress all round. He is much less withdrawn and is able to stick to boundaries.

"He is working hard, able to concentrate and above all is not afraid to let his opinions be known," he said.

The reasons a child is referred to Place 2 Be are many and various: bullying, truancy, domestic violence and drug abuse, long-term illness, abandonment, physical and sexual abuse, divorce or the disruption of arriving in a new country as a refugee.

But whatever leads them to Place 2 Be the counselling is uniform - patient, attentive and confidential.

As a consequence, success stories like Femi's are common in the 40 odd schools in which Place 2 Be operates. In each school a care manager works 2 days a week with a team of four volunteer counsellors.

Place 2 Be counselling counts as a clinical placement towards a variety of degrees and qualifications so it is able to draw upon part-qualified volunteers from across London.

The organisation's next aim is to roll out its counselling services across the UK in the next four years. It is currently focused on London and the south-east, working in Southwark, Enfield, Southend, and Medway. But it hopes to start working in schools in Nottingham soon, and has had inquiries from the local authority in Durham.

The money raised by this appeal will go towards the roll out, recruiting and training staff for the new counselling centres, and providing support for existing staff.

For as little as £15,000 Place 2 Be can put a trained counsellor in a school for a year, offering advice, help and hope to as many as 150 children. For the price of a Big Mac, the organisation will provide a day's counselling to a confused, frightened child like Femi.

How they help

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford the fees of commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

webTitle: Feminism in the 21st century

fields.headline: Feminism in the 21st century
fields.standfirst:
Lynne Segal, professor of psychology and gender studies at Birkbeck College, University of London, speaks to Dave Hill exclusively for Guardian Unlimited

The truth about men and women
fields.trailText:
Lynne Segal, professor of psychology and gender studies at Birkbeck College, University of London, speaks to Dave Hill exclusively for Guardian Unlimited.

The truth about men and women
fields.body:
Dave Hill: Tell me about the theme of your inaugural lecture. What lies behind the title: Back To The Boys?: Temptations of the Good Gender Theorist?

Lynne Segal: Well, although this is a rather august occasion, there's obviously a tease in the title. Should we be going back to the boys? Why is the gender theorist, who of course came out of women's studies, talking about men and masculinity at all? That's a serious issue for some feminist scholars, who fought hard to set up women's studies programmes in the 1970s, usually only found a home in the academy in the1980s, and didn't appear in the old universities ­ if at all - until quite recently.

Moreover, that move has accompanied a switch of designation from women's studies to gender studies, incorporating the immense interest in men and masculinity, burgeoning since, and only since, the 1990s. Some feminists see gender studies as a way of sidelining women and the problems they still face, while allowing men into the spaces which women fought to open up. But I don't see this, in itself, as such a serious issue, because as I see that feminist scholarship now has emerged within all the disciplines. Or at least, that's what we're fighting for, and that's the important thing.

DH: Your most recent book asks the question, "why feminism?" But what is feminism these days? And why is it relevant to today's society?

LS: Lots of people like to see feminism as part of the problem of the present overloaded working day. Both the workplace and the home are now such demanding and divided terrain to occupy. If we want rewarding jobs, we're all expected to be able to sacrifice our home lives for them.

And feminism is blamed for this, as if all we wanted was to exchange our primary concern for the home for career success. In fact, of course, what feminists fought for was the negation of this: to make the demands of the job better suited to the demands of the home and participation in wider community life.

And we wanted the joys and burdens of caring for ourselves and other people, of raising our children and building communal lives to involve men. This meant shorter working time, shorter working days; men as well as women helping to create richer lives for all. And in that sense, feminism failed.

Nothing upsets me and those feminists I was closest to more than to see how we are nowadays portrayed. We hardly have been more concerned, or emphasised more often, that in trying to create a new world for women we were creating a new world for men. If you read what people like Sheila Rowbotham wrote, there's no mistaking it. Nobody's saying, "Right! All women into the workforce! We can all work longer hours!"

DH: What do you make of the recent appearance of some prominent women in public life, as in the House of Commons or the House of Lords?

LS: It's a question of how one looks at it. Another way in which 70s feminism has been caricatured is by naming it "equality feminism". It is an odd move, when its goal was to transform the world, not just see women in powerful jobs.

But, of course, I'm I want to see women on top, women having it all, if they can, and want to. But at the same time I think any formal equality agenda misses out on much of the feminist project.

But the first thing to notice, of course, is that prominent women MPS have come and gone rather fast. And when they go there's usually a lot of sneering following them - whether it's Harriet Harman or Mo Mowlam. You almost hear the top boys' sighs of relief. Blunkett or Brown never seem to be in the same sort of jeapody, and when Mandelson went he popped up again pretty fast. The women don't.

DH: Well he's gay so that's all right, isn't it? [Laughter]

LS: Except that gay men, too, may yearn for all the symbolic trappings of manhood. Women in power come in for more stick. It's the contradictions which women so obviously represent once they are in positions of power. It's very easy to attack the powerful woman, who should carry the burden of representing the softer, gentler values - wherever they are!

DH: How do you evaluate the current anxieties about boys and their performance in schools?

LS: Just a few months ago Blunkett was fulminating about the fact that equality had gone too far in the schools, and there was going to be a serious backlash. A backlash? This was all because 0.6% of boys - less than 1% of boys ­ for the first time ever, had done worse at A-levels than girls!

Nothing could be less enlightening here than to make a gender comparison, blaming the girls and the attention they receive, rather than make the more relevant comparison between boys, to see which boys were failing and why. That, of course, would bring out factors about class, about neighbourhoods, about state schools - all the things that Blunkett himnself is responsible for. He's simply refusing to tackle the problem.

DH: Blair seems to vacillate over the kind of man he wants to be seen as. It's partly just trying to be all things to all people - as politicians must. But you know, he's the man who takes a bit of paternity leave but not too much in case it looks bad. There's this anxiety about giving it up isn't there?

LS: That's right. Again it comes back to the question of "what is masculinity?" Well, it is primarily about what it a man is not: not feminine; not passive; not gay; not subordinate.

Showing you are not anything which could be seen as inferior. And this goes very deep.

There's also nothing new about it - it's always been there. Nowadays there's more and more work being done on the history of manhood. You¹ll find it was the same a hundred years ago: this fear of effeminacy; fear that you had to take the boys away from their mothers or else they wouldn't be manly enough to out and defend the British empire.

Indeed, it's thought to be why the empire was lost. There's always been this horror and fear that men won't stay on top. It's also just as traditional to blame all social problems on women, and women usurping men's place.

DH: I'm fascinated by the David Beckham phenomenon, the whole public performance. I think the hatred he inspires in some men is about more than jealously over the fact that he's rich, talented, married to a pop star and got sent off in the World Cup.

I think it goes much deeper. People just can't stand him being both those of qualities simultaneously. It's breaking all the rules. It literally horrifies them.

Just look at Sylvester Stallone, grunting, suffering, flexing his muscles and preening like a beauty queen. You're absurd, and displaying masculinity itself as a joke, as not something to be taken seriously.

But also, the only way we can know things are securely masculine is if they occur in a space that women, or anyone else who can be seen as inferior (whether black men or other subordinated groups of men) are excluded from.

There you are. I think that covers the lot, doesn't it?

Why is the gender theorist, who of course came out of women's studies, talking about men and masculinity at all? That's a serious issue for some feminist scholars, who fought hard to set up women's studies programmes in the 1970s, usually only found a home in the academy in the1980s, and didn't appear in the old universities if at all - until quite recently. Moreover, that move has accompanied a switch of designation from women's studies to gender studies, incorporating the immense interest in men and masculinity, burgeoning since, and only since, the 1990s. Some feminists see gender studies as a way of sidelining women and the problems they still face, while allowing men into the spaces which women fought to open up. But I don't see this, in itself, as such a serious issue, because as I see that feminist scholarship now has emerged within all the disciplines. Or at least, that's what we're fighting for, and that's the important thing. DH: Your most recent book asks the question, "why feminism?" But what is feminism these days? And why is it relevant to today's society? LS: Lots of people like to see feminism as part of the problem of the present overloaded working day. Both the workplace and the home are now such demanding and divided terrain to occupy. If we want rewarding jobs, we're all expected to be able to sacrifice our home lives for them. And feminism is blamed for this, as if all we wanted was to exchange our primary concern for the home for career success. In fact, of course, what feminists fought for was the negation of this: to make the demands of the job better suited to the demands of the home and participation in wider community life. And we wanted the joys and burdens of caring for ourselves and other people, of raising our children and building communal lives to involve men. webTitle: Prince pitches in during Chile trip

fields.headline: Prince pitches in during Chile trip
fields.trailText: It seems that Prince William harbours a secret dream: to achieve some street-cred as part of the Staines massive. The prince impersonates comic character Ali G in a pack of photographs released by Buckingham Palace in its latest PR offensive.
fields.body:
It seems that Prince William harbours a secret dream: to achieve some street-cred as part of the Staines massive. The prince impersonates comic character Ali G in a pack of photographs released by Buckingham Palace in its latest PR offensive.

Officials, who are determined to maximise their use of the royal family's greatest publicity weapon, have issued pictures documenting the 18-year-old's 10-week trip to southern Chile, which are intended to portray the future king as an average "Gap Year Kid".

He is pictured cleaning a bathroom, building walkways in a village, teaching children English and tracking deer in Patagonia as he nears the end of his Raleigh International expedition. He will start a history of art degree at St Andrews University next year.

In an interview he said he enjoyed being treated as an "equal" by the other volunteers, who called him William or Will.

webTitle: Romanian far right boosted in election

fields.headline: Romanian far right boosted in election
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Unofficial exit polls put Romania's nationalist party leader, Vadim Tudor, behind his Socialist opponent last night in his first assault on the presidency, but they left him in a strong position to attack the new president and government which he predicted would last less than three months.
fields.body:
Unofficial exit polls put Romania's nationalist party leader, Vadim Tudor, behind his Socialist opponent last night in his first assault on the presidency, but they left him in a strong position to attack the new president and government which he predicted would last less than three months.

The Socialist candidate, and likely new president after yesterday's second-round vote, was Ion Iliescu, 71, a former senior communist who was elected as president in 1990 and 1992, before losing the post in 1996.

His party of Social Democracy won the most seats in last month's parliamentary elections and is expected to form a coalition government with centrist parties shortly.

Mr Tudor's extreme nationalist Greater Romania party is now the second biggest party in the 483-seat parliament with 121 members - a result he himself considered a "miracle". It was a result that even eclipsed the success of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party in Austria.

Any stumble by the Socialists, such as a shift in their popularity caused by any tough new economic reforms or a rise in unemployment, could bring true Mr Tudor's prediction that the government will fall by March.

The nationalists' rise from obscurity is the result of widespread disillusion 11 years after the fall of the former strongman, Nicolae Ceausescu, who ruled the country for 24 years. It is a sign that Romanian patience is running out, and many are desperate for change.

A day-watchman at the Dulciuri Excelent sweet factory on Samuel Vulcan street in Bucharest says he voted for the Socialists in 1992 and the Conservatives in 1996, but yesterday he voted Nationalist.

"I voted Vadim because I'm fed up with the mafia who run this country," he said. "So many people are sick - they die from heart attacks or diseases of the brain. I still live with my parents. If I go to the city hall and ask for a flat, they turn me down. Only those with money or contacts get flats."

In Rahova, a poor suburb of nine-storey housing estates in the capital, stray dogs fight over bones in vacant doorways. The Vulcan heavy machinery factory at the heart of the district has a bright blue coat of paint, but that is the only colour on a grey afternoon.

The fifth and final child of working class parents, Mr Tudor grew up in the shadow of the factory. He excelled at school, and won a place at Bucharest University, studying the sociology of religion. His former professor remembers a bright, but scatter-brained student, who once begged him for enough money to buy his girlfriend a small cake.

His image among Romania's poor, is more like that of Robin Hood. "Down with the Mafia, Long Live Romania" was his most popular campaign slogan. But not all voters in the Rahova district were won over by Mr Tudor's promises. "I voted Iliescu," said Iulian Mihalcea, 37, a bus driver. "Because I don't want another Yugoslavia here."

Margareta Popescu, 70, a retired economist, also voted for the Socialist candidate. "I voted Iliescu out of fear of Vadim," she said "I have a duty as a citizen to prevent anarchy engulfing Romania."

But her husband, Ion, 80, vehemently disagreed. He voted for Mr Tudor "to destroy the mafia, and end these last 10 unhappy years for us, and then raise our standard of living".

He said he was not worried that Nationalist success may harm Romania's chances of joining the EU. "We don't want to enter it anyway, not for many years," he said. "Why do we need them, to squeeze more money out of us?"

webTitle: Lack of four sites?

fields.headline: Lack of four sites?
fields.standfirst:
Express websites are likely to be axed or dragged downmarket under the group's new owner.MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Express websites are likely to be axed or dragged downmarket under the group's new owner.
fields.body:
For the 40 employees still trooping in each day to work for Express Digital Media's remaining four websites, the future is bleak. Following last month's £125m takeover of the newspaper group by Richard Desmond, publisher of OK! and various adult magazines, staff have been put on 30 day's notice.

In letters delivered to them last week the closure of the sites was described as "likely", and although there are still three weeks of the "consultation period" left, some staff expect the axe to fall before then. Ian Monk, a spokesman for Desmond, says the sites are "desperately unprofitable", heading for a loss this year of £8m. Refusing to say whether there had been approaches to buy any of the sites, he says: "There are options which have been put forward, which include redevelopment or closure as we seek ways of making them more profitable. Should the sites be closed, every attempt will be made to find staff new roles within the group."

The new owners, Northern and Shell, publisher of porn magazines including Asian Babes, has its own "major internet strategy" under new media director Matthew Bugden, says Monk, and the OK! site will be "considerably redeveloped". "Newspapers in general are examining again what the internet can do for them. The Guardian and Associated Newspapers are very keen, but if you look at the Sun and News International, you will see they are scaling down their interest," Monk says.

Tony Cuthbertson, director of Express Digital Media, rejects the claim that high costs and advertising revenues of only around £240,000 a year meant the websites - except for lads' site MegaStar, which Lord Hollick's United News & Media has retained - were already dead ducks. "All the sites had business plans in place, and all the funding had been agreed," he says, stressing that advertising revenue would increase.

Of Express Digital Media's four sites, the Express website, SportLive, Allaboutparents.co.uk and Company-Leader.com, the last two have been up and running for less than four months. Reflecting relative optimism before the takeover, SportLive was in the process of hiring a new journalist as the surprise arrival of Desmond was being played out. "They offered me the job knowing the Express was going to be sold, but they thought they were all going to stay with United," says the journalist. "They were completely shocked - they had been given budgets and were looking to expand. They were planning for the future, and aiming to do more of their own content."

Similarly, Neil Harley-Rudd, of design consultancy UK Media, had been invited to redesign the Express websites just before the takeover speculation reached its zenith late last month. "I had a message from the internet editor asking me to do it, but then, from emails I received, it seemed to get less of a sure thing and I've not heard anything since," he says. While Cuthbertson stresses that "all the sites are still up and running, with all their features, and they are being updated as normal", one former Express employee is less positive. "There is a lot of fear and morale has gone through the floor," he says. "The root cause is that United got online very late into a crowded market and didn't invest enough. "There is also the theory that the Express was not a big enough brand for the internet market. It had a low internet conversion of its readers. The main site has not been going two years and the two which are less than four months old have never had a chance. But the foundations of the whole operation were wrong, and always seemed muddled. The Express site began under LineOne, the internet service provider that United owned with BT, and now has up for sale."

A former employee of Express Digital Media says: "At first, the Express site was within LineOne and really just provided it with news content until this spring. Only later did it start to become a proper site in its own right, although it looks like those plans will not come to fruition. "It was only quite late this year that SportLive and MegaStar were given any significant funding. They were a tremendous team doing a very good job, but with no resources. Allaboutparents and Company-Leader were vertical sites, modelled on Guardian Unlimited, with the idea being to put the various strengths of the paper onto the net, but they have just not had a chance. You can't justifiably shut them down on the question of profitability.

"I can't believe the Express is going to be the only newspaper without an internet site, which is now such an important part of the brand development of a paper." Hugo Drayton, the Telegraph's new media managing director, agrees that the muddle of the framework behind the sites did not help. "They had too many disparate things going on," he says. "Other, more successful sites had better strategies. Websites are an easy target because they are usually nobody's fiefdom. They do not offer any short-term return. The owners are doing what anyone new does - looking at where they can trim and cut down duplication. That said, from what I have read and heard they were not operating as viable propositions anyway.

"But I will be very surprised if they did not reopen something in the next six months, an online and newspaper strategy which complement one another." That Desmond is taking a cost- minimising approach to the internet is perhaps reflected in his response to a request to find a replacement for the outgoing health editor. "Why do we need a health reporter? Get it off the internet, it's free," he is reported to have said.

Within the newspaper stable, it is the Star which is more profitable than the Express, and on the internet, MegaStar emerged as the strongest Express site. Some may argue that glamour and the lower end of the market are what Desmond knows best, but Lord Hollick kept MegaStar, which has just benefited from a £3m advertising campaign. Since the start of that campaign, the number of individual users has grown by 40,000 to 330,000 and monthly page impressions now average 18.7m. Drayton says he would not be surprised if the group's internet future was more downmarket. "Pornography and gambling are two things which often lead new technology, and did so with audio text phoneline services and then the internet as forerunners for more acceptable sites," he says. "Desmond will no doubt have learnt from the experience of the adult sites".

A recent survey claims that 36% of home internet users are more interested in porn than sports or news - something that will not be news to Richard Desmond.

webTitle: America's highest court goes on trial

fields.headline: America's highest court goes on trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: First came the narrowly divided presidential and congressional elections. Then there was the desperately close run poll in Florida. Last week the Florida supreme court split 4-3 in favour of counting the votes, as Al Gore wanted. At the weekend the US supreme court split 5-4 in favour of stopping the count, thus supporting George W Bush.
fields.body:
First came the narrowly divided presidential and congressional elections. Then there was the desperately close run poll in Florida. Last week the Florida supreme court split 4-3 in favour of counting the votes, as Al Gore wanted. At the weekend the US supreme court split 5-4 in favour of stopping the count, thus supporting George W Bush.

Every twist in the five-week drama that has consumed America since November 7 has been marked by sharp divides and intense partisanship.

Today, in perhaps the final act of the drama, the supreme court in Washington faces a decision which puts its authority as America's national arbiter on the line as few in history have done.

The question before the nine justices is whether the court can take any decision on the presidential election which will not be seen as a partisan ruling.

For much of its lifetime, the over which the conservative chief justice William Rehnquist has presided for the past 14 years has tried to avoid divisions.

As recently as last week it issued a unanimous ruling after its first deliberation on the Florida election. Its decision to pass the legal issues back to the Florida supreme court in Tallahassee embodied the doctrine of "judicial restraint" which has often been a hallmark of the Rehnquist court.

But Saturday's decision transformed all that. The 5-4 ruling to "stay" the count authorised by a 4-3 majority on the Florida supreme court only 24 hours earlier catapulted the US supreme court's role from cautious supervision to direct engagement. If nothing else, it almost certainly inaugurated a new period in which the court, and its members, are certain to become much more controversial.

Three main groups of justices have been decisive in the events of the past 48 hours. The conservatives are led by Mr Rehnquist,and include Antonin Scalia and court's only black member, Clarence Thomas, whose confirmation hearings in 1991 produced one of the most bitter fights in the history of the appointment process.

All three voted in favour of the stay, and Mr Scalia wrote an accompanying opinion in which he said the majority believed that Mr Bush had "a substantial probability of success".

Opposed to them are the four liberals, headed by the oldest member of the court, John Paul Stevens, 80.

Ranged alongside him are the two members nominated during Bill Clinton's eight-year period of office - Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a former American Civil Liberties Union lawyer, and Stephen Breyer, a former Watergate prosecutor - and David Souter, who was nominated by President George Bush in 1990 but who, in the view of conservatives, has defected to the liberals on litmus-test issues.

These four made up the minority which opposed the stay on Saturday and on whose behalf Mr Stevens wrote a note of dissent warning that approving it would "inevitably cast a cloud over the legitimacy of the election".

That leaves the two justices in the centre, who tend to vote with the conservatives, as they did on Saturday, but sometimes side with the liberals, as Mr Gore's lawyers hope they will after today's hearing.

Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony Kennedy were both nominated during the Ronald Reagan era, but both have revealed an independence in their voting which makes them the court's key swing members. Mr Kennedy, in particular, will be the focus of the Gore lawyers' arguments.

If either of the centrists swings to the liberal side today, Mr Gore will win.

The key legal question the court has to decide is largely the the one which confronted it 10 days ago, when it heard Bush's previous appeal against the Florida supreme court's November 21 ruling permitting recounts in three of the state's counties.

The issue is whether the Florida court has overstepped its authority to interpret Florida law into areas governed by the US constitution and federal law, of which the US supreme court is the ultimate guardian.

Today's arguments will therefore focus on jurisdiction, not on whether it is right or wrong to hold recounts, and not on the rules which the recounts should follow.

The crucial documents in the case are article two of the constitution, which governs the calling of the electoral college by each state "in such manner as the legislature thereof may direct", and section five of the 1877 United States Code, which says that states must resolve questions concerning their electoral college members according to procedures that were in effect on election day.

Mr Bush is now arguing that the Florida supreme court has exceeded its once powers again.

His lawyers say the Florida court's action on Friday "imperilled" his chances of taking Florida's 25 electoral college votes by raising "a reasonable possibility that the votes will be called into doubt", and did so too close to the electoral college deadline for him to get relief from the courts.

In granting the stay and agreeing to hear the case today, however, some of the justices seem to have been willing to broaden the issue from a basic "who does what" argument between the different courts.

Mr Scalia's opinion is that "the counting of votes that are of questionable legality does in my view threaten irreparable harm [to Mr Bush]".

By raising the whole issue of the recounts and the procedures, Mr Scalia has certainly widened the legal argument and has increased the political stakes for the court as it hears today's case.

webTitle: Post civil war electoral act haunts divided nation

fields.headline: Post civil war electoral act haunts divided nation
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Today's judicial hearings in Washington will not be the first time that supreme court justices have been involved in the resolution of a contested election. But the previous experience is hardly encouraging for the health of the US judiciary.
fields.body:
Today's judicial hearings in Washington will not be the first time that supreme court justices have been involved in the resolution of a contested election. But the previous experience is hardly encouraging for the health of the US judiciary.

On the last occasion, after the 1876 election, the justices did not offer their services as they did this weekend but were dragged into the fray by a divided Congress.

The Democratic governor of New York, Samuel Tilden, initially appeared to have won both the popular vote, by 251,000, and the electoral college vote against his Republican rival, the civil war general Rutherford Hayes. But in the days after the election three southern states, Florida, South Carolina and Louisiana - which were still under postwar military occupation by Union forces - disqualified Democratic ballots for various reasons, shifting the majority to Hayes.

The 19th-century equivalent of the butterfly ballot was the rooster ballot. To allow for widespread illiteracy, the Democrats were indicated on the ballot form by their mascot, a rooster. The Republicans were portrayed by a picture of Abraham Lincoln. But in 1876, the Democrats printed ballots with Tilden's name alongside Lincoln's face, to mislead illiterate Republicans.

Then as now, Florida was the most contentious state, and both sides sent trainloads of lawyers and high-profile advocates to the southern state to press their case. But the dispute could not be resolved and Florida ultimately sent two rival sets of electors to the electoral college and left it to Washington to decide.

Congress was also split. The Senate was Republican-held and the House of Representatives was Democratic, and in an attempt to produce a non-partisan body, both houses set up a special commission of 15 senators, representatives and supreme court justices.

The commission's nominees were evenly split as well, with seven Republicans, seven Democrats, and one independent justice. However, before he could be named to the commission, the judge was offered a Senate seat by the Illinois state legislature, taking him out of consideration. He was replaced by an "independently minded" Republican justice, who first sided with Tilden, then switched to Hayes after Republican pressure.

The Democrats were outraged, and Inauguration Day was marked by a bitterness unthinkable today, despite the tone of the current rhetoric.

Democratic newspapers published pictures of Hayes overprinted with the word: "Fraud." Throughout his single-term presidency he was derided as "His Fraudulency" and "His Accidency".

In order to govern, Hayes negotiated a deal with southern Democrats, agreeing to withdraw Union troops from the South. He also ended the Reconstruction era, a brief interlude during which freed slaves were given civil rights.

The election was a disaster for black southerners, setting them back nearly 100 years.

The 1876 election also produced the Electoral Count Act, which was meant to force states to resolve disputed polls before dispatching a slate of electors to the electoral college. But that act itself is ambiguous.

Section two says: "Whenever any State has held an election for the purpose of choosing electors, and has failed to make a choice on the day prescribed by law, the electors may be appointed on a subsequent day in such a manner as the legislature of such State may direct."

That seems to give the lead role to the Florida state legislature but then section five stipulates that the state judicial proceedings "shall be conclusive" in the electoral count, if finalised by December 12.

The conundrum has now come full circle.

webTitle: Key judges with ruling power

fields.headline: Key judges with ruling power
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: William Rehnquist, 76
fields.body:
William Rehnquist, 76

First appointed by Richard Nixon in 1971 and US chief justice since 1986. "Oh Christ, he's way to the right of Pat Buchanan," the Nixon adviser HR Haldeman said on recently published Watergate-era tapes. Opposes abortion, one of the two justices who opposed the 1973 Roe v Wade judgment. Against affirmative action, strongly backs the death penalty, advocates limiting federal powers. Chaired President Clinton's impeachment trial. Poker player and pillar of the Washington legal scene. May step down in the next presidential term.

Antonin Scalia, 64

Appointed by Ronald Reagan in 1986. George W Bush's favourite and darling of the right. A strong conservative with a fundamentalist "strict interpretation" of the constitution, along with Clarence Thomas. Had a reputation in Washington as a highly conservative federal judge before his appointment to the supreme court. A brilliant and aggressive legal mind, given to intervening during oral arguments. Wrote a powerful opinion in support of Saturday's decision by the court to intervene and stop the Florida count.

John Paul Stevens, 80

Appointed by Gerald Ford in 1976. The oldest member of the court and its senior liberal, although he was once considered a centrist. Formerly a federal appeals court judge and a lawyer in private practice. Always supports abortion rights and affirmative action but is against fixed-term limits for office holders, on which he wrote the court's ground-breaking opinion in 1995. Supports suspects' rights in the criminal justice system. The author of the minority opinion on Saturday's ruling. Likely to step down during the next presidential term.

Sandra Day O'Connor, 70

Appointed by Ronald Reagan in 1981. The first woman to serve on the supreme court, though subsequently joined by Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Once active in Republican politics in her native Arizona. Once a staunch conservative but has become more liberal on some social issues. Often the key swing member, especially today, with Anthony Kennedy. Has been pivotal in earlier cases on voting rights, voting against redrawing of electoral districts on racial lines. Pro abortion, anti-affirmative action. May step down in the next four to eight years.

webTitle: GPs rebel against flu drug advice

fields.headline: GPs rebel against flu drug advice
fields.trailText: A flagship of the government's NHS reforms, the national institute for clinical excellence, will face its biggest crisis this week as rebellion grows against its advice to GPs to prescribe the flu drug Relenza to the frail and elderly.
fields.body:
A flagship of the government's NHS reforms, the national institute for clinical excellence, will face its biggest crisis this week as rebellion grows against its advice to GPs to prescribe the flu drug Relenza to the frail and elderly.

Last week a group of doctors in Devon said they did not intend to prescribe the drug to those at risk from complications of flu, flouting Nice's advice. More doctors are expected to follow their lead.

On Thursday the Drugs and Therapeutic Bulletin, which goes to all GPs, will announce that it remains "unconvinced of the benefits" of the drug and will not recommend its use.

The double challenge is a blow to the standing of Nice. It assesses the cost effectiveness of medicines and other treatments. If its committees of experts decide a drug is valuable, advice goes out to doctors to prescribe it. If they do not act on the advice they are likely to earn a black mark when their own performance is assessed.

But the mid-Devon group, which represents about 70 GPs and advises the primary care group, voted last week not to prescribe Relenza because it was not convinced that Nice's experts were right about it.

A year ago, a Nice evaluation committee rejected the drug on grounds that it would not help those at risk of flu complications because of a heart or lung condition or other frailty. The drug shortens a flu bout by a few days but has to be taken within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms.

Last month a review by a new Nice panel recommended that it should be given to at-risk groups in the light of new evidence from the manufacturer, GlaxoWellcome.

David Jenner, a GP in Cullompton, Devon, and chairman of the primary care group, said: "The doctors decided the weight of evidence was poor." They were also concerned that the drug was to be given out by nurses and pharmacists without reference to the GP.

"There is a particular problem with the diagnosis of flu: you get it wrong two times out of three. They were rebelling against the diktat from Nice, which made them feel that their individual clinical responsibility was being eroded."

webTitle: Over the counter in 25 minutes

fields.headline: Over the counter in 25 minutes
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It would have taken 25 minutes and three questions to get the morning-after pill over the counter in a supermarket on a Sunday afternoon in central Manchester.
fields.body:
It would have taken 25 minutes and three questions to get the morning-after pill over the counter in a supermarket on a Sunday afternoon in central Manchester.

This is not the pill that will go on sale for around £20 in chemists from the new year, but a free morning-after pill paid for by the NHS and provided over the counter by pharmacists to women as young as 13. It is a health action zone pilot scheme in Manchester, Salford and Trafford, which began on Christmas Eve last year. Women have driven from as far away as Buckinghamshire to get it.

The first hurdle was getting through to an operator on the NHS Direct helpline who could list Manchester chemists open on a Sunday. This took 10 minutes. An operator gave phone numbers of three local supermarkets open until 5pm. The nearest was five minutes' drive.

Beside a display of table sauces, Christmas peanut barrels and a special offer on 24-can packs of Carling Black Label, stood the sympathetic supermarket pharmacist who took women behind the counter to a secluded pine stool beside a shelf of Waspeze and E45 cream.

He asked about menstrual cycles, other medication taken, and the hours that had passed since sex. For audit reasons, he also asked if any form of contraception had been used.

He did not ask for the name of a GP, and said this pill would not be put on the patient's medical records. The pharmacist did ask for a name, but, as he said: "There is nothing to stop you saying you're called Mickey Mouse." All details and notes taken were countersigned by the patient and would go no further. The "consultation" was free and took 10 minutes.

Around 120 chemists in Greater Manchester offer this service and 6,600 women aged between 13 and 56 got the pill over the counter in Manchester this year. August figures were down on July, because of the large demand from the student population of 78,000 who go home for the holidays.

"Some women come in, answer all the questions then break down and admit they have never had sex, but want to keep the morning-after pill at home in case they do. Obviously we will not give it out in situations like that. It's not a form of contraception," the pharmacist said.

"I worry that once the morning after pill is available at a price over the counter the health professional's control in dispensing it will disappear. A woman would not have to buy it in person herself, which means a rapist or abuser could come in and buy it. We would lose valuable contact with the victim."
