webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: Reaction to PM's resignation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: What the Middle East papers say
fields.body:
Ma'ariv, daily tabloid newspaper

Barak resigned, and put the whole establishment into a frenzy ... He made his adversaries crazy, mocked his supporters, pulled the rug out from under all the goings on ... Perhaps the somewhat sadistic pleasure which Barak derives from his chutzpah [nerve] can explain the move, since from every other point of view it looks like he shot himself in the foot."

Yedioth Ahronoth, Israel's largest circulation daily

"Barak loves to surprise so much that he often surprises himself."

"Yesterday Barak not only determined when elections would take place. He also tried to determine who the candidates would be. What might have been seen 10 days ago as an elegant move, both honourable and courageous, was done yesterday without dignity or courage, and most of all without any public logic ... This is a crude,not to mention desperate, attempt by Barak to influence two processes: who will run against him and the change in the election system."

Ha'aretz, liberal broadsheet

"Nobody imagines that within 60 days the prime minister will surprise voters by presenting the draft of an agreement with the Palestinians ... Thus his decision to go ahead with immediate elections is a gamble - should he lose, all of his plans will go down with him ... It is be hoped that those who support the peace process with the Palestinians have not lost their confidence in the man who has not given up on the chances of attaining an agreement."

Jerusalem Post, rightwing English-language weekly

"Once again, prime minister Ehud Barak has shown a commando-like ability to improvise on the fly. His latest feint, however, looks more like that of a kamikaze than a commando ... Barak's reign, and it seems we must begin to speak of it in past tense, will be seen to be a truly tragic one."

webTitle: 73 flood warnings across Britain

fields.headline: Water, water ... everywhere
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Seventy-three flood warnings were still in place last night as thousands of people were left clearing up after rain and storms lashed much of Britain, writes Keith Perry.
fields.body:
Seventy-three flood warnings were still in place last night as thousands of people were left clearing up after rain and storms lashed much of Britain, writes Keith Perry.

The Environment Agency said Wales and the Midlands faced problems as heavy rain persisted. Forecasters said further rain would pose a flood risk for low-lying areas that were already saturated.

Since the Meteorological Office reported the wettest autumn since records began in 1766, rivers are flowing at high levels, catchments are saturated and conditions are likely to remain that way over winter.

The flood warnings were mainly across the Midlands, Wales and the south-west.

The warning for the Wye between Hereford and Ross-on-Wye has been reduced from a severe flood warning overnight. There were 40 flood warnings for areas around the upper and lower Severn and the Trent.

Warnings also remain for the lower Dee and Vyrnwy, and for the Ems, Lavant, Adur (from Burgess Hill to Henfield) and Cuckmere (from Alfriston to Exceat Bridge), the Ouse (from Lindfield to Barcombe) in Sussex and the Itchen in Hampshire.

In Kent the Beult and Teise were on flood warnings, but the Medway was downgraded to a flood watch.

webTitle: Comment: Peter Preston on the unedifying spectacle of the US election

fields.headline: Supreme court judges bring themselves into disrepute
fields.standfirst:
The end of the US presidential endgame is an unedifying spectacle
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The end of the US presidential endgame is an unedifying spectacle
fields.body:
Now we can glimpse the end of this American endgame, and pretty damned dismal it looks, too. Everything, top to bottom, side to side, is politics. Everybody has a spin. There is no higher authority - only low, calculating authority - so there can be no respect for authority, or the decisions it proclaims. That is the curse the US supreme court has brought upon itself.

Some time in the next 24 hours, the ultimate keepers of the constitution have chosen to decide who will be the next president of the United States. If they let the hand recounts in Florida go on, then we'll get Albert Gore Junior. If, as they seem so minded, they stop those recounts, then it will be George W Bush. Either way, the stench of politics infects their court room.

The moment this court of last resort split five votes to four was the moment these emperors of the law lost their clothes. They became not lordly beings commanding respect, but individual human beings with a history and an angle. They became mere players in an infernal, corroding drama.

Do you hear the four horsemen of the apocalypse galloping round the Washington beltway? Keep calm. This isn't the end of the world. There will be a new president and a new administration soon and American democracy won't shatter. Doom deferred. But, equally, cynicism - prime begetter of apathy - is the only big winner here; and there is a genuine feel of tragedy to the way that every twist along the road makes things worse.

An outsider from a foreign country called Britain has one advantage surveying such shambles. I am not, and cannot be, a partisan Democrat or a partisan Republican. I come from elsewhere. I may personally prefer some - not all - of Gore's policies, but the man himself is an uninspiring, wooden hulk. (Edna O'Brien calls him "The Wardrobe".) Bush, by contrast, may be intellectually punier, but he tells good jokes, clearly connects with middle America and has gathered some shrewd operators around him. This is a decent democratic choice, as usual: it is not the edge of some grand canyon.

The question - from night one, four anguished weeks ago - is: who chooses? The voters, by their ballots. But what if the machinery of this vast election, ludicrously rickety and fallible, isn't up to the job? What if, instead of resolution, there is no solution? Then, in democracy, we have "the rule of law". Then the legal eagles fly in.

Ah! democracy, the American way. So thorough, so zealous, so much to admire. It means that the canvassing boards who supervise the elections and the counts are political nominees. It means that the state officials who certify those returns are elected politicians. It means the same for the judges on up through the chain to the Florida supreme court (with an election in waiting, even for them, after a first term on that bench). It means that the battalions of lawyers making their cases come from Republican or Democratic firms and translate their masters' political imperatives into legal language. It means that the administration of justice itself is politically accountable.

Good thing? Often, when the will of the people, expressed at the ballot box, needs to be turned into verdicts - on racism, say - that make the law part of the evolving fabric of society. But a bad, bad thing when the decisions to be made reach to the heart of the legal process itself, when there is, in perception, no such thing as an independent judiciary.

Because ordinary Americans understand their system of governance, they are not, most of the time, either surprised or dismayed by the politicisation of their legal machinery. They find the checks and balances of different elections, working their way out over years, broadly satisfactory. They are utterly used to politicians running for office threatening, if elected, "to throw out the liberal judges who are dragging our country down". They clearly registered the Gore warning that Bush would appoint three or four anti-abortion judges to the supreme court who could unpick Roe v Wade and a woman's right to choose.

In that way, even the US supreme court is an accepted part of the political landscape. But tomorrow's crucial vote is different. Here, essentially, the nine judges are deciding who will follow them and thus define the political lean of their court for decades to come. When they pick the president, they pick the man who will nominate their own successors. When they do that - especially as they divide along party lines - they put their authority in pawn. They signal that everything in American life is politics, which means that everything is manipulable and fixable.

There have - in retrospect - been many better outcomes along the way of the past four weeks. It would have been better if the Florida votes had been re-recounted across the state when Gore made that offer. It would have been better - first time round - if the Florida supreme court had been more flexible on time frames and more specific on hanging chads. It would have been better if the first intervention from the US supreme court had been more decisive and, perhaps, if the Florida court's final throw hadn't happened.

Then, at least, a grimacing Gore would have found his support on Capitol Hill fading away and a country ready - after a fashion - to see what President Bush could achieve. Not an an end to argument or bitterness, to be sure: but an end that could, for a while, have been accepted.

There's no such end in sight now. The nine supreme justices have put themselves on the line and their arguments in doing so are inevitably frail. (When Justice Scalia says he wants the hand counts stopped because continuing them might undermine the validity of the election, he inevitably puts Bush's validity and his own validity above a voter intent that favours Gore.)

Ways out? Continuing the hand counts and seeing whether Gore nudges ahead is best, because - in humble, comprehensible fairness - it at least puts the ballots and the people who cast them first: but it also unleashes another month of court challenges and political furies. Only Gore, alas, would fancy being president in such dire circumstances. Stop the counts and effectively proclaim George W the winner, even though his lead was down to 96 and shrinking? Where's the legitimacy or the respect in that?

It is easy - too easy - to talk constitutional crisis. There is no such crisis here in the sense that something, at the end, will not be resolved. Hail to some new chief sometime or other. But the crisis is real in the sense that it taints and unravels America's most vital institutions and the authority of those who administer them. The politics of the damned.

webTitle: Girls found dead in car after party

fields.headline: Girls found dead in car after party
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the mysterious deaths of two teenage girls whose bodies were yesterday found slumped inside a car after a party.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the mysterious deaths of two teenage girls whose bodies were yesterday found slumped inside a car after a party.

The pair, who have not been named, were found in a vehicle which was parked in the double garage of a property in Crawley, West Sussex.

The girls, both thought to be 17, had been at a small party the night before which was being held at the address in the Pound Hill area of Crawley by a teenager whose parents were away.

The host discovered the girls slumped in the car early yesterday morning and immediately dialled 999, but resuscitation efforts by paramedics who had rushed to the scene, proved fruitless.

The exact circumstances of the deaths remained unclear last night, but a police source said: "We are looking at the theory it was a double suicide, but at present we cannot be sure exactly what happened."

He added: "Some of them decided to sleep over but exactly who, and whether that included the girls, is unclear.

"At 8am the boy went into the garage and found the girls in the family car. They could not have been in the car more than a couple of hours. The situation is very confused and we are handling the young people very gently."

Sussex police said they were not treating the deaths as suspicious nor looking for anyone else in connection with the inquiry.

Detectives yesterday interviewed all those who were at the party.

Detective Inspector Jason Taylor said: "Police are conducting a full investigation. We are supporting the young people and the bereaved parents. They are in a deep state of shock."

Police would not reveal any details about either girl, but it is understood one was a local teenager who knew the party host and the other was a visiting friend from Ireland.

Post mortems are due to be held today.

webTitle: Comment: Roy Hattersley on becoming a vegetarian

fields.headline: I join the rope-sandal brigade
fields.standfirst:
Turning veggie has dealt a blow to my reputation as a soccer hooligan
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Turning veggie has dealt a blow to my reputation as a soccer hooligan
fields.body:
Just over two weeks ago I became a vegetarian. At least I decided that I would never again eat meat. Fish remain in danger. But quadruped mammals are safe from me for ever. The extraordinary aspect of the past 14 days is the ease with which I have broken the habit of a lifetime. I attribute the smooth transition from carnivore to almost herbivore to the long gestation period of my conversion - and to the total absence of morality from my motivation.

Although bass, sole, cod and, above all, haddock are still at risk, it was seafood that first convinced me of the need for a discriminatory diet. I guess that I have eaten lobster three or four times in my life. So the decision to avoid any dish that had been boiled alive was no great sacrifice. Similarly, pheasant was easily abandoned when I discovered that the eggs are carefully hatched and the young birds reared by hand in order that they can be shot when they learn to fly. The thought of eating what had once been living shotgun targets put me off game forever. Veal, however, was different.

I have loved veal ever since, at university, my closest friend's fiance (Austrian by both birth and inclination) cooked me Wiener schnitzel. At the time I believed it to be an exotic version of deep-fried plaice. But even when I realised that it was what the Oxford dictionary calls "flesh of the calf", I still thought of it as food of the gods. Then, 30 years later, I read about how we bred calves and my appetite shrank.

Earlier Endpiece complaints about intensive farming have prompted Guardian readers to send me a subtle suggestion. If I was really concerned about calves' welfare, I should stuff myself with veal for three meals a day - thus keeping as many animals as possible in Britain rather than risking their live export to countries in which they still spend their anaemic lives in dark packing cases. I ignored the advice. Perhaps I could have single-handedly saved a calf a year. But I wanted no part of the veal business.

I turned my back on beef, mutton and pork for the same sorts of reasons. Watching television news - not an invariable source of either inspiration or education - I saw film of cattle trucks being stopped at the border between France and Italy. The pictures were supposed to illustrate the spread of BSE across Europe. But the sight of the cattle looking out of the lorries stimulated quite a different image in my mind. I thought of slaughterhouses. Suddenly, I did not want beef to be butchered on my behalf.

My decision was not built on sentiment. I was not concerned with whether the cattle in question were likely to meet a "humane" end. Nor was I influenced by the discovery that the opera festival with which I am associated is to produce Shostakovich's The Nose, in which the eponymous organ is reunited with its owner via a sandwich. I became a vegetarian because cutting up animals and eating the pieces suddenly seemed a bizarre way to live. I make no complaint against people who take a different view. And I certainly do not suggest that my position is more moral than theirs.

Were I not afraid of the word, I would claim that it was aesthetic considerations that changed my mind - the thought of blood on abattoirs' floors, skinned carcasses moving along conveyor belts, torn-off pelts lying in heaps and red-raw joints of meat being prepared for the butchers' shops. My feelings were not so much "shame!" as "ugh!"

So giving up meat was not a sacrifice. The thought of cutting up the carcasses was an aversion therapy in itself. But I remained apprehensive about being regarded as a "veggie" - a body of men and women whom I still associated with rope-soled sandals and folk dancing. I feared that I had sacrificed the reputation of being, at heart, a soccer hooligan. My identity crisis came a week ago in Derbyshire.

I was presenting awards at a dinner which, although described as "literary", was addressed by Richard Whiteley. Inevitably a waitress, plate in hand, wandered the dining room crying: "Who's the vegetarian?" Feebly, I held my hand in the air. On the discovery that I was the deviant, Mr Whiteley almost choked on his saddle of lamb and refused to believe that my mushroom pie was delicious. But other guests treated me as if I were a normal person. I managed to walk out into the cold Peak District night without being accused of deviance.

Of course, I did not drive myself home. At, or about, the time that I decided to abandon meat, I also determined to cut down on alcohol. But - not being revolted by the way in which Frenchmen jump up and down on grapes - that plan has not worked out so well.

webTitle: Israeli law fails to deter ex-PM

fields.headline: Netanyahu vows to take on Barak
fields.standfirst:
Israeli law fails to deter ex-PM

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Nineteen months after his drubbing at the polls, Binyamin Netanyahu returned to Israel's political stage as its self-proclaimed saviour yesterday, declaring his candidacy in a prime ministerial election.
fields.body:
Nineteen months after his drubbing at the polls, Binyamin Netanyahu returned to Israel's political stage as its self-proclaimed saviour yesterday, declaring his candidacy in a prime ministerial election.

Legally he cannot enter the contest to be Israel's next prime minister because he is not an MP. But that did not prevent him attacking the incumbent, Ehud Barak, for mishandling the 10-week Palestinian uprising and the peace process, or announcing that he was a contender anyway.

Last night he urged the knesset (parliament) to change the election law to allow him to stand, or to vote for dissolution, which would also smooth the way for his candidacy by letting him stand as an MP as well - parliament and prime minister are separately elected.

"In order to restore security for Israeli citizens, every home, mother and child in Israel and to establish a stable and strong government that will unite the nation ... I hereby declare my candidacy," he said.

Israel's complicated election law bars Mr Netanyahu from standing in the special electionbecause he is not an MP. He has also given up the leadership of his rightwing Likud party, presently under the stewardship of the former general Ariel Sharon.

That was precisely Mr Barak's calculation when he submitted his resignation to President Moshe Katzav to stand for re-election. In effect, his shock announcement cut the former prime minister out of the picture - "the most cynical trick in the history of the nation," Mr Netanyahu called it last night.

If Mr Netanyahu is allowed to stand, opinion polls predict a walkover. During the insurrection in the West Bank and Gaza, Mr Barak's support has fallen away with dizzying speed.

The right, which has gained ground during the crisis, accuses him of being too soft on the Palestinians - a charge made with increasing frequency as Israeli casualties mount. Nearly 40 of the 310 dead during the last 10 weeks are Jews or Israeli soldiers.

If Mr Netanyahu's supporters in his party can remove the obstacles to his candidacy, the February election will be a replay of Israel's last polls less than two years ago. Mr Barak emerged from the May 1999 election with 56% of the popular vote, a relative landslide by Israeli standards. Mr Netanyahu went into political hibernation, the humiliation of his defeat compounded by his investigation on corruption charges.

But by the weekend, opinion polls were giving Mr Netanyahu roughly a 20-point advantage over Mr Barak, prompting his surprise announcement on Saturday night.

The prime minister stands a far better chance against Mr Sharon.

"An hour doesn't pass when a citizen doesn't come up to me and say, 'Come back and make the country what it used to be - a place where we could live'," Mr Netanyahu said.

The claim says much about Israelis' short-term memory. Mr Netanyahu's three-year tenure was notable for its acrimony, both in Israel and with the Palestinians, who watched in frustration and dismay as the peace process ground to a halt.

Mr Netanyahu and his wife Sara were haunted by a corruption scandal. Although the attorney general decided in September not to charge the couple, his report on the affair said that Mr Netanyahu's conduct was not suitable for a man in public office.

Many analysts now blame the three-year freeze in the peace process under Mr Netanyahu for the eruption of Palestinian rage in late September. Yesterday Mr Barak told his first election rally that his rightwing opponents had yet to come up with a realistic vision for the Middle East.

At his press conference last night Mr Netanyahu spoke only of a "cold peace", without much elaboration.

"The problem of the Likud is not who will be its leader, but that it doesn't have an alternative way or position that can change reality," Mr Barak said.

However, after 10 weeks of bloodshed, the Palestinians have lost all faith in Mr Barak's ability to bring about change. Even if he does return to power, without an overhaul of the fractured parliament he would find it just as difficult to govern as before.

Yesterday the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, said Mr Barak's resignation meant yet another setback to the efforts for peace.

"[There is] no doubt that the resignation will mean peace negotiations will be put on hold until the end of the election," Mr Arafat said.

He said he was very disappointed in Mr Barak's efforts to date.

That was precisely Mr Barak's calculation when he submitted his resignation to President Moshe Katzav to stand for re-election. In effect, his shock announcement cut the former prime minister out of the picture - "the most cynical trick in the history of the nation," Mr Netanyahu called it last night. If Mr Netanyahu is allowed to stand, opinion polls predict a walkover. During the insurrection in the West Bank and Gaza, Mr Barak's support has fallen away with dizzying speed. The right, which has gained ground during the crisis, accuses him of being too soft on the Palestinians - a charge made with increasing frequency as Israeli casualties mount. Nearly 40 of the 310 dead during the last 10 weeks are Jews or Israeli soldiers. If Mr Netanyahu's supporters in his party can remove the obstacles to his candidacy, the February election will be a replay of Israel's last polls less than two years ago. Mr Barak emerged from the May 1999 election with 56% of the popular vote, a relative landslide by Israeli standards. Mr Netanyahu went into political hibernation, the humiliation of his defeat compounded by his investigation on corruption charges. But by the weekend, opinion polls were giving Mr Netanyahu roughly a 20-point advantage over Mr Barak, prompting his surprise announcement on Saturday night. The prime minister stands a far better chance against Mr Sharon. "An hour doesn't pass when a citizen doesn't come up to me and say, 'Come back and make the country what it used to be - a place where we could live'," Mr Netanyahu said. The claim says much about Israelis' short-term memory. Mr Netanyahu's three-year tenure was notable for its acrimony, both in Israel and with the Palestinians, who watched in frustration and dismay as the peace process ground to a halt. Mr Netanyahu and his wife Sara were haunted by a corruption scandal. Although the attorney general decided in September not to charge the couple, his report on the affair said that Mr Netanyahu's conduct was not suitable for a man in public office. Many analysts now blame the three-year freeze in the peace process under Mr Netanyahu for the eruption of Palestinian rage in late September. Yesterday Mr Barak told his first election rally that his rightwing opponents had yet to come up with a realistic vision for the Middle East. At his press conference last night Mr Netanyahu spoke only of a "cold peace", without much elaboration. "The problem of the Likud is not who will be its leader, but that it doesn't have an alternative way or position that can change reality," Mr Barak said. However, after 10 weeks of bloodshed, the Palestinians have lost all faith in Mr Barak's ability to bring about change. Even if he does return to power, without an overhaul of the fractured parliament he would find it just as difficult to govern as before. Yesterday the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, said Mr Barak's resignation meant yet another setback to the efforts for peace. "[There is] no doubt that the resignation will mean peace negotiations will be put on hold until the end of the election," Mr Arafat said. He said he was very disappointed in Mr Barak's efforts to date.

webTitle: Police drop Fayed inquiry

fields.headline: Police drop Fayed inquiry
fields.trailText: Detectives have dropped a criminal investigation into an allegation that Mohamed Al Fayed obtained stolen documents belonging to lawyers for the disgraced former Tory minister Neil Hamilton, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives have dropped a criminal investigation into an allegation that Mohamed Al Fayed obtained stolen documents belonging to lawyers for the disgraced former Tory minister Neil Hamilton, it emerged yesterday.

The investigation by City of London police began nine months ago, after Mr Fayed had successfully defended a libel action brought by Mr Hamilton and left the latter with a £2m bill in legal costs. It was claimed that the Harrods' chairman had paid £10,000 to obtain papers setting out Mr Hamilton's cross-examination strategy in the trial.

The police investigation was reported to have involved Benji "the Binman" Pell, who is said to scavenge through the bins of the rich and famous in order to retrieve saleable documents. After it emerged in March that police were looking into the allegation, Mr Hamilton won a court stay on paying £500,000 towards the £2m he owed Mr Fayed.

Last week officers investigating the claim, which was consistently denied by Mr Fayed, announced they had found no evidence of any wrongdoing.

In a letter to Mr Fayed's lawyers, Detective Chief Inspector Andrew Mellor, wrote: "Following my investigations I have decided not to interview your client in relation to this matter.

"Additionally, I have decided not to charge any person with any offence. These decisions are made on the basis of the evidence available."

Mr Fayed's spokesman, Alexander Hitchen, said last night: "We have maintained all along that this is nonsense, and was clearly yet another deliberate attempt to blacken Mohamed's name."

Mr Hamilton was ordered to pay both sides' costs after a high court jury decided Mr Fayed's allegations - that Mr Hamilton had accepted cash and hotel stays in return for asking questions in parliament - had been fair comment.

Mr Hamilton is today due to go to the court of appeal in an attempt to overturn this verdict.

Last night a confident Mr Hamilton dismissed any suggestion that his appeal had suffered a damaging blow. He said that the police investigation was not part of his case, and that he believed it to have been "neither here nor there".

"It is completely irrelevant to us. The crown prosecution service makes its own decisions whether this might be right or wrong."

Mr Hamilton also said that his lawyers had other evidence which had already been submitted to the court, adding: "That might well include evidence which the CPS did not have. It is not a blow. All litigation is inherently unpredictable, but all I can say is that we are hoping for the best."

fields.trailText:
Tourist plunges 230ft to death
Insurance risk of gap students
Breath tests for rail commuters
Two share £7m jackpot
fields.body:
Tourist plunges 230ft to death

A British backpacker died after plunging 230ft (70m) down a waterfall while paddling in a rock pool in the Blue Mountains near Sydney. Paul Marshall, 27, a carpenter from Leicester, had been travelling and working in Australia on a temporary visa.

Insurance risk of gap students

More than half of the 100,000 gap year students visiting countries outside Europe, Australasia and North America leave without proper insurance and vaccinations, according to a survey for the Gap Year Company. While the big fear for travellers was being mugged or kid napped, the main insurance claims were for medical expenses.

Breath tests for rail commuters

Train commuters in south London will have the chance to take voluntary breath tests in the morning and evening as part of an anti drink-driving initiative launched today. They will also be given information about the "I'll be Des" campaign which urges people to designate a non-drinking driver when they go out.

Two share £7m jackpot

Two tickets shared Saturday's £6,917,260 National Lottery jackpot with numbers 11, 16, 25, 31, 32 and 33. The bonus was 23. In the Lottery Extra game, no tickets matched all six numbers of 6, 39, 41, 44, 46 and 49. Two winners matched the five Thunderball numbers plus the Thunderball to win £250,000 each. The numbers were 9, 16, 19, 21, and 28, and the Thunderball was 4.

webTitle: Record fingernails go under the hammer

fields.headline: Record fingernails go under the hammer
fields.trailText: He is scared of the wind, has slept badly for years and has to avoid cows and other moving objects. Now, almost 50 years after deciding to let his fingernails grow, Sridhar Chillal has had enough.
fields.body:
He is scared of the wind, has slept badly for years and has to avoid cows and other moving objects. Now, almost 50 years after deciding to let his fingernails grow, Sridhar Chillal has had enough.

Mr Chillal, a retired Indian photographer, has decided to cut off his nails, listed in the Guinness Book of Records for 20 years as the world's longest, in the hope of selling them for around $200,000 (£125,000).

"I'm much older now, so I feel I can't take this inconvenience for much longer. That's why I'm ready to give up," he said

Mr Chillal, who is 64 and lives in Pune, near Bombay, has problems sleeping - "I can't move, can't turn sides, can't pull over the covers" - because his nails are more than a metre long.

"I have so much tension as a result of the worry that my nails are going to break, that with every heartbeat I'm tense."

Worse, the weight on his left hand has given him constant pain in his left wrist, elbow and shoulder, and not using it has killed off vital nerves and left him deaf in one ear.

The nails sprout from a misshapen left hand which is permanently disfigured from the extra weight he has been carrying around.

The longest nail is his thumb nail, measuring an astonishing 1.474 metres (more than 4ft 9in) in length. Most of the time he keeps his nails in what looks like an oversized golf club.

He tries to remain vigilant for cars, scooters, cows, small children and adults - anything which might damage them.

"Even when there is a big gust of wind, I turn my back and position my body so that the wind takes my back and my nails are secure," he said.

Mr Chillal's obsession began at the age of 14, when he read about a Chinese priest whose nails had grown to 22 inches in length. "I was amazed and I decided I would do that, and I could beat that," he recalled.

His family despaired. They predicted that he would end up destitute, but he proved them wrong. He worked as a photographer until his retirement in 1995, making good use of his functioning right hand. Then exhaustion set in.

Now he wants to sell the nails and is asking on the internet for at least $200,000 for all five.

"I prefer a museum or a curator to preserve them and I will also get reimbursement for all those years of inconvenience," he said. "I'll miss them. But I'll be happy knowing they are preserved and that my name will carry on."

So, was it worth it? "What does man not do for fame? He jumps from boats, dives from planes and does stunts on motorcycles. This is also done for fame. Were I to have another life I would do it again."

webTitle: A setback for Global Megabucks plc

fields.headline: A setback for Global Megabucks plc
fields.standfirst: Special report: Globalisation
fields.trailText: A subtle shift has occurred in the lexicon of globalisation over the past 12 months. Prior to Seattle, it was assumed that there was an inexorable logic to the process and that, despite the objections, the market supremacist model would benefit rich and poor alike.
fields.body:
A subtle shift has occurred in the lexicon of globalisation over the past 12 months. Prior to Seattle, it was assumed that there was an inexorable logic to the process and that, despite the objections, the market supremacist model would benefit rich and poor alike.

This line of argument was, of course, particularly attractive to those doing rather well out of globalisation, which - surprise, surprise - just happened to be the wealthy and the powerful. In other words, the same people who had done rather well out of the policies favoured by right wing governments in the 80s and 90s and could not see why people were making such a big fuss about mass unemployment and rising inequality.

Since Seattle, the mood has changed. Globalisation is no longer viewed as a force of nature, rather like the weather, but something that can and must be shaped by human endeavour and ingenuity. It has been recognised that there are inherent problems in a system where capital calls all the shots and has total freedom of movement, while labour is voiceless and has to stay where it is.

The release of the government's white paper on globalisation today is a step in the right direction, as is its title - eliminating world poverty: making globalisation work for the poor. Clare Short, the international development secretary, rightly says in the foreword: "Cynicism and negativism are the enemies of progress. It is when people see that progress is possible that the demand for reform and advance is energised."

Making globalisation people friendly requires two things - a closing of the yawning democratic deficit and a re-balancing of the lop-sided relationship between labour and capital. One proposal is that any future trade deals should contain a commitment to abiding by core labour standards, with sanctions against those countries that breached the global code. Unsurprisingly, poor countries are extremely hostile to this idea, seeing it as a back door form of protectionism, which it is. As Ajit and Ann Zammit argue in a paper written for the South Centre - an intergovernmental organisation of developing countries - there is a better way.

The paper's argument is fairly straightforward. Labour standards improved in the west as countries became richer not because draconian conditions were imposed on them from outside. The main factor preventing labour standards from improving in the developing world is poverty and economic hardship, not the wickedness of governments.

Moreover, it says that "adopting measures which are tantamount to forcing compliance with ILO core labour standards will not achieve the declared objective of raising labour standards in the south. Indeed, this would be quite the wrong way to go about achieving improved labour standards, both core and otherwise, in developing countries."

Even so, there may be some in the north who would say that workers in developed countries deserve to be protected, whether labour standards improve in the developing world or not.

In fact, there is not much evidence that this would happen even if goods from developing countries were priced out of western markets. Why? Because the most severe competition for advanced countries comes from the small number of newly industrialising countries whose productivity growth rate is much faster than that of advanced countries, not from those countries that would become the targets of trade sanctions.

Singh and Zammit say that in recent years there has actually been greater slippage in labour standards in the north than in the south. But they argue that the main cause of this malaise "lies in the current processes of economic globalisation, which emphasise free trade, free movement of capital, and labour market flexibility within national economies. Most analysts will agree that the last two characteristics disadvantage labour, north and south, and favour capital".

This is not the perception in the north, particularly in those industries, such as textiles, which are threatened with extinction by cheap imports. The lack of western-style labour standards is seen as leading to greater import penetration, undermining efforts by northern trade unions to improve the terms and conditions of work and providing incentives to shift production to the south.

But while exports from developing countries have been growing rapidly, most manufacturing trade of the advanced countries takes place between these countries themselves and only a small fraction - 1.5% excluding China - is with developing countries.

In the circumstances, Singh and Zammit say it is difficult to argue that this has been the cause of huge shifts in income inequality and mass unemployment in the west, particularly since the rapid growth of Japanese exports to the developed world in the 50s and 60s (when Japan was essentially a developing country) was accompanied by full employment and rising real wages in the US and Europe. The main difference between then and the more recent period is the fact that in the earlier period advanced economies were growing at about 5% a year compared with half that long-term rate since 1973.

As such, imposing labour standards on developing countries would at best be an irrelevance and at worst positively harmful. For the really poor nations, a code backed by sanctions would choke off export growth, worsening the balance of payments, and force growth rates to be lower to keep the current account in equilibrium.

Asian tigers

The experience of the Asian tigers is that this would slow up the pace of structural change and hinder the improvement in working conditions. Real wages grew 5% a year between early 80s and mid-90s in east Asia and south-east Asia, countries that were repressive of trade unions in their early stages of development. But the pace of growth led to the expansion the formal economy at the expense of the informal sector, leading not only to better labour standards but a very considerable expansion of unionisation. India had better core labour standards than Korea in the 50s; but the situation has been turned on its head as a result of much slower growth in India ever since.

Singh and Zammit say that higher labour standards in the south would require faster economic growth and structural change, which would involve measures to reduce poverty and inequality that would include labour market policies. Such a process would be helped if advanced countries themselves were growing faster, which inter alia would help improve labour standards in those countries.

"Faster economic growth is feasible - both because of the unrealised potential of the information and communications technology revolution and the catch-up possibilities of developing countries. However for this potential to materialise, a trend increase in the long-term rate of growth of real world demand is needed, which... would in turn require new institutional arrangements for a people-friendly globalisation. Specifically, this entails among other things close cooperation between leading economies, so that international demand expansion is not thwarted by co-ordination failures and balance of payments disequilibria."

Their solution, in short, is one where the burden of economic adjustment falls on creditor as well as debtor nations, where developing countries are given special and preferential treatment in trade agreements, where a floor is put under commodity prices and where controls on the free movement of capital permit more rapid economic expansion.

Those who have read the final volume of Robert Skidelsky's magisterial three-part biography of John Maynard Keynes (Fighting for Britain, Macmillan, £25) will know that such a scheme was proposed in the build-up to the Bretton Woods conference in 1944, but was rejected in favour of the more limited, and harsher US alternative. There is, undoubtedly, a route to people-friendly globlalisation but there is a long struggle ahead. As Keynes found, having the right answers is not enough, because while Britain had the arguments, the Americans had the power. And that is what counts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Ghana election needs run-off
Nobel laureates receive medals
Imelda suffers blood clot
fields.body:
Ghana election needs run-off

Ghana's presidential election will be decided by a run-off, both leading candidates having failed to secure a majority of the vote, the country's electoral commission said yesterday.

Provisional results showed the opposition leader John Kufuor on 48.44% and the vice-president, John Atta Mills, on 44.80%.

The run-off must be held within 21 days of the declaration of the final result, which is expected today.
Reuters, Accra

Nobel laureates receive medals

The exiled Chinese author Gao Xingjian joined 11 other laureates in Stockholm, Sweden, yesterday to receive their Nobel Prizes.

The South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, received the peace prize in Oslo, Norway, for his work for democracy, human rights and his country's reconciliation with North Korea.
AP, Stockholm

Imelda suffers blood clot

The former first lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos, was recovering in a Manila hospital yesterday after an operation to remove a brain blood clot.

Mrs Marcos, 71, who has a history of heart ailments and is diabetic, has been considering standing for mayor of Manila.
AP, Manila

fields.headline: A basic wage cuts poverty
fields.trailText: Woe betide the economy, said the chambers of commerce, the company directors and, of course, the Tory party when Labour fulfilled its manifesto commitment and introduced a statutory floor for pay. But the sky did not fall in when the minimum wage was introduced in April 1999.
fields.body:
Woe betide the economy, said the chambers of commerce, the company directors and, of course, the Tory party when Labour fulfilled its manifesto commitment and introduced a statutory floor for pay. But the sky did not fall in when the minimum wage was introduced in April 1999. Wage hierarchies were not affected; jobs were not lost; inflation did not run rampant. The UK economy turned out not to depend on paying workers derisory amounts for their labour. The £3.60 an hour minimum was hardly generous - that is the adult amount, younger workers get less - but it has none the less proved important in pushing up income in poor households and, marginally, making the distribution of income more equal.

But cautious economists say the effect of a minimum wage can only be gauged over the course of a cycle, in other words only after we have seen the effects of a floor for pay during a recession. Yet other countries, including the United States, have decades of experience. Capitalist economies are not drained of their life blood, as narrow-minded employers would have us believe, by taking faltering steps towards guaranteeing their workforce a living wage.

Labour seems set to raise the minimum to £4 and may seek to fix a permanent link between it and earnings at large. Going into a general election with this rise will give canvassers an immediate answer to the "what did you ever do for us" point, especially in poorer areas. There is more to do - many are still deprived of the minimum because their employers flout the law. There is more to say, too. The minimum wage needs the context of today's social exclusion report from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. It is a necessary step in meeting Labour's aim of eliminating child poverty, which is of course a euphemism for an the even more audacious commitment - yet to be made - of abolishing poverty in working-age households.

webTitle: Plea for Railtrack free ride urged

fields.headline: Plea for Railtrack free ride urged
fields.standfirst:
Train operating companies say that penalties for failure would make things worse

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train operating companies say that penalties for failure would make things worse
fields.body:
The train operating companies are to tell the rail regulator not to throw the book at Railtrack if it fails to deliver its national recovery plan designed to get the industry working normally before the election.

Sources from several companies last night warned that the regulator, Tom Winsor, would make matters worse if he decided to take legal action against the company for falling down on the plan.

Railtrack and the 25 companies are due to sit down to gether this week to approve the plan with Mr Winsor. He is anxious to find out what the companies want and if they are happy with Railtrack's plans.

Mr Winsor could issue enforcement notices against Railtrack if the recovery plan does not work. This could involve both sides in a bitter legal battle which the industry does not want.

One company source said: "We have enough problems on our hands without letting the lawyers in to create even more chaos. This is a situation which requires common sense and not confrontation. We must be allowed to resolve it that way, or we will lose even more public confidence."

Mr Winsor wants Railtrack to spell out the recovery package in detail, listing the milestones along the way, and explaining what contingency plans it has drawn up to deal with any emergencies.

One train operator said it was reasonably pleased with the way Railtrack had dealt with the crisis. It said that flooding and bad weather were placing an extra burden on the company which was doing its best "to contend with an unprecedented crisis".

The train companies acknowledge that some of the smaller operators may receive less favourable treatment because Railtrack has to prioritise the inter-city routes and the London commuter network.

Rail's unrelenting crisis has set back a number of key projects, of which the most crucial is the installation of a new train safety system by Railtrack at a cost of £400m.

The programme was ordered by John Prescott, deputy prime minister, following the Paddington rail disaster in October last year. More than 800 key signals controlling track junctions should have been fitted with the train protection warning system, but only 600 have been completed.

The system is designed to stop a train if it passes a signal at red. Railtrack says that it will soon make up the difference and fit 11,000 signals by the end of 2002.

Health and safety executive officials said yesterday that they are concerned at Railtrack's slow progress and that the installation scheme has fallen behind. They said the HSE would not hesitate to use its statutory powers to enforce the timetable of completion by 2003.

The system has been strongly criticised as a cheap alternative and not very effective for trains travelling at more than 70 miles per hour.

The regulator has signed off Railtrack's periodic review for the next five years beginning in 2001.

The company has been allocated almost £5bn to spend, money which will come from subsidies, fares and the train companies.

Rail workers will receive bonuses of up to £3,000 to complete Railtrack's emergency re-railing and engineering work over Christmas and the new year, the company confirmed yesterday.

More about transport

webTitle: Letters: arming the police

fields.headline: A fair cop
fields.trailText: Jeremy Hardy (If you want to die, ask a policeman, December 6) quoted me out of context from a live interview I gave to the BBC Newsroom South East programme. He quoted me as follows: "On Monday Glen Smythe of the Police Federation described facing an armed suspect as 'exciting'."
fields.body:
Jeremy Hardy (If you want to die, ask a policeman, December 6) quoted me out of context from a live interview I gave to the BBC Newsroom South East programme. He quoted me as follows: "On Monday Glen Smythe of the Police Federation described facing an armed suspect as 'exciting'."

I did use that word, however the context in which I used it was: "I can remember not so many years ago I myself was faced with an armed robber on the railway lines in the dark in Acton. That was a pretty exciting episode, he was armed, I wasn't. We chased him, it was only by the grace of God nobody was killed but he surprised me and there was no cover for me.

In those circumstances it is reasonable for one to have been 'stirred into action', 'be agitated' and be 'stimulated' by the situation - dictionary definition of 'excited'."
Glen Smythe
Chairman, Metropolitan Police Federation

webTitle: Letters: The next Chernobyl

fields.headline: The next Chernobyl
fields.trailText: Paul Brown says "energy efficiency measures and gas power turbines would be cheaper and better" than building two new nuclear reactors at Chernobyl (Britain backs new Chernobyl plants, December 6).
fields.body:
Paul Brown says "energy efficiency measures and gas power turbines would be cheaper and better" than building two new nuclear reactors at Chernobyl (Britain backs new Chernobyl plants, December 6).

But the project was considered by Stone and Webster, a reputable US company, as the most acceptable of a range of available options (modernisation of existing thermal generation, construction of steam-gas turbines, energy efficiency measures). In its view, completion of the two units would bring the highest degree of compliance to the cost-effectiveness principle.

The article quotes the judgment of a German environmentalist that "the last thing the world needs are two more hazardous reactors to replace the hazardous Chernobyl reactor". The reactors for the new units are up-to-date water-cooled moderated reactors of the VVER-1000 type, modernised under a European Bank programme to full western safety standards.

Some 60% of reactors worldwide, including those in western countries, employ the same principle of operation. The fundamental differences in design between the VVER-1000 reactor and the old RBMK type provide assurances of the absolute impossibility of a recurrence of the 1986 accident.
Alexander Maistrenko
Energoatom Company
Kiev, Ukraine

 Ian Traynor draws attention to the cost of the Chernobyl clean-up - $300m so far plus another $700m to build the sarcophagus, $1bn in all to deal with the nuclear waste (Buried alive, G2, December 7). How much will be spent on the workers at Chernobyl? Nothing.

Last month in Kiev, I met Alexander Yurkin, leader of the nuclear power workers union in Ukraine, who told me that a Chernobyl social plan had been drawn up, costed at $200m - a fifth of what will be spent on waste. But western donors will not fund it.

On August 27, Robin Cook announced a special UK fund of £80m for nuclear clean up in the former Soviet Union. I have tried without success to get the Foreign Office to tell me how much will be spent on workers in the industry.
Stirling Smith
Bolton

webTitle: Letters: a better deal for working parents

fields.headline: Still struggling to win a better deal for working parents
fields.trailText: You are right to praise the government's green paper offering a better deal for working parents (Leader, December 8). Ministers have indeed been brave in putting together a radical package.
fields.body:
You are right to praise the government's green paper offering a better deal for working parents (Leader, December 8). Ministers have indeed been brave in putting together a radical package.

But this is only a green paper. Its proposals are for discussion, not yet firm pledges. Predictably, the employer onslaught has begun, as the different lobby groups queue up to denounce the proposals as red tape and burdens on business. Supporters of rights for working parents will need to be vigilant to ensure these proposals are not chipped away by employer lobbying.

Yet many of Britain's best known companies already offer terms better than those proposed by the green paper. Modern companies care desperately about their corporate image. Is it not time to ask whether they really want to be associated with these mean-minded campaigns against proposals enjoyed by their staff and widely supported by their customers?
John Monks
General secretary, TUC

 Working mothers (and some fathers) already have rights to work flexible child-friendly hours unless the employer can justify refusal on good business grounds. The rights, which the CBI so resists, are already regulated; it's just that no one knows about or understands them.

The proposals will just clarify the present position to everyone's benefit. We were promised a code a year ago but the government reneged. The CBI should stop making such a fuss about existing rights and the government should stick to its promise this time.
Camilla Palmer
Bindman and Partners

 Polly Toynbee (Blair must listen to parents more than to employers, December 8) seems to be saying we can afford £100 a week for every child's mother for a year's maternity leave. Is this the same Polly Toynbee who earlier this year wrote that we could not afford to fund long-term care for the elderly? Only one in four requires long-term care and then for on average 18 months at £300 a week. Are the sums not comparable?
Phil Molyneux
Kingston upon Thames
molyneux@kingston.ac.uk

 Men already have a period of time that can be allocated for paternity leave - their annual leave. While men have nearly nine months to organise themselves, perhaps employers could allow flexibility on the final timing. The cost is effectively nothing. Most men have been doing this for years.
Dr William Notcutt
Gorleston, Norfolk
willy@tucton.demon.co.uk

 Who is expected to hold the fort at work when colleagues take maternity and paternity leave? The single colleague as likely as not - who is also expected to take annual leave outside school holidays, but who may have equally onerous family and personal responsibilities. I am all in favour of paternity leave; a similar entitlement to family leave should be extended to all employees on an equal basis.
Robert Charlesworth
London

webTitle: FSA chief faces questions about Equitable crisis

fields.headline: FSA chief faces questions about Equitable crisis
fields.standfirst: Policyholders demand inquiry
fields.trailText: Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, is expected to face a grilling today over the City watchdog's role in the Equitable Life crisis.
fields.body:
Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, is expected to face a grilling today over the City watchdog's role in the Equitable Life crisis.

Critics have claimed that the FSA should have taken earlier action against the mutual insurer which closed to new business on Friday after failing to find a buyer.

But Sir Howard, due to speak at a conference at the Royal Lancaster Hotel, London, is expected to insist that banning Equitable from selling new policies would have ended any chances of a sale.

An FSA spokesman said Sir Howard was not expected to make a speech solely on Equitable but would be willing to answer any questions.

Disgruntled policyholders this weekend called for a government inquiry into the supervision of Equitable by the FSA and want to establish how well their interests were being protected. Their complaints, said to be compiled into a dossier, will initially be dealt with by the FSA itself or by the financial ombudsman.

But they could eventually be referred to the Treasury, which has the power to an inquiry.

"The Treasury will look at any representations but will need to be satisfied that all the existing channels for dealing with complaints have been properly used," said a spokesman.

Last night the Equitable Life Members' Action group, which has been coordinating complaints, was meeting to discuss the feasibility of legal action on behalf of policyholders who are not protected by guaranteed annuity products.

They are expected to make a further statement regarding their decision this week.

Equitable put itself up for sale in July after House of Lords judges ruled its attempt to cut bonus rates on with-profits pension plans, to offset rising liabilities from guaranteed annuity products, put it in breach of its contract with customers.

Last Friday's decision to close the doors to new business followed the failure of negotiations with the Prudential, the last potential buyer.

Today the company publishes a notice assuring policyholders the society remains intact and all benefits will continue to be paid out in line with the contractual obligations of their policies.

It has also given those who have taken a policy out within the last 14 days the option of cancelling up until December 22.

John Sclater, the society's president, said: "I apologise most sincerely on behalf of the whole board to members, policyholders and staff that this has come about."

A spokesman for the FSA said those who bought policies since the July ruling, who believe they were given insufficient advice, had the right to take their complaints to the financial ombudsman.

webTitle: Deutsche Börse to approve flotation plans

fields.headline: Deutsche Börse to approve flotation plans
fields.trailText: Deutsche Börse's supervisory board is this week expected to give the go-ahead to the Frankfurt exchange's plans for its own stock market flotation.
fields.body:
Deutsche Börse's supervisory board is this week expected to give the go-ahead to the Frankfurt exchange's plans for its own stock market flotation.

The move is designed both to raise cash and to widen the shareholder base with Deutsche Bank - the exchange's largest single stakeholder - which is expected to sell part of its holding in the public offering.

The board will not put a value on the Frankfurt exchange but when it comes to pricing the issue the £1bn bid for the London Stock Exchange by Sweden's OM Gruppen is likely to serve as a useful benchmark. The German group will not want to see itself valued at less than the UK exchange.

Frankfurt initially tabled plans for a stock market listing one year ago but the move was put on hold by the decision to merge with the LSE - a strategy which was derailed by the OM bid.

The move to reactivate the flotation proposal is likely to be seen as the Frankfurt exchange's determination to get across a "business as usual" message after the months of uncertainty between the announcement of its merger with the LSE back in May and the failure of the OM group bid for the London exchange.

Such a view has been reinforced by two announcements last week from the bourse which focused on developing day to day operations.

Last week saw the Frankfurt exchange announce two separate initiatives. The first is designed to improve access for the increasingly important retail investor through the launch of XetraLive in the first quarter of next year. XetraLive is an information screen that will provide greater transparency for private investors by showing the best five bid and ask prices.

The exchange is also introducing NeuerMarkt.com - a portal for online investors which information on international capital markets and research from leading investment banks.

The portal will connect investors to online banks allowing them to trade electronically in a number of markets.

Though the Frankfurt exchange is keen to signal that it will continue to develop irrespective of the shifting background of rumoured alliances and mergers officials are keeping a close eye on developments - not least reports of a tie-up between the LSE and Nasdaq. Deutsche Börse has also held its own talks with OM - though they are understood to have focused on possible developments in specific areas and not on a closer relationship at the corporate level.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The likelihood of MG Rover remaining a volume car manufacturer is being thrown into fresh doubt by banks which are warning component suppliers in the West Midlands that funds will be cut if they continue to rely on the car maker for business. Engineering companies clustered around the Longbridge plant in Birmingham have traditionally focused production on the giant plant, funding their operations through overdrafts with high street banks. But banks have made it clear that they consider this strategy too risky and will continue funding only companies which diversify away from Rover. Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, wants to seal a merger with Germany's IG Metall to create a pan-European union representing more than 3m manufacturing workers.

Mail on Sunday

Sainsbury is just days away from signing a deal to sell its Homebase DIY chain - for far less than it had hoped. Sainsbury initially hoped to make up to £1.2bn on the sale of its 300 Homebase outlets. But now new chief executive Sir Peter Davis is expected to get between £700m and £800m in a deal with venture capital group Schroder Ventures.

Sunday Times

Talks between British Airways and the Australian government could lead the way to the British airline taking effective control of Qantas in a £450m deal. The mystery bidder for the Alfred McAlpine housebuilding and construction group is Gerald Ronson's Heron International. Nine days ago Oliver Whitehead, McAlpine's chief executive, said the company had rejected an approach valuing it at £244m, or 235p a share. English rugby union officials are expected to raise as much as £250m from the latest auction of television rights for the game.

Sunday Telegraph

Thomson Multimedia, the world's fourth largest consumer electronics business, which is part owned by Microsoft, has emerged as the surprise buyer of Technicolor, the film technology and duplication business being sold by Carlton Communications for £1.5bn. Telewest, Britain's largest cable communications company, has abandoned plans to offer local telephone services using BT's wires amidst mounting concern in the industry over delay's in ending BT's local monopoly. Le Creuset, the French cookware maker, is poised to fall into British ownership. Bridgepoint, the City private equity firm, is in talks to buy the company in a deal worth up to $200m.

Sunday Business

Athletics is back on the agenda for Wembley stadium after the Football Association decided to scrap its current plans and start again from scratch. Littlewoods is expected to announce about 200 job losses and the closure of 35 stores when it unveils a massive fall in first half profits on Tuesday.

IoS David Heathcote-Amory, the shadow trade secretary and one of the rising stars on William Hague's front bench, has pledged to restructure BT radically if the Conservatives win the next election.

Reports out this week

fields.bodyText: Observer The likelihood of MG Rover remaining a volume car manufacturer is being thrown into fresh doubt by banks which are warning component suppliers in the West Midlands that funds will be cut if they continue to rely on the car maker for business. Engineering companies clustered around the Longbridge plant in Birmingham have traditionally focused production on the giant plant, funding their operations through overdrafts with high street banks. But banks have made it clear that they consider this strategy too risky and will continue funding only companies which diversify away from Rover. Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, wants to seal a merger with Germany's IG Metall to create a pan-European union representing more than 3m manufacturing workers. Mail on Sunday Sainsbury is just days away from signing a deal to sell its Homebase DIY chain - for far less than it had hoped. Sainsbury initially hoped to make up to £1.2bn on the sale of its 300 Homebase outlets. But now new chief executive Sir Peter Davis is expected to get between £700m and £800m in a deal with venture capital group Schroder Ventures. Sunday Times Talks between British Airways and the Australian government could lead the way to the British airline taking effective control of Qantas in a £450m deal. The mystery bidder for the Alfred McAlpine housebuilding and construction group is Gerald Ronson's Heron International. Nine days ago Oliver Whitehead, McAlpine's chief executive, said the company had rejected an approach valuing it at £244m, or 235p a share. English rugby union officials are expected to raise as much as £250m from the latest auction of television rights for the game. Sunday Telegraph Thomson Multimedia, the world's fourth largest consumer electronics business, which is part owned by Microsoft, has emerged as the surprise buyer of Technicolor, the film technology and duplication business being sold by Carlton Communications for £1.5bn. Telewest, Britain's largest cable communications company, has abandoned plans to offer local telephone services using BT's wires amidst mounting concern in the industry over delay's in ending BT's local monopoly. Le Creuset, the French cookware maker, is poised to fall into British ownership. Bridgepoint, the City private equity firm, is in talks to buy the company in a deal worth up to $200m. Sunday Business Athletics is back on the agenda for Wembley stadium after the Football Association decided to scrap its current plans and start again from scratch. Littlewoods is expected to announce about 200 job losses and the closure of 35 stores when it unveils a massive fall in first half profits on Tuesday. webTitle: Compete with the forecasters

fields.headline: Compete with the forecasters
fields.trailText: Once again we invite talented amateurs to pit their wits against the professionals in our annual economics forecasting competition.
fields.body:
Once again we invite talented amateurs to pit their wits against the professionals in our annual economics forecasting competition.

Send in your estimates of the shape of the economy in 2001 and you could win £500 worth of book tokens from Palgrave - a leading publisher of academic and professional books - as well as the traditional magnum of champagne and the chance to have lunch with the Guardian's economics team.

We are looking for the most accurate forecast of key economic indicators: growth, interest rates, underlying inflation, unemployment, the current account and the exchange rate. Your forecast should contain six elements:

 Annual percentage growth in GDP in 2001

 Bank base lending rate on December 31 2001

 Inflation, excluding mortgage repayments, December 2001

 Total unemployed in December 2001 on the seasonally adjusted claimant count

 The UK current account in 2001 (in pounds, not as a % of GDP)

 The pound's value against the euro, or how much one euro will buy, on December 31 2001

The entries will be marked as follows:

You can score a maximum of 50 points for each question, giving 300 points for a perfectly correct entry.

For the first three questions we will deduct five marks for every 0.1 percentage point difference between the outcome and your answer.

For question four we will deduct five marks for every 50,000 difference between the claimant count total and your answer.

For question five, we will deduct five marks for every £250,000 gap between the outturn for the current account and your answer.

For question six, for every penny difference between your prediction and the value of sterling against the euro you will lose one mark.

Send your answers on the back of a postcard to: Guardian Economics Competition, Economics Desk, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

This year, for the first time, you can send in your entries by email by clicking on the special link at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/economy.

Online entries will be in the running to win an extra prize - a Palgrave economics dictionary.

The usual Guardian competition rules apply and the deadline for entries is February 1.

Winners will be decided when the first estimate of 2001 GDP is available, in early 2002.

webTitle: Obituaries: Bill Baker

fields.headline: Bill Baker
fields.trailText: Churchy, anti-Europe and rightwing, Bill Baker, who has died aged 80, was Conservative MP for Banffshire from 1964-74.
fields.body:
Churchy, anti-Europe and rightwing, Bill Baker, who has died aged 80, was Conservative MP for Banffshire from 1964-74. He fought Prime Minister Edward Heath in 1971 over what he considered to be a sellout to the EEC over fishing subsidies for his constituents. He also called for a slowing down of school building as a way to curb national spending, opposed divorce reform and Sunday trading, and defended the 39 Articles.

His family was steeped in the Church of England; he was a lay preacher and his stepfather and two brothers-in-law were vicars. A tall, long-faced but engaging man, he was neither a headline-snatcher nor a Commons orator, preferring to argue his case in the privacy of the 1922 Committee.

Baker lost his seat in the February 1974 election, when, in the wake of the miners' strike, enough Labour voters switched to the SNP candidate, Hamish Watt, to give the nationalists their first real breakthrough.

Born in Dorset, Baker lost his father at 10, his mother remarrying a parson. He was educated at Hardye's school and Nottingham University, where he began to study medicine before joining the Queen's Own Dorset Yeomanry in 1939. Commissioned into the Royal Artillery when war broke out, his military career seemed at an end when his motorcycle crashed. However, he recovered, joined the 1st Airborne, landing in France in a glider after D-Day, and went on to fight at Arnhem. He was demobbed a major.

Resuming his studies at Edinburgh University, he emerged with a BSc in agriculture, which he capped with agricultural economics at Cornell University, New York state. These skills were useful in managing the Aberdeenshire and Banffshire farms belonging to the family of his wife, Kathleen. They later bought a 236-acre farm at Rothiemay, replete with Georgian mansion.His interest in politics was brushed-off by the sitting Tory MP, ageing Sir William Duthie; even after he was selected in 1962, Duthie dismissed him as a "political theorist".

In retirement, Baker moved first to the Channel Islands to deal in stamps, and then to Paignton, Devon, where he worked in the local job centre. His marriage to Kathleen was dissolved in 1976, and she died in 1987. He is survived by his second wife, Jean, and the son and two daughters of his first marriage.

Willfred 'Bill' Harold Kerton Baker, politician, born January 6 1920; died November 9 2000

webTitle: Diary: Luke Harding @ Dharamsala

fields.headline: email
fields.trailText: With its Tibetan bakeries and congenial muesli breakfast parlours, Dharamsala is arguably the most pleasant place in the world to be an exile.
fields.body:
With its Tibetan bakeries and congenial muesli breakfast parlours, Dharamsala is arguably the most pleasant place in the world to be an exile. The former Raj hill resort, in the foothills of the Himalayas in northern India, has long attracted refugees - most famously, of course, the Dalai Lama, who came here in 1959 after fleeing Tibet.

He lives in a green-roofed bungalow, opposite the Tibetan temple, just down the road from the Om Hotel. These days getting an audience with His Holiness is a tricky business, such is his popularity, but if you are persistent it can still be arranged.

Since escaping from Chinese oppression, the Dalai Lama has been joined by thousands of other Tibetans, many of whom have moved to Dharamsala merely to get a glimpse of him. The town is now an important centre of Buddhist learning.

It is also one of the most popular tourist destinations in north India, where backpackers can be heard mumbling to each other over waffles: "I'm not a tourist really, it's more of a spiritual thing." Some of them end up wearing red and maroon robes, shaving their heads, and embracing Buddhism. In the evenings, they gravitate to Dharamsala's many internet cafes.

Dharamsala is not really one town but two. The upper part, McLeod Ganj, is named after a former British governor of the Punjab, David McLeod. Most travellers end up here. During the monsoon, the dirt track which connects McLeod Ganj with Dharamsala lower down the valley turns into sludge. In winter it is a pleasant 20-minute walk past good-natured beggars and old Tibetan women whirling prayer wheels.

Next to the Dalai Lama's temple, I bumped into Ani Tshampa Drimay - a twice-divorced, 59-year-old German former actress who decided to become a Buddhist nun two years ago. "In my previous incarnation I was a Tibetan," she explained. "My daughters are very happy for me. I never felt at home in Germany."

Nearby, a group of young Tibetan monks were waiting for His Holiness to appear. "I walked for 35 days across the Himalayas. There were 25 of us. I wanted to meet the Dalai Lama," said Dogon Rimpoche, from Tibet's Amdo province. "I left after the death of my father. He was Chinese," he added.

It is not just backpackers who feel Dharamsala's spiritual allure. Hollywood, too, has its celebrity devotees. Richard Gere visits every March, when the Dalai Lama gives a week-long open seminar. Last March he brought Goldie Hawn with him. Pierce Brosnan also dropped in recently.

Inside the temple, elderly yellow-robed lamas from all four of Tibet's schools of Buddhism were banging cymbals and tingling bells. Halfway through the ceremony a living oracle - an old monk wearing an enormous headdress - was brought staggering before His Holiness. The oracle whispered some predictions in the Dalai Lama's ear before being dragged away. A succession of objects was then paraded for blessing: holy texts in orange boxes, dozens of small Buddha statues (one of whose arms fell off) and what looked suspiciously like a carpet. Despite China's best efforts, Tibet lives on.

On the outskirts of town another group of exiles can be found - the dead colonial British. Next to the church of St John in the Wilderness, the Earl of Elgin, a viceroy who died in 1863, is buried. His Victorian tomb looks out through a vista of pine trees on to the shimmering plains below. It is appropriate that Lord Elgin should have ended up here - he ordered the sack of Beijing in his previous job and tried to teach the rebellious Chinese a lesson by burning down their summer palace.

Inside the Victorian church, a plaque records how another British adventurer "was eaten by a bear in the woods around Dharamsala" in 1883.
