webTitle: Obituaries: Frank Roper

fields.headline: Frank Roper
fields.standfirst: Sculptor entranced by ancient subjects and modern materials
fields.trailText: Sculptor entranced by ancient subjects and modern materials
fields.body:
Frank Roper, who has died aged 85, was a versatile and prolific sculptor. His work included surreal beasts, fantastical machines and important church commissions, among them his lettered panel for the tomb of Bede at Durham Cathedral (1970), the lady chapel screen at St David's Cathedral, Pembrokeshire (1973) and his Crucifixion at Peterborough Cathedral (1974). With his wife, Nora Ellison, he made architectural glass, including a comprehensive scheme for St Peter's Church, Chippenham (1968).

It was a reflection of the arcane fascination of his occupation and his vital personality that he became the subject of two BBC films: Mind Into Metal (1964), and, 12 years later, a programme in the documentary series Look, Stranger.

Roper was born at Haworth, Yorkshire, where his grandfather had a stone-carving shop. He and Nora met in 1933 while studying at Keighley art school, and went on to the Royal College of Art together. During the war, Roper helped design tanks and minesweepers for the Ministry of Defence. In 1947, after appointments at art colleges in Lincoln and Sheffield, he became vice-principal at Cardiff College of Art, where he was an outstandingly supportive and encouraging tutor. Though he thought of teaching as "a temporary measure", he stayed on until 1973, when he retired to be "free to play my own games".

Throughout and beyond his teaching career, Roper was a tireless practitioner. He attracted numerous commissions, and established a foundry on the ground floor of his Penarth house - relegating his family to the upstairs rooms. His longtime assistant, Maurice Carey, recalls that even in his 80s, Roper was unstoppable in his passion to make.

Like many artists in the 1950s and 60s, he benefited indirectly from the bomb damage wreaked on churches during the second world war. The thirst for an artistic language expressive of the postwar optimism also enabled him to use new materials and idioms.

In the 1950s, he became interested in aluminium, inventing the process of lost-polystyrene casting; his deft transformations, with sandpaper and soldering irons, became a signature. Perhaps his most exciting period was his collaboration through the 1960s with the architect George Pace, which resulted in a series of commissions for the bombed Llandaff Cathedral, in company with Jacob Epstein and John Piper.

Roper's bronze panels of Welsh flowers mounted on the medieval reredos of the lady chapel (1964) is one of his most touching works. His figure sculptures are expressively distorted, showing deep sympathy with medieval art, as well as admiration for Henry Moore. His wall-mounted Stations of the Cross, at St Martin's in Cardiff (1959), are emotionally charged, the modelling recalling Grünewald's agony rather than more beatific passion. His gilt aluminium reredos of the Last Supper at St Martin-le-Grand, York (1968), was thought too avant-garde, and relegated to the west end of the building. Church authorities were his one abiding horror.

Outside these ecclesiastical commissions, Roper worked incessantly, making mythic figures and animated constructions - for example, water clocks, musical fountains which forced air through reeds, and a walking lion automaton. In the late 1970s, he collaborated with Karlheinz Stockhausen on 12 zodiac sculptures incorporating music boxes. His own favourite piece was a small, sensitive figure of a bishop in full carapace of mitre and regalia. A version purchased by the Contemporary Art Society for Wales is in the national library, Aberystwyth.

Roper's works were regularly exhibited with the Howard Roberts gallery, the South Wales Group, the Welsh Arts Council and the Royal Academy. He was an associate of the Royal College of Art and the Royal Society of British Sculptors. In 1990, he was made an OBE.

Roper was a man of entrancing contradictions: a modernist whose work absorbed tradition, deeply conservative but a vivid individualist. His working days were hard and hazardous, but, like Magritte, he dressed at all times in collar and tie. He attracted and amused a wide circle of friends, and relished sharing sculptural toys with his daughters and grandchildren.

Given its ubiquity in churches, Roper's work remained surprisingly little-known, a fact which perhaps reflects his humility in placing the function of devotion above expression of the artist's personality. Writing of his work at Llandaff, he referred to Pace's suggestion, "that I should seek inspiration by putting my head into a thorn bush, a painful operation intended to prevent my formalising, or inflicting my conventions on the subject".

Last year, after Nora died, Roper designed a memorial to her of simple cast letters fixed to a sea-worn stone, at Lavernock church, near Penarth. When he himself became terminally ill with cancer, he designed the letters for his own matching memorial. With due caution, he had both a zero and a one cast as the last digit of his dates, and took wry delight in the sweepstakes started at the foundry as to which one would be needed.

He leaves his daughters, Penny and Rachel.

fields.headline: Lack of four sites?
fields.standfirst:
Express websites are likely to be axed or dragged downmarket under the group's new owner, says Mark Oliver

<A HREF="http://www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/netnews"Net news
fields.trailText: Express websites are likely to be axed or dragged downmarket under the group's new owner, says Mark Oliver.
fields.body:
For the 40 employees still trooping in each day to work for Express Digital Media's remaining four websites, the future is bleak. Following last month's £125m takeover of the newspaper group by Richard Desmond, publisher of OK! and various adult magazines, staff have been put on 30 day's notice.

In letters delivered to them last week the closure of the sites was described as "likely", and although there are still three weeks of the "consultation period" left, some staff expect the axe to fall before then.

Ian Monk, a spokesman for Desmond, says the sites are "desperately unprofitable", heading for a loss this year of £8m. Refusing to say whether there had been approaches to buy any of the sites, he says: "There are options which have been put forward, which include redevelopment or closure as we seek ways of making them more profitable. Should the sites be closed, every attempt will be made to find staff new roles within the group."

The new owners, Northern and Shell, publisher of porn magazines including Asian Babes, has its own "major internet strategy" under new media director Matthew Bugden, says Monk, and the OK! site will be "considerably redeveloped".

"Newspapers in general are examining again what the internet can do for them. The Guardian and Associated Newspapers are very keen, but if you look at the Sun and News International, you will see they are scaling down their interest," Monk says.

Tony Cuthbertson, director of Express Digital Media, rejects the claim that high costs and advertising revenues of only around £240,000 a year meant the websites - except for lads' site MegaStar, which Lord Hollick's United News & Media has retained - were already dead ducks. "All the sites had business plans in place, and all the funding had been agreed," he says, stressing that advertising revenue would increase.

Of Express Digital Media's four sites, the Express website, SportLive, All about parents and Company-Leader, the last two have been up and running for less than four months.

Reflecting relative optimism before the takeover, SportLive was in the process of hiring a new journalist as the surprise arrival of Desmond was being played out. "They offered me the job knowing the Express was going to be sold, but they thought they were all going to stay with United," says the journalist. "They were completely shocked - they had been given budgets and were looking to expand. They were planning for the future, and aiming to do more of their own content."

Similarly, Neil Harley-Rudd, of design consultancy UK Media, had been invited to redesign the Express websites just before the takeover speculation reached its zenith late last month. "I had a message from the internet editor asking me to do it, but then, from emails I received, it seemed to get less of a sure thing and I've not heard anything since," he says.

While Cuthbertson stresses that "all the sites are still up and running, with all their features, and they are being updated as normal", one former Express employee is less positive. "There is a lot of fear and morale has gone through the floor," he says. "The root cause is that United got online very late into a crowded market and didn't invest enough.

"There is also the theory that the Express was not a big enough brand for the internet market. It had a low internet conversion of its readers. The main site has not been going two years and the two which are less than four months old have never had a chance. But the foundations of the whole operation were wrong, and always seemed muddled. The Express site began under LineOne, the internet service provider that United owned with BT, and now has up for sale."

A former employee of Express Digital Media says: "At first, the Express site was within LineOne and really just provided it with news content until this spring. Only later did it start to become a proper site in its own right, although it looks like those plans will not come to fruition.

"It was only quite late this year that SportLive and MegaStar were given any significant funding. They were a tremendous team doing a very good job, but with no resources. Allaboutparents and Company-Leader were vertical sites, modelled on Guardian Unlimited, with the idea being to put the various strengths of the paper onto the net, but they have just not had a chance. You can't justifiably shut them down on the question of profitability.

"I can't believe the Express is going to be the only newspaper without an internet site, which is now such an important part of the brand development of a paper."

Hugo Drayton, the Telegraph's new media managing director, agrees that the muddle of the framework behind the sites did not help. "They had too many disparate things going on," he says. "Other, more successful sites had better strategies. Websites are an easy target because they are usually nobody's fiefdom. They do not offer any short-term return. The owners are doing what anyone new does - looking at where they can trim and cut down duplication. That said, from what I have read and heard they were not operating as viable propositions anyway.

"But I will be very surprised if they did not reopen something in the next six months, an online and newspaper strategy which complement one another."

That Desmond is taking a cost-minimising approach to the internet is perhaps reflected in his response to a request to find a replacement for the outgoing health editor. "Why do we need a health reporter? Get it off the internet, it's free," he is reported to have said.

Within the newspaper stable, it is the Star which is more profitable than the Express, and on the internet, MegaStar emerged as the strongest Express site. Some may argue that glamour and the lower end of the market are what Desmond knows best, but Lord Hollick kept MegaStar, which has just benefited from a £3m advertising campaign. Since the start of that campaign, the number of individual users has grown by 40,000 to 330,000 and monthly page impressions now average 18.7m.

Drayton says he would not be surprised if the group's internet future was more downmarket. "Pornography and gambling are two things which often lead new technology, and did so with audio text phoneline services and then the internet as forerunners for more acceptable sites," he says. "Desmond will no doubt have learnt from the experience of the adult sites".

A recent survey claims that 36% of home internet users are more interested in porn than sports or news - something that will not be news to Richard Desmond.

webTitle: Media Guardian: New media diary

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • At the Boobnight Christmas party and annual awards ceremony, the invited guests were raucous to say the least and free booze was abused along with the dance floor, the door man and the award winners.
fields.body:
 At the Boobnight Christmas party and annual awards ceremony, the invited guests were raucous to say the least and free booze was abused along with the dance floor, the door man and the award winners.

Punter in receipt of most abuse was Tim Lowes from Associated New Media who picked up the award for sexiest man in new media. The crowd waited with baited breath, only to see an Ian Beale lookalike step up to collect the award.

Other recipients of audience heckling were Tara Lloyd-Jones of Engage, who picked up the award for best dressed person to cries of "she could have made more of an effort".

Theft of the night went to Matt Teeman from beeb.com who beat the lovely Stevey 'Dubya' Wing from Guardian Unlimited to the grand prix of media owner of the year. With only 13 votes in it, clearly Teeman's hardcore canvassing and campaign manager helped solicit the win.

A blushing Jo Cox of Real Media fame was crowned as the sexiest woman for the second year and direct marketing whizz Nero Shayvard from Gecko triumphed with 60% of the vote for personality of the year. Next year expect a long, drawn out canvassing period, hustings and maybe even the odd "vote for Nero" banner. Can't wait.

 Christmas has warmed the cold, cold hearts of sarcastic e-commerce outlet ntkmart.com, which has coughed up three of its notorious "I got £80m for my dot.com idea - and all I have left is this lousy T-shirt" T-shirts, to give to Media Guardian readers.

What do you have to do to get one of these must-wear sartorial lovelies? Simple. Just complete the phrase "You know your dot.com is doomed when ... " in a witty or heart-wrenching way. The more amusing, the better.

Winners will be announced in next week's diary. Prizes should be received just in time to provoke fights and/or bouts of uncontrollable weeping at office parties. Entries to the usual address.

 The truth is out. Microsoft duped us all last week when it said 9m people logged onto the Madonna webcast. It's the oldest trick in the book: throw around the term hits to confuse mainstream media and let the rest of the media copy the figures.

Time to set the record straight: a hit is not an accurate gauge of anything other than server demand and is certainly not a page impression or a unique user figure. In all likelihood, if there were 9m hits for the webcast, that could mean that only 1m people (if that) actually viewed the concert.

The average web page contains about seven hits and the page impressions can generally be divided by about 10% to estimate the average number of unique users. Using this metric would come up with just 130,000 users, and who's to say that all of them could actually view the webcast once they got there?

webTitle: Media Guardian: Media Monkey

fields.headline: Media Monkey
fields.trailText: • Monkey apologises for misleading readers last week. Channel 4 chief Michael Jackson was not at Madonna's gig of the year. But neither was he at the C4-sponsored Turner prize event - a witness reliably places Jackson at dinner at 11 Downing Street. Monkey is very sorry for confusing Ms Ciccone with Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
 Monkey apologises for misleading readers last week. Channel 4 chief Michael Jackson was not at Madonna's gig of the year. But neither was he at the C4-sponsored Turner prize event - a witness reliably places Jackson at dinner at 11 Downing Street. Monkey is very sorry for confusing Ms Ciccone with Gordon Brown.

 BSkyB execs at last week's RTS rubber-chicken-fest were surprised to escape a broadside from speaker Stuart Prebble, chief exec of ONdigital. After all, the OFT had just given Prebble a big stick with which to beat BSkyB - the investigation of its maligned pay-TV supply deals with the likes of ONdigital. Could Prebbo's reticence have anything to do with his rumoured impending move to ITV's digital channels, where the first item in his in-tray will be a distribution deal with Sky Digital?

 Before they'd even recovered from moving to new premises in Docklands, Independent staffers discovered that the windows of O'Reilly towers bear the alarming message: "Danger - do not open". Because Street-Porter underlings might hurl themselves out? Nope, the panes are not properly stuck in - as one unfortunate, desperate for air, discovered when the window fell out and landed on the floor.

 On arriving at the new Indy HQ, it's said, Simon Kelner's deputy Ian Birrell discovered that the office of Tristan Davies, features chief and Birrell's rival for the portly editor's ear, was a couple of feet bigger. Intolerable! Birrell's bunker was immediately extended.

 So who is to replace the Rev Ernest Rea, stepping down as the BBC's head of religion as the churches unleash an anti-Beeb crusade over its perceived failure to take spiritual matters seriously? Some insiders tip Justin Phillips, a Christian and head of BBC Heritage, but they're hardly lining up. A case of let this cup pass?

webTitle: Media Guardian: Roy Greenslade on inaccurate reporting

fields.headline: On the press
fields.trailText: Without phoning a friend, try this quiz. What do these stories which appeared in papers on November 30 suggest about education secretary David Blunkett's statements at an Institute for Public Policy Research seminar?
fields.body:
Without phoning a friend, try this quiz. What do these stories which appeared in papers on November 30 suggest about education secretary David Blunkett's statements at an Institute for Public Policy Research seminar?

1. Daily Express, under a picture of a boy laying flowers at the spot where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor died: "Cabinet minister David Blunkett yesterday condemned the money-mad culture exemplified by TVs Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?"

2. Daily Star, under the headline "Blunkett 'blames quiz show'", said he was "at the centre of a storm last night when he appeared to link Damilola's death to TV quiz show Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?"

3. The Independent, in a story which nosed off on the Damilola killing, claimed that Blunkett "singled out" the quiz for "cultivating a popular culture reminiscent of the yuppy era".

4. The Times, again in its Damilola story, quoted Blunkett as criticising the programme.

There is no prize because the answer is obvious. Blunkett clearly made a link between the boy's murder and the TV programme. The papers said so. It must be true. Yet it was far from the truth.

Before his prepared speech, Blunkett did indeed refer to Damilola's killing, urging the creation of a society in which people don't walk on by when confronted by trouble. He then delivered his prepared text about the relationship between government and people, before a question-and-answer session.

The first question was about the influence of consumer capitalism to which Blunkett replied: "In the 80s, yuppyism was seen as being the end of civilisation. We are back to Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? now. The people who produce programmes have a pretty low view of the rest of the world." This somewhat flip, but quite reasonable, response had nothing whatsoever to do with Blunkett's views on the murder of Damilola.

Yet the Press Association report wired to newspapers made just that link. By juxtaposing his remarks on Damilola with those on the TV quiz, it looked as if he was suggesting that the programme was somehow responsible for the killing.

Alerted to the error during the afternoon, Blunkett's office contacted PA and urged the agency to amend its report. It later did so, filing a substitute story which deleted references to Damilola.

By now, a reporter had also contacted the show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, to obtain his comments. But these, of course, were based on the false assumption of Blunkett's linkage between the death and the show. To make matters worse, PA's substitute was not accompanied by a note ordering the previous story to be killed, so some newspapers didn't realise that Blunkett's remarks were not linked.

PA news editor Jonathan Grun says: "Directly we realised there should be no linkage we issued a new story. Blunkett's office seemed happy with that, which is why we didn't add an advisory note. Our watchwords here are 'accuracy and fairness'. The quotes were accurate. But we are happy to accept that it wasn't Mr Blunkett's intention to have his comments linked."

But IPPR director Matthew Taylor, who chaired the seminar, thought the PA story "highly tendentious". Quite apart from the false link, the millionaire remark was an off-the-cuff reply to a question. Not a single word of Blunkett's thought-provoking speech was reported. If the story had come and gone, perhaps none of this would have mattered. Instead, as is common now in a journalistic world dominated by columnists rather than reporters, Blunkett was subjected to days of ill-informed comment.

The Sun's Richard Littlejohn was vicious. The Daily Telegraph's Alice Thomson, the Daily Express's Martin Samuels, the News of the World's Michael Winner and the Sunday People's Sue Crawford all took Blunkett to task for making a link he had not made. Even a special PA note to editors which stated that it "would like to make clear" that the remarks were not linked was evidently ignored.

Days later, Mick Hume in the Times was still criticising Blunkett. By now, it had featured also in the rest of the media, on BBC TV's Question Time and Radio 4's Today. Regional papers, such as the Scotsman - which accused Blunkett of "moralistic waffle" - had also weighed in.

Never truer was that maxim about a lie being halfway round the world before the truth is out. Though some papers, such as the Times, later ran apologies and several others carried letters, it is highly likely that most people still believe Blunkett blamed Damilola's murder on a gameshow.

Even if the error began at PA, it would be wrong to view the agency as the sole villain. This attitude about what constitutes a story stems from the current journalistic culture. It demeans all of us who work in newspapers.

Perhaps it would be carrying things too far to claim that falling journalistic standards are one of the reasons for declining sales. Anyway, whatever the reason, they continued their downward path again last month, as our chart below illustrates. It is noticeable though that broadsheet papers are doing much better than the tabloids. Despite slight losses by the Daily Telegraph and the Times, the overall picture for serious daily papers is bright.

It is too early yet to tell whether the new ownership of the Daily Express and Daily Star is having an impact, but the scale of Richard Desmond's task is clear. The Express sold only 823,432 copies at its full cover price in November compared to 2.2m sold by the Daily Mail. Of the Sundays, the figure that stands out is undoubtedly the Observer, up by 7.58% year on year. It needs to curb its quota of bulk sales, but these pale in comparison with the Independent on Sunday's 40,000-plus which account for more than 15% of its total.

One final note about the two Sunday sports papers which have done so well. Sport First enjoyed its fifth successive sales increase, up to 85,775 copies. The Non-League Paper also sold a creditable 42,216.

Yet the Press Association report wired to newspapers made just that link. By juxtaposing his remarks on Damilola with those on the TV quiz, it looked as if he was suggesting that the programme was somehow responsible for the killing. Alerted to the error during the afternoon, Blunkett's office contacted PA and urged the agency to amend its report. It later did so, filing a substitute story which deleted references to Damilola. By now, a reporter had also contacted the show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, to obtain his comments. But these, of course, were based on the false assumption of Blunkett's linkage between the death and the show. To make matters worse, PA's substitute was not accompanied by a note ordering the previous story to be killed, so some newspapers didn't realise that Blunkett's remarks were not linked. PA news editor Jonathan Grun says: "Directly we realised there should be no linkage we issued a new story. Blunkett's office seemed happy with that, which is why we didn't add an advisory note. Our watchwords here are 'accuracy and fairness'. The quotes were accurate. But we are happy to accept that it wasn't Mr Blunkett's intention to have his comments linked." But IPPR director Matthew Taylor, who chaired the seminar, thought the PA story "highly tendentious". Quite apart from the false link, the millionaire remark was an off-the-cuff reply to a question. Not a single word of Blunkett's thought-provoking speech was reported. If the story had come and gone, perhaps none of this would have mattered. Instead, as is common now in a journalistic world dominated by columnists rather than reporters, Blunkett was subjected to days of ill-informed comment. The Sun's Richard Littlejohn was vicious. The Daily Telegraph's Alice Thomson, the Daily Express's Martin Samuels, the News of the World's Michael Winner and the Sunday People's Sue Crawford all took Blunkett to task for making a link he had not made. Even a special PA note to editors which stated that it "would like to make clear" that the remarks were not linked was evidently ignored. Days later, Mick Hume in the Times was still criticising Blunkett. By now, it had featured also in the rest of the media, on BBC TV's Question Time and Radio 4's Today. Regional papers, such as the Scotsman - which accused Blunkett of "moralistic waffle" - had also weighed in. Never truer was that maxim about a lie being halfway round the world before the truth is out. Though some papers, such as the Times, later ran apologies and several others carried letters, it is highly likely that most people still believe Blunkett blamed Damilola's murder on a gameshow. Even if the error began at PA, it would be wrong to view the agency as the sole villain. This attitude about what constitutes a story stems from the current journalistic culture. It demeans all of us who work in newspapers. Perhaps it would be carrying things too far to claim that falling journalistic standards are one of the reasons for declining sales. Anyway, whatever the reason, they continued their downward path again last month, as our chart below illustrates. It is noticeable though that broadsheet papers are doing much better than the tabloids. Despite slight losses by the Daily Telegraph and the Times, the overall picture for serious daily papers is bright. It is too early yet to tell whether the new ownership of the Daily Express and Daily Star is having an impact, but the scale of Richard Desmond's task is clear. The Express sold only 823,432 copies at its full cover price in November compared to 2.2m sold by the Daily Mail. Of the Sundays, the figure that stands out is undoubtedly the Observer, up by 7.58% year on year. It needs to curb its quota of bulk sales, but these pale in comparison with the Independent on Sunday's 40,000-plus which account for more than 15% of its total. One final note about the two Sunday sports papers which have done so well. Sport First enjoyed its fifth successive sales increase, up to 85,775 copies. The Non-League Paper also sold a creditable 42,216. webTitle: Breathe ends its unmetered access

fields.headline: Breathe ends its unmetered access
fields.trailText: Breathe.com has ended its unmetered internet access service just two months before the sector is to be properly opened up.
fields.body:
Breathe.com has ended its unmetered internet access service just two months before the sector is to be properly opened up.

Breathe, an internet service provider, had offered unmetered access for a one-off payment of £50, but closed the service yesterday saying the business model was no longer viable.

It is unclear what will happen to the 50,000 users who have already signed and paid up, but they are unlikely to be reimbursed. The £2m this would cost would make a further dent in breathe.comÍs finances and make it harder to find the buyer it desperately needs to remain in business.

In an official announcement, the company said: "Developments in the wider unmetered access market indicate that the only sustainable model for such services is based around FRIACO (Flat Rate Internet Access and Call Origination). This imposes a regular monthly subscription fee on the ISP who, in turn, has to pass on this cost to end-users. This has resulted in a general market-wide correction of unmetered tariff offers now that the economics of such services have become clearer.

In short, it is not yet possible to offer internet access at the rates originally promoted by breathe.com. However, all this looks set to change in the New Year.

Last month, Oftel said it intended to require BT to provide other phone operators with a new wholesale flat rate internet access product from 1 February 2001. This new product, it said, would be a major enhancement of FRIACO. The current system takes unmetered internet traffic from the customer as far as BTÍs local exchange, leaving operators with the additional costs of transferring the calls onto their own network.

The new product will carry internet traffic on an unmetered basis from the consumerÍs home to the network of a competing operator.

Other newcomers to the ISP market say they will wait until this new system is in place before developing their own unmetered access packages.

webTitle: Pick of the week

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A giant radioactive tongue, a witty bad-day parable, footage the Beastie Boys let get away, and contemplating the beauty myth
fields.trailText: A giant radioactive tongue, a witty bad-day parable, footage the Beastie Boys let get away, and contemplating the beauty myth
fields.body:
Tongues and Taxis
(Sputnik 7)
Now that internet film festivals are as frequent as Florida ballot recounts (and as hotly contested) it can be hard to sort the taste-makers from the time-wasters. In a crowded field, digital film festival ResFest somehow manages to offer up a consistently classy and eclectic roster of new talent. Chief amongst them this year is animator Michael Overbeck whose ranting hymn to the stresses of city life, Tongue and Taxi, won their Audience Choice Award. In his twisted primary-coloured world, letting your mouth run away with itself takes on a whole new meaning, as a giant radioactive tongue goes on an urban rampage. Sneakily surreal and worth every vote cast for it. (KS)
 View the film (7 mins 30)

Brass Tacks
(Hypnotic.com)
Anyone who's ever fallen foul of a breadknife, an eviction order, a traffic warden or a girlfriend will warm to this bad-day parable. In two neighbouring apartments, a young man and an elderly woman both find their days going from bad to worse. When they both wind up in a neighbourhood bar to drown their sorrows, either one could be salvaged or savaged by the other. Find out how it shakes down in Richard Seyd's cunning May-December comedy, which uses a stiletto rather than a sledgehammer for its storytelling effects. (KS)
 View the film (15mins 22)

The Robot vs the Octopus monster saga
(www.Ifilm.com)
Fans of the Beastie Boys will already know this nine-minute short. It's been put together from outtakes of the video of the trio's global hit, Intergalactic. The plot is seriously thin; a breakdancing giant robot saves the world by beating up a giant octopus, with a bit of help from the Beasties. But Nathaniel Hornblower's (aka Adam Yauch) first short feature is more than just a music video - indeed the Intergalactic track makes it only as incidental music. A well observed, funky and laugh-out-loud funny pastiche. (SD)
 View the film (9 mins)


(www.beezlebugbit.com)
A young, lonely woman gets the ultimate makeover by combining the black arts with extreme piercing. Rendered in attractive black and white computer graphics, the film has a stylish look that works well on the web. As a musing on the beauty myth, its good intentions are let down by a lack of depth and plot development, but at only three minutes long, its makers have gone for style over substance.
 View the film (3 mins)

webTitle: Reviews: Theatre: On a Night Like This

fields.headline: John Godber shows his age
fields.trailText:
On a Night Like This
Hull Truck Theatre
****
fields.body:
On a Night Like This
Hull Truck Theatre
****

Is John Godber beginning to feel his age? For most playwrights, encroaching years are an opportunity to cultivate a long, white beard and become sage-like. But what if your career has been based on high-octane, knockabout physical comedy? Godber is the genial, big bloke whose work at Hull Truck single-handedly turned theatre into a contact sport. How do you keep that up when you feel a stiffening in the joints and the old knees giving in? What do you do when Bouncers loses its bounce and Shakers begins to look like a case of delirium tremens?

Apparently, you make a big prat of yourself on a bender round Hull. Without identifying Godber's latest creation too closely with its author, there is the bleak chill of lost vitality whistling through this play; and while it's hardly Prospero casting away his books, On a Night Like This feels like a farewell to Godber's early career.

It also suggests that the best of Godber is yet to come: indeed the older, wiser version promises to outstrip the pumped-up, occasionally ham-fisted earlier one. If On A Night _ feels like a young Turk waking up one morning to find himself inside a flabby, 40-year-old body, it is none the worse for it. This has all the best attributes of a night out at Hull Truck - great music, rowdy nightclub scenes, packed house laughing uproariously - but it also deals with a depth and poignancy of character far beyond the ebullient stereotypes of old.

Godber is much tougher on himself these days. Richard, disarmingly well played by James Hornsby, is an excoriating portrait of the artist as an old fart. Rather too comfortable in his nice house and nasty cardigan, Richard ends up with more than he bargained for when he gets the decorators in. This pair of stooges - Leo (Robert Angell), a bit of a hard-case, and Danny (Nick Lane), who has the pinched demeanour of a miserable ferret - are devotees of the Northern Soul scene and soon reconnect Richard with his hedonistic past.

A few years ago, Godber would have written only about one, hilariously embarrassing evening. Now he carries on until events take a distinctly sour turn in the early hours of the morning. Once you left Hull Truck with a spring in your step. After a Night Like This you grope out with fur on your tongue.

 Until January 13. Box office: 01482 323638.

webTitle: Reviews: Classical: Von Otter/Forsberg/Sparf

fields.headline: Von Otter/Forsberg/Sparf
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Wigmore Hall, London
****

The Wigmore Hall won't reach its 100th birthday until May, but with so much to celebrate it has decided to start early. The launch of its centenary festival was entrusted to one of its best-loved regulars, the Swedish mezzo soprano Anne Sofie von Otter, sharing the platform with her accompanist Bengt Forsberg and violinist Nils-Erik Sparf.

Although half of the programme was given over to pieces for violin and piano, it was effectively von Otter's recital. Her choice to give an entire concert of Sibelius, marking the Finnish composer's own 135th birthday, was intriguing - and rewarding. The revival of interest in Sibelius's orchestral music has not spread to his songs yet and the fact that he was a prolific composer of vocal music, with more than 100 songs to his credit, is still a well-kept secret.

Listening to these often vivid settings, it seemed incredible that Sibelius should need the kind of boost that von Otter has given to several Scandinavian composers in the past - presumably it's the language barrier that prevents more singers from including them in their repertoire. They are interesting because they link two distinct periods; the earlier songs especially are grounded in the Germanic Romantic tradition of Schumann, while later compositions look towards the more modern expanses of Sibelius's symphonic writing.

The same can be said for his pieces for violin and piano, and the innocence of works such as the 1888 B minor Romance threw the edginess of some of his later works, performed by Sparf with freshness and vigour, into sharp relief.

Von Otter's appeal in lieder is not just down to her warm, unaffected tone but to her ability to make the most thoughtful and considered performance seem flowing and spontaneous. As ever, she and Forsberg were utterly tuned in to each other. The Jewish Girl's Song, with von Otter singing a wistful, folk-like melody over the sparsest of piano accompaniments, was particularly spellbinding.

webTitle: The inside track: Socialising at work

fields.headline: The inside track: Socialising at work
fields.standfirst:
Industrial tribunals tend to find in favour of those sacked for misbehaviour at office parties. But let's hope it won't come to that.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Industrial tribunals tend to find in favour of those sacked for misbehaviour at office parties. But let's hope it won't come to that.
fields.body:
Sadly, the prospect of the annual Christmas party seems to fill the majority of us with foreboding. According to research by Office Angels, 57% of workers would rather not go to their office bash, but feel compelled to attend, fearing that their absence will damage their careers. Certainly, few have the courage shown by the chapel of the National Graphical Association at the Stockport Messenger, who demanded overtime for attending the firm's social functions. The outcome of the dispute had a certain seasonal flavour, however. Like Santa, they all got the sack.

Equally though, there is the fear that our very presence could end up doing our careers more damage than good. While you are unlikely to be sacked directly for any drunken antics, it is in the nature of management that it has to take unpleasant decisions from time to time. And when it comes to duff jobs, the Ghost of Christmas Past can easily come back to haunt you.

If you're one of the 41% of people who eagerly await the Christmas party as an opportunity for sycophancy, however, you should watch your step, too. Remember, people would rather they had the goods on you, than that you had the goods on them. Nobody likes a tell-tale, either, so resist the temptation to take the inside story of your department to those in authority. Similarly, discourage people from becoming indiscreet with you - however juicy the revelations. There is such a thing as knowing too much.

Above all remember that, if you decide not to go, you will give your colleagues a topic they can safely get their teeth into: your personal failings over the past 12 months. And, if you do go, bear in mind that nobody else wanted to come either. Try and cheer them up. After all, it is Christmas.

webTitle: Reviews: Pop: The Levellers

fields.headline: Levellers live on with the feelgood factor
fields.trailText:
The Levellers
Brixton Academy, London
****
fields.body:
The Levellers
Brixton Academy, London
****

There is a convincing argument that declares that rock tribalism is dead and we are all musical polymaths now, tucking into Craig David as easily as Limp Bizkit. Convincing it may be, but nobody has bothered to tell the Levellers, or their audience.

Often decried for seducing the dogs-on-string market while being able to afford Gucci collars for their own hounds, the Levellers are the voice of a lost, scuzzy generation: travellers, new hippies, old punks, eco-warriors and anyone bypassed by well-scrubbed, Big Tent society.

A Levellers concert is essentially an atheistic version of a religious experience, and when Mark Chadwick sings "I don't believe in heaven, I don't believe in hell" during The Game, he is merely preaching to the converted. Despite their collective facelessness, the quintet cannot disguise the fact that they are a fine pop band with an admirable line in succinct anthems, who - despite seeming likely to break into The Devil Went Down to Georgia at any moment - firmly uphold the English folk-protest tradition, with dollops of scarf-waving punk thrown in to placate the headbangers.

The anger - about capitalism, about drugs laws, about the police - at the heart of band and crowd, particularly on the Falklands epic Another Man's Cause, is tilting at long-demolished windmills and both parties know it. Yet it scarcely matters, for this is a good-natured occasion.

Oddly, the Levellers' current album, Hello Pig, is their best. Their new thoughtfulness - a cello solo decorates the gorgeous Edge of the World - suffers amid the heaving, drunken mass of humanity who know every word to every song, old or new. Yet, in 61 Minutes of Pleading, with its enormous chorus and storytelling verses, they have a song that could last them for decades if Jon Sevink's fiddle - often utilised where others field a lead guitar - takes them further down the Strawhead route that the Men They Couldn't Hang once travelled.

Despite the tribal bonds, the Levellers rarely banter with their clan. Chadwick's Mike Scott-like vocals bark their way through Hope Street, the Pogues-esque The Riverflow and The Boatman (curiously for such crowd-pleasers, the band omit their biggest hit, One Way), but bassist Jeremy Cunningham is the closest they come to a rock god: tattoos, waist-length dreadlocks and the invaluable knack of mounting an amp without looking stupid.

Unfashionable, marginalised and contradictory - the Levellers' moment has long past. Quality of song, power of performance and the feelgood factor, however, are timeless.

 The Levellers play De Montfort Hall, Leicester (0116 2333111) tonight, Northumbria University, Newcastle (0191-232 6002), tomorrow, then tour.

Their new thoughtfulness - a cello solo decorates the gorgeous Edge of the World - suffers amid the heaving, drunken mass of humanity who know every word to every song, old or new. Yet, in 61 Minutes of Pleading, with its enormous chorus and storytelling verses, they have a song that could last them for decades if Jon Sevink's fiddle - often utilised where others field a lead guitar - takes them further down the Strawhead route that the Men They Couldn't Hang once travelled. Despite the tribal bonds, the Levellers rarely banter with their clan. Chadwick's Mike Scott-like vocals bark their way through Hope Street, the Pogues-esque The Riverflow and The Boatman (curiously for such crowd-pleasers, the band omit their biggest hit, One Way), but bassist Jeremy Cunningham is the closest they come to a rock god: tattoos, waist-length dreadlocks and the invaluable knack of mounting an amp without looking stupid. Unfashionable, marginalised and contradictory - the Levellers' moment has long past. Quality of song, power of performance and the feelgood factor, however, are timeless.  The Levellers play De Montfort Hall, Leicester (0116 2333111) tonight, Northumbria University, Newcastle (0191-232 6002), tomorrow, then tour.

webTitle: Joining the dot.coms

fields.headline: Joining the dot.coms
fields.standfirst:
After 25 years as a PA, Julie Samuels decided to start up her own internet company. Like her, many support staff already have the relevant skills. But, as Kate Hilpern discovers, grit, patience and money play a part, too

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: After 25 years as a PA, Julie Samuels decided to start up her own internet company. Like her, many support staff already have the relevant skills. But, as Kate Hilpern discovers, grit, patience and money play a part, too
fields.body:
Last October, Julie Samuels gave up a 25-year career as a PA, with a vision of becoming a dot.com entrepreneur. Fed up of not being able to find a magazine aimed at secretaries that was constantly available, she decided to set up one herself on the internet.

"I'd been studying for a diploma and could never find a publication for PAs that I could count on being able to buy over the counter any day of the week," explains the 47-year-old from Manchester. "The more I discussed it with my family, the more obvious it became that such a magazine - accessible to everyone and free of charge - could provide all the tools that today's secretaries need to perform better in their daily work."

Samuels' brave transition into the online world was followed by a film crew for a documentary to be broadcast this week under the somewhat hopeful title Easy Money. However, far from showing her pile in the easy cash, the programme highlights the struggle of a project which for a long time lacked financial backers and true believers.

Throughout, though, she was never abandoned by her own secretarial skills which have been handy not only in developing the content of the website, but also "in moving into the domain of dot.coms in the first place". Today's secretaries are often three or four times as skilled as those of previous generations, she explains. "The top ones are highly proficient in research, organisation, IT and communication - the four key skills needed to start up an internet-based company."

Susan Saloom, who as manager of the Shell Live Wire Enterprise Unit has in the past two years helped more than 200,000 people start up their own business ventures, knows this all too well. Like all internet experts she will tell you that, while a good idea is the crucial first step, organising content, networking with contacts and discovering how it will all work on screen comes a close second. For many modern support staff, at least the basic skills needed to carry out these tasks have already been learned.

"The internet has advanced to such a point that the technological skills of secretaries is enough to get a sophisticated website up and running," agrees Mike Roberts, senior lecturer in entrepreneurial studies at Harvard Business School. But as a few dot.com casualties have already told us, the world wide web is a risky place to head with these skills alone - a lesson which Michelle Williams, a 29-year-old PA, learned all too quickly. Having attempted - and failed - to set up a website selling top-quality stationery, she cautions internet wannabes against hasty decisions. "I gave up a wonderful three-year secretarial job because I thought my skills were enough to become the next Martha Lane Fox. But in addition, you need masses of guts, determination, money and most of all, patience. If you don't have anything to live off while you're waiting, the months - and sometimes years - that it takes for your website to kick off, life can become very grim."

For 26-year-old Andrea Stock, and many other secretaries like her, the solution has been, "If you can't beat 'em, join 'em". Having been unsuccessful in getting her internet idea off the ground, she decided to jump on the bandwagon of someone else's. "As soon as I got a peep into the world of dot.com, I realised the informal, young and anti-hierarchical way of working would suit me perfectly, and that I didn't mind the instability and highly competitive environment. If I couldn't run my own business, I decided, it didn't mean I had to get out altogether and that's why I continued being a PA, but moved to working solely for web-site companies."

Because many internet start-ups are too small and young to invest in full-time secretaries, Stock temps. "I belong to a number of recruitment agencies, all of which know my preference towards internet companies," she says. "I'm happy because I get to work in companies where my level of responsibility is far higher than ever before. And the dot.com companies are happy because my knowledge of the internet world is already high, and growing all the time. These are businesses where, for the first time in my career, I get to use my skills to their full potential, and where I know they're appreciated."

Back at secretaryworld.com, Julie Samuels is only too aware that temps like Stock are becoming a fast increasing phenomenon. "Many PAs want to get involved in dot.coms because they realise they don't have to be at the start-up end, like me, to use it to their advantage. They realise that the lines between the roles in internet companies are more blurred than in traditional companies, and that as a result, they can enjoy higher status jobs."

Indeed, it is the changing role of secretaries within internet companies that is the reason Samuels refused to give up on her website even when every venture capitalist she approached for funding turned her down. "We're moving into a world in which a fast-growing number of managers are expecting more from their support staff every day, and so these secretaries need more help every day. That's what secretaryworld.com is all about."

Eventually realising she'd have to fund the project herself, Julie brought in a "technical expert" and a "contacts expert" and, together with her husband, they started the website aimed at all modern administrative workers. It includes information on relevant products, details on courses, advice on interview skills, summaries of news, suggestions on setting up better conferences, material on how to improve your financial skills, and more.

"I so often hear about modern secretaries who take instructions from the boss, only to leave their office thinking, 'How the hell can I do that? I don't know what he's talking about.' The expectations are out there, but the help hasn't been," says Samuels.

Together with the discussion forum, she hopes her website will become "a worldwide network for secretaries. If they can't find the information they need on our website, they'll be able to post a question and undoubtedly, a user somewhere will have the answers."

Dot.coms, she concludes, are changing the face of the millennial secretary in almost every way possible. "The net is causing the secretary's job to become more challenging. Managers are expecting more from them and, in turn, bosses in conventional organisations are following suit. But alongside that, the net is providing ways in which this transition can be made smoother - whether it's by enabling secretaries to be a better PA or, as in my case, enabling them to wind up running their own business."

 Easy Money is at 9pm, Dec 12, on Channel 4.

webTitle: Sec's tips for conference menus

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst:
15. Conference menus

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 15. Conference menus
fields.body:
There's no excuse for it. Giving conference delegates prawn cocktail, roast beef and Black Forest gateau is a sackable offence. An unimaginative menu can label your event as uninspiring as the food. How many times have you asked delegates how the conference went - expecting their views on the content, the speakers, or maybe the venue - only to be told, "the food was awful". About 68% of conference organisers contacted by meetings agency Banks Sadler ranked "quality of food" the third most important influence on a successful event, after "stimulating agenda" and "user-friendly conference room". So, how do you meet today's demand for magnificent menus?

 Keep your options open. Offering only meat or vegetarian menus isn't enough. The list of 20 minority menus - taken up by more than 10% of delegates - includes a wide range of preferences: no red meat, no dairy products, no shellfish, no veal or lobster, additive- and preservative-free dishes, dolphin-friendly tuna, and, increasingly, GM-free ingredients. Encourage the venue chef to prepare imaginative dishes for every taste, however small in scale. A good tip is to request menu ideas in advance, and insist on a pre-conference tasting (well, there have to be some perks).

 Be imaginative. Bland and stodgy food is unacceptable. The secret of achieving catering creativity is to liaise with the chef direct, and involve him or her personally. Explain your needs and invite the chef to give his own ideas.

 Agree a system with the banqueting staff to identify, but not patronise, those with special requests. Don't settle for waiters with plates wandering about, shouting, "Who's the vegetarian?" Colour-coded placings are more dignified.

 Discuss in detail with the venue the expected demographics of your conference - the broad categories of age, gender, seniority, and so on. The more information they have, the better they can target your delegates.

 Finally, think delegate care. Seventy-two hours of sitting in seminars, plus bouts of culinary excess, is not good for the hearts and minds of participants. The challenge is to make eating a highlight, not an exercise in forced-feeding. Thoroughly research opinions after each conference, and involve experts to ensure that your chosen meals lift morale and add a sparkle to your event.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Reviews: Opera: Verdi's Requiem

fields.headline: Verdi's Requiem lost in a war front
fields.trailText:
Verdi's Requiem
London Coliseum
*
fields.body:
Verdi's Requiem
London Coliseum
*

Emerging from English National Opera's production of Verdi's Requiem, I couldn't help but wonder if someone, somewhere, had lost the plot. It goes without saying that the piece was never intended for theatrical performance, but that doesn't seem to be a deterrent to a company that, as part of its Italian opera season, shoved on stage a film score during the course of which no one sings a note.

For all its popularity, the Requiem itself has produced a divergent ambiguity of response. It has been described as "dramatic" and "operatic", words that have frequently been flung at it indiscriminately, and that actually fall wide of the mark, since action, psychology and the vocal delineation of individualised characters form no part of its scope.

The work has also been seen as inherently irreligious. Verdi, an agnostic, took a dim view of organised religion, which he saw as inculcating fear. The God of the Requiem is a vengeful deity who doles out judgment and damnation in equal measure, terrorising humanity in the process.

This certainly is the starting point of Phyllida Lloyd's awkward production, which pits cowering mankind against an unseen destroyer who appears - if the gestures of the cast are anything to go by - to be located in the Coliseum's dress circle. The opening, to be fair, is rather good. The chorus sit in rows, heads bowed, as if in prayer, then rise to their feet during the Kyrie in gestures of defiance.

When the day of judgement is unleashed, however, things rapidly start to go wrong. The stage becomes a war zone as furniture is noisily flung about and the chorus huddle together in all-purpose dread. As we progress, the imagery becomes increasingly banal. The mezzo-soprano goes into what psychologists call "denial", ignoring her mortality by contemplating herself in the mirror of her powder compact. The chorus try to placate God with libations, which include a ballgown and a plant pot. Kids romp around the set in arbitrary unconcern with what is going on, and a heavily pregnant naked woman wanders on, presumably suggesting the origins of all life, which is about to be destroyed. By the time we get to the Lux Aeterna, the cast have stripped to their underwear and spend their time lighting candles.

All this is depressing, but musically the evening is a nightmare. No one seems to have taken into account the fact that Verdi's compositional technique differed depending upon whether he was writing for the theatre or not. Within five minutes of the kick-off, it's painfully apparent that the balance is rendered redundant when the orchestra is in a pit and the singers are on stage. The chorus sing it with brave ferocity, but can't disguise the fact that the polyphony blurs when the individual vocal groups are jumbled together. Paul Daniel, conducting, can't hold the resulting miasma together, and the soloists have a terrible time of it. Only the bass, David Pittsinger, comes close to conveying the necessary nobility and range of emotion. The tenor, Rafael Rojas, is an also-ran, while the mezzo line lies too high for the usually excellent Susan Parry. The soprano is Claire Weston, hopelessly over-parted, with a wide vibrato that flaps somewhere round the notes under pressure. She's very young, and should never have been advised to tackle the piece.

The whole is one of the most dispiriting evenings I've spent in an opera house. Don't waste your money on a ticket. If you want to hear the work, buy a decent recording instead.

 Until December 16. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: Reviews: Theatre: The Three Muskateers

fields.headline: The Three Muskateers
fields.trailText:
Young Vic, London
***
fields.body:
Young Vic, London
***

It is a real boys' night out at the Young Vic, where there is more swash and buckle (not to mention feathers) on show than the British stage has seen for decades. Fight director Renny Krupinski provides the best and most extended sword-fighting I've seen on stage, and the intimacy of the raised cross-shaped playing area that cuts right into the audience adds to the sense of high excitement. And yet there is enough good-humoured send-up to the cut-and-thrust heroics that they never seem over-glorified.

Boys are notoriously reluctant theatre-goers, but Julian Webber's adaptation of the Dumas novel should have them queuing around the block, even if some will find there is rather too much history and plot to swallow at one sitting. In truth, the first half, apart from the fights, is slightly plodding, even though Webber's stagecraft has a wonderfully seamless quality.

It is as if Webber himself isn't particularly interested in all the political intrigue and Cardinal Richelieu's attempts to dishonour the queen, and win himself more political power, by revealing that she has given her diamonds to the Duke of Buckingham. After all, political niceties and historical veracity are beside the point: as far as the audience is concerned, D'Artagnan and his friends are the good guys and anyone wearing red, leather or a sneer is a villain.

Once we've got most of the plot out of the way, the second half comes alive. D'Artagnan's perilous journey to London, to retrieve the Queen's diamonds in time for the grand ball where she must wear them or be publicly shamed, is played out as a thrilling dance in which the musketeers are picked off one by one by sinister masked dancers. Throughout, David Benke's superb music is used like a film score to create atmosphere, pace and sometimes the emotion that might otherwise be lacking.

There are other grown-up touches, such as the playing of the doomed relationship between the unhappy queen and her childlike husband. Graham O'Mara is so good as the blustering monarch that one boy in the audience told him to shut up.

There are cracking performances, too, from Phil Rowson, who makes D'Artagnan an open, likeable boy with just a touch of the country bumpkin, and from Candida Benson as the wonderfully villainous M'Lady.

 Until January 13. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

webTitle: WPM

fields.headline: WPM
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week, WPM's column is graced with its first special guest, in the form of advertising big shot Robin Wight.
fields.body:
 This week, WPM's column is graced with its first special guest, in the form of advertising big shot Robin Wight. Actually, it is less Wight himself who is the focus of her attention, and more the leak of an eight-page guide for potential secretaries, entitled How to Keep Robin Wight Happy. Readers are sure to empathise with the document, from which Campaign magazine highlighted the best bits as follows:

Part I: "Once I've managed to book a new-business meeting into the diary, you need to send a standard follow-up letter to confirm it," he starts, simply enough. "Finding a free lunch date is generally rather difficult as I tend to get booked up two months ahead. The contacts often cancel or change at the last minute, and so do I. You then have to make convincing excuses on my behalf, and if I've told you to cancel because I have 'flu' for instance), you have to remind me of it when I eventually do go to meet that particular contact so I don't make a booboo."

I hope you're taking notes, ladies. We're just getting started ...

 How To Keep Robin Wight Happy, Part II details Wight's penchant for the white stuff: "I like to drink pints of cold milk," he warns his dutiful desk-hands. "You must, therefore, try to keep a couple of pints in the fridge for me and defend them from all comers. The fridge is on the ground floor, you are on the fourth floor, the glasses are in the basement (though often you won't actually find one), and generally by 5pm there isn't a drop of milk left in the agency, but try all the same ..."

 And there's more ... After Wight's unfortunate assistant has managed to arrange his lunch date successfully and secure him the last pint of milk (and a glass to drink it from), she will be forced to endure a spot of ear-bashing from the great man himself.

"I do all my dictation on tape," he writes. "My dictation is not at all clear and it will take you a while to get used to my funny little ways. According to the report, a significant minority of offices around Britain - one in 10 - are brought to a daily halt when colleagues quarrel openly about which tunes to play. webTitle: Body language could be your route to career success

fields.headline: Hold your head up high
fields.standfirst:
Body language could be your route to career success. Hilary Whitney reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Body language could be your route to career success. Hilary Whitney reports
fields.body:
News of the world's largest experiment to investigate telepathy last week set staff tongues wagging. How wonderful it would be to know what Sandra in accounts really thinks of Susan in systems, and what's behind the faux niceness of Rachel at reception.

But while mind-reading is a skill we're unlikely to use in the office, the ability to read people's bodies is not so unfathomable. Understanding Body Language In A Week, published this month by The Institute of Management, aims to show how body language in the workplace betrays your true attitudes, hints at what others really think and can help you become a more effective communicator.

The existence of a body language speaks for itself through the statistics. Less than 10% of the messages we communicate occur through our speech; a surprising 40% are conveyed by our tone of voice and 50% simply from our gestures. This is the claim of the book's authors, Geoff Ribbens and Richard Thompson, who say that "communication without body language would be like writing without punctuation."

Such an analogy may ring true for the bumbling fools among us, who can't get the gist of how to conduct a good office relationship with our peers. While Ribbens and Thompson argue that our ability to interpret others' behaviour is inherent, they acknowledge that not everyone knows how to use that 90% of unspoken communication for the best.

For the growing number of support staff, the art of body language is a talent worth nurturing. With technology liberating them from the more time-consuming chores, PAs and secretaries are able to pursue more social responsibilities - managing staff, attending meetings and handling clients. But to milk these social settings, their body language has to say "confident and capable" - otherwise they will amount to no more than wasted opportunities.

Judi James, business consultant and author of Body Talk: The Skills of Positive Image, offers some advice to the shy secretary. "In America, PAs will give out business cards as a matter of course, but if I suggest this in the UK it tends to provoke nervous laughter," she says. "People in support roles in this country are terrified that being assertive will be misinterpreted as arrogance, which it won't."

Recognising that the nation's confidence is somewhat lacking, an increasing number of British organisations are encouraging staff to learn how to use body language to communicate better.

"I don't like to portray body language as a bag of tricks, but in terms of marketing yourself more effectively at work, there are tips that make a massive amount of difference," says James. "Always enter offices and meeting rooms confidently, as if you're meant to be there. It's amazing how many people have difficulty going up to someone and confidently shaking their hand with just enough eye contact to make them realise you're worth speaking to. Once you've made that initial impact you can probably afford to let it drop a little during the meeting, but that first impression is really important. Always avoid tiptoeing into meetings looking apologetic and trying to be invisible. It looks awful and - although it isn't fair - people will probably question your credibility, however brilliant you might be at your job."

James cautions against being too reticent with our bodies. "If you have to approach a senior colleague at their desk, try to do so with as much purpose as possible. Many people find it very irritating to have someone lurking at their desk, timidly waiting to speak to them, and it can get your conversation off on the wrong foot. I think you can afford to move with a degree of authority without looking like the young pretender." It can also help to slightly mirror the other person's body language, although obviously it pays to judge this sensitively.

But let's not kid ourselves too much with all these career-furthering intentions. The really appealing thing about analysing body language is the idea of interpreting other people's behaviour. From now on, never believe a colleague who has a habit of rubbing his eyes or touching his nose. He is lying, according to the gospel of body language, and should not be trusted.

All of which doesn't bode well for poor unfortunates struck down with conjunctivitis or for those who can't resist fingering a snotty nose. The authors' get-out clause for this little discrepancy is to argue that "it is seldom one gesture or posture, but a combination of body signals that convey the clues. It is also important to put the body language in context."

So next time someone picks at their clothes while talking to you don't automatically assume - as the textbook has it - that they privately they disagree with you. They might be trying to remove traces of the morning's toothpaste from their lapel.

 Understanding Body Language in a Week, by Geoff Ribbens and Richard Thompson, is published by Hodder and Stoughton, £6.99.

 Body Talk: The Skills of Positive Image, by Judi James, is published by the Industrial Society, £9.95.

webTitle: Vengerov's one-man show at the Barbican

fields.headline: Vengerov's one-man show at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
ECO/ Vengerov
Barbican Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: ECO/ Vengerov Barbican Hall London Rating: ****
fields.body:
Much of the best - and a little of the worst - of Maxim Vengerov was in evidence on this occasion. Despite the presence of the English Chamber Orchestra and the Israeli conductor Vag Papian, this was very much a one-man show, and although Vengerov exuded bags of charisma and his usual self-effacing charm, one couldn't quite help wondering if an ego had landed.

The concert certainly formed an effective showcase for his formidable talents. He played the Beethoven Violin Concerto with Papian conducting,and after the interval took the baton himself in a performance of Mozart's Jupiter Symphony. For all his enthusiasm and exuberance - he twirls around on the podium with balletic grace and tangible glee - that was perhaps an unwise move. He's a plausible conductor, though not a great one, and the symphony took an awfully long time to get going. Much of the time, he aspires to the kind of spaciousness one primarily associates with Klemperer's Mozart, though with little of the latter's emotional depth and resonance. The first movement was sluggish and the Andante dawdled. When we got to the Minuet, however, Vengerov suddenly struck form, shading it towards a waltz and infusing it with an infectious, unashamed Viennese lilt. The finale had a certain magisterial elan, without quite scaling the heights of elation that the greatest interpreters bring to the work.

He's better off as a violinist, in short, and his performance of the Beethoven was, in its way, stunning. Rarely, I suspect, has this most noble of concertos been played with such perfection of technique and such lacerating sweetness of tone, its long, rapt phrases seeming alternately to hover and swoop seraphically in the air. Interpretatively he plays safe, refusing, on occasion, to sacrifice beauty of sound for emotional danger. There's no self-conscious showing off, even though the cadenzas - his own - are filthily difficult. The first, a massive triple-stopped variant on the opening movement's second subject, veers closer to Brahms than Beethoven and breaks the mood a bit. The second is an exhilarating cascade of tone. Papian's conducts with violent, emphatic gestures, not always securing a comparable emotional response from the ECO, whose playing was muted on occasion.

When it was over, Vengerov returned to the platform clutching a Baroque violin rather than his Strad, and gave us the Adagio from Bach's G Minor Sonata as an encore, probing it rhapsodically rather than opting for a stiff formality of approach. The audience held its breath in wonder, then went wild.

webTitle: Reviews: Opera: Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet

fields.headline: Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet
fields.trailText:
Wilton's Music Hall, London
**
fields.body:
Wilton's Music Hall, London
**

Did you know that ostrich shit can make you blind? I am not 100% sure that this is true, but becoming ocularly challenged through the application of bird turd is an important part of the plot of Kurt Schwertsik's opera The Wondrous Tale of Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet, Broomhill Opera's Christmas show.

The restoration of eyesight, by the way, is achieved by the application of fish bile. Someone at Broomhill should have had a bottle of the latter handy, for after interesting and inspiring work of late, the company has come something of a cropper with this effort.

Premiered in Stuttgart in 1983, Fanferlizzy Sunnyfeet was intended as a seasonal show for kids, and at the time provoked comparisons to that other operatic Christmas favourite, Hansel and Gretel. This is rather wide of the mark, for, if anything, it comes nearer in subject matter to Mozart's The Magic Flute and Strauss's Die Frauohne Schatten. Based on a novella by Clemens Brentano, it's a sprawling, symbolist fairy tale that aims to combine magic with profundity. Unfortunately it achieves neither.

The plot concerns the king dom of Scandalia, whose monarch, Laudamus, is deposed in a violent coup by his slobby son Harum.

At this point good fairy Fanferlizzy comes to the rescue with the aid of the opera's hero, Allingoodtime, who has been given a parthenogenetic birth by Fanferlizzy's pet goat, after the creature has been transformed by magic into a beautiful woman. The various parties then slug it out in various ways that involve sorcery and the aforementioned ostrich until order is restored - or is it?

The point the opera labours to make is that no one, in times of conflict, ultimately emerges as the moral victor. The fact that the message fails to hit home is largely due to a paucity of imagination in the score. The Austrian Schwertsik studied with Stockhausen and cites John Cage as an influence, but here he reverts to a mixture of minimalism and imitation 1920s modernism. Much of it sounds like Stravinsky on an off day, with bits of Kurt Weill thrown in. Punchy conducting from Charles Peebles and splendid singing by Alison Crookendale (Fanferlizzy), James Cleverton (Harum) and Hubert Francis (Allingoodtime) can't disguise the fact that the score just doesn't grab your attention.

The most alarming aspect of the production is its violence. Harum's coup begins in the audience and caused moments of genuine distress when what appeared to be members of the public suddenly leapt to their feet training guns on their fellows. Throughout, Swiss Army knives are glorified as weapons, and at one point we're shown how to open the blade. In any show for kids, this is worrying; after the murder of Damilola Taylor, it is tactless in the extreme.

 Until December 16. Box office: 020-7420 0222.

webTitle: Jo Dimitri on organising corporate bashes

fields.headline: Non-stop partying
fields.standfirst:
It's Christmas all year round for Jo Dimitri. She tells Tom Twentyman about organising corporate bashes

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's Christmas all year round for Jo Dimitri. She tells Tom Twentyman about organising corporate bashesIt's Christmas all year round for Jo Dimitri. She tells Tom Twentyman about organising corporate bashes
fields.body:
If Jo Dimitri finds herself briefing walking pineapples and hot-chocolate pots, or putting the finishing touches to table decorations in the form of aliens' brains, it's all part of her job. She's a senior project manager with Theme Traders, an event design and production company that masterminds bespoke parties. British Airways, EMI and Pricewaterhouse-Coopers feature on a client list for whom Dimitri and co "come up with party ideas and bring them to life. Our aim is to get that 'wow' factor."

There's certainly the chance to let the imagination go. She's helped to create Caribbean islands and Dickensian marketplaces, Austin Powers parties and James Bond bashes, as well as moonscapes and winter wonderlands. She devises this sort of fun all year round. "St Patrick's day, midsummer, Halloween - nobody needs an excuse for a party. Not that I'm complaining, I hasten to add."

Naturally enough, it's seasonal revellery that's occupying Dimitri now - an example of which will take place outside Versailles in the week before Christmas. Travelling within Europe for Theme Traders is nothing new to her - she's already been to Istanbul and Strasbourg and, when we meet, she is planning to go to France for a day or so to combine work and a short break.

Dimitri, 22, is one of 14 project managers, and her involvement begins at the preliminary discussion stage with a client. "We talk through what they would like to do," she explains. "The style or format envisaged is important, but equally so is who's going to be invited - will it be solely management, or the entire staff? Are they looking for something low-key, or the best bash ever?" From this brainstorming session, Dimitri will deliver a proposal within 24 hours.

Once she has been given the go-ahead, Dimitri places orders with colleagues whose job descriptions ("set designers, lighting technicians, costumiers and prop-makers") sound more like backstage theatre hands than party organisers. "We also have our own caterers and installation teams," she adds.

The policy of using in-house personnel is deliberate, although an exception is the roster of more than 500 speciality performers she uses. "Even the most shy and retiring of guests discover that coming face to face with escapologists, drag queens and snake charmers is a great ice-breaker," she says with a broad grin.

Throughout the big day itself, Dimitri is in overseeing mode at the venue while "all the different strands are woven together. A very finely coordinated process, rather than a mad panic," she insists. She sees lending a hand here as pure pleasure. "I really enjoy arranging the displays. That's the best part of it for me."

On the night, her presence ensures a point of contact for the hosts should they have any questions, or need any help. Effectively, she's on duty, which requires a suitably professional approach. "I'll chat with people," she says, "but having a good time myself is not the reason I'm there." It's also conditional that she doesn't bear a grudge for the long hours, late-night finishes and weekend shifts that are all part of the job.

It was at university, when she worked on a May Ball for Clare College, Cambridge, that Dimitri first gained experience in organising entertainment. At her level within Theme Traders, she carries a lot of responsibility for someone so young. But then, the emphasis is already on youth since the average age of employees is only 25.

In the summer of 1999, when she arrived for her interview at Theme Traders' north London office, she immediately got a picture of what was in store for her. "Within a few seconds, I had walked past a Dalek and a mannequin of Queen Elizabeth I wearing shades. There was an amazing, funky atmosphere, and I just knew that Theme Traders was the place for me."

But managing to keep her feet somewhere near floor level when she's creating fantasy worlds is not a problem, she says. "I need to use a lot of different skills, from administration and budgeting to communicating well and working to deadlines, and that helps to keep me grounded in reality." But if there's ever a need to let her hair down from the pressure, there's little doubt that her office will this year be throwing one hell of a Christmas party.
